Been playing ARMA for almost 10 years now. It‚Äôs grown alongside me, and has created some of the most memorable moments I‚Äôve ever experienced in a videogame. It‚Äôs one of those games which, when it finally ‚Äòclicks‚Äô with you, never quite leaves you. You always find yourself going back to it. It‚Äôs not a game which necessarily empowers you like DOOM or Wolfenstein, but the pay-off from successfully pulling off that mission, that flank, that firing solution, that landing, even that single shot, is unparalleled. 

I‚Äôll always remember the moody fog of the APEX Protocol co-op missions as me and my friend crawled through the jungle, silently taking out patrols hunting for us with flashlights dancing in the dark. I‚Äôll always remember finally Escaping from Tanoa after six hours with my mates ‚Äî it felt like a hiking trip by the end. I‚Äôll always remember staying prone in a ghillie suit as a whole platoon of Russians patrolled past my squad, just like in All Ghillied Up. No other game can recreate the thrill or complexity of these memories in an emergent and inherently personal manner. 

My friends and I, after ten years, have talked for hours about that one mission which went so wrong or that incredible shot one of us made across a whole valley, or just how much we associate some terrains like Sahrani or Stratis with our first years as teenagers back at school. ARMA, for me, is an experience equal in its thrills and frustrations as it is in its nostalgia ‚Äî you come to learn these towns, these fields, these roads and valleys and recall them each as affectionately as the other. Sure, things go wrong: a miscommunication is made, a helicopter crashes, the physics engine freaks out, or the server messes up, but most of the time, you‚Äôll laugh through it. 

ARMA is unlike any other game ‚Äî any other experience. I think this ramble has been quite open in displaying just how much it means to me, and how much it will continue to mean to me. I can assure you, if you give it a chance, it will quickly mean as much to you too.

There really is no more of an immersive experience than ARMA III. I cn't count the times that I have totally wasted 6-8 hours in one sitting, just in a MP lobby doing special missions, with 4 or 5 other guys that are fully embracing each other while the rest of a 60+ player server were grinding it out on a primary objective. 
This game has one of the steepest learning curves in FPS genre, only because the incredible amount of content and ability, So if you are new to ARMA, just find a good servier with a clan presence and learn your way, people generally are helpful , because most people enjoy ARMA as a COOP expierence and fe servers stray from that. 
My steam only shows 231 hrs in game, but I'm almost sure that I have quadruple that if you could the hours outside of steam, and then double that number again for the hours I spent in Arma II before. 

There is a ton to do and learn, and no one truly knows everything there is except maybe Dslexi, but once you find a good group to game with it's truly a unique experience.

I strongly recommend not playing this if you wish to keep your sanity. Many of the communities can be extremely toxic, and being sucked into this can lead to many issues.

That being said, the game itself is half decent.There are many communities dedicated to this game that came from Arma 2 and the first iteration of the game. There are many communities to get involved in, Halosim (OPTRE), Star Wars (SWOP or Legion Studios), Vietnam (Unsung), and many more. The communities are hit and miss, and the mods make more problems then they sometimes try to resolve. After 5 years of time being sucked away from this game, I've made many friends, and several enemies in the community. 

The unique aspect of this game that I enjoy the most is Zeusing. An RTS Gamemaster against many players was really fun, though stressing. Trying to entertain 70+ ppl on a half working server can be detrimental to your PC, so play at your own risk.

Played with a group around when Arma 3 first dropped. Made fun times and memories, racked up thousands of hours. I won't say Arma 3 is best when played with a group but one has to try it. Since I played so much with a group I feel like I no longer have that itch to scratch; I've been a platoon lead, squad lead, team lead, pilot, regular grunt, etc., Also there's the normal multiplayer vanilla modes that are okay. Played a few DayZ clones that were fun for awhile in the early days too. Single player can be just as fun. Knowing how to use the editor or a mission building mod you can get whatever you want out of it. Also mods add tons of content. Some mods make the game better or worse depending on who you ask.

-Cons 
The AI. There are tons of mods that change the behavior. Can range from too hard to fair depending on settings, very hard to get right.
Stiff movement and general Arma physics clumsiness.
Some mods are essential like ACRE for the best group play. But it needs the 3rd party app teamspeak to work. If they make Arma 4 they should integrate radios right.
Buildings boring and bare. There are mods that can make them better without spending hours in the editor though.
Very hard to stealth or stealth in close quarters without getting detected. 
Cant knock someone out from behind (theres a mod that does it but it doesn't work good due to the engine).
Flying jets is awful but the helicopters are really good.

Before writing this review, I played a workshop sniper assassin mission that took three hours to beat (once again the AI will laser you at times). Arma will drain hours out of your day no matter what. And you'll have serious fun (lol).

If you are here for a review then you'll be sorely disappointed. What I can say is that I have a great Japanese noodle soup for you to try.

Ingredients:
700ml chicken stock
3 garlic cloves, halved
4 tbsp soy sauce, plus extra to season
1 tsp Worcestershire sauce
thumb-sized piece of ginger, sliced
¬Ω tsp Chinese five spice
pinch of chilli powder
1 tsp white sugar (optional)
375g ramen noodles
400g sliced cooked pork or chicken breast
2 tsp sesame oil

For the garnish:
100g baby spinach
4 tbsp sweetcorn
4 boiled eggs, peeled and halved
1 sheet dried nori, finely shredded
sliced green spring onions or shallots
sprinkle of sesame seeds

STEP 1
Mix 700ml chicken stock, 3 halved garlic cloves, 4 tbsp soy sauce, 1 tsp Worcestershire sauce, a sliced thumb-sized piece of ginger, ¬Ω tsp Chinese five spice, pinch of chilli powder and 300ml water in a stockpot or large saucepan, bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 5 mins.

STEP 2
Taste the stock ‚Äì add 1 tsp white sugar or a little more soy sauce to make it sweeter or saltier to your liking.

STEP 3
Cook 375g ramen noodles following the pack instructions, then drain and set aside.

STEP 4
Slice 400g cooked pork or chicken, fry in 2 tsp sesame oil until just starting to brown, then set aside.

STEP 5
Divide the noodles between four bowls. Top each with a quarter of the meat, 25g spinach, 1 tbsp sweetcorn and two boiled egg halves each.

STEP 6
Strain the stock into a clean pan, then bring to the boil once again.

STEP 7
Divide the stock between the bowls, then sprinkle over 1 shredded nori sheet, sliced spring onions or shallots and a sprinkle of sesame seeds. Allow the spinach to wilt slightly before serving.

the most in-depth Milsim game in the world period, there is no other game more complicated and in-depth than this one. but the thing keeping this old gem of a game alive is the mods. if this game had no mod support I'm sure it would've failed miserably. This games graphics arent That bad, the models are well made and the textures arent bad either, the issue stands with optimization, this game was not meant to run on modern computers, it was built for old computers and it was built to be ran in vanilla. Unfortunately this game lacks extreme content without mods, if you are willing to play without mods, then don't bother buying this. even my computer with the highest specs money can buy with a 3090 and an extremely powerful cpu, my FPS hovers around 40 - 70 mostly 50. lowering graphics do not help. the fps drops are caused from scripts from mods, and too many entities at once. this game cannot handle full out warfare, well it can but be prepared for a slideshow. the reason why we play this and not newer games is not even the newest games have as much content as this game (with mods). also this game is not for singleplayer, yes there are alot of singleplayer missions, but they are mediocre and not fun, to get the most out of this game you should join a unit, usually its a community of players on discord that play arma with custom made missions made by a dedicated zeus, a zeus is a mission maker, thats what i am. this game has something called zeus mode which allows a player to make a mission in real-time while hte players are playing it, your job as zeus is to make stories, spawn enemies, and etc all for the fun of the players. though it is complicated and requires maybe at least 200 hours to get good at zeusing as its a lot of scripting and stuff. bottom line is, if youre looking for a an extremely realistic and in-depth military simulater and you dont care about performance and graphics this game is for you. the fps is low but not low enough for it to be unplayable. The graphics themselves are good enough to simulate real world scenarios. but if youre looking for beautiful landscapes, physics, textures, effects. this game doesnt have it, its strong point is simply is complicated milsim nature. if you are not familiar with Military simulaters this game is not for you... yet, its complicated and requires experience, i suggest a game called Squad to get into Military simulaters, Arma 3 is on the very last game you get, its the most complicated of all military simulaters but once you get the hand of it, its extremely fun, you buy this game once you know you enjoy milsims, and are extremely familiar with them. Many IRL veterans play this game. Remember, mods are the fun of this game, no mods no fun.

Playing this game is like being in a relationship with an abusive boyfriend. It has a high barrier for entry for the maximum amount of enjoyment, it takes many hours to mod the game, make a mission, and hell even hours to play the damn thing. I recommend people to play it if they like grounded military shooters so they can join me in my misery.

Long story short, this is a great game that has a unique experience in military sim shooters.

Now for the catches:
- It has singleplayer capabilities, but you'll find the best content and quality by playing multiplayer, with mods, or in units with other players
- This game can still be hard to work with. It hasn't aged well for optimization.
- This game has a steep learning curve, and will require a time investment to get back out of it what you put into it. It took me a month to learn, but nonetheless led to over 2500+ hours for me, and still does to this day.
- Wait for it to go on sale. 
- The only dlc worth something is the Apex dlc, I recommend getting it with that.

Cheers while we all wait for ARMA 4.

This game is like no other, I had a lot of fun on multiplayer servers and making my own (bad) scenarios. I don't have all DLCs but it does not matter THAT much since you can play with people that have a DLC that you don't and even join their vehicle. It has a good campaign that i saw a lot of people disliked but i really loved it, and I really like the content provided in some DLCs. like Prairie Fire, Apex or maybe even Contact. And there's also  the Western Sahara DLC that  adds a nice map and some vehicles/weapons. Pick this game up if it's on sale or if you got a lot of money (28 euros to be exact). I suggest before your first multiplayer experience you play the campaign, watch some guides on planes, helicopters and tanks. After learning how to play the game i suggest you join a multiplayer game on US servers. US servers are a lot of fun and I enjoy them a lot more than European servers. (example: people are more talkative on US servers). The stock content or the content that's in the base game is good, but mods add a lot to that. There are a lot of mods, ranging from weapons mods, vehicle mods to Titanfall mods, faction mods(RHS for example) and even star wars mods. There are mods that add effects, particles, (i.e blastcore) and 3 editor mods that add some quality of life improvments. I whould've liked to type more but I think that this is too much for most people already.

Wow. What can I say about ArmA 3. (Armed Assault 3, that is) This is an absolute phenominon of a game, and that goes beyond the core gameplay and fun factor delivered in the executable file itself, but in the knowledge gained from partaking on this veritable adventure. First, there is the transferablle tactical expertise, which when gathered from playtime in this game can be moved to other games like CSGO, or PUBG, or even the Witcher 3, to further enhance your experience there. Upon seeing the loading screen of this game, your mind is injected with subtle yet core changes to its strategic stratephos, allowing calculations on a grand scale to be conducted in lightning speed. Next, we see that the game actually makes you an immediate comedian. Simply saying in game catchphrases like, "Contact Contact Contact", "Im taking overwatch", or "Calling in CAS" will have your friends, family, significant others, and neighbors sprawled on the ground laughing. Finally, this game gives you a complete rudimentary understanding of everything military based, think of it as being in the army for a year or two. When you see a veteran in public, you can now approach with a wide variety of conversational topics, such as PTSD, or how black NPCs are worse than white ones. You can tell them you fully understand how heavy a pack of gear weighs, and how long average in operation transport flights take. If you dont understand some of the "terminology" ive been interspersing throughout this review, I think that just goes to show how simple minded your brain can be pre-ArmA 3 experience. (Armed Assault 3, that is) Talk to me when you barrel roll your first helicopter inside of a friendly APC while blasting trap music over the stereo system while 600 invisible objects explode around you, sending you flying under the map, while your CO applauds you on your incredible dedication to immersion and realism. Silly casual. Maybe (Scoffs) COD, or (Chuckles) Battlefield is more your thing.

The inclusion of the Workshop allows you to upload or download Mods ranging from Graphical overhuals, Weapons, maps, Cosmetics, Gear, Characters, and more. Making the eden editor something to be feared my other games.

I enjoy the act of RP and having fun, then RP while going on a cocaine gathering run. Gets me into the game and results in hours of fun. Even if we stand around thinking of what to do for 10 minutes; there's always something going on or someone randomly approaching us that we kidnap and sell their organs. When trying to take out a vehicle from your garage though, be careful. Some people like to camp out and attack you once you do. Or you can go out into the outskirts of cities/towns to more remote garages or truck shops. 

Getting Uranium is a pain. Most players don't seem to take part in the fun activity of mining in radioactive areas, then processing the Uranium at a nearby Nuclear Plant. But my friend and I sure do. So if you're ever nearby and want to say hi be sure to wave! We love guests and enjoy some company between driving and the process of mining all the resources. 

If you ever go to a busy city, just go prone and roll. This is the pro strategy for getting out of being arrested or being detained and kidnapped. The majority of people don't know what to do or are so caught up in you rolling around they get mesmerized by it and join you. They could kill you for not cooperating but that isn't very nice. So if someone does kill you without a valid reason, spawn back and kidnap them. The most realistic war simulator on the market by a far margin. It has its trolls but they are nowhere near as common as in games like CSGO and some of the other FPS on the market. expect to die a lot. and then expect to die some more. but then you start to slow down and peak every corner and listen to your team making calls and you start getting the hang of it. and then you die a few more times.....now you should be able to make the AO on a regular to semi-regular basis. Now hold houses within the priority zone in KOTH. Move with the zone as it moves. You will have every enemy that knows how to play coming to you and it will increase your gun play opportunities and therefore your gun play results. I try to play with at least one person in my friends list but honestly the teams don't scream and yell at each other. The community just seems more mature than the communities of other games I have played. I can honestly say my run ins with "suspicious" players is less common in this game. If you look hard enough you can probably get a mod that runs a game you want to play within the arma infrastructure but only with the more detailed imagery and options.

The epitome of jank. Just about everything in the game is janky. Movement is janky. You basically move like your character just downed a fifth of Jack Daniels. Just navigating over fences without the advanced movement mod is pain because instead of a jump key you've got an awkward stepping key that may or may not clip you into a fence. Deploying bipods is a nightmare. You may only deploy your bipod when and how the bipod god deems it appropriate, usually clipping into a rock or in a way that gives you like a 5 degree field of fire. To top it all off, the enemy AI practically use aimbots given their insane accuracy and ability to spot you.
That said, it's got the most insanely fun and intense multiplayer experience. Despite all the flaws I mentioned, I've still put close to 200 hours into it just from mostly playing invade and annex 64 player co-op and I've had more than a few memorable moments from said co-op experience. Landing in a hot LZ in a little bird only for the pilot to get SHOT IN THE FUCKING FACE as everyone bails out and scrambles for cover, hopping in the gunner seat of an IFV in a convoy and rolling into a town blasting enemies left and right, and storming towards an enemy HQ with like 20 other guys in a Soviet esque charge as guys drop left and right and enemy mortar fire rains down around us are just a few of a the fond memories I've had of the game so far.
If you do get it, I'd recommend playing just enough of the singleplayer to familiarize yourself with the controls (believe me, there's a lot to familiarize yourself with), jump into the multiplayer, and then never bother with the singleplayer aspect again.

Honestly, I was about to tire out of King of the Hill, then I got recommended to try a Modded RP server out, and I've been hooked. The game itself has a lot of bugs that you just end up getting used to, but you end up still having a lot of fun even in high populated servers.

Oh man. Where to even begin with this one. It would be an extreme disservice to simply call Arma 3 a shooter, as it is so, so much more than that. Arma 3 is a military simulator. This is a distinction that it‚Äôs developers hold sacred and are proud of, and one to which I can attest is completely accurate and deserved. But it‚Äôs even more than that. Arma 3 is a gaming platform, upon which so much has already been and will continue to be built for years to come.

At its core though, Arma 3 in a supremely excellent military sim. The graphics are stunning, the gameplay is excellent, the mechanics are solid, and Bohemia Interactive has done an absolutely amazing job packaging this all together. New comers to the Arma series (as I was) may initially be overwhelmed by the game‚Äôs complex mechanics and decidedly different pace from your typical FPS/shooter. Enemy engagements happen at much greater distance than is typical in the genre and are often brief, brutal, and more times than not will conclude with your demise. There is no handholding here. No mini-maps, no enemy UI icons/indicators, no hit markers, no health bars. If you get shot a couple of times, you will find yourself unceremoniously dispatched. While this creates a high barrier for entry and a steep learning curve for new players, it provides a unique and distinctive play style. Situational awareness, cover, teamwork, suppressive fire, and generally moving purposefully and as if your ass depended on knowing what was behind the next ridge or hiding in the bushes are paramount to your success. Add to these infantry mechanics the amazingly rendered vehicles, armor, helicopters, and planes, each with their own realistic mechanics to learn and master, and you end up with a truly amazing military simulation experience.

Out of the box, Arma comes with a great single player campaign comprised of 3 separate acts, each containing ~12-15 missions. The campaign focuses on a well crafted story of a military conflict that has erupted over Arma 3‚Äôs two HUGE islands of Stratis and Altis. You play the part of a NATO soldier who finds himself stuck in the middle of a complex engagement. The campaign is rewarding, and challenging. (I have yet to complete it as I‚Äôm stuck on one mission that I simply can‚Äôt seem to complete.)

However the single-player campaign is FAR from the end of this title. The mission editing tools have allowed this amazing community to develop some absolutely awesome single player missions, all of which can be downloaded free of charge from the Steam workshop and numerous other sites around the interwebs. I would also recommend you check out the supremely excellent full game conversion single player mods Whole Lotta Altis and Dynamic Universal War System which will provide countless additional single player hours and could be completely stand alone titles in themselves.

Oh and the multiplayer, oh god the multiplayer. Wasteland, King of the Hill, Invade and Annex, Battle Royale, Breaking Point, so many Co-Op opportunities, the amazing looking upcoming Epoch (currently in closed Alpha). I‚Äôm sure there are so many others that I haven‚Äôt even discovered yet. Each of these represent COMPLETELY USER GENERATED and totally disparate ways to play Multiplayer within the Arma 3 platform. By purchasing Arma 3, you immediately have access to each of these completely gratis and each could essentially be considered totally separate game.

In wrapping up this lengthy review, Arma 3 is an amazing experience and a true accomplishment in game development. It is the only game in recent memory that I can say with confidence that I never get bored with playing. Bohemia Interactive has made it clear that they plan to support this game for years to come, and they have built something amazing on which the possibilities are truly endless.

Purchase this game. Purchase it now. Thank me later.

Solid 7/10. This game is special in the way that knowing the game is far more important than being good at shooters. It's not a difficult game to get into after learning the controls, but there are so many mechanics that even players with hundreds of hours will still be learning. However, the game's age definitely shows, with performance issues and AI that is so inconsistent that it's sometimes frustrating. The developers have given plenty of tools to make your own maps and game modes, which is my favorite part of the game. You can be as simple or complicated as you want with the mission editor, and you can use their game engine's shitty scripting language if you really want to do something cool. The biggest issues I have with making my own content is the lack of accurate documentation on various tools and scripting commands. The developers are somewhat active in the discord, and the community is mostly friendly, so pretty much any question about the game will be answered. All in all, the game can be fun if you play alone or with friends, or if you want to play PvE or PvP. If you can get past the shitty graphics, the annoying AI, the lack of weapons, and the normal occurrence of smoke grenades and vehicles being launched into the stratosphere, you will have fun with this game.

TLDR: game good, mil-sim optional, give it a try. Continue for details and recommendations.

NOT JUST A FUCKING MILSIM!

this game is not exclusively a mil-sim. If someone recommends you this game, and you discard it because "its a milsim, i dont want to follow a bunch of rules, do nothing, talk certain ways, have certain roles". Very tragic. any time i hear people describe this game, mil-sim is usually in there. it kills me because thats usually where THEY stop summarizing, or people stop listening. This game is VERY flexible. want a faster paced, more actiony experience? Liberation, its a pve capture the map game mode created by the community, it works very well, tons of fun. what if thats too arcadey, but the action is nice. maybe you want to do a little more planning but still the light-hearted fun where nobody is telling you how you fucked up. Antistasi, another community made gamemode, PVE, capture the map. Or what if you want something closer to Dayz but with all the fun mods and nice maps, Exile can be PVE or PVP. 

Point being, you can do a lot with this game without coming even close to mil-sim. If the game SEEMS interesting but the mil-sim part of the game scares you off, dont worry theres lots more to do. all of my hours have been exclusively between those three game modes, and i have absolutely ZERO interest in mil-sim and feel no pressure of running out of things to do. ive made servers for all of the game modes I've mentioned. Not the easiest task, but something I'm glad i took the time to learn because i can create the exact experience i want. theres plenty of help available to learning how to create servers, seek out the discords for any of the game modes ive mentioned, people will help you understand, and you can create exactly what experience you want out of a shooter like arma. 

THE BAD: Its worth noting, this game is rough around the edges, id love to see more performance, stability, nicer tools for those who wish to create AND USE mods. The game could improve on a lot. the whole game is a learning curve, from just the menus, to the vehicles, to just moving your character and using your equipment. error messages are common. the game will frustrate the ever living shit out of you by randomly dying, touching a fence post and flying across the map, touching a bush and dying. it is seriously almost a skill just avoiding bugs. 

so yes, tons of bugs, sometimes hilarious, sometimes day ruining. bugs aside its not an EASY game. but i'll never forget playing antistasi, clawing my way to work from a pistol, to arming a rebellion. VISCOUS fighting for two in-game days, tooth and nail, for an airport, and seeing friendly green tracers and rockets fly through the night sky and take down incoming enemy helicopters, gunships, and jets. Javelins spiking down onto enemy tanks or ground vehicles. 

its buggy, its high maintenance but gosh dang if this isnt the best game ive ever played, i dont know what is.

[b]After about 600 hours I started the campaign...[/b]

[i]This game is great if you:[/i]
- Like modding
- Like using mods
- Like 'realistic' shooters
- Don't mind long build-ups to short but high intensity fire-fights
- Like semi-real vehicle/air combat

There are various conversion mods that take you from a modern mil sim to say, Halo or Warhammer - and the communities to back em. That said, you do have to get lucky with the communities you become involved with.

[i]Why it might not be something for you:[/i]
- You don't want to spend more than 30 minutes to an hour on a game session
- You want quick dopamine shots, easy kills and someone to hold your hand while you're playing
- You are sensitive to war depictions

The communities in Arma 3 in my experience are extremely varied, both in what they offer and how toxic or welcoming they are. In the end it'll come down to your luck and perseverance when searching for online communities. 

For the single player or co-op buddies: There's also plenty of content for you on the workshop to enjoy :)

[i]Guides, support, troubleshooting and content:[/i]
- You can find a lot of helpful tutorials and guides on YouTube
- The game has a decent support system and an active forum
- The game offers a decent amount of starting content in the base game, further expanded by DLC's, mods, and scenarios from the workshop.

This is a fundamentally broken product.

The single-player campaigns would be dismal even without the mountain of bugs and crappy UI in this game, but in its current state it is basically unplayable. Interacting with game objects is done through the mousewheel because actual UI is more-or-less non-existent. Operating vehicles is borderline impossible as the game's physics engine seems to think vehicles belong upside down. AI squads are incapable of traversing longer distances than a hundred meters without getting stuck in random rocks or trees, and cannot drive vehicles without ramming every wall, sign and building in their path. Commanding squadmates is an exercise in frustration as the commands can ONLY be navigated with the numbers row, and if you do actually find the command you want, it will most likely not do anything at all, or cause the AI squadmates to take totally bizarre actions like trying to run across the map, or repeatedly crouch and stand up, or randomly shout "covering fire!" even when nobody else is around.

The AI is so broken that it is almost comedic, traversing flat ground by crouching, lying down, shouting "covering fire!" then getting up, walking ten feet, crouching, lying down, shouting again, is this a "military simulation"?

And even if you do teleport them in range of the enemy, the extent of their abilities is to stand stock still and shoot wildly in the general direction of enemies. They won't engage armor, instead they will happily take out their anti-tank weapons, hold them, put them back, take them back out, turn around to look at you, then get mowed down. Or, sometimes, take out their weapons, aim point-blank at a wall or a teammate, and just blast their own squad away.

I spent eighteen hours in this game over the course of a couple of weeks, and every single moment of it was either digging in menus, or trying to run test games "to see if it would work this time" but it never fucking did. Every SINGLE time I tried to play this game, I would set it up, begin a scenario or whatever, figure out the objective, start trying to go there..... and then realize half my squad is back at the base because they can't walk through doorways or are inside the floor. Or the vehicle hits an invisible wall and flips or injures everyone. Or I get stuck in something. Or the game crashes. Which one of those is realistic military gameplay? I never experienced a single moment of gameplay that I would call interesting or fun. Every play session with this game was spent trying to delicately babysit AI squadmates across simple terrain or through doorways, or searching Google for how to perform minor interactions, or searching for solutions to bugs, hoping that EVENTUALLY I would figure it out and finally start PLAYING THE GAME, but I gave up.

I have watched gameplay videos online and saw people putting up with a lot of jank, but I didn't realize they were walking such a fine line to get this utterly broken project to even work at all. And the multiplayer is so awful and desynchronized it might as well be a play-by-phone board game.

Basically, this game is bad at every level: bad engine, bad UI, bad single-player campaigns, bad multiplayer functionality, bad community. The fact that this is the current state-of-the-art milsim game with a die-hard following is deeply disappointing, and speaks loudly to how little gamers actually care about quality control.

The DLC model for this game is so awful, it's turned me off to this developer permanently. It's impossible to play the base game that you actually paid money for without having advertisements plastered all over your screen for their many expensive DLC's. 

In the middle of a firefight? Let us take a moment to block your line of sight with a message telling you that the gun you happen to be using is part of a DLC, even though there was no indication of that when you were selecting your weapon for this mission.

Want to make an escape in this civilian vehicle before the 50 enemy troops on your tail catch up and monkey-stomp your head into the pavement? Tough luck, because this vehicle is part of the "bend over a little further" DLC.

Want to take 30 seconds to get immersed in the "Simulator" environment? Feel free, but you can do that while we cover the entire screen in DLC watermarks, right? And I do mean the entire screen. 

I really tried to like this game. I think I would have if they'd shown even the slightest amount of respect for their own product and their customer. As it is today, however, you're paying money to open up ad-space for Bohemia on your hard drive. Please do not make my mistake and contribute to this terrible business model.

The PACER Test score is combined in the FitnessGram software with scores for muscular strength, endurance, flexibility and body composition to determine whether a student is in the Healthy Fitness Zone‚Ñ¢ or the Needs Improvement Zone‚Ñ¢.

he enormity of the map is the foundation for the experiences that distinguish Bohemia Interactive's flagship franchise. It's what makes radios, topographical maps, binoculars, and compasses practical equipment in an FPS. It's what allows for kilometer-long headshots and coordinated convoy raids. It's what makes using your eyes to spot hints of enemies--muzzle flashes, tracers, gunsmoke--as valuable as being a crack shot.

The scale of Arma 3 dwarfs everything in the genre, including Arma 2. Altis, a keyhole portion of which is seen in these screenshots, is a Mediterranean island-nation assembled from ruins, airports, coastal villages, solar power plants, military outposts, salt flats, and tank-friendly scrubland. It's a variegated backyard for you to play war in, but what's more significant is that Arma's landscape finally has the technology it deserves.

You Will Need:

10 tablespoons (145 grams) unsalted butter
1 ¬º cups (250 grams) granulated sugar
3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons (80 grams) unsweetened cocoa powder, natural or Dutch-process
1/4 rounded teaspoon kosher salt, use slightly less if using fine sea or table salt
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
2 large cold eggs
1/2 cup (65 grams) all-purpose flour
2/3 cup (75 grams) chopped walnuts or pecans, optional

Directions:

Prepare Batter:
Position an oven rack in the lower third of the oven and heat to 325 degrees F. Line the bottom and sides of an 8-inch square baking pan with parchment paper or aluminum foil, leaving an overhang on two opposite sides. (This helps when removing the baked brownies from the pan, once cooled).

Add enough water to a medium saucepan so that it is 1 to 2 inches deep. Heat water until barely simmering.

Combine butter, sugar, cocoa powder, and salt in a medium heat-safe bowl. Rest the bowl over simmering water (if the bottom of the bowl touches the water, remove a little water). Stir the mixture occasionally until the butter has melted and the mixture is quite warm. Don‚Äôt worry if it looks gritty; it will become smooth once you add the eggs and flour.

Remove the bowl from heat and set aside for 3 to 5 minutes until it is only warm, not hot. Stir in the vanilla with a spoon. Then add the eggs, one at a time, stirring vigorously after each one.

When the batter looks thick, shiny, and well blended, add the flour and stir until fully incorporated, then beat with the wooden spoon or spatula for 40 to 50 strokes. (The batter will be thick). Beat vigorously here. You want to see the brownie batter pulling away from the sides of the bowl (if you do not have the strength to do this by hand, use a hand mixer). Stir in nuts, if using. Spread evenly in lined pan.

Bake Brownies:

Bake the brownies for 20 to 25 minutes or until a toothpick can be inserted into the center and come out with a few moist crumbs. As a visual test, brownies are done when the edges will look dry and the middle still looks slightly underbaked.

Some readers have found they need to bake an extra 5 to 10 minutes. Brownies are easy to overbake so keep an eye on the doneness of the brownies and use the visual and toothpick test as your guide.

Cool completely then remove from pan. For the cleanest lines when cutting, place into the freezer for 20 to 30 minutes to firm up. Cut into 16 squares.

Arma ... what can I say its Arma. I have been playing Arma for a pretty long time, Arma II all expansions really liked OP Flash Red River, All the way through to todays Arma 3 and its littany of content... there is a ton. I love this game.  Rediculously immersive SIm.... Yes SIm. DONOT expect to pick this game up and just play it.... Yeah thats not a thing here. This Application took me a good year to be fully functional. You must understand why, and appriciate it for that. If its in any military from 1900 through today and beyond... Yeah Arma does it.... Faithfully most of the time. Literally the only FPS ive seen where you can turn your head independent of your rifle while in a full sprint if you so choose. Only FPS where, when your prone, and that Commie is popping at you because you overstayed your welcome, You can ROLL while prone behind the tree trunk you were firing around..... So many weapon systems , so many weapons to learn and/or choose from.What to do? well there is Single player campaigns Persistant Coop missions that evolve over days, Straight up tdm.... The versatility and openness is staggering really. but it can be clunky, definitly sensitive to the build you create. Can be frustrating. but once you achieve what you were looking to achieve,  the rewards are there for those with the will and interest. Its not COD or Battlefiledf or Apex by a long shot. If you want to tinker, Your gonna need to understand your PC in general. Must understand File systems, and Extensions, compiling and all the technicality related stuff. if not it can still be a brat if you mix two paid dlc that dont like each other. . 

The combat.... Punishing and Rewarding on equal levels, She's gonna hurt your before she pleases you...Your gonna march with your squad for 45 minutes through any terrain you can immagine. then take two well aimed rounds from 110 meters and its freakin over.... or on the other side you and your squad Marched for 45 min.... Anticipated your foe, FLanked before they know its and enemy mowed 12 men down and overwelmed the last two who managed to make a stand, and took the town... this gunfight lasted 3.5 minutes and when your the winner it feels good.

In the end you get out of Arma and its community what you put into it. Again it is a Simulator through and through no Rambo shit here, Rambos die early and hard in Arma. if you like preperation unmatched customizations, planning, troubleshooting and thorough immersion Arma might be your home. If you want to dive in for 30 min at a time gets some rounds off, move on....

It's a bright morning in Altis.
The loud clanking of a broken engine comes from afar, the only source of sound besides the deadly silence, the whishing sound of an allied helicopter hovering above the island slowly reaches you, followed by the insects screeching, you moved on, the town was just ahead, you can make it on foot......

"Sir... What's the plan?"
Your teammate calls from behind you in a worrying whisper, his voice, dry and tired, just like everyone in this unit, you raised your hand from your rifle to wipe off the sweat on your forehead, silently pondering in your own thoughts as the team stopped.
You stayed mute, for seconds that seemed like minutes.

"We're going to regroup, with our allies."
Your team stayed silent, there's nothing else they could say, nothing was better, it's either through this uncharted, possibly filled-with-opfors town, or trace back few kilometers to another friendly unit.

"Formation diamond."
You waited, for your teammates to form the mentioned formation, but there were only silence, the quiet, but noticeable clanking of that engine, and the rotors of the helicopter.
Maybe, they're all tired of being led by an incompetent leader, maybe they just want to end this war already, that's right, in this cruel battlefront, every town you capture, every meter you drive, every step you take, might be the last...

You turned your head, the infantry truck was about ten meters away, sideways, the driver's window shattered, the scent of blood, gasoline, gunpowder forms a mixed cocktail in your nostrils, your gaze lands on the group of corpses, either on the ground, or dangling from the railings.

Your own corpse was laying in the middle, your service rifle was dropped beside you, half-empty from the resistance you tried to put up, but being hit by an IED, thrown around in a crashed truck and being shot at from all directions made everyone panic, and aim worse than an untrained office worker with a machine gun.

You knew it'd happen, you always knew, you've been here before, you've died before, seemingly several times, the wind, tainted with the smell of rust, creeps towards you, the grunts and weeps of fatally injured soldiers, creeps towards you, the snapping sounds of super-sonic rounds flying pass you, creeps towards you, they creeps towards you from your own mind, you're used to it, and you thought to yourself,
Would this time... Be any different?

You reloaded your MX rifle, completely empty by the excessive amount of rounds you needed to shoot into what feels like an easy target, the empty magazine falls on the ground, the engine finally stopped, ran out of fuel it seems, the team silently moved, into the town, into the trap, because everyone knew, there's nothing they could do to prevent this from happening.

Followed by a silent, unnoticeable pop, you felt yourself hovering, 4 just stepped on a landmine planted by the local guerillas, the detonation rocks the ground, you fall to your knees as you were brought down by someone, whizzing noises go past your head, you look up, your face splashed with a rust flavored liquid, a thud lands beside you, followed by another.

"Six is down!" You hear 2's voice shouting, you crawl behind your teammate's corpse, praying it'd conceal, or block some rounds for you, you watch as 2 put up a valiant fight against the ambush, only to be brought down by the returning fire from several opfors, and then, it ended.

Followed by a loud boom for a split second, your vision fades to black, distorted television appears in your sight, followed suit with a "Mission Failed", you've died, everyone died, there were no allies to regroup, you were always on your own on this god-forsaken island, with nothing to escape from, with vehicles that doesn't have fuel, with guns that doesn't have ammo.

"Leader's down! I'm the new field leader!" You hear 2 shout, as your team runs past your body, running to safety against the sniper that just dug a hole in your chest, unknowingly running into an enemy MRAP with a manned MG turret.

It's another loop, it's another loop until you finally finishes the mission, until you finally completes the objective.

It's not really playable in its current state. The developers add more and more and more content to it with each update, instead of fixing the huge issues that cripple this game's fundamental features.

The abysmally bad performance notwithstanding, it's playable in multiplayer. But the singleplayer features are useless. The AI couldn't hit a barn 10 feet away and is incapable of walking in a straight line without bumping into a wall. Indoor navigation is nonexistent, and even just navigating city streets seems like an impossible challenge for the unbelievably stupid AI - despite the game boasting and advertising several maps which feature dozens of cities. The built-in scripting language is a frankensteinian abomination that barely deserves being called a language, and there is no meaningful debugging available.

Despite seemingly very advanced functions to command NPC comrades, the AI fails the most primitve tasks, such as "aim at this guy and fire". Any attempt to lead AI comrades into the field is hampered by NPCs either running around where they shouldn't, going prone when they shouldn't, aiming but not firing, or firing when they shouldn't. More often than not, you're better off telling your NPC squad to wait and then finishing the mission on your own.

The advertised "wide variety of single- and multiplayer content" is really just multiplayer content. Which works, I suppose, if you have friends willing to play with you. The public servers are a dumpster fire where cooperative play is virtually impossible. So unless you plan on wandering the maps alone, playing singleplayer isn't really a thing you can do. Even the official singleplayer campaigns are rendered worthless by NPCs who appear to have been lobotomised. An untrained toddler with an assault rifle would be more effective than an entire squad of NPCs. With no functioning pathfinding, seemingly randomly malfunctioning aim, and a complete inability to follow commands, the AI alternates between being absurdly perfect aimbots, and brainless targets barely useful as cannon fodder.

Let me be very simple. Arma 3 is not only a milsim. The mods and all the content created by the community allow you to make this game to be whatever you want it to be.
Whether it's a great battle simulator, a cheap knock-off of GTA V (although, much better), a WW2 war crimes re-actment or an real-time editor and sandbox. This game has it all. And if it doesn't the modders will probably make it so.

Why buy CoD, Battlefield, GTA or any other game really. This game has it all.


Of course, this game has quite some issues in terms of performance. But that's easily forgetable. This game is most playable at 30 fps or higher and it highly depends on the scenario going on. I play IFA3 on my own servers with 50-120 FPS depending on what's going on. If I replay a D-Day scenario with over 300-400 units, planes, ships, canons and whatnot I can expect 20-30 FPS. That's normal.


Anyhow, feel welcome to join and go do great things. Join a server, make your own, make friends and do crazy shit like backflipping tanks with JBU's.

I recommend looking into Zeus mode as it allows you to do scenarios/stories dynamically with friends. There are great mods that enhance the experience and IMO if it weren't for Zeus mode this game would probably have died off long ago.

I bought this because I read some people said they have thousand of hours playing single player. Minimal SP content and sadly i didn't find it fun playing SP. Being a 'realistic' milsim it is known that there is no such thing as solo operatives on the field, and you must have battle buddies, in SP your battle buddies are AI, and they are very bad, even though i took the game really slowly clearing building and tried to position them the best I could at every place (even download the C2 mod), but they died of ridiculous cause i.e. I stationed them inside a 2 stories stone building for overwatch and they took fire from outside without firing back and they all died INSIDE the building. Even the dev-made 'showcase' mission for SP have our squad rushing ahead and getting killed on open terrain rendering the mission unable to be completed. Very high learning curve, especially if you install mod which drastically change gameplay, in my case this means faster time for my AI teammates to get killed. Because the base game isn't fun for me, I don't want to bother with learning this game further.

Maybe it's fun in multiplayer, but it's not my cup of tea.

I've played Operation Flashpoint for ages, same for Arma. For some reason I could never get into Arma 2, but my love for this franchise is huge...

Current overall opinion (aka tl;dr):
If you liked any of the previous installments, get it on sale (70%+). Depending on what you want to do, prepare to buy DLCs (which can easily range into AAA prices)

*********

Since I've only spent 3 hours so far, I will update this review, but there are some points I already have a strong opinion about:
1) A launcher... really? Can't I just launch the game?!
2) "Buy ALL the DLCs! YES! You must buy them! Have we told you about the DLCs already?" I remember when we got the AH-64 in OFP for free...
3) "Oh hey there. I see you are playing a campaign... Look at how many campaigns there are! oh yes, those are only available with some DLC..."

8.4h:
4) Campaign missions can get locked up if the squadleader (AI) dies, removing neccessary triggers to proceed...

19.5h:
5) I found a dog, but I couldn't pet him!

100+something hours:
6) The DLC-issue persists into multiplayer. 
- Vehicles are locked, with a pop-up prompting to buy the DLC.
- Equipment is marked as DLC in the arsenal, except sometimes it's not (Ghillie suits, looking at you) and if you equip it (which is possible), you have a constant frame prompting you to buy the DLC. Also, in certain intervals, your screen is overlayed with... something... that makes it hard to do what you were doing at that moment. Much fun to be had if you were currently fighting.
7) The launcher promises to deliver all neccessary mods to play on a server, except it doesn't and you'll get run over by a floating player, because the model of the tank didn't load. Or you get run over/crashed into by an invisible jet on the runway. Or you get shot by an invisible enemy...

Man this game is awesome. It might seem overwhelming at first but as soon as you get the hang of it it just turns into this game you'll want to play everyday all the time and you'll just want to explore more. The fact that the average arma buyer spends more than 100+ hours in this game is not false. I will now list some tips for you to enjoy the game and get setup as soon as possible
1. As soon as u get the game regardless of when u wanna play it download the game and then download the common top mods as they are used by pretty much every unit/server and are pretty huge so completing major downloads at once just makes it hassle free
2. Join a unit: even if u have 0 experience and haven't even loaded into a game applying for and joining a unit is still possible and is the best way to learn arma in the easiest way possible plus it just makes things way easier. I'd recommend joining only one unit as joining two is like a burden and joining more is near impossible as most have minimum attendance and have a lot of activities u have to do such as marking attendance giving loa's if ur missing an op etc
3. Before your first op and after boot camp or the training camp for unit load into single player and play some of that just to learn some other keybinds controls and things about arma. I'd prefer playing with the simple single player cheat mod so u do not have to worry about dying and bullets and such and can focus on learning the mechanics tho if u wanna enjoy the story as it is load in without any mods.
4. That's pretty much it to get settled into the game. U can now join multiplayer servers and can participate in game modes like exile, king of the hill, wasteland and can rp in altis life. Time to rack up those hours :)

The best MilSim still on the market. I've had more joys, laughs, epic moments, and frustrations with this game then with any other. ArmA is something I look forward to and it keeps me building awesome memories with friends I rarely get to see. Thanks to regular updates and a well established modding community, the greatest limitation to play with ArmA is your imagination. A major thanks to Bohemia and the modding community for keeping me playing ArmA since 2008.


Let me start off with the 2 biggest cons that dissuade people from playing ArmA 3...

#1. Not the Best. ArmA is a jack of all trades, master of very little. It is not the best flight sim, it is not the best FPS, in 2021 it is not the best visually, and it is not the easiest to launch and play. If you want the best shooter experience, or the best air-to-air fighter pilot experience, go with something else. These silos of excellence exist in many other games. If you want to forgo excellence in one category and you want to try everything combined under one roof, then read on.

#2. ArmAisms. If you play ArmA, you will regularly deal with frustrations. These can include but are not limited to players occasionally bugging out, dropped connections, getting stuck waist down in a rock, team speak and Arma not syncing properly, etc etc. These frustrations are affectionately called ArmAisms. There are far less now than there were in 2015 and if you left the game then, I'd suggest taking a second look. That said, bring a little bit of patience and a good attitude. ArmAisms can be a great laugh and memory, or they can send you packing.


The three best aspects of this game...

#1 The Environment. The ability to play solo or with a group of friends in any 20th/21st century battlefield setting. This is in large part thanks to the modding community which has worked tirelessly to build upon the excellent vanilla maps created by Bohemia. Thanks to the efforts of so many, I can fight as member of a U.N. Taskforce in C.A.R. 2016, storm the beaches of Sicily 1943, conduct a night raid on a drug cartel in Columbia 2005, conduct an armored assault in East Germany 1985, investigate an SCP breakout tomorrow in down-town USA 2021, or fight a well designed list of campaigns from Greek Islands in 2035, to Vietnam 1967. There is no limit to the places you can "operate" in.

#2 Practice made Fun. I do not know any other game that has immersed me in air and land combined arms more than ArmA. I will never forget the day in 2015 when my friends and I conducted a night time HELO insertion, trekked 2km behind enemy lines to an over watch position, and using long range radios talked on a friend in a fast mover at 6,000' AGL who acquired and locked-on our target lase to destroy a militant assembly area. We had worked weeks at putting it all together and that day it all fell in place was epic. 

This game makes practice fun and rewarding. Of course you can practice in other games, but in Arma you get the real opportunity to practice on your own and then come game day weave your capabilities into those of your team. Ask anyone who has played this game and made the 1km sniper shot so the team can move forward unnoticed. Or dropped the mortar rounds danger-close using a radio, map, and protractor while your buddies are on their last mag, black on bandages, and screaming for support stuck in a near ambush. Or you step up and hit the moving enemy APC with an RPG at 350m before it rolls up your friends fighting in the village... the ability to practice and become good at something is so worth it in this game.

#3 The Editor. The editor is fun and easy to start using, especially since they made it 3-D. For every hour I have playing this game, I likely have 2 hours building missions. Your imagination is seriously your only obstacle as you create the scenario that best suits your style of play. I've been intimidated by many editors in other games, but this one really is easy to get into. 

The addition of Zeus is also a tremendous advantage. As I've gotten older I have far less time to build missions the way I used to. No worries, now I can set up a simple mission and add to it in-game using Zeus. There are also many modules that let you focus on playing while the AI creates its own environment.

Encore...
#4. Civilians on the Battlefield. I had to add one more. I have a hard time enjoying other combat focused games when there are zero civilians on the battlefield. As far as realism goes, what battlefield in modern times doesn't have civilians seeking shelter or walking around getting in the way of your very important operation. ArmA missions that add in civilians just increase the excitement and confusion. Using mods you can interact with the civilians, gain information, or try to win over their support. Then the suicide vest goes off, you've got 2 local nationals down and small arms has just opened up from a civ dressed combatant. Oh wow Saturday night just got real. If you are looking to immerse yourself in a real combat environment, but still want to sleep at night, then ArmA is probably for you.


Get ArmA 3, find a group that suits your style, mess around in editor, check out the workshop, and then make a few memories with friends (or strangers) that you'll remember years later. 2,022 hours and 8 years later... it's worth it.

I don't know why i keep coming to this unoptimized piece of crap.

-Inventory system is just really really bad. You see a weapon on the ground and it's almost impossible to grab it sometimes because it doesn't show up in the action menu or the ground when you open your inventory.

-AI so bad the community had to fix it (try ASR AI or VCOM.)

-Physics are absolutely horrid. You'll get your vehicle flown to an altitude of 5km/blown up if you happen to touch a stationary MG etc. Also walking on rocks is extremely dangerous, you might somehow warp inside the rock and never get out.

-A lot of copy&paste vehicles on BLUFOR, INDFOR and OPFOR. For example every side has the same stationary weapons, even the same UCAV but with different names (it's like if China operated the MQ-9 reaper lmao.)

-Very clumsy weapon handling. You reload certain weapons like rocket launchers and your character will stand up, crouch, holster your rifle, unholster your sidearm, holster your sidearm, then actually unholster the launcher, holster it back, then unholster it again. (a little exaggerated but if you've played the game you know.)

-Vault mechanic is hilariously buggy. Vaulting over something will sometimes get you stuck in the object you're trying to vault over and your character will do the fall animation and damage you. Also you're able to walk through some wall objects if you look down facing the wall, vault, then by walking backwards you're able to slowly phase through the wall.

-Bunch of overpriced half-assed DLC. Just stick to the awesome community made content by RHS, CUP, JSRS and many more.

-Very very very very poorly optimized so if you don't have a beast PC then DO NOT GET THIS GAME.

There's probably A LOT more stuff i forgot to include but despite all this the game looks very good for an 8 year old game and Bohemia Interactive is still very active with the community. I like the gunplay because you actually have to shoot semi-auto accurately and the only time when full-auto is useful is when you're giving suppressive fire or in very close-quarters. I also kind of like the clumsy movement in a way because it prevents players from being able to dodge bullets by sliding, bunnyhopping and shifting from side to side like you always see in mainstream shooters. Zeus allows for some really fun scenario making with friends and the 3D editor is manageable.

For some reason i'm still having fun here and there and i've accepted the negatives in this game but i know a lot of people won't so that's why i can't recommend this to anyone. With Bohemia Interactive announcing their new game engine i'm beyond excited for the future of Arma.

Well it was about time I reviewed this game, huh?

Short version: It's good. If you like military stuffs, this game is as close as it gets to the real thing.

Long version:

I've been playing this game since the Beta, and I've seen it grow into what it is now; The best military experience you can get without having to step outside.

The game has a steep learning curve and can be intimidating at first, but once you get the hang of things, you'll have a very fun and rewarding experience.

I'd reccomend the new players to play the base game's campaign, it will show you the ropes, but dont expect hand holding. When you've had enough of the base game, there are a couple DLCs, which honestly are pretty good and I'd reccomend getting. If that's still not enough for you, well you're in luck.

Arma 3 has a massive modding comunity. Wheter you are into hardcore milsim, roleplaying, sci-fi, PvP, Coop or simply wanna hop in with a couple friends and mess around, I can guarantee there is something out there just for you.

Arma 3 also has a big online presence as well, ranging from public servers to propper communities/clans.

I'm not big into PvP, so I won't get into it, however what I love about this game is a specific game mode; Zeus.

Zeus is a multiplayer mode where one player acts as a game master and can make and change missions on the fly, using a real time 3d editor.  This means that for example. the same mission could be infinitely replayable, or that a mission could have different outcomes depending on player actions without having to script a single thing.

If you are not into the multiplayer side of things, don't worry. Arma 3 has plenty of official SP experiences, and if that's not enough for you, the community has you covered. You can also make your own missions using the Eden editor, a very solid 3d editor which offers you a wide variety of tools to make your own scenarios.

Not everything is positives though;

The game and its engine show its age. The physics can backfire in hilariously ridiculous ways (specially on multiplayer), be careful when driving vehicles at speed over bumps!

On a less funny note, the AI can be pretty hit or miss. It's usually fine, though, and there are AI mods you can put in the game for a different experience.

All in all, it's a really good game.

[h1]Arma 3 is what you make of it[/h1]

If you like drop in / drop out gameplay, then you will enjoy public servers.
If you have a set time per day/week to play, then you will enjoy private Unit servers more.

If you like PvE, then you will flock to gamemodes like Zeus, Escape, and Campaign;
While PvP players jump at Warlords and KOTH.

'Real Military' equipment not your style? Download a total conversion mod, and join a unit that runs operations with it.
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=769440155] Halo [/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2649081108] Star Wars [/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2221541445] Alien [/url]
The possibilities get pretty wild

Want more realism and 'milsim'? Mods like 'ace3', 'jsrs', and 'suppress' add a realism feel. Combine those with unit modpacks like RHS and/or CUP and you have several additional factions, maps, equipment, and uniforms to fight with.

Interested in all this and not sure where to start? Join an interesting unit's Discord and ask away. [url=https://units.arma3.com] https://units.arma3.com [/url]

If you want the true experience without missing anything however, you're gonna need to buy some DLC. Sites like Kinguin or G2A have a lot of the keys at ridiculously low prices that undercut the Steam store by up to 90%, so definitely look there first.

DLC's that you WILL NEED are as follows:
Apex (It adds  too much to list here)
Marksmen (Rifles and sights)
Helicopters (You're gonna use these a lot)
Tanks (Could do without this but its nice to have)
Zeus and Malden are free, just download em

OPTIONAL DLC but still great to have:
Karts (cmon dude its a kart)
Jets (only if you are fond of being a CAS pilot)
Laws of War (adds some misc. gear)
Contact (Adds a fantastic map for use in multiplayer, some gear, and a subpar campaign with bad fps)
Western Sahara (a 'standalone' mod that launches apart from the regular game to add a fun survival mode and a co-op campaign style Extraction mode)

Every creator DLC aside from the one listed can basically be simulated for free via workshop content. SOG is supremely overpriced and the Unsung mod is the same thing but free

Tacops mission pack will probably come with some other DLC if you buy from Kinguin, but don't buy on its own

This game has a lot of potential but unfortunately i think it is too rigid and difficult, especially lone wolf players.  It took me about 20 hours to learn the "Basics of the game" via tutorials and a couple of the single player missions.  I go online and spend 5 hours trying to figure out how to join a multiplayer game. Then another 2 hours trying to learn how to fast travel on a map (there are NO instructions on how to do this).  Then another total of 5 hours trying to get into vehicles that it doesn't let me get into because of my rank/loadout.  Then another few hours waiting for other players in helicopters to ferry me over to the battlefield where i die within seconds.  

This game is not for people who enjoy battlefield games. This is for groups of people looking to have teamwork, most likely veterans.  This is not for the casual gamer.   

I want my money back. But since I invested 40 hours trying to learn this game, Steam declined to give me a refund because i exceeded the max play time of 2 hours.  You heard me TWO HOURS.  It took me over an hour to finish the crash- landing a helicopter tutorial ALONE! and that was part 1 of 4 which was one section of 12.  

Not only is this a bad game for casual gamers. But STEAM  has a terrible return policy. I will no longer buy games from Steam nor will i buy games by Bohemia Interactive.

ARMA 3 can literally be whatever you want it to be. The modding potential for this game is insane. Even if you play it straight though, it's a stupid fun time.

Invade and Annex is what I love to play with ARMA. It's basically a PVE mode where you're working with a team of human players to take areas from an AI faction. I have already done a ton of cool things: using an anti-tank rocket to take down a heli Rambo-style, having an epic last stand beside my comrades in a tiny fort against a horde of enemy troops... the best story bar-none though is the story of a friend and I waiting for heli pickup along with maybe 10-15 other people. We made jokes about "Pepsi flares" because there were twenty blue and red flares going off all at once. I wanted to throw a flare to join in on the party... and accidentally threw a grenade into the middle of our group huddle. The entire squad died... and I freaking died of laughter. I still have yet to laugh as hard as I had in that moment.

ARMA is an amazing game to create stories, whether you're playing with friends or strangers. No matter how you play ARMA, at the end of the day you're gonna have SOME memorable experience you can talk about... and that is ARMA's magic.
Is it a nice game? yes. Am I addicted? yes. Can you commit war crimes? yes. Is my life going downward? probably.
its a really good realistic mil-sim and i would recommend it to others wanting a mil sim experience.

Starting with the good, it's a great platform to set up intresting multiplayer games, coop or pvp, Zeus is amazing, and of course, mods!

Now with the bad. The DLCs. Some are good, some are not worth the price, some are just awful, but in general they're way too expensive, a massive ivestment to get them all, and if you dont own them and somebody, out of your control, sets up a game with them, you'll suffer game breaking popups all over your screen.

Physics are janky af, vehicles, and even movement sometimes behave like its gmod, or even worse than gmod sometimes. Destruction looks quite bad.

Sound design and gunplay sound underwhelming. Not outright bad, but just not as good as other games like squad.

Now all those are possible to overlook often, but the thing that fully kills it is: The community. Holy shit the community. Now if you just have a group of friends and play with them, you'll be fine, but most "clans" "groups" "squads" whatever you join are... UGH. The WORST

Not only you'll get bullied if you aren't good at the game, they'll also actually add GRIND to it. like they'll often make you get promotions and shit in their stupid group before you can actually get access to all the game's features and play different roles. It's packed full of edgy violent military wannabe LARPers that are just the most annoying kind of cringe in the universe. Also these """clans""" have this braindead annoying retarded kind of tribal mentality where they'll constantly get into drama with one another and just in general it seems like half the players of this game need to see a psychologist. I'm sure there are exceptions, but that's my experience.

Now, apart from that, the modding community is just THE WORSE. Instead of working together towards a common goal you'll get 10 mods trying to do the same thing all working independently and fighting each other, and this going extremely slow and just... So stupid. Often this competition is linked to the same kind of shitty "clan" mentality they've got since sometimes mods will be attached to a specific clan, officially or unofficially. Hell! Some clans just play with private mods they make and don't release! Just overall, AWFUL community.

The game itself is very fun and engaging when are not getting team killed. The game took awhile to actually get into. The controls are many and my brainpower is few; I can fly a chopper, but I can't land. My only gripe is trying to make it so your friends can join in on the co-op campaign as Bohemia still thinks its 1995. The game is enjoyable if you find the right people in the right mindset to enjoy the game. The tutorial could have been made a bit more clear than it was put out to be. The soundtrack slaps. The VR Training is very useful if you are new and would like to try to learn the basics and a few niches. Anything goes in Arma 3 a game made in 2013.

*If you just wanna the overall, just skip until you found the OVERALL section.

What's good in the game
- Mod/Steam Workshop Support
- Sound Effects to weapons, and armaments.
- Extensive, yet awesome Post-Launch content.
- Interesting story/lore.
- Amazing Weapons (Base + DLC)
- Multiple Large Terrains

What's Suck on the game
-Bad Optimization/Performance
-Braindead/Stupid AI


OVERALL

This game is overall fun and expansive, but it's plagued with a horrible performance/optimization and a stupid/braindead AI, especially during a firefight. But that can be compensated for the meantime if you find yourself in a mp community/doing solo on campaign/custom content that are available on the Steam Workshop.

Final Score: 8.5/10

Arma 3 is a difficult game to talk about. The vanilla offering, even with DLC is quite mediocre, but certainly worth the price so I can recommend it on that level, but when you buy Arma 3, what you're really investing in is a platform; consider this the G-Mod of tactical shooters. It's a blank slate, a chaotic playground for you and your friends to mess around with hundreds of mods, all tied together with complex ballistics, huge maps, a rich community and an endless supply of mission generators and milsim groups to get you out on the field.

It isn't terribly important, but the overarching setting for Arma 3 is the year 2035, with the CSAT alliance of China and Iran making up the featured antagonist for this entry, however PMC groups and other NATO adversaries like the Russian Federation or the fictional Altis will make regular appearances both in Bohemia Interactive's content and beyond. I wouldn't call the game futuristic as such, but there is a pretty nice helping of fictional firearms, vehicles and equipment if that appeals to you.

Arma 3 is often slow-paced and can be brutally difficult. Unless you have a great deal of experience in the game, one combatant is easily enough to kill you, so taking on groups of enemies without allies is a fruitless endeavour. Firearms function (for the most part) with a high degree of realism. Wind, distance, drop, calibre and penetration are all things you will have to consider while fighting, as well as keeping track of how many shots you have left per-magazine. This goes for vehicles too, where sharp turns in jets will spark you out, and the wrong launcher rounds will not take out a tank no matter how hard you try.

I'll wrap this up by saying that Arma 3 is a very personal game, your experience depends on who, and what you play with, regardless there is something here for everyone.

I love this game so much.  When I look at how many hours I have on it I always consider playing something else.  But something always draws me back.  This game has allowed me to make so many memories with all the different things that could happen.  I appreciate this games campaign as well.  It took me a while to figure out the story and all the complex parts.  But when I did put time and consideration into it my appreciation for it skyrocketed.  The controls for this game are complex and take some practice but when you do figure it out it makes the experience much better.

This games community has always been in my opinion one of the best parts about it.  I have met countless people through this game that I have had much fun with.  It always makes me happy when I first meet someone new in the game.  I have a special love for the people that use this game for art. Some of the pictures I've seen of this game amaze me with how much effort was put into it.  This games lot of DLC's are very fun.  Especially the S.O.G Prairie Fire DLC it is so well made.  Although the DLC's are so much fun another incredible thing about this game is the mods.  The mods for this game make it what it is.  The diversity of it is incredible.  They are so easy to install; for example, it takes 4 minutes and I could have Darth Vader be fighting the bugs from Starship Troopers.  The mods of the game are incredible.

My final message of the game is that this is simply one of the greatest games I have ever played.  I will continue to play this game with countless hours of fun.  Then when or if Arma 4 is released I will move on and keep playing another game from one of my favorite game series ever.  I love this game

Simulation isn't the defining aspect of Arma. It's scale.

The enormity of the map is the foundation for the experiences that distinguish Bohemia Interactive's flagship franchise. It's what makes radios, topographical maps, binoculars, and compasses practical equipment in an FPS. It's what allows for kilometer-long headshots and coordinated convoy raids. It's what makes using your eyes to spot hints of enemies--muzzle flashes, tracers, gunsmoke--as valuable as being a crack shot.

The scale of Arma 3 dwarfs everything in the genre, including Arma 2. Altis, a keyhole portion of which is seen in these screenshots, is a Mediterranean island-nation assembled from ruins, airports, coastal villages, solar power plants, military outposts, salt flats, and tank-friendly scrubland. It's a variegated backyard for you to play war in, but what's more significant is that Arma's landscape finally has the technology it deserves.

681 hours logged at the time of this review, and I still crave more. Some things that I have really enjoyed doing in this game:

Downloading a map of Manhattan, spawning myself and a tank onto a building roof and driving off of it. 

Putting a static platform 5k meters in the air and spawning on it to try to start a mission by skydiving. 

Spawning 20 NPCs in the air at the start of the mission and skydiving down with them - no one had parachutes. 

Finding a way to cause chaos, destruction and death in the showcase missions without triggering a mission fail for friendly fire and having it actually work. 

Placing 50 empty vehicles on a runway, spawning a plane with infinite ammo to practice bombing runs. 

Trying to fly the speed of sound four inches from the ground. 

Trying to make a hill defense mission in the remains of a hill top castle. 

Renting a private server to play custom missions with my brother. 

I have enjoyed manyof the campaign missions, had a ton of fun on various multiplayer servers and spent at least a hundred hours in the editor. The learning curve is steep, the keybindings can be ridiculous, but it has been a rewarding experience, with a lot of rich content out there to be experienced. Highly recommended.
