This review comes from somebody who majorly plays unmodded; spending most of their time in the 3DEN editor, and little bit in the official Warlords gamemode.

[h1] Infantry gameplay [/h1]
If you plan on hopping in any common official server, it's more than likely you're going to be playing infantry most of the time. There's a countless amount of oddities, such as
* Walking crouched with a primary weapon, you have almost no movement sway with your weapon, except the occasional bump, but only when walking forward-right.
* Sidearm sway can only be negated when moving very slowly or standing still.
* Standing with a rocket launcher gives you less sway than when crouched.
* Sprinting speed is affected by your equipped item; fastest run speed is in the order of unarmed > binoculars > sidearm > primary > launcher.
* Unarmed stance can only be achieved by having nothing equipped or by going prone while holding a launcher; unarmed crouch sprinting is the fastest way to travel as infantry.
* Trying to mount certain ladders is metaphorically painful.
* Switching and reloading weapons can feel really awkward at times.
* There are some timegated mechanics that you can stack for an advantage (reload then heal, reload then mount ladder), but not the other way around.

[h1] DLC [/h1]
It's not too intrusive, but for when it does show, DLC markings are very inconsistent within the editor and arsenal. A few examples being
* Karts DLC items are not marked as DLC items in the arsenal, but are in the editor.
* Equipment and clothes from various DLCs are marked as DLC, but only some items require ownership.
* Reskins of vanilla weapons and attachments that are marked as DLC typically do not require DLC ownership.
* Being able to situationally use DLC equipment without owning a DLC as a try-before-you-buy thing is nice, but having the player learn what items do and don't require ownership through trial-and-error isn't intuitive.

[h1] Hidden/unused content [/h1]
There is a load of unused content in the official game, such as uniform/vehicle reskins that requires unusual techniques to access, such as using the setObjectTexture commands in the editor. There are also props that you can only access using the createVehicle command, such as foliage props and pieces of large buildings.

[h1] Vehicle gameplay [/h1]
There's a sizeable variety of vehicle gameplay. Submarines, boats, karts, quadbikes, cars, APCs, MBTs, helicopters, and jets, and it mostly feels pretty solid.
Unfortunately for submarines, there's only one, and it's not very enjoyable.
All water vehicles, even aquatic APCs while in the water, suffer a bug that makes them go in a direction indefinitely if the driver changes seats or dies while holding forward/backwards.
Small land vehicles are extremely delicate, quadbike, car, or truck, you'll probably learn that driving through a few bushes will harm you very quickly.
Armored vehicles have no issue knocking over bushes, and even fences, at low speeds.

[h1] Multiplayer UI [/h1]
The chatbox feels old and clunky with no way to filter chat channels.
This is a generally a gripe of mine because I may not want to see server messages (Player is connecting, player connects using modified data, player forced respawn, etc.) or the global chat channel of a server, which usually ends up being two teams mocking eachother.

The playerlist is only sorted alphabetically. No way to sort by team or join order.

Muting players only affects their voice activity, and the "mute all" button only mutes players currently on the server for you.
If a new person joins and starts screeching into the mic, you have to open the player menu again to mute them. My current workaround is to just have the voice-over-network audio option turned all the way down.

Hackers/exploits exist.
I can only remember one encounter with what I'm assuming is a hacker. They did something that just rapidly played a honking noise that disregarded my volume settings. It's wasn't voice activity; I had that way down at the time, and muting all players on the server didn't solve it.

[h1] Character management [/h1]
You get to pick your face and some facewear. Usually doesn't even matter, though, unless you're a tryhard that refuses to use anything other than the stealth balaclava. The preview is bugged and won't show reskins properly.
You can upload a custom face, but a server has to allow it, or else you'll like Mr. Clean dipped his head in a vat of bleach.

Overall it's kind of okay, but not something I'd recommend to others.

I'm really torn on this game. I *love* the idea of it and it's actually pretty well done overall. Great graphics given how old it is and it's definitely one of the more satisfying FPS games. I even loved the first episode of the campaign. But I got to the second episode where you have to control the AI and it's absolutely terrible. It's game-breakingly bad. Not only do I not want to control the AI and I'm forced to, but they're also idiots. 

Your AI units are just utter morons and the control system is one of the most unnecessarily difficult and overly-complicated things I've ever seen in the history of games. You have a couple of seconds to set your units up and give them all commands, yet you find yourself cycling through endless, unnecessary commands. "Crouch, not fully crouched, but not half standing crouch, yeah, that's the right sort of crouch". I'm not exaggerating. There's about 3 or 4 different levels of 'crouch'. Then you've got to control each person individually, because they can't just do what should be common sense to anyone with even the minutia of experience of combat. Tell them to hold fire and they wont fire at all. Even if they're getting shot at from point blank. 

It's a shame, but their idiocy has legitimately ruined my experience so far. I'm hoping to play some multiplayer because it sounds fun with people that aren't idiots like the AI, but I haven't yet, so I can't comment on that.

What I can say though is that it's ruined the campaign for me. After my 5th attempt at the 2nd episode mission, it annoyed me so much I rage quit and uninstalled the game.

I love this game. I haven't played nearly as much as the other people in these reviews, but I love this game. 51 hours in and I'm happy as a clam. There are some things I would like to point out (even as a fairly inexperienced player):

Pros: 
Really, REALLY Good tactical shooter. Feels like you are immersed in the game. 

Good gunplay, I'd wager better than most games I've played. 

Really great emphasis on team communication (more on that later) 

Most people say this game isn't beginner friendly, but by 10 hours I was making maps for me and my friends to play on our own, and knew all of the controls decently well. 

Great online community (albeit sometimes toxic, as with any online community) but you can find some really great servers and the game still has active servers by the developers to play on, 8 years after the game came out! 

I personally really love the vehicle selection, especially with easy-to-download mods, it's a blast.

Cons: 
While there is an emphasis on team communication, if one of your team mates sucks at communicating or just isn't very friendly, it ruins that game. You get into this negative feedback loop of wanting to quit because of this teammate but you can't because if you do that you jeopardize the mission. If you mute the, you miss important callouts and stuff too. This isn't a huge problem all the time, but it can be a glaring issue when it pops up. 

Toxic online communities seriously suck. I hate getting into a match and seeing slurs in the chat or hearing them on radio. I also see offensive server names from time to time, which really sucks. Wish I could report those. 

Finally, this game is 8 years old. It's got flaws, and while most of them can be overlooked, it would be nice if Arma 4 or a comprehensive patch to this game came out in the near future. 

Thanks for reading! :)

Hetman's War Stories and A.I. Skill around .2 and A.I. Accuracy around .3. Remember this. That is what makes this game the best infantry soldier simulator on the market. Yes, you can do anything that a military can do in Arma 3 from flying planes to driving tanks, to being a commander of an entire army while being able to play as an individual unit. However, Arma 3 is really buggy in the mod department and really underachieving in the vanilla game, so to really tweak the game, you gotta sacrifice ALOT of time. However, I have spent that time doing that and you might not have to. I initially hated this game, because I felt like the vanilla game did not do it justice, since this is a sandbox game and why would you make it so FREAKIN' difficult to create any scenario, with any faction, on any map, with full scale joint operations, using all the units, vehicles and weapons??? So, with almost all simulators, a stong mod community is a requirement and the former mod mentioned with a few option tweaks makes Arma 3 a study course in warfare. Period. Hetman's War Stories is the mod that jailbreaks Arma and makes it easier to "see everything" in the game without having to be dang near a software engineer and read LOTS of material on how to create the type of war you want. Alot has been said about the A.I., but with the above settings, you will be sweating and feeling the full effect of a ground war. Arma 3 isn't perfect in it's vanilla state, but wilh some help from the community and a few tweaks, this will be the last FPS game you will ever need in your game library. Also, I took the time to take a break from the game to write this.....the British and CSAT are having a brawl on Malden for 3 real time hours....seems to be a stale mate with lots of casualties, but I wonder what will be the strategy that will allow either side to finish on top....and before that I helped NATO wipe CSAT off Stratis using the "expeditionary" strategy with superior air forces....but before that CSAT really gave the FIA independent militia a hard time and class in guerilla war 101. Welcome to Arma 3.

One of the best purchases i've made in gaming, hands down. Performance is really determined by what you are running, but I have both myself and my girlfriend playing this together on a private server (PHRP - Project Harvest Roleplay Server - a halo modded server) and we both can run it. My machine is pretty up-to-date, but her's is for all intents and purposes the definition of a 'Potato' machine - but yet she can run it smoothly on low-mid graphics. To say this game is accessible no matter your PC is an understatement.

The best part IMO is honestly the community. Due to the sandbox nature of this game, there is so much that you can do in Eden Editor / Zeus that allows for so many different scenarios and stories to be told - you don't see it all that often in the current world of gaming. There are so many passion project servers / scenarios, that you are bound to find something that interests you. I never expected myself to start playing in a Halo-modded RP server, but here I am months later playing twice a week with a great group of folks.

I woke, floating to the ground in my parachute. I assumed the flames in the distance was my airplane. I had no idea where the other people I had been with were, or if they were even alive. We had been experiencing magnetic distortions for more than an hour, so I knew we were way off course. Maybe by hundreds of miles.
I got to the ground and immediately started checking my drop bag for any food or equipment I might be able to use. Other than an MRE and a bottle of clean water, there wasnt much.. It was already nearing dark, and not knowing the area, I knew I needed to find shelter soon. There was no telling how long it would be before I found civilization, or even another person so I had to prepare for the worst.
No more had that thought filled my head and I froze as my head and ear instinctively turned. "Did I hear an engine?", I thought. I closed my eyes and listened for a second. At first I thought I had just been hoping, but then I heard it. It was a helicopter! "It couldnt be a rescue so soon." - I stood and began meandering toward the sound of the blades off in the distance. Someone flying nearby must have seen the crash or saw the flames. 
As I walked, listening, I could hear the small craft getting nearer and as it peaked over the distant hills, I began jumping and screaming and waving my arms. The chopper put its nose down and began heading straight toward me and I felt an overwhelming since of relief knowing that I wouldnt be stranded. And just as my screams became a calmed smile, I heard it. "PPEESSSHHEEWWWWWW!" - From my days in Afghanistan I instinctively recognized the sound and the streak in the sky as a portable ground to air rocket. My shoulders  shrugged as a forgone reaction and I almost grabbed my ears as I already knew what was coming. I saw the chopper try to make a very abrupt evasive maneuver, but it was to no avail as the rocket hit its mark. The chopper exploded and I saw the pilot thrown to the side as a parachute started opening. I was relieved he made it, but immediately I started hearing gunfire from a high powered rifle and watched in horror as the man in the chute became a dangling, slow floating target. I knew he wouldnt make it and gave up even watching, as I knew my life was in danger and I had to get some cover. I crouched as low as I could while still being able to run and began heading toward the wood line in the distance.
"What the fuck is happening here? What is this place?"

This game is very different than other shooting games such as COD or Battlefield. Though they also have some single player campaigns, ARMA truly focuses on the single player battle experience. ARMA replicates how real life soldiers would go on about on a mission. There are many scenes where there are many enemies to shoot at, but are also many others where you would need to just walk for a very long time, or just wait for orders. Nevertheless, that is necessary for a real mission experience. 

Though ARMA could improve on the human aspect like Scum, GTA Online, or Minecraft (heart rate, hydration, stamina, hunger, etc - this would help make the game experience even more real), it is still a very great game to enjoy if you want to try what a mission-specific battle experience is like. 

For me personally, it is a great game to enjoy from time to time if I want to play a slow paced game, and not a too extensive and fast paced game like COD or Battlefield where you're constantly facing enemies and respawning. ARMA actually got a bit boring after the 20 hour mark, so it is only enjoyable from time to time.

Greatest military simulation ever created. Period. Been playing since the European version of Operation Flashpoint was released back in early 2001, ever since I've been addicted. I'm an old salty dog veteran of this franchise so I've watched this simulations game engine mature and be refined over the last 20 years. The greatest asset Arma 3 has is it's huge amount of amazing modifications and the people that create them. For the folks making them it's a labour of love. Do I recommend this simulation? I'll let my hours played speak for itself. Is it perfect? No. Does it do something on a scale no other current military simulation does? Yes. Once you get the hang of the keyboard layout and customise it to your own needs, you'll be immersed and addicted. 

The multiplayer community that surrounds this simulation is fantastic, it's mostly comprised of "older" folks who have been playing for years. They are very protective of their servers and the people they play with because there's been so many pathetic cheating idiots attempting to disrupt their games. That said, they weed them out and are always welcoming to new players who are looking for the same kind of experience and good time as they are.

I know, 1200 hours and I am sending a negative review. "Clearly you liked it else you wouldn't have played for 1200 hours." Yeah, I will be honest Arma 3 has had its ups and downs over the years. For the people who care I finally snapped and I realized that this game pales in comparison to Arma 2 even years after release. If you want to play arma 3 MODED like Liru, go for it. Else stay away from this if you value your sanity. For the people who care, this is why

Day 1: I just bought Arma 3, this is before the Apex DLC or anything of that sort. I realized straight off the bat that Arma 3 was shallow in almost every way. The three factions in terms of kit were spread with 1 MBT for each, 1 jet for each which really was just CAS (neophron for CSAT, A10 ripoff for NATO, buzzard for indie). In terms of armored cars, 1 for each and 1 APC type of each (except indie, since they had 2 APCs). There was NO RADAR, no advanced tank armor, the module esc damage was a thing of the past since most things just outright killed you. 

Flash to today

Jets DLC added 3 more jets, of the air-superiority type, radar was added but really it is just pathetic. From playing DCS for every just a few hundred hours I can see truly that their radar is sad. AA combat because little more than a point and click adventure 

Tanks DLC added a few new items that fleshed out the tanks, interiors is a waste that never gets used. Armor system was revamped so tanks can now be disabled easier however getting hit by a tank shell still tends to just "dent the armor" with no real damage being done. This makes it so the other tank can return fire and depending on the hit it might be an insta kill. So essentially the devs need to make up their mind. Do they want tanks to be disabled preferably or destroyed preferably. Either way again this is just a point and click adventure now. They even do ranging for you and speed for moving targets (which is realistic though).

This is not even going into detail about their aggressive marketing which was upped from Arma 2. As opposed to arma 2 where using a vic from a DLC might have a watermark show up. In Arma 3 you just CAN NOT use said vehicle in multiplayer what-so-ever. This is disgusting since it means people have to test DLC items against the AI which is frankly a hot mess that can either one shot you across the map, or fly into a cliff (A3 wasteland has shown me.. a LOT of AI bugs). 

If we want to continue this pain train from hell. How about we talk more in depth about the AI shall we? Without mods the AI pathing is sad at best which can be backed up with quotes from Liru and other Zeus users. Fast vehicles on a curving road will not slow down enough to actually make the corner. Prime suspect here is the Hatchback Sport. Tight bridge crossings like in the NW of Malden have also seen many tanks/apcs when they panic straight drive off the road. This is actually a tactic in A3 wasteland since if you hit the convoy at the right time one or more vehicles can get stuck. Aircraft pathing is easy to see as bad because the aircraft slow down on attack runs making them easy to hit even with Vorona TOW missiles. They act like they are coming in for a gun run on a Tigris that just mulches them when they should boost off and hit it with a mav. 

I genuinely believe aircraft was a second or even third rung priority for the team. the aircraft wobble up and down when passively flying hinting that there are no buffer zones or that the AI does not calculate where the plane will be in advance (say where it will be in 2 seconds). This type of system may even help vehicle AI not drive off the road and slow down before a curve. 

The worst part of all is that there are TONS of GOOD MODS that people like Liru use that completely fix or overhaul the AI for all elements to make them much better within the confines of modding. Yet these are mods so for people like me they will never be a reality. Especially since, years and years out from its launch these are still issues that plague it to this date. They have no intention of fixing them assuming they CAN even fix them. 

How about we talk about viewdist now.. and how this game looks like it could stand in for Silent Hill. Multiplayer default viewdist is a travesty that has range from 2 to 3 km. This is fine for most things, infantry combat will not exceed 1km for the most part. Tank combat also will not exceed maybe 2 to 2.5km. However aircraft get the short end of the stick. If you are flying 1km above the ground that means you will "see" 2km of ground in a circle around you. However around this 2 of 3km mark this haze starts occluding your view. This makes it borderline impossible to spot something small unless they are really stupid. So that being said, the effective viewdist is <2km. Even in wasteland they use a plugin to modify this and that increases the max dist to 5km (mist appears at 3.5km). This makes aircraft a lot more use-able but again, MOD.

I will not say anything more, but understand that this is just the tip of the iceburg here for all the problems in Arma 3. I do not want this post becoming longer than some school essays. Even with that said though the game is really fun sometimes. You get a group of friends together on wasteland and get some missions done. Just this game is not fun most of the time since outside of having friends it is a slog.

I guess, when was the last time you saw pure Vanilla Arma 3 without any mods just DLC. if the answer is no then you will probably be shocked by this review.

[b]"Our studio is dying, and we can't effectively develop games anymore - so we're going to sell MODS to the community instead!"[/b]

From the *cough* new and improved 'Bohemia Interactive' that has completely forgotten their job as a 'development studio.'  I guess the talent left with Bohemia Interactive Simulations and VBS3, eh?

Let's take a look at how BIS feels about old daddy BI, shall we? https://www.bisimulations.com/company/news/press-releases/bisim-statement-investment-former-owner

[quote]Feb 09, 2021

ORLANDO, Fla. (USA) ‚Äî Commercial game developer Bohemia Interactive recently announced that Tencent Holdings agreed to acquire a minority stake in the company. Bohemia Interactive‚Äôs announcement has no impact on the operations or ownership of Bohemia Interactive Simulations.

...

"Bohemia Interactive is not and has not been an active participant in BISim‚Äôs business for many years,‚Äù said BISim CEO Arthur Alexion. ‚ÄúBISim has been a completely separate business from Bohemia Interactive since Riverside acquired BISim in 2013. We have no commercial links or ongoing business relationship with Bohemia Interactive."[/quote]

Hmm - as soon as everybody's favorite 'technology conglomerate holding company' bought into Bohemia Interactive, not only did their golden son - that makes [b]virtual reality simulation games for Government Militaries and Private Security Contractors abroad[/b] - disown Daddy BI, but the sheer quality of their DLC practices has dropped.

Immensely.

Consider the sheer difference in quality between S.O.G., Global Mobilization: Cold War Germany, and CSLA Iron Curtain.  Assets from each DLC aren't even uniform.  You have two different Strelka AA launchers that aren't even the same size - don't even get me started on the textures and shading of freaking AK-47s.

[b]Bohemia Interactive simply took what modders made, put a price tag on it, slapped it on the table, and sold it.[/b]  They performed no quality control whatsoever (if you want to argue, I just have to say say [b]"CSLA: Iron Curtain"[/b] five times fast and I'll win) and they proceed to profit.

All of that profit, because their legacy is what fuels them.  ArmA 1 was great, ArmA 2 was better, and ArmA 3 had the best potential out of all of them.  Then the little split happened, which should've been a red flag to all partakers...

At this point, it looks as if ArmA 4 is going to be a fan fiction collaboration between players, that Bohemia Interactive will sell as their own.  I don't know WHAT happened to them, but if you're looking to waste money, there are countless other military themed games you can spend it on and get your money's worth for.

If you want to invest in the dying legacy of the ArmA series and set yourself up for disappointment - consider yourself warned.  Like their future sales will reflect, I give the direction of this company a solid thumbs down.  I wouldn't pay ten cents for their next game knowing they've lost touch with everything that made them great to begin with!

Ultimate military sandbox game. Infinite mod-ability allows for a huge amount of user content. The scale of the maps is enormous, perfect for combined arms operations or urban operations. However, not every building is enterable so not a lot of opportunity for out of the box close quarters combat. 
The single player experience is passable, but I enjoy it most with multiplayer cooperative modes. The large scale of the maps make Player vs Player modes not super fun in my opinion. Too many opportunity for bush snipers. 
There is a fair amount of bugs and built in weirdness, but given the scale of the game and the relative small size of the development team, this should be expected. I've been playing this franchise for about 20 years and enjoyed all of it, flaws and all.

Beware this game has a bit of a deep learning curve and the tutorials aren't great nor the campaign mode too scripted. Would I recommend this game, absolutely.

My Super Fancy Criteria:
Talking with cool people and shit: 9/10
Gameplay Shit: 7/10
Doing Cool Shit in a cool place: 8/10

Talking with cool people and shit: 
This game might be my favorite of all time, and most of the reasons are not because the actual game play.  The comradery you can feel with a bunch of random guy's on the internet is pretty cool, given they're not jackass Delta Seal Special Force Wannabes.  The community has it's dark sides, but I have also met some long time friends in this game that I hang out with on the regular (not just in Arma).  If you are lucky to get yourself in a good community then you can have the time of your life.

Gameplay: 
Yeah this games mods and initial concepts are awesome and really fun to play, but it's so fucking buggy. Arma really shows its age. If you play Arma and say "Wow! Everything is fine!" then you are a pathological liar, or just really lucky.  The only other thing I would say in terms of game play, do yourself a favor and look through the workshop and find mods that you find fun.

Doing Cool Shit in cool places:
If you just want to feel like a bad ass or really dumb this is the place, some of the moments in this game feel straight cinematic. Despite it's old age, the vanilla maps still are very pretty besides some textures that are on the lower side.  Even when there's nothing going on just being in a visually appealing environment can make you experience that much better. 


Overall rating: 8/10

This is not a game, it's a simulator. Think of it as DCS but for infantry. From fire team movements to section tactics to platoon sized assaults to Combined Arms operations with APCs, Tanks, CAS and Naval Artillery, ARMA has it all. And that's just the base game. oh and did i mention IEDs?

With mods, you can do realistic reenactments of famous operations like market garden with realistic equipment and accurately recreated maps. You can play as the UNSC, hunting down Covenant elites. Heck, you can even reenact a walking dead episode with the zombie mods or play as a Vietnamese Tiger chewing of american flesh. Someone even recreated COD:MW2 campaign in ARMA which is pretty good.

There's no learning curve in this game, but there's a learning mountain so tall that you might meet Morgan Freeman up there narrating your fails. As of writing this review, I have 563 hrs in ARMA but i'm still running around like a headless chicken with Morgan Freeman up there laughing at my incompetence. 

10/10 would recommend if you enjoy multiplayer military simulators.

Have you ever wanted to simulate numerous crimes against humanity, experience the horrors of war and feel what it's truly like to be a soldier. Well, this game can do that, and that's the reason I and many others have played this game. However, expecting that to happen is a bad idea. A combination of a jank physics engine, dumb players and a malicious Zeus means you will probably not have the full military experience. 

However, that doesnt make Arma a bad game, far from it. Player interaction and the sheer scale of an 8 year old game with decent enough graphics makes it a blast to play. Arma 3 units become a group of close nit dumbasses who joined for the milsim and stayed for the community (probably). Modding is mandatory, vanilla Arma is expensive and no where near as content rich. Trust me, thousands of hours of entertainment await if you hit the right note with this game.

You can also play on public lobbies and experience war crime induced aneurysms and metal insanity through KOTH and Invade and Annex. You could join the ranks of a questionable resistance. Or you could simulate the state of Florida in Altis life (dont). Or you could destroy your will to live while making missions for friends to play, only for them and dumbass AI to ruin your perfectly laid plans.

Arma 3 is worth the purchase. You probably wont regret it

Alright lets begin. My review about Arma 3.

Hmm where to start.. lets begin with the gameplay itself, this game is very very replay-able the  level of difficulties is very customizable, from easy for beginner to extreme for real veterans. as for me myself i play this game with the level of difficulty at 'normal' and guess what? it's hard af. the gameplay on the story mode is really immersive, the way how u can give orders to ur AI teammates individually is just mind blowing, there's so many ways you can interact with the game, but i have never said the game itself is smart at following what u want them to do. For example, you want your AI to get in the car, you know what they will do? they shoot you. yes you. i don't even know what have happened or what i did to them. It is quite disappointing for the AI itself, but the game? dang i never regret a single buck paying it. Just buy it during the sale. Also expect playing while watching youtube for tutorials, because it is both combat and strategically hard. If you know what you're doing then it would be easy, but if you still need to find a way to play the game, then it would be challenging, not hard. 

Alright next one, public co op or private co op. As for this i can not say much, this is due to the fact that i live on Asia and the server i've been wanting to play to is a north america server, so i always get high pings. This is also a warning for you who wants to buy this game for the online server, make sure that you're in the right region and right server, because it could affect your ping. This game would and will kick you if you have ping above 200.

How about the graphic? well for a game that has been here since 2013 i would say the graphic is magnificent, this is because the developers keep on giving us updates non stop, there's always something to do in Arma 3, no doubt. The map has amazing details, shadow, textures, shadow, and lighting everything is near perfect for a game that's already 8 years old.

im too lazy to write everything and the review i have wrote above is just 1/5 of my total review. So i will state my point. The game is worth it, it is a very replay-able game, so many things to do with various mode of gameplays, also good graphic. My note for all of you is try to buy it on sale since this game might be a little bit off from your expectation both gameplay and difficulties.

"So why are you giving a positive review" you ask?

Besides its quirky faults and bugs, this game is the ultimate epitome of the sandbox MilSim legacy of Bohemia Interactive. Not only Arma 3 gave rise to several game genres on its own, like MilSims (Squad/Post Scriptum), Battleroyale (PUBG with PUBG developer starting out as an Arma 3 multiplayer game modder), it also allowed unique customisation options.

The vanilla game version offers you a Singleplayer campaign, Co/op missions, and multiplayer games/missions. You can either create, cooperate and multiplay scripted missions, permanent missions, co-op PVE and PVP missions. Everything you see on the map (and even under the water) is within the game zone; see those distant mountains? You can climb there to get a vantage point on the enemy or carelessly get sniped form there... whilst on foot, driving, flying and swimming, whilst also carrying a wide range of equipment.

And this is not even the best part of it yet:
Arma 3 is very mod and modder friendly, with developers releasing increasingly quality of life and user friendly updates, mod integration and semi-official, themed DLCs. After 7 years the modding community is still up and running.
Want to play as a WW1 trench fighter? a WH40K space marine? a WW3 panzer commander in the 80s? or even go go-karting dressed as My Little Pony? There is possibly a plethora of mods for those, making the sandbox experience unique, and giving the players unlimited creative freedom to create, share and play their own missions/content.

Also has a decent multiplayer community, ranging from retired army corporals shouting in military jargon to "warcrimes go brrr"-toxicity players, but despite all the flaws i counted, this is one of the games i enjoy playing the most, both SP and MP and has a unique feel.

The best part of this game is that you can make it whatever you want.
Want to play as Sgt. Thundercock, a DEVGRU operator who singlehandedly kicked down every door on Altis? Go for it.
Want to play as Pvt. Joe Schmo of the 508th IR, fighting in a foxhole with an M4 while enemy tanks close in on your position? Sure thing.
Want to be a part of a massive milsim group, practicing squad-based tactics with a set structure of command? There are plenty of units who do just that.
Want to play casual drop-in operations on the weekends with a group of likeminded individuals? There are units for that, too.
Hate interacting with other people and just want to play on your own? Official and fanmade singleplayer campaigns exist and are very good.
At the end of the day, ARMA is whatever you want it to be. There's no right or wrong way to play.

I love this game. 1st person shooters with larger maps are fine and all, but this game really does it for me. The community is mostly adults from what I can tell, but that hasn't stopped me from having fun in this game. There are many ways to play, from logistics to acting as close air support, to infantry. Many different play styles are supported through this game. Sure, if you want to try something new, you are definitely going to have to experience a leaning curve, but that's nothing compared to some mods for the game. The modding community for the game a very active, and there is something for everyone. From turning the game into straight up HALO, to smaller things for QOL like workable helmet lights or some prefabs for Editor or Zeus. Of course, some mods focus on realism to the max. Things like realistic starting procedures for F/A-18's or just mods for ambiance such as traffic and other things like that. Another thing to look at is the customization aspect in Arma. The virtual arsenal is a thing that you should first be introduced to in your first minutes on a Zeus multiplayer server, or your first few minutes trying to figure out hoe the Eden editor works. It allows complete customization of things from your weapons, clothes, and gear, all the way down to things like what you want in your gear when you start, like some extra ammo or a few grenades. You might want to watch out for the stamina system though. The more items you carry, the smaller the stamina bar gets. The stamina bar shows you how long you can sprint for, among other things. If you are loaded to the brim with items, you may be slowed to a walk, with no sprint bar. you would have to drop some of your items to get it back. Now here's the only reason that I don't like it. The DLCs are expensive and there are a lot of them. Sure, just don't get the DLC, but its not that simple. A lot of assets in Arma are locked by DLC content. Things from Jets and helicopters, all the way down to simple things such as clothes. It is possible to play Arma without said DLC content, but it is very locked down. If you really want to play Arma at its fullest, then you might want to purchase the DLCs. Other than that little bit, I love the game. It was a wonderful buy. If you are thinking of buying now thanks to my review, I would recommend waiting for a Christmas sale, or another sale. The game itself is worth a pretty penny, but I got it on sale for around thirty dollars. As a little heads-up, the game is set in 2035. That might sound like the content will be super futuristic, but it really isn't as futuristic as you would think. They put it in a semi-realistic perspective on how combat would be in the mid 2030s. Thats all for me, I hope that I shed some light on how the game is going to be for you. If it sounds like a good one, I hope that you would consider buying this game,  but if you don't, I won't hold it against you.

ARMA? ARMA IS LIFE. Honestly, I bought arma years before I actually was able to get into it. I tried the first time to learn on my own. I am decent at games. However, it was just too much at first, and I just kept dying. So, after spending hours trying to figure out how to get a drone to lift off the ground I gave up. Then years later a tactical buddy of mine that i play fps with told me to join him again only on arma. I am sooooo thankful i did. I dont ever need to play another game again. Seriously, if you are planning on getting this game and know nothing about it. please please trust me on this and find a group on discord or on google somewhere that play arma. thats where its at. you need to find someone who knows what he is doing. thats the only way. Anyone with over 400 hours in should be fine. They will be able to tell you what everything is and it will quickly become muscle memory. Seriously, that is the only way to learn this game. Theres too much going on to not get involved with the arma community. There are people from every country. You need to google the servers and find your group. they will teach you. There are countless groups everywhere for arma. Its a techs game. So, they spread themselves out over a whole bunch of gaming communication apps. Like discord. Just google them its easy and find someone mature ussually an admin of one of the servers to set you up to have someone show you the ropes. Its the most realistic military game to date. As far as simulators go. SO, you need to get involved with the community. Other than that advice. I have to say that arma is like real life. My options are endless because of the modding community connected to the game. I can create any scenario i want. I can play anything i want. But i had to really learn my character first. Being an advanced FPS in other games i knew the most important thing was learning how to make my character work. So really i spent about 300 hours perfecting that to really really get to know my character. And now im perfecting it. Another note. Make sure you try the old man scenario. Its a great way to get to know your character and the weapons and game mechanics since the scenario is free roam. If you dont have the apex dlc get it. also, if there is any dlc you dont have just get it. its worth it. The game is absoloutly amazing. But you need to follow my instructions or you can easily get overwhelmed and give up. Its critical to have someone who already knows the game a bit to help show you the ropes so you can start to learn on your own. even just a couple sessions with guys like that will be enough. alright. thanks for joining our community!

I have a lot of hours in this game, it is great. The base game is decent and a lot of fun can be had with it, but the real fun comes when you have all the mods and the big community. The community is certainly not as big as it used to be, but there are still plenty of friendly units that run missions and if you aren't into the PVE stuff you can do PVP or you can go play on Roleplay servers. There is just a lot to do. There are TONS of mods for the game and now there are Creator DLC's. Arma 3 While being pretty old now, 8 Years old to be specific. It's still relatively modern and keep up to speed with mods making it always a blast. Some hurdles with it is optimisation is not bad. But not great. Usually at least with not that many AI You can get 30-60 FPS Constantly depending on your specs. Some devices can dive as deep as 15 if they are a bad Laptop or have non-gaming spec's. Most gaming PC's can run about 100 AI v 100 AI When unmodded and be fine during the fight in most cases. But mods can really hinder performance but you can't really play without them as they improve the gameplay 10-fold. Mods should be noted, aren't like some other games where they add in MUST HAVE Features that for some reason, weren't added. Instead the mods branch out for example more realism with things like Ace, Then you got more mod's that have different settings and add in different faction's from different era's or games. It's like downloading a whole new game when you enable a few mods which is fantastic. Sadly performance can drop quite a bit if you aren't careful but it's pretty good at staying away from turning down right awful on the performance side of things with mods, Which some other thing's aren't able at doing. Speaking about performance surprisingly there are very few to no crashes during game play.. Don't let that fool you bug's still exist. But they aren't too bad. Unless if you don't like being flung into orbit as if it's Skyrim and a giant just hit you. Game play length wise it's pretty good. You got give or take maybe about 5 hour's of campaign from the dev's base-game without mods. Now Mod's can add technically, infinite amount of game play potential, not to mention multiplayer which has all sorts of game modes and the sort. So I'd say it's even worth full price to buy Arma 3. Although I wouldn't say waiting for a sale is a bad move or anything but you get your money's worth when you buy Arma 3. Now. I have to mention one.. Small problem for many. A Huge problem for some. The AI. It's a dreaded concoction, Ever thought AI in other games are bad? Wait till you get to Arma 3's AI. They are going to be so bad it's not even funny. But don't worry. Once you learn how to make AI Properly in the editor and use them properly? They get alot better. Add on mods? And they are just as good and sometimes better then player's. Anyway. Basically what I'm trying to say is.. If you somehow haven't bought Arma 3 Yet? Do yourself a favour and get it. I think you aren't going to regret it. Oh but be wary of the HUGE STORAGE SPACE it takes up. Like YIKES man.

Arma 3, I played it for a bit. The campaign is good, it really throws you into the situation and you don't expect a lot of things to happen or go downhill so fast. I would give examples but I don't want to spoil it for some. On the other hand, multiplayer servers are my problem. When I hop on an average multiplayer server, it's mostly people fucking around. There is no organizational structure, there is no solid purpose or understanding of the mission. The confusion it creates I do not appreciate. For example you get to the objective or fight mostly as an individual warrior, not a soldier like a cog in a war machine which is a military force. When you ask "What's the plan?" or "What are we doing?" you simply get the response "Killing the enemy" or something around the lines of that most of the time. This is common in most games, but the reason I stress this for Arma 3 is because of how much people claim the game to be realistic or like a military simulation, which is why I am disappointed. 

My second complaint is graphics, for a game released in 2013 that was a finished product this would be understandable, Arma 3 was released in 2013, but it's essentially not a finished product, the developers still release content for the game. With the lower quality graphics it makes it harder to enjoy the game and brings the feeling of immersion down by reminding you it's just a simulation. 

To conclude while the campaign was done good and enjoyable, the multiplayer experience did not deliver the hard core coordinated military force I expected and the graphics let me down in immersion. Squad, while still having it's own faults, trumps Arma 3 in the general unit experience.

[h1] Overview [/h1]
ArmA 3 is a highly realistic military simulation game. Note military simulation, in the sense that you can simulate conflicts and whatnot. This is not a military "simulator" as some would claim. It simply is not that realistic in some details to hold up to that term. 

[h1] Story [/h1]
Honestly pretty mediocre, the futuristic setting is a 50/50. It is evident that the developers went on vacation in Greece and just kinda decided to put it in the game and then made a half assed story to back it up. It's average, some like it and a lot of people don't. Luckily you can download lots of missions/stories/campaigns to fit yourself.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
Difficult, tactical and sometimes frustrating. But ultimately rewarding. Contrary to what many say, the AI is good. Playing singleplayer is definitely viable (thats what I did). The editor is easy to learn and you can set up nearly any kind of mission imaginable. Multiplayer is a hit and miss. Many servers run really poorly and lots of communities/groups are grown men pretending to be in the military. Very cringy. But you can find lots of groups that are chill and relaxed and do more than the usual US vs Taliban mission every single day. 

[h1] Graphics/Performance [/h1]
The game looks good for it's time and age. Even today it looks very up to date. Unfortunately this comes at a cost. This game runs poorly and maintaining 60 fps is a struggle. Some will say get a better PC, some will say try this try that. But honestly the game itself is poorly optimised. Some folks with worse PCs run with better FPS than the other way around. 

[h1] Community [/h1]
Great community with lots and lots of content. Mods for almost anything. This is where the game shines. WW2? There's a mod for that. Cold War? Yes. Pretty much any other conflict? Yep. This is definitely a sandbox. You can make it into whatever you want with some limitations.

[h1] Additional info [/h1]
None.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
I recommend this game. I enjoyed it and people who like tactical/simulation shooters with a sandbox will enjoy this.

While it might be a hard game to get into, when you do, it's a joy to play. There is a single player campaign, but the real show here for most people will probably be the multiplayer.

The thing is, getting into a multiplayer game and having fun might be a big chore when getting started, with many servers requiring specific mods or joining some clan to play, but it's possible to get into the game without any mods at all.

Two servers I've really liked and recommend for beginners are the 77th JSOC Invade and Annex, as well as CodeFourGaming's King of the Hill servers.

In addition, the huge modding scene and built-in Eden editor allow for hours of fun times just messing around offline, or even creating some serious missions for you to play in.

Good to keep in mind, that sometimes the game runs really poorly, even on medium range hardware, but other than that, it's quite a fun experience.

Recommend to anyone looking to get into milsims!

"So why are you giving a positive review" you ask?

Besides its quirky faults and bugs, this game is the ultimate epitome of the sandbox MilSim legacy of Bohemia Interactive. Not only Arma 3 gave rise to several game genres on its own, like MilSims (Squad/Post Scriptum), Battleroyale (PUBG with PUBG developer starting out as an Arma 3 multiplayer game modder), it also allowed unique customisation options. 

The vanilla game version offers you a Singleplayer campaign, Co/op missions, and multiplayer games/missions. You can either create, cooperate and multiplay scripted missions, permanent missions, co-op PVE and PVP missions. Everything you see on the map (and even under the water) is within the game zone; see those distant mountains? You can climb there to get a vantage point on the enemy or carelessly get sniped form there... whilst on foot, driving, flying and swimming, whilst also carrying a wide range of equipment.

And this is not even the best part of it yet:
Arma 3 is very mod and modder friendly, with developers releasing increasingly quality of life and user friendly updates, mod integration and semi-official, themed DLCs. After 7 years the modding community is still up and running.
Want to play as a WW1 trench fighter? a WH40K space marine? a WW3 panzer commander in the 80s? or even go go-karting dressed as My Little Pony? There is possibly a plethora of mods for those, making the sandbox experience unique, and giving the players unlimited creative freedom to create, share and play their own missions/content.

Also has a decent multiplayer community, ranging from retired army corporals shouting in military jargon to "warcrimes go brrr"-toxicity players, but despite all the flaws i counted, this is one of the games i enjoy playing the most, both SP and MP and has a unique feel.

I will explain the performance I am getting.  Game is good, yes, but performance is the ugly head which never goes from view.  If you like the game you will need to suffer this.  

I have played this for longer than 30 hours, trust me and I have all the dlc and I do like this game but they seriously need to improve its performance when they get the new engine up and going, if not for the next game fine, but for this one as well.  People legitimately need an extra 40% for this engine if they are to have the goodwill I believe of the next title should that title come.  This game engine is in huge need of a modern core-update.  Just a little, until then beware because this is a good game which will frustrate you with performance, and indeed, in general because while not tedious it is complex to get going at full speed/goodness in terms of full gameplay.

Performance setting:  What I do for my ryzen and graphics is I have heaps of mods, but with 3700x with ryzen master setting of auto overclock - ryzen balanced power plan installed via amd website chipset drivers on a aorus ultra 570  and an OPEN-sided case (lol yes for air flow and I blow it out now and then, its relatively dust free), and CPP states switched on in BIOS and switch-state 2 as stated in bios, meaning it uses its fast switching, so we know its doing as best it can plus it looks at which is the preffered fastest core, and with ryzen master on a second monitor I can check it all


 I use the distance at 10k on livonia and object at 6400 and it seems to usually hold high fps, at 60-70.  But in lots of action is can sink.  I drop the anti aliasing to 2x and then have other settings on as game auto's to, which is mostly high.  Its cpu limited not GPU.  

I do not use any parameters because with ryzen you do not want to go over and tax anything and the default is just fine for me.  

So its smooth and all that but I wish it remained so, the engine as you can imagine is taxing in the modern day multi cpu's.

I do rate the game highly.  But the performance in 2021 is a sufferance.  It is beautiful though and the nam jungle maps especially as well as several others, but many overall, just the several top tier such as the map from Prairie fire are great.  But the maps alone is a reason to get this, all official maps are good, and plenty of mods.

Even if you do not mod you will like this game should you be able to suffer the performance.  

I was also speaking about single player - in multiplayer, your 70 will become 35 real fast, and sometimes less in heavy moments.  Like down to 16.  This is why they must give this game a little love with the game engine.  Its too expensive othewise in terms of value.  I am trying to be fair, and actually to be fair the dynamic recon and dynamic combat ops mods in the workshop and dynamic civil war mod missions in the game, and normal missions make the game good.  

Remember this game is from 2013 iirc.  That engine is the major blight.  Its not a big company, but for a product can only hope it improves.  In the meantime you will suffer-enjoy it.  You should buy it and hope the bone is thrown toward you one day

Do not be fooled, fellow gamers. This is not a shooter. This isn't even milsim. This is straight-up, unadulterated horror. The intense spastic sensation of your heart being ripped out of your chest after rounding a corner only to be greeted by a full-on 50mm autocannon barrage from an AI tank you thought you had snuck around is irreplicable. Not even the most aggressive of horror games such as Dead Space, Resident Evil, or Twitter are capable of instilling the same quantity of fear into your fragile soul as you learn the painful lesson that bullets. freaking. hurt.

The feeling of being watched by an unseen predator, the constant looming threat of landmines hidden cheekily under the dead floor of rotting pine nettles, the agony of forgetting to quicksave in the campaign before you chucked a grenade that bounced back inside your house. All of these contribute to the obscenely terrifying reality of Arma 3. Real life is less scary than this simulator when the difficulty's cranked up to eleven.

But for real tho. Good game. Very fun. Only played single player 'cause am lonely. The bots have the combined senses of the Predator and intelligence of a gnat. Buy when on sale, DLC is a bit overpriced. Experience the true horror of modern armed conflict in any spine-contorting manner you can think of. Trust me when it comes to the contorted spines. This is the single greatest FPS in existence today. The variety of combat ability is amazing. In one mission you could be dropped off at sea, travel inland, underwater as a combat scuba diver (which could involve underwater combat if enemy divers spot you), take out the beach guard, steal a tank to drive half way across the map destroying enemy vehicles, weapons and buildings then abandoning the tank when it runs out of fuel and ammo. Then you climb a mountain to avoid enemy lines, snipe the enemy general from 1500m away in the middle of a thunderstorm that's making your bullets drift waaay off course. Now the fog is coming in, visibility is down to just a few feet but you have your thermal vision googles, a compass and a sat nav to help you navigate the 30 miles to the exfil point. But on the way you run into a combat patrol which splits you up from the rest of your team. So you make your way to the secondary exfil point but on the way you discover an attack helicopter which you're able to steal and fly to the second exfil but your team members are under attack by an armoured convoy so you hover behind a hill 2 miles away and engage the armour with your heat seeking missiles and cannon before moving in and finishing the enemy off with your unguided missiles. Just as your team mates relax an enemy jet shows up and damages your tail rotor causing you to spin wildly out of control. You manage to bail out and safely parachute to the ground where you search the enemy supplies for anti aircraft weaponry of which you find numerous different types from RPG's to Stingers, there's even an auto guided, auto targeting long range missile system near by but it has no ammo and there are no ammo trucks near by or transport trucks that can pick up the ammo container and move it to the AA system so you have to take out the jet manually. The first few shots are easily dodge with excellent flying manuevers and flares but finally a well timed rocket, fired at the jet's nose while it's diving for an attack run, completely destroys the jet and pilot. You steal an undamaged jeep and exfil with your team, mission completed. Take all of those elements online and combine them with Arma's sandbox design and you can find millions of missions, campaigns, mods, game modes and other addons that take a base game that's an easy 100/100 and turns it into a 1000/100 level of fun.

In short I love this game, but you'll be hard pressed to find an Arma player who doesn't, it does have a few bugs, the AI pathfinding can be a bit annoying and vehicle physics isn't perfect but the combat physics are incredible. The issues just pop up every now and then but in all honesty they just add a level of natural dynamic problems that can upset your mission and make it more difficult which just adds to the fun. Like yeah a tank couldn't flip over onto it's roof after hitting a kerb but accidents have happened where tanks have mounted berms and flipped, if you think of the bugs as being natural errors like that, it doesn't take away from the fun of the game, it adds to it.

Arma 3 is one of those games that rides a very thin line in the mainstream gaming scene without a safety net I believe, some players love it and others don't have the patience for it and it's cool. Arma 3 and the ArmA series in general is all about giving players the ultimate form of freedom, from large scale warfare to complete mod support to a mission editor with an entire open map spanning kilometers for you to just pour your creativity into. But where Arma 3 really shines is when it brings all those things together and creates something that distinguishes itself from the rest of the gaming scene, the game doesn't restrict you, it's all about how far you can go.

This game is probably the most difficult, frustrating, head banging game I have ever played. It is also probably the most rewarding, fun, and diverse game that I have ever played. I wanted a game that made me think, I wanted freedom to execute my missions the way I wanted to, and I wanted a true sim. This game is a very unique beast. On the surface, you have what appears to be a tactical MILSIM game with both 1st and 3rd person perspectives that has a heavy focus on realism. That isn't untrue at all, but Arma 3 is so, so much more than that at the same time. The term 'military sandbox' is what the devs call it these days and I think that works best, because within a certain scope.. Arma 3 is sort of whatever the hell you want it to be. If you want to go full sweaty tryhard MILSIM tacticool badass with a group of your friends and insist you all call each other by rank and pretend it's real life, Arma 3 can give you that. If you want to join Life / RP servers and burn down opium fields while getting into shootouts with the cops, Arma 3 can give you that. If you want a specific experience of a wartime conflict from a certain era (WW2, Cold War, Vietnam, etc) outside of the modern one, Arma 3 can give you that. If you want to sit around in the editor for hundreds of hours making your own missions, Arma 3 can give you that. If you want a totally solo experience, Arma 3 can give you that. If you never intend to touch the single player content and focus only on MP, Arma 3 can give you that.

I could go on.. and on. Arma 3 has damned near limitless possibilities. Between all the DLC and mods, there's so much you can cram into this game. I love it, love it to death. One of my all time favorite games, however.. it's not something I would recommend to just anyone. You need to be a particular type of gamer to get into this game, as freeform as your experience can be.. it's still targeted at certain audiences over others. I recommend doing some research and watching gameplay.. and if at that point you seem into the idea, buy it and all the DLC and never look back. You won't regret it.

First thing is first, do you want to know what was the last military game I played? Yes? Well it was Ghost Recon for the PS2. Yes, I played for an hour or two Counter Strike, but that doesn't even count. That ain't military in my book. Any who, as I was saying, I haven't touched a military game since the PS2 days. I decided to purchase this game, and guess what? Is hard as hell. This is a Dark Souls military game. Yes, you will die a lot. If you're expecting a crazy first person shooter in where you can shoot everybody, jump, roll, explode everything in your path and feel immortal, then you're out of luck. I tried playing this game as if I was playing any other first person shooter and I died in less than 10 seconds. I got better at this game after 2 hours. I died over 15 times the first hour. Either I wasnt hiding good enough, didn't drop quick enough, got injured and now I am slow as a turtle and I can barely do anything, etc .. this is a simulator. A good one, more like a great one. The use of common sense clicks to you while playing this game. Once you come to your senses, and see this game as a simulator, you'll end up getting good at it. The game play is very very slow paced. The graphics, the environment, and the realism is very top notch. This game runs pretty smooth on my end (56 to 60fps) very playable and enjoyable. But yes, this game will give your GPU quite a beating. 

Once again, this is a simulator, not Doom or your typical boring Call of Duty nonsense. In this game every move, strategy and bullet counts. 

I recommend this game, just be patience and don't get crazy. And make sure you can run this game.

Wonderful game, but it has its flaws.
Pros:
[list]
    [*]Amazing singleplayer feel. Usually, with these milsim games multiplayer gives it the taste. But i find myself spending most of my time on the editor with tons of mods such as ACE, CUP etc.
    [*]Diverse modding community. You've got everything from semi-realistic healing (tourniques, field dressing, etc.)[ACE mod] to zombies! Yes, zombies.
    [*]Vehicles. You've gotta love them. You want to commit warcrimes with a UAV? Gun down enemy troops in your A10? Spy on your neighbors with the drones? You've got it.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
    [*]Steep learning curve. I can't even describe how steep. I *call myself* a fast learner, took me 30h to say that I could understand the basics. Here's my main tips: If you're confused, use the "industry standard" control scheme and use the 4th and 5th mouse buttons for zoom in and out. Also, zooming in ‚â† aiming downsights. You'll get used to it, and frankly, grow to like it. Also, don't play KOTH at the start. Play COOP.
    [*]Rip GPU. No kidding. It'll eat your GTX1660Ti whatever, and you'll hardly get 50-60fps with that on *singleplayer*. The KOTH maps? Oh yeah, 20-30 fps.
    [*]Get some friends. No really, you'll need them. Although it's very, very fun in singleplayer which I spend most of my titme in, its not ARMA without friends.
[/list]
Conclusion: Are you determined? More importantly, can your computer (or your used-to-ness to low fps) handle it? Go for it. If you're a play-and-dump person with no determination, it'll be hard, and it'll end on you rage quitting, and, in turn, refunding.

*Fair Warning: EXTREMELY addicting.*

This military simulator has great modding capabilities, which create never ending fun.

Personally, i use Arma for dedicated server hosting, which lets me delve into mission creating with the zeus feature.

The Zeus feature adds depth to this game because it lets you dynamically play around what's already given to you in the mission for your own enjoyment.

As for the community, the workshop showcases work still being created despite this game being quite dated.
This means that it is hard to run out of stuff to do in Arma, as there is always something to try.

Some negatives include the fact that this game isn't well optimised and you would need a beefy rig if you wanted to enjoy this game to its fullest capabilities.

Also the AI sometimes have unfair advantages over areas with high vegetation.

The AI can also be finicky to handle with Zeus (example being: getting an AI to go to a gunfight when they feel 'endangered' - instead they would stay prone).

Overall, the player experience is still very fine and it would be cool if other open world war games would consider having a Zeus-like feature or large-scale AI battles.

Oh arma 

A development studio with a tumultuous history but able to produce somewhat clunky somewhat dated and so many bugs it's a feature massive scale military simulators.

And it's still probably the most unique genre among gaming ever others have tried but just couldn't quite match the easy to learn impossible to master formula of Arma.

This is definitely a game you're going to get out of it exactly what you put into it in an odd way nobody cares about the gameplay it's just a method of delivery for the experiences, and they are incredible.

Arma is the sandbox that allows you to be anything from a struggling merchant just trying to get by, to a veteran special forces operative dodging patrols directed by a human intelligence or done by humans themselves.

The community is the thing that can make or break your experience if you think you can just install some mods pick up and play in single player you're going to be entertained for a while but thousands of hours can be found in the wildly wildly diverse modded multiplayer community. 

And with the resurgence of the previously under appreciated Zeus mode It generates an experience that can only be described as "DnD Dungeon Master is the opposition force in a massive scale military shooter with a backbreaking commitment to realism" or 40k or halo or mass effect or the napoleonic wars...

You're starting to see the pattern

Now for some of the drawbacks the kind of 2035 semi futuristic setting of the vanilla assets isn't terribly appreciated by the majority of the community so mods are almost a requirement to play, performance demands are pretty substantial but significantly lessened by the performance of modern hardware, Expect to dedicate 200GB for this game on preferably a SSD or M2 drive to help cut down on some of the admittedly painfully long load times while modded.

Still that being said if you are looking for experiences you can't find anywhere else and have been sleeping under a rock for the past 4 years at 20 bucks you have nothing to lose.

Review 2021 
  
   Arma 3 is still hands down one of the best Mil-sim on the market even after 7 years since its release! No game like this can offer the replay-ability thanks to the community which is still very active and detail in realism as Arma 3 does. You want a futuristic warfare, modern warfare, maybe WWII or even WWI, heck I've even seen some mods going far back to the FIFTEENTH HUNDREDS for crying out loud this game has it. I highly recommend playing with a microphone and with the boys and not to mention a beefy PC. Yet despite this game being 7 YEARS OLD and having a high-end PC(specs at the end) it runs like absolute trash. 

   The optimization of this game is absolutely abysmal to say the least, and its borderline unplayable at times on multiplayer. To give you and idea, if you walk into a empty town or even a city, expect your FPS below 40! Surprisingly no matter what graphic settings I have it to, my FPS remains the same(especially on multiplayer). I've spent hours trying to optimize the game manual however the changes made little to no difference. The base game is pretty bland and generic at best but with a bunch of mods the community has created, that is what breaths the life into this game and gives the player a huge amount of re-play value which is why I still play this game to this day.

  In all, despite the horrendous performance and outdated graphics I still am recommend Arma 3 which to me should speak volumes for a game this old and for its problems. I want to give a huge thank you to all the community and especially the mod creators out there for carrying this game long past its life expectancy and giving us 'endless' content to the players free of charge.

Arma III...

At first I was hesitant, Arma III had been sitting in my library for quite some time unplayed. Finally, one day I decided to give it an honest shot.

And boy did I enjoy it.

Not only does ARMA III offer a nice and detailed campaign, but it's near-limitless multiplayer possibilities can make a fun time for your friends, and if you decide to deep-dive into the Eden Editor, you can craft your own missions for yourself and AI or your friends, and even the Arma community as a whole. While somewhat difficult to understand, the Eden Editor is very thorough and provides a lot of avenues for making different missions. The Steam Workshop provides hours of free custom content, and the DLC can provide even more, for a penny or two of course. 

The controls of Arma can be complex to a newcomer, however with a little practice you can manipulate them quite well. Overall, Arma provides a fun yet realistic military simulation if you really wanna feel like a SOLDIER.

Campaign is solid if you want realism and not your typical run and gun action and has a decent amount of singleplayer content to boot. A incredible sandox/creation toolset with great mod support to allow you to go nuts creating all kinds of military scenarios and such. The online community at this point and time is doing amazing as well with tons of public and private servers and one of the largest communities to exist outside of the game.

The only major drawbacks are that it can be a bit of a headache to learn how to use the creator at first without online help, the game can feel more then a little dated with some of its animations, textures and even voicelines, a lot of additional game play content has been made paid DLC with varying degrees of quality and lastly the game does contain its fair share of minor bugs but nothing so far that's game breaking.

In my entire steam library, this game purchase is the one I regret the most. I've played 40 hours, the last time I played it was in 2018. This should give you an idea of how boring this game is.

There is a campaign that can't keep my interest for long. I restarted it every time I started the game up because I forgot how everything works and I lost track. Story isn't interesting at all. The online experience isn't much different. It feels like there is nothing to do and there is no point of starting up the game and playing with other players. The only reason I wanted to play this game is because I wanted to do some role-playing with my friends, but boy did that backfire. No one found the game interesting enough to keep playing.

Game doesn't run too well on a mid-range system. As far as I could remember I couldn't reach a stable 60fps on low settings with high view distance, which puts you at a disadvantage if you don't leave it at high. For low-end systems, you'll have to put everything at the lowest settings to achieve a somewhat playable frame-rate.

You spend so much money on a game with no goal. That being said this is my opinion, I couldn't find anything interesting to keep investing time into this game. If you somehow find something to do that you know you would invest a lot of time in, then I'd say give the game a shot. For me however, it's a no.

imagine growing too old for online games because everyone under a certain age was raised on youtube reaction channels and they think that over-reaction and saying every thought you ever had out loud on a global channel across 100 players is how you have to play every game, including tactical shooters.

now, imagine a game that isn't a game, but a military simulator targeted to veterans and adults who appreciate complex systems for serious tactical fun; an ascension to leave the FPS twitch shooters and mature into a world that requires patience, and doesn't hold you hand. 

Now, make that milsim so clunky that modders have to fix it, and those modders get a tad carried away over time. Over the past decade They literally give birth to the hardcore survival genre (DayZ mod),  the fortnite genre (battle royal mod), and probably the forerunner of online City heist role play games (Altis Life). 

Because of these mods popularity online with streamers, the kids couldn't get enough youtube content. Developers with more resources and vision than Bohemia Interactive had seen these metrics, and raced to make better copies of these mods that are now milti-billion dollar franchises.

Have you imagined all that? I'm not done. Now, send all the serious tactical nerds to isolated milsim clans hidden behind passwords, private servers, miles of red tape drama, and 100gb of ever-changing mod packs, and replace all the cool streamers that have long since left to other games with the kids who grew up watching it: The weird ROTC kid with acute ASD whom (after waiting an hour for a mission to finally make contact) wants to PASSIONATELY argue with you over the finer points of why he is the supreme expert on [ military subject] in the middle of a firefight, then asks how to toggle walk/run while wrapping a helicopter around a power line. 

did you imagine all that? now Imagine me deleting it and reinstalling it at least once a year, and coming back again and again to chase that dragon of what potentially could be were it not for a core community of man-children who learn to script exploding chickens raining from the sky BEFORE they ever learn how to aim a rifle. There is a guy here who has been grifting servers with scripts for almost 9 years straight. never been dealt with by Bohemia. and has to be pushing age 30 by now, but has not yet evolved from his favorite childhood pastime.

got the picture? Good! then i saved you the experience of Arma3 in 2021. the golden age is over. it's best you move along.

Arma is, and I have full confidence to say, one of the best, most realistic military simulators I have played and has yet to be beaten. Everything you would expect, realistic weapons, bullet drop, fucking massive maps (nothing like I've ever seen), sanbox, mission creator, EXCELLENT community and the people are amazing but very repetitive gameplay loop, there's no real gameplay loop, so it's mostly sandbox. Unless you go onto a server and play with people. I have never had such a positive experience with any other shooter but I personally ended up leaving my unit and everything fell apart because I got bored super quick. You can get a mod called Dynamic Recon Operations which makes for some fun-ish games. Realistic map reading, it uses your entire keyboard, which can be either a great or awful thing. Jets and other flying vehicles have never been harder to fly if you don't know what you're doing, which is a good thing. Because the community mostly has dedicated crew and assigns certain people to certain roles which is amazing. This game is nothing without it's community, and to be honest, if you're looking to play single player, enjoy dying to a bot that is calculated to be better than the worlds best sharpshooters regardless of difficulty over and over. There are mods that help the issue, but never have fixed it. If you're still reading, I suggest getting a few things first. Remove sprint (I think it's called), ACEX (and associated mods) RHSF (or something like that), GRSF (again, something like that). inventory is practically a gauge that says how much you can fill to a certain point regardless of item (which I find both stupid and genius), but I'm sure if you want a tarkov inventory space you can get one.One last thing, you will have to purchase a few DLC but they don't cost much. And that's about it.
