Just remember, regardless of the marketing, this is more a game, not a simulation, and Bohemian Interactive appears unlikely to ever really improve the core engine, remove most of the bugs, or add all the little obvious things everyone thinks of and agrees they should.  This includes frequent crashes and stuff that newer first-person shooters are using like not only integrated VR but, you know, the ability to look strait up or strait down first-person, move around in an natural manner over obstacles, or manipulate objects in the environment or the environment itself. 

For instance, the scope zeroing changes from rifle to rifle, as if the scopes' knobs magically change.  Arma 3 is also missing features that literally every other, not only combat but non-combat, flight sim EVER has had, too, and even Ace Combat series has.  It's all strange because BI miraculously licensed a high-end helo flight model from RT Dynamics called GenHeli600, and while the RT documentation clearly indicates RT knows what they're talking about, Bohemian Interactive clearly does not, calling the Auto Trim, for instance, a "difficulty setting", which it is not.  It's an actual AFCS intermediary for use with digital deflection or pressure joysticks rather than long-pole cyclics with their own mechanical trimmers or damping.  Heck, there's no reason for BI to be including the simple helo flight model anymore.  

This isn't even getting into the additional detailed fixes and nuanced features they also should have thought of but apparently didn't, either.  I've had this only a week and I have a list of like two dozen things already that aren't even the bugs, and when I bring some of this up with others in multiplayer, they often go, "Yeah, I noticed that too, and BI knows about that.  They'll never (change that, add this, or do that)."  

Speaking of documentation, BI wants you to either pay for their Field Manual or buy the more expensive versions of Arma 3 to get it.  I have it and I can tell you it's sparse and just some little clickable menu of cursory info, like that aforementioned part is literally two short sentences.  None of the manual is thorough.  It's laughable.  I found people all over the internet looking for a long printable manual in PDF, and there isn't even enough content to put in a pamphlet.  

What does BI seem interested in doing with their time?  Apparently releasing new vehicles, uniforms, guns and sometimes just in a new color in packs of like 4 or 5 and wanting you to pay 10 bucks for it in an additional DLC.  If you accidentally equip some of that gear in multiplayer that you don't 'own', BI will shut your multiplayer session down in a few minutes during your brief instance of rare, glitch-free gameplay.  

Arma 3's controls configuration is also literally the weirdest, most awkward I've ever seen, and I've seen many, with each line of keypress or button assignment being the same as those for an axis, such that certain axis will turn into binary on/off or not have their full range and there's no way to predict which it will be.  It's just a bunch of trial and error and you have to make due with what you can configure.  You don't even get one axis per function, and instead it's broken up into positive and negative movements.  Totally bizarre.

Arma 3 is fun and addictive, far more than the eventually monotonous and boring Elite Dangerous that I also bought, but Arma 3 is not a simulation and not particularly polished or thorough.  BI has clearly been 'sitting on their laurels' for a very long time raking in the money for little effort.  Someone like DCS could start including infantry stuff and basically easily destroy BI's market share overnight.  I'm not saying that's definitely going to happen, so maybe this is as good as we'll get.

Edit: 

It can be made a bit more simmy with mods, of which there are thousands of serious ones, but it's worth pointing out that your already precarious stability is going to probably get worse with each additional mod.  As of right now, I have a hundred actively in-use.  My search for stability is still ongoing.  None of these mods substantially improve the aircraft weapon systems or sensor implementations, unfortunately, which are just plain universally goofy -- how and when you can employ weapons is worse than Gunship! and there isn't even a Field of Regard box in any of the EO/FLIRs.  So, for instance, there's no way to tell which way your turret is pointed in relation to the rest of the aircraft when you're heads-down.

Nonetheless, I have expanded from the Apex Bundle to the Ultimate Edition.  You should also know that the install size of the official entire Arma 3 is about 42GB, but with the big add on 'mod' map collections or the optional third-party DLCs that size will balloon.  

Lastly, during multiplayer you should be aware there are hackers cheating even with BattlEye requirements, so don't be surprised if you see people walk through walls, withstand multiple direct hits from rockets, seem to be omnipotent, or you get suddenly booted when you become too persistent and try too hard.  Some of them REALLY like to 'win'.  This isn't getting into the impatient intoxicated people online, the people who are just trolls that pose as the other side, or the random neo-Nazi orator that you can always mute.  Remember the single player experience is available and not bad (ignoring the stability issues for a moment), especially user-created ones and free mission generators.

Played since Operation Arrowhead during Arma 2. Improvement over A2:OA in every way it feels like. I run the game with a load of mods (which the community is good at). Campaign is fun for a while but does start to grind after a while (DLC campaigns are slightly better especially Prairie Fire). This game excels at light simulation for active warzones. Mostly focus on PvE though as the game is focused mostly on fighting AI as the system is not refined enough for most PVP situations. There are PVP servers but most clans and mil-sims run Zeus (player creating a story using AI with the players interacting with said story). I've logged an ungodly amount of hours on this and the other Armas on other accounts long lost. If your into light scifi, WW2, Vietnam, modern warfare...odds are there are mods for you out there. Arma is ok standalone but the Mods are what makes this game great. DLC can get you there but I don't recommend many of them since if you play with a clan they typically don't expect you to have them (most assets are mods so you don't need to bother with many DLCs except maybe PF and Apex.)

Today I noticed that I have never written  a review for ARMA 3, and boy was that odd. On record it says I have 2,732.8 hours of gameplay. Now, All of that  was years ago, and I barely get in these days, though I wish to. For me there is no real reviewing of ARMA 3. Its a simple expression about what this "Tool" meant to me. This "Tool" and that is where its value is, was in what it made possible for me to do with others. "Social" and "Tactical value" is immense when you use it for that reason. Sandbox is the most accurate term. You have "play things" that are "Military" and you have "Creative tools" you have 'Editing tools" and you have a "Modding Community" that are simply MAJESTIC. So, what you get out of using this Military Simulator tool Set called ARMA 3, is what you try to get out of it. You will succeed to get what you try to get. Over the years, one would say, it has never been truly optimized, even for high end PCs, which I have always played with. there is plenty to say about the build and the Engine used, it being outdated or this and that. However, with the ARMA experience I had, which was a lot, none of that got in the way. 

What is amazing is that there is no ARMA 4 in sight. Perhaps this is because ARMA 3, is still alive, and an amazing tool for so many to use. If this team, who built ARMA 3, had been in years of development since 2013, on an ARMA 4, and implemented work done by moderrs, making some mods, standard like ACE and so on, that product would be the greatest MILSIM one could get their hands on. ARMA 3 is the greatest MILISM experience, if one seeks out making it so, or joining with others who do so. A great deal of time I spent in ARMA was creating, and Game mastering, offering others the experience of unconventional warfare. I am not conventional, and I myself do not enjoy dressing up in Kit, and running around doing the cycle of soldiering. I did not enjoy that in real life, and so, it is not what I look for in ARMA. Instead, I was looking for Guerrilla small unit themed action, and where I could not find it, I was able to create it, and that, was grand, and those hours listed as play for me, were some of the best hours experienced with others, where I have "Friends" to this day, that were acquired through ARMA even though no longer active.  I do not game much. So that number says a lot. I have a strong preference for SIM, and Cooperation, and NOTHING, compared for me, to that of what ARMA made possible in this area. So much, I am here looking at ARMA and installing it today, because, I want to see what I can get out of it some more, after all these years. I would say for me, and many, ARMA is not just one more of those games in our library. ARMA is community, and I do not say this loosely.

As I recently released my final ArmA 3 workshop mission I realised that I never have given ArmA 3 game a Steam review so now might be good time as any.

The ArmA 3 is a very openly struct military simulator where players can do/ have many kinds of gameplay experiences from regular rifleman perspective who witnesses betrayal of their ally faction or simple platformer experience (yes someone has actually done that). https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1281184230 The learning curve is quite high when compared to other military shooter-games on market, but that‚Äôs because there are so many things player can control/ guide during a mission.
The biggest selling point (at least for those who like to make missions for people to play) is 3D editor which works well. What doesn‚Äôt work as well is Ai as it feels sometimes way dumber than for example Far Cry 2 that was released five (5) years before. Of course, in FC2 enemy Ai only focuses on infantry, turret, and ground vehicle activity but ArmA 3 Ai is something that prevents it to be overwhelmingly positive during play-troughs and mission-editing.

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
ArmA 3 is made with heavy focus on open database which allows everyone to create many things and play many things. If Ai that can get you frustrate on time to time is too much for you, I can‚Äôt recommend this game but for everyone else I recommend grabbing the game and it‚Äôs DLCs at least on sale.

Arma 3 is a brilliant military simulation game, with a huge focus on teamwork and coordination to achieve victory in battle. It places you right into the depths of all-out warfare, something which has yet to be achieved by any other game on the market. Arma 3 is still extremely unique in this respect, allowing the player to carry out whatever operation they so choose. Want to go behind enemy lines with a small group of elite troops? How about flying a CAS attack helicopter? It's your war, your choice.
  
As great as this sounds, there are two issues that really let the game down. The base game content, and the game engine. The base game content is lacklustre, leaving much to be desired. Uniforms, vehicles, and weapons feel mundane in comparison to the custom assets available on the workshop, which is why many servers/players decide to use the wonderful selection of workshop content to spice things up. It feels wrong to have to add 15+ mods to the game just to make it worth playing, especially when the DLC content doesn't resolve this issue either. Side note: Apex best DLC.
 
The game engine. Oh boy, where do we start? Tanks and other vehicles randomly flip over or fly into the distance, colliding with other vehicles will result in the second coming of Jesus, dropped weapons will freeze you in place if you walk over them, corpses weigh 50 tons, back-blast pressure will wipe out an entire army, shot down aircraft bounce back into the air, rockets travel at 2 mph or Mach 1, and don't even think about towing a vehicle. Ever. Arma 3 was designed on the worst engine of all time. It can ruin operations, but also make for some hilarious, unpredictable moments. It's just something you have to learn to work around.
 
Placing these issues aside, Arma 3 is fantastic fun. The graphics still look amazing, it has amazing mod support, dedicated servers full of enthusiastic people, and huge maps full of possibilities. You can even make your own operations for friends to play on. It truly is the best military simulation game available on the market. For DLCs, I recommend Apex and Jets. Zues and Malden come free with with the base game. Enjoy!

Arma 3 is a masterpiece. This does not mean there are not mistakes, as there are many, many mistakes. But a masterpiece does not have to be perfect, it just has to be beautiful.

Arma 3 is my favorite game to play with friends. There are so many things in this game, only vastly improved through mods. Zeus is one of the best additional modes to any video game ever, in my opinion. The way my friends and I play Arma 3 is like a Mil-sim game of D&D. There's a story, characters, progression, continuity, and this only adds to the fun. The DLC are pretty much necessary for Vanilla or Vanilla+ games, but otherwise you'll probably not need them. The only gripe with this game I have is the fact that you need to use teamspeak in order to use the Taskforce Radio mod, but that's not especially the fault of the game, I just wish it used directional voice chat like DayZ does. The fact the game does not come with a directional voice chat, however, IS the fault of the game, and it's a major one. Luckily mods fix this.

This game, especially while on sale for $7.49, is a must-buy for serious or semi-serious multiplayer narrative games, a must-buy for enclosed PvP or PvE mil-sim experiences, and a must-buy for creative level designing. There's so much more to this game than the marketing allows to be seen. I recommend this game completely.

Arma's base game is very good at what it does, it's a combat simulator.  But that isn't where the value lies, that honour goes to the community.  I have played this game on and off for a little while now, and from my experience, the best times I've had is finding a group of players that a similar minded then pushing the Arma engine to the limit.  
Bohemia have done an excellent job at giving you a "blank canvas", but each and every community brings a little more.  Arma is one of those games that whatever you, the player wants, has.  
There are communities that are full-on sim, to others that are PvE only.  Whatever your tastes there is a community out there for you, If you want a hardcore sim where you have to go through basic training just to be a pilot or medic; Arma has got you covered, or maybe a fully modded zombie horde base building experience is what you're craving, perhaps even a full on role playing game where you have to get a regular 9-5 job gets your blood pumping; you guessed it, Arma and it's community has it.  
This game is totally worth sinking your hard earned cash and free time into.  I've just downloaded Arma again, it's time for me to sink another couple of hours into.

Aside from the various 'features' of Arma, I strongly recommend it. Make no mistake, it is not a game (yes it's a game- not a simulator) for those who will not invest time into it. If you are willing to learn the intricacies of advanced marksmanship, ACE or Kat Medical or how to start up a MH-60 Blackhawk that is so close to the real thing with individual startup and shutdown sequences carried out by interacting with the cockpit, then this game is definitely for you. If you're not then don't bother. I also strongly recommend joining a Milsim unit (you can find one through Steam Community or any Arma discord server) as they will teach you the ways of the game and you'll make some great friends along the way. At just over 1k hours sunk into the game at the time of writing, although I know there are people with way more hours than me, I am still not bored of the game and I'm still finding new things- whether bugs/features/equipment/mods/videos/screenshots/locations/tricks/gamemodes/servers- every day. 
I hope this helps and thank you for your time.

This game is a kind of game that is incredibly rare these days. It certainly is a lot harder to get into for first time players, but once you get past the learning curve, this game has limitless potential. Aside from a compelling main campaign story with some eerie parallels to real world events, this game offers a limitless variety of multiplayer modes that allow you to play this game however you want to play it, and if there isn't something you were looking for in this game, Arma 3 gives you the tools to make it yourself if you so desire. There is an endless sea of community-made content with some outstanding mods such as ACE, CUP, Unsung, Iron Front, There Is Only War, etc. that completely change the gameplay experience. Despite releasing back in 2013, this game is still going very strong, and will remain that way for a long time to come. This is the sort of thing PC games were meant to be, the ability to craft your own experience backed up by an extensive library of both official and unofficial assets, and is set to have a long lifespan that can continue long beyond what even their own developers anticipated.

USAF Mod - Absolutely amazing mod around the USAF - several aircraft with EXTREME fidelity cockpits.
CUP - Community Upgrade Project - Amazing weapons and other items that will improve your gameplay drastically
NiArms - INCREDIBLE but big weapons pack (the all in one especially) but VERY worthwhile, super high fidelity awesome handling weapons.

Overall the game is a little hard to learn but is SUPER satisfying to play especially with friends, highly recommend this.

Right before i get started - I was a massive fan of the Arma series and have been for 10+ years, it is the reason i bought my first gaming PC.

311 days ago i was Developer banned from Arma 3. The day before i received this ban i had decided to download arma after months away from it. I downloaded the game, it remembered all my mods, downloaded them then i fired the game up.

Do you lads feel out of sorts some times and you sit looking at you vast steam library wondering what to play. Its kinda like choosing a film on Netflix, before you know it times up and you cant be bothered. It was like that. I sat in the in game menu for one minute (screen shot to prove it) before deciding not to play. I exited the game, steam and shut down my PC. 

The following day i decided i was going to fully get back into it. I loaded up my computer. Steam automatically opened but this time with a message. You have been banned from the following games (ARMA 3).

It stated i was banned by the developer. I immediately thought why the hell was i banned. I contacted BI within ten minutes. The response was the same as it remains today. 'we do not deal with bans, battleye do. Please contact battleye if you need support with a ban.' 

BUT YOU DO DEAL WITH BANS - THIS IS A DEV BAN NOT A BE BAN????

I spent the last 10 months contacting BE who eventually responded to tell me that they did not ban me nor did they find anything on my PC that was suspicious to them at the time of my ban. They informed my my logs were 'spotless'

I swung my attention back around to BI. I contacted them the other day. A chap called Dominik responded saying the ban was a battleye ban not a DEV ban.  I have since sent him images of my ban stating it was a DEV ban, steams explanation of a DEV BAN which states a developer informs valve of an account that is suspicious and valve ban them. I have sent images of my conversation with BE and proof that in the two weeks before my ban i had one minute of game time which was spent in the menu. 

The emails have fallen of deaf ears.....No response from Dominik. 

I am absolutely heart broken that from the past 10 months i have been unable to play with my friends and it looks like this situation is not going to change. I am disgusted as the lack of acknowledgement and willingness to support and resolve this from BI. 

I have so many fond memories in Arma 2, OH & 3 but it looks like this is the end of the road for me. I will miss the random chats in game, the communities i was part of and the battles of the field. 

You never know, if you guys blow this up they might just let me back :)

Lovely game if you like military simulations and tactics. Albeit not easy to learn at the beginning, the possibilities it offers and the depth of the simulation is stunning. Amazing what the modding community has managed to achieve as, with the list of most commonly used mods, the game looks like what could be Arma4 or something, a much better experience.

Graphics are still holding after so many years (the game was released in September 2013 and I am writing this review in July 2021), the engine not so much as it has not been updated to modern hardware and standards (e.g. optimal use of multiple cores and threads, among others). The game also has some bugs (mostly graphic glitches and random behaviours) but they do not seriously hinder the playability.

I definitely recommend this game and I am looking forward to Bohemia Interactive to release Arma4 (or Squad maturing to match it in terms of possibilities and improving it tech-wise).

After almost 800hrs in this game, having played almost every major mod and having joined multiple groups during that time I feel that I have experienced almost everything Arma has. I genuinely enjoy the game and can definitely say that there is fun to be had playing with a handful of friends. The main problem I have with this game is the polarised extremes of the playerbase. On one hand, you have people who larp as special forces and will spend hours in silence because they have been told to be quiet by some armchair soldier on Teamspeak and on the other, you have a community of players who have nothing better to do than teamkill anyone spawning into a public server. 

These two groups make it almost impossible to join and play multiplayer in public servers and groups alike as there is basically no middle ground. You are either forced to join a group whose idea of fun is a compulsory parade every week or play with randoms in public servers with no coordination and awareness. I don't particularly care if people want to play in milsim groups or if they're one of the aforementioned randoms but because there is no alternative it makes the game un-enjoyable for anyone who is in between the two extremes.

My other issue is Arma 3's terrible way of handling DLC which means you either have to play on strictly base game servers or be subject to constant watermarks displaying some garbage like a popup for the karts DLC. This doesn't make anyone want to buy the DLC any more than they originally did but instead makes it actually aids to play, I won't even bother talking about the cesspit of contact and the other garbage that the devs roll out to flog money out of the corpse of this game.

TLDR: fun with friends, bad otherwise

Having played over 90 hours of this game I supposed I should recommend it but it was a love/hate relationship. I played ARMA 2 ages ago and remember enjoying it in spite of its "clunkiness", so ARMA 3 has been on my wishlist for years. For some reason I bit the bullet at the last Steam sale and spent ¬£20. That got me the APEX package plus Contact and the Marksman DLC. I'm only interested in single player mode so I ran through the tutorial which was where I realised that my old PC (i7 2700K with 980GTX SLI) was struggling to run this CPU-bound game. The tutorial seems to be more a series of rendered cut-scenes than actual gameplay and the fps went through the floor. A bit of research later I configured the game to be playable and set about running through the showcases - which I would recommend for new players.

Finally I felt that my PC was running the game well enough and I could remember enough controls to survive so I played the original single player mission East Wind. That's when I realised how buggy the game is. Enemy soldiers teleporting about was annoying enough but the real PITA is when tasks can't be completed and it is necessary to revert to an old savegame. But I also didn't like the close-contact style and was irritated that I couldn't use the marksman DLC, so I loaded the single player cheat mod. Now with a sniper rifle I could play more in the style I wanted and could make adjustments to compensate for the bugs. The scenario was longer than I expected and the storyline fairly strange but I had fun.

So next I played the APEX single player mission Old Man. This felt less military simulation and more Far Cry to me, but not a very good Far Cry. I mostly ignored the sandbox opportunities and played through the mission task by task, putting up with the bugs. Part the way through the game I completed a new PC (5900X with RTX3090) which could run the game smoothly on max settings. This made it look and feel better, but still old. There was a bug that prevented me from completing the game or exploring the other endings but luckily I have a home server and was able to restore an earlier savegame from backups and finish it - although it seems that one ending has an unavoidable bug.

By now I was feeling neutral about the game and doubting that the ¬£20 was worth it until I started Contact. I really liked this mission even though it still uses the buggy ARMA 3 engine. Shame that the developers couldn't have given it more depth and increased content - the sandbox potential was underused in my opinion. I certainly recommend Contact for single players, and APEX (Old Man) not so much. I finished off by playing some content from the Steam Workshop but whilst I applaud the authors for their efforts they all felt unpolished and after a while I got bored of them.

ArmA is:
- [b] GREAT [/b] military sandbox for role-playing, modding, scenario building, tacticool soldier dress-up, shooting range simulator
- [b] HORRIBLE [/b] military action FPS/3rd-person shooter with vehicles

The BAD:
[*] [b] Optimization. [/b] Frequent hiccups and frame drops no matter how good your pc is or how low you set the game's options.
[*] [b] JANK. [/b] You'll die walking up a staircase b/c your legs clipped through the ground. In-game Interface is dated and clunky. The control scheme is complex, uses your entire keyboard, and the interface makes it worst.
[*] [b] A.I. [/b] Is worse than that of many 90's games. Enemies act like robocop, looking at one direction, moving towards another and shooting towards another one. Their movement speed and trajectory changes non stop in the most uncanny and unpredictable manner. NOT in a realistic challenging way, but in an irritating inhuman way. [b] Playing as a sniper/marksman against A.I. is just a sad experience [/b] because you don't get the joy of anticipating the target's behaviour and landing a brilliant intuitive shot.
The A.I. also sees you through buildings, objects and high grass, even when not looking at you, walks through walls of buildings w/o using the doors (like Homer Simpson going through the bush meme), have bad path finding, bad driving/piloting and frequently ignore commands.
[*] The complexity of the player's movement set does NOT work for action gaming. A clear example: You can crouch, crouch lower, a bit lower, prone, lean, lean more and more to position yourself firing from cover. Problem is, you'll still lose the fight against the player that simply strafes in-and-out of cover like hes playing Counter Strike.

The GOOD:
[*] Visually great all around.
[*] Playing soldier dress-up and practicing shooting at the gun range (virtual armory)
[*] Full 3d editor to create and play whatever scenarios you want (most of my playtime is from there)
[*] Outstanding modding scene. Devs are very friendly to mods.
[*] Dedicated servers
[*] Plenty of complexity regarding weapons/attachments, ballistics, communication, vehicles, maps and coordination.

Do not buy it if you're searching for a fun ACTION 1st/3rd person military shooter with vehicles. Get anything else for that.
Buy if you want the military role-playing/simulator aspect of it.

Well, it's been roughly a year since I got this game. I originally got it to play with a couple of friends, but we hadn't been very active on it. After a while, I met a good friend of mine on another game, and they had invited me to their unit -- The 5th Rangers (5R). I was a bit nervous at first, as I had literally no knowledge of anything in the game. I figured I should give it a shot. Slowly, but surely I'd been playing. It was fun, and I had met new friends. A few hundred hours in, I began to have an attraction to Zeus. I started out just using Zeus, as I didn't understand the Eden Editor.
I then took a small hiatus from the 5th Rangers, and started my own unit. I called it Tau-14. Knowing little to nothing about management, I tried my hardest to remain organized. Originally, I was hesitant on inviting people, but slowly I began releasing operations, and inviting more people. After a while though... nobody was active, and I had disbanded the unit. As all things do, it had come to an end. Earlier than I had wished. I may try again one day, but I'm doubtful.
I returned to the 5th Rangers in order to regain my traction in the unit. Now I've met some of my best friends on this game, and make operations for some of the nicest people I can relate to. After my return, I learned many more terms used by our military, and I have much more knowledge in some fields. Arma 3 has had me meet my best friends, and to learn. It's been the greatest thing that I've played in a very long time. Although I only have 2,000 hours, it's changed the people around me, and it's changed the way I view certain things.

Get this game, and enjoy it. You'll have your ups and your downs, but in the end it's so worth it.

I've really enjoyed some of the single player content in this game, there is really nothing like it that I have played in terms of realism - the maps are huge, there are plenty of weapons, vehicles and aircraft, and some of the campaigns and missions are great fun to play, as well as having a pretty good story line. Overall it has been worth the purchase. However, multiplayer is where the fun stops for me, it's an absolute headache to try and set up a server to play with friends, having to fiddle with settings on my router is not something I expect to have to do to simply connect to a server. Also, the learning curve is so high for this game, playing on public servers is a real gamble - even in player vs ai modes like escape.

All of this could be forgiven for the massive potential and scope of this game, but recently I have been experiencing repeated crashes to desktop without any warning or error messages. Until this major bug is fixed I simply can't recommend the game.

Bonus:
If you're looking for a multiplayer military simulation game focused on team play and realism check out SQUAD. There's a great community and it retains a lot of the realism without sucking the fun out of multiplayer play. Still a bit of a learning curve, but you can pick up most of the game mechanics in a few hours and everything is focused on team work and strategy.

Task Force Spartan - SOF DEVGRU Semi-Milsim (EST)
Special Operations Task Force Spartan is made up of three military units which were selected by the unit creators. These units are as follows: 

DEVGRU Blue Squadron: This is the backbone of our unit, Blue Squadron is our main force for our operations, and where most of our recruits are transferred to. Their goal is to perform HVT captures, assassinations, recon, hostage rescue, counter terrorism, and much more. Blue Squadron will sometimes join with friendly forces and work together in order to secure any objectives given to them.

Black Squadron: In many ways similar to Blue Squadron, these guys are the best of the best. Comprised of our most highly talented members, Black Squadron are the first ones in, and the first ones out. These men operate secretly in the AO for special purposes that our Blue Squadron cannot complete.

160th SOAR: The 160th SOAR or Special Operations Air Regiment is responsible for all forms of air deployment for the other divisions. Not only are our pilots responsible for transport, but are also responsible for aerial drone reconnaissance to provide our ground forces with ISR or Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance. This is to help our units with extremely delicate missions such as hostage rescue or HVT takedowns. Last but not least, the 160th may be required to provide CAS in the form of a light attack helicopter or with a drone. We value our pilots greatly and always treat them with respect for their talented flying capabilities.

With each unit comes with unique training and tactics. We believe within TFS that this will bring some unique game-play to Arma with the diversity of our Arma Unit. Now, very much like joining any Arma unit, your division or military unit is not set in stone and you can transfer.

Let's not forget, it's a military-themed game, and Bohemia is actually working on interactive projects that are used by literal f*cking militaries, so there's much to expect, and if you're looking for the game that has bot the realism and the endless capabilities, Arma's for you.

Now, the thing that catches one's attention when observing Arma is the finish of it. No other milsim game on the market has such a variety of weapons, vehicles, uniforms, terrains, and a lot of other aspects. Sure, the initial game may feel a tad bland at first, but as you start to acknowledge the full potential of Arma 3, it's more than enough. Although like 60 percent of content is DLC-based and not all high-end material within the game is accessible for free, you're paying quite a small price (if buying during sales) for a clean canvas for hundreds of thousands of community-made addons and mods, so, I guess, if you don't have 90 dollars just laying around for all the downloadable content to be bought, I believe it's still playable to full extent, as legendary mods like CUP series, ACE3, or RHS series got your back.

After discussing the contents of the game, it's worth to mention the actual mechanism of Arma 3. If someone asked whether Arma's a FPS, or a simulator, or a mislim, or a RPG, or whatever else, a clear answer couldn't be given, because Arma is all of that, and much more. However, what Arma is remarkable for is its campaign mode with about a dozen of possible story modes, a showcase mode with different aspects of the game given for the players to experience, and of course the mission maker, where all your imagination and strategies can be put into practice. To put it straight, if you're looking for a quick round to play (like playing an FPS), or looking for a straight-up day-long milsim, you can get all of that from Arma, as it's almost like several different games with all of that.

I could go on and on with the pluses, but I wish to leave it for the newcomers to discover themselves. I believe it's necessary to mention the hardships with the game. Those who come from older Arma games know how f*cking difficult it is to learn all the controls. Like, seriously, I doubt you could find a button on your keyboard that is not bound to some specific action in Arma. It will take a considerate amount of time to learn, but eventually it will work out on its own, without much thinking. The next thing is the bugginess. The game is quite old by now, about 7 or 8 years old at this point, if I'm not wrong, and it takes quite some time to catch all the bugs, software issues, and incompatibilities that raise from the game. The Bohemia team, especially recently, doesn't find much time to solve them as their focus now is the new gaming and simulation engine. In the end, you are remained to adapt your computer around the game, not the other way around, in order to make it work. Talking about the computer, despite having quite basic minimal requirements, you'll probably need more than that in order to have Arma run smoothly, not decently. The good, well-working CPU and GPU are a must, there should be quite some RAM with some to spare for hardware needs, and have a considerate amount of free space for all the addons you'll be downloading. Simply, Arma 3 is a demanding game, and if you wish to see the true potential of it, your grandmother's old 2005 Dell won't do the trick, sadly.

TL;DR: an extremely broad and interesting game with millions of capabilities that is enjoyable even without DLCs that is quite demanding in terms of hardware and sometimes bugs out. Worth the money and time, though.

ArmA 3 is easily one of, if not, the best shooters i've ever played. Despite the fact that it runs like hot steaming garbage, I have consistently had fun playing both the single player and multiplayer game modes, and it has single-handedly gotten me back into the FPS genre, and introduced me to a genre I find even more fun - MilSim.

ArmA 3's gunplay is at its core more interesting and developed than the typical FPS I tend to get my hands on. This is due to how methodical and slow the combat can be. Everything from look and feel to range and bullet physics is here, and it's awesome. Combat is so much more engaging when you can die in one or two hits, and you're keeping track of everything from fire rate to how many bullets are left in your particular mag. For a genre based solely on combat, this is a huge boon to be able to engage the player in real risk reward, tactical combat without feeling genuinely unfair. 

Which brings me to my second point - ArmA is NOT just combat. It's traversal, resource management, and in many cases intense problem solving. The AI reacts much how you'd expect real humans to (although not without their own faults and exploits), and the world is built with a level of care and detail rarely seen in the genre. 

Of Course, most people will be playing the game for multiplayer. You won't be finding much COD style team deathmatch here, but it's to its core most enjoyable throwing commands and working as a team to overcome your enemy. Laying down mortar fire on an outpost as your friends spot for you is never a dull experience, especially not when a squad of soldier rolls up on the mortar, and you're forced to engage a squad of enemies in a split second where one shot can end your whole operation.

For anyone who wants to play a realistic shooter, or experience an immersive, engaging game with a focus on player control (12 different stances and all that), I recommend ArmA wholeheartedly. An easy 9/10, despite some glaring issues with the game engine. I've yet to find a game like it in the genre(s).

An amazing game, with it's highs and it's low. I would definitely call it the ultimate and king of role playing. Which conqueros many of the attributes which other programs such as fiveM and other role play game have. The experience of the role playing, due to the well organized servers and admins it creates a nice environment which makes it fair to play in and be part of. As I mentioned at the beginning this game does have some disadvantages, which in comparison to the advantages and the games functionality don't decrease playing scenerios. Some of the disadvantages which i found was the high utilization of hardware, making it really hard to get a really good performance with low end hardware. I also found that the physics were abit odd, creating funny and weird experiences but can be really annoying at times. The physics make it feel as if you're vulnerable at all times and most actions are some what delayed on multiplayer servers. By this I mean that in a role playing server and you crash into another car and defying all of newtans law your car could go flying and you be the one injured although u where at a lower speed than the person crashing into you. However, I am only experienced in the role playing side of things but that is also a small piece of the pie when it comes to the content in the game, there are so many other severs such as war gamemodes, battles, pvp and you can create any scenerios which u could ever thing of in single player. In conclusion, i would definitly recommend this game, especially when u have commited friends to play with as you will have a laugh, and feel rewarded after you complete a drug run successfully.

Im sure this game is great for the fans it has and is very impressive. I truly wish more games were like this. Issue is, this game is old. Like old old. The graphics dont automatically detect your hardware from what I can tell cause my first impressions were PS1 Hagrid levels of bad. However you can manually change that and it looks great. Some people report FPS issues which I didnt, your mileage may vary.
Now, the main issues that arent just annoyances are the 'campaign' and the multiplayer. The single player missions are pretty broken in places where changes have been made apparently, but when youre playing I can only describe it as like leading a group of monkeys into combat. Any mission that relies on the AI being competent is immediately gonna be hard or impossible. This is fair since Im a sucker for pain apparently and just keep trying but I cant honestly recommend most of the campaign. 
The multiplayer isnt the devs fault. This is a community that has lasted for years. Getting into this game now, for the first time will mean either playing with experienced friends that are willing to explain things (the ideal situation), bumbling through with some friends or alone or you can join a clan. Most of these clans have people that have been playing the game for years and know exactly what theyre doing. They also often have a long list of mods that they use that you will need to learn how to use and that will likely change between clans if you move. I have noticed that the people who run the clan are people who want to help and bring people in, but the average squaddie doesnt have time for you to be clueless. This has to be one of the least accepting community for new players I have come across. Personally, it feels like work to play this game with other people and I dont quite want the level of realism where I want to be paid a wage for turning up. 
Arma 4 may be a different story thanks to the influx of new players it will likely bring but if you dont already play Arma 3 I cant recommend you buy it

Whenever I see a friend of mine buy Arma 3 one of two things tends to happen: Either they play it for 30 minutes and never touch it again, or they fall completely in the hole and spend hundreds and hundreds of hours on it. There's no in-between. If you're someone who is looking for an easily approachable shooter that you can just have a good time with out of the box, this is a decent game for that, but there are many better options out there. If you're someone who is interested and willing to put in the time to customize the game to what you're looking for spend time getting good at the challenging combat, then there is almost no better gaming experience out there. Arma 3 shouldn't be thought of as a "game" Arma 3 is a toolbox for which you can build or piece together the game you always wanted. If you can find a couple friends who are willing to share tat obsession for you, this becomes the ultimate "game night" game, where you can spend countless hours accomplishing your goals while chatting about the week. If you're someone who's comfortable with the workshop and making small tweaks to games to get what you want out of them, this is a no-brainer must buy, especially at the sale price it has once a month or so. You will find few better values in gaming. If you're just looking for an easy military style game to play, you'll have an okay time with it, but your attention is better directed elsewhere.

This game is trully something else. There's nothing quite like crawling for 200 meters to the objective then immediately getting shot and dying, as your body falls and slams on the pavement like a bad of horse shit, you wonder what you could've done differently. That's the true Arma 3 experience.
Arma 3 is a game meant for ultra realistic simulation of combat. So realistic in fact that the U.S military has used it to run infantry drill training. That's what makes this game very interesting.
Arma is extremely expansive, even in plain vanilla you can still get sufficiently good enjoyment out of it, specially when it comes to multiplayer modes. The game's ballistics are top notch and the guns feel okay, nothing Call of Duty Modern Warfare, but good enough.
Much like Garry's Mod, this game shines through it's mods and communities. With varying degrees of seriousness, it can be a highly accurate Afghanistan U.S Army unit with actual veterans, or a goofy time in WW2. Doesn't matter, the fun is there.
The mods are true best part, and add soo much into this game. The first mod that is a must have is ACE3, simply put, the best mod around. And it is compatible with most popular mods too, you can completely convert your game into a WW2, Modern setting, Star Wars and even Halo if you're into that. 
Paired with mods, the Editor lets you make your own missions which you can use for anything, wanna try piloting a helicopter/plane? (good luck, prepare to crash, MULTIPLE TIMES.) want to make a skirmish to fight random enemies? Go for it dude. Want to make a very elaborate operation with multiple distinct units and objectives? That works too. 
The maps are also fucking enourmous, not much to add about 'em, go explore.
Now, this game has a few short comings. Even for good computers, performance might vary significantly, it is not very well optimized even for lower ghraphic settings. It also has many bugs that may one time be funny, or fuck everything up and be a pain in the ass. AI sometimes is absolute dogshit, others, it will kick your ass mercilessly, there's no in between.
Also, the mods are gi-fucking-gantic, I'm talking 3+ GB and the Arma launcher takes ages to download anything, doesn't matter your connection speed. So even though it says I got about 300 hours, most of those are waiting for mods to finish downloading. 
DLCs and other content is pretty fucking pricey, and some like Zeus or Apex are pretty necessary as most servers require 'em to work. So, yeah, be ready to dumb some cash at this. 
this game gets a 8.5/10 for me. It is very much worth buying, just know of it's short comings.

Well seeing as its the Arma franchise's 20 yeah anniversary i should probs write a review. So here goes:

Pro's

The sheir amount of teamwork in this game is unrivaled. From just 1 squad working to capture 1 objective. Too a  commander making several squads + 2 transport helicopters and a tank platoon work together.

Its a sandbox combined with a FPS. This is great because you can make literally anything in this game. If you can script in this game then the sky is the limit.

The sheir amount of mods that have been built up over the years. For example want to play DCS but dont have the money? Just download a the F-18 super hornet with a almost fully modelled cockpit. Or the fully modelled Apache and Blackhawk. 

The game engine is a funny of its own. Ever wanted to kill a tank by sending it to the stratosphere? Well just grab a quad bike and go full speed ahead.

Most computers can run this game. Yes i said it i do not care about the FPS argument, just turn ur render distance down. Someone in the community that i play with uses a 5 year old school laptop to play the game and he can clutch with his machine gun like a god. The only thing that will be bad is ur frame rate and graphics but hey who needs frame rate, its Arma after all.


Cons:

Your experience in this game heavely depends on the community that you find. Do not go for one of the hardcore milsim units is my advice, go for one of the casual or semi realism units. These are usually the best. I myself have found a nice casual unit that is the most fun experience ive had in this game.

Its a large scale game wich can make new players feel quite lost at first.

If you want to have a heart attack then try to open the controls menu. Although all these controls can be nice for experienced players, for new players its the number 1 complaint. 

Good luck and have fun!

The Arma series(And its predecessor, the Operation Flashpoint series)are not tactical games: They are infantry and combat vehicle simulators. Totally focused on co-op games(either PVE or PVP) and tactics, the overall experience goes far beyond anything else in the first person tactical shooter genre. The outstanding work done by both Bohemia Interactive and the Modder/Designer community keeps this 2013 release fully up to date. Be it mods or Creator DLCs(I¬¥m absolutely hooked to SOG: Prairie fire at the  moment) the quantity and quality of content available for this game is almost limitless. The scope of the game is still one of the largest on the market with hundreds of square mile-long maps, tons of weapons, vehicles and editable objects ensure hundreds or even thousands of hours of playing, providing Arma 3 with one of the longest shelf-life in the gaming market. An absolute must play if you like no bs military simulation computer games. 

The only drawbacks are the outdated AI(getting stuck everywhere, being complete killer bots or useless moving targets with little in-between ground) and some textures "swallowing up" dropped items. Apart from that, the game is awesome.

Let me start off by saying that I love this game, but that doesn't mean that if doesn't infuriate me. For the most part, the movement is straight forward with no issues, but then you'll be trying to get to an overwatch position and get launched into the air. You will spend a lot of time in this game as long as you have friends that enjoy it too. Most of my time has been playing the Antistasi mods with my buddies. If you enjoy modded play, this game is a great choice. Just don't pay full price.

Arma 3 isn't a game.
There are several reasons why people say that expression sums it up.

First, the game is intended to be a military simulation, the game offers a great deal of missions and scenarios that need to be executed with military precision to be successful.
It covers most if not all specific weapons in a modern army. The game modes on a single player level train you for the multiplayer game where all that exercise can be put into action for a more challenging opponent.

Second reason, Arma in its ambitious goals to be a milsim, created a platform where players can create more content in-game and/or dive into the huge mod community.
Here the game opens up and gives most players the main reason to play arma for a prolonged if perhaps interrupted time. It kept and still keeps giving us amazing new game modes that have sometimes even have been developed by third partys (palyers)  into standalone variants like DayZ, PlayerUnknownBattlegrounds and several others. 

Last reason why arma isn't a game, Arma isn't just "a" game.
And why I've kept coming back to arma and finding new ways of enjoying it.
As a veteran player and a terribly bad shot, I still have a tremendous amount of fun. Where in other games secondary tasks in the army can fall behind in satisfaction, arma shines in offering essential roles in tactics and vehicles.
However you enjoy your arma is up to you.

+++  It's Arma baby
++  Notable workshop/modding community
++  Varied community that can cater to your rp/casual preferences
+    The jank is part of the experience tbh
+    [Obligatory war crime joke]

Negative(s):
--  Better get some friends and a lot of them, 'cause playing solo is madness and playing with randos is a about what you'd expect
--  Hope you like a good ol' kraken every now and then
--  Loading times are notable if you don't have it on an SSD, and god forbid you don't have space for the game AND the mods on it
-    You can still use equipment and vehicles that are from DLC's you don't own, you just regularly get a screen-wide watermark that obscures your vision and is very distracting. Not good for ops or anything that demand stuff from DLCs you don't have

I don't nearly have as much time as most of the modern day ArmA 3 enthusiasts given I've only just started playing 6 months ago, but in my time of playing it this game has been nothing but punishing amounts of fun. I keep dumping hours into this game learning new things everytime I play. Whether it's how to command a tank squad, properly take off from a runway, or how to accurately use AA, there's something new waiting for me. I've begun using it for photography as well, and already have a folder dedicated to exactly that. I'm still learning on the mission making side of things, and I cannot wait to see what cool missions I can make with this games amazing editor mode. I definitely recommend this to someone who enjoys the milsim sandbox experience and wants to get away from the Battlefield style game that seems to be everywhere these days

‚ÄÉprecise shots, requiring you to take short stops, or
‚ÄÉnot run like a bloody monkey all the damn time.
‚ÄÉIt defnitely doesn't feel immersive from te get go,
‚ÄÉbut mods can help you achieve some immersion.
‚ÄÉAlso, rifles aren't your only means of weapons.
‚ÄÉYou've got AA and AT launchers, stationary

‚ÄÉit still works well, and can quite be the experience

I bought this game about 2 years ago, and maybe played it for a grand total of 30 minutes.  The game just seemed overwhelming jumping straight into multiplayer servers.  I watched several videos over the 2 years since I purchased the game that made it look amazing, so I decided to give it another go.

I ran through the tutorial and campaign, and by the time I started multiplayer, I had a much better grasp of what to do.  It's also important to direct your play style toward your preferences, there are several variations of PvE and PvP, with all kinds of scenarios to play out in them.

The players I've encountered so far range across a broad spectrum, of course.  Even the most meme worthy trolls still usually prove helpful though, allowing you to properly play the game while they tell you how they slept with your mother.  The bulk of the community really has been fairly good, though.

I started out with just the base game, I played using that steadily for 2 weeks.  The mods went on sale about 2 weeks into me seriously playing, and I didn't hesitate to buy them up.  Note, the base game is worth the price as it stands, however I would NOT pay full price for all of the add ons; you also run into quite a few restrictions in game if you don't have at least the Apex expansion, your weapons and vehicle access are handicapped.

If you want to play a mil-sim that's probably not as daunting as it may seem, I would recommend Arma 3.  If you want something beyond the run-n-gun style of games like CoD or the Battlefield series, I would recommend Arma 3.  If you want to buy a game with all the features included without paying out the ass for expansions, I would not recommend Arma 3.

I accidentally got sucked into the world of Arma 3 and now I can't stop.

This game has too much. You have too many options in terms of weapons, vehicles, locations, factions, and the list goes on. If you have any interest in virtually any aspect of military sim, then this game has it, I promise.

(+)I spend most of my time in the Eden Editor which gives you the ability to create your own wartime scenarios. From dogfights to hillside ambushes, you can make it all. Maybe one day I will actually upload something I make but for now its all in good fun.

(+)The multiplayer is what I feel most people come for when it comes to Arma 3. Playing with a squad of friends definitly is the best way to experience what Arma 3 has to offer, but you can still rely on the community to play a fair game and that leads me to my next point. 

(+)The community is one of the best I have ever encountered. I don't know what others have experienced, but I was quite surprised at how helpful and fair the majority of my encounters with randoms have been. This to me is a huge plus.

(-)This game has its negatives however. Graphics, for start, have the ability to look "pretty" from afar or in some situations, but overall, the game looks dated (but you have to remember that IT IS DATED). I wouldn't have much of a problem with it but the issue I do hold against Arma 3 in regards to graphics is that the game runs like shit. This game is notorious for the god awful frame rates and this really holds true once you get into large scale battles. I have a pretty good rig and I usually hold 60-80 FPS out of combat, 40-60 in combat, and anywhere from 10-40 in very large scale scenarios. This is unfortunately a reality many of us Arma users have to face. To give you an idea, I have seen a $1650 computer run this game and only go below 60 FPS in those crazy large scale battles.

(+/-) This one can be seen as either a positive or a negative depending on what you are looking for. This game has a stupid number of controls. You have the ability to go as deep or as shallow as you want with them depending on how complex the scenarios you get yourself in, however everyone who starts out playing Arma 3 usually makes or breaks during the "control learning phase" which can easily take anywhere from 10-30 hours to get muscle memory for.

Overall, its a good game and I think you should make the purchase. What? That's not enough? Isn't this why you're here? So I can tell you whether or not to spend your money? BUY THE DAMN GAME

She and I have returned from a holiday back-packing (well, case-pulling) around Albania. We went the length of the country, catching buses from town to town and finding somewhere to stay when we arrived.

I wanted to again see a European country much as I remember them in the early 60s before everything became the same, with same shops and similar food, and that's pretty much what we found. Albania is family-centred, safe, respectable and amazingly cheap; two people can eat with a drink for ¬£5 and eat like royalty for ¬£15.

Every evening, families and friends get dressed up and go promenading up and down the main street. It's a young society with few fat people and is untouched by the Americans (we didn't see a single McDonalds in the whole country).

So, if you can survive a run-down infrastructure and customer-blindness, you could try a holiday in Albania. It has wonderful scenery, beach resorts and important archaeology.

Arma 3 is insane. Let's just get a short pro con list. I'll save the good parts for last so cons first.

CONS:
- Performance (My PC is a 1060 3gb with an i5 7400 can run as low as 20-30 fps in some cases where there's a lot of vehicles and NPCs loaded)

- DLC price (The DLC for this game is amazing, although a lot of it should be available from the start, and it is overpriced normally. wait for a sale, or look into mods)

PROS:
+ Huge maps (the first map, Altis, is 270sqkm/170sqmi, about 4x the size of PUBG's maps, 7x the size of Skyrim's map, and about 10x the size of Fortnite's map, making it amazing for piloting aircraft in large scale missions, as well as selecting one of the many villages for diverse small scale missions, and of course there are 4 or 5 other official maps, and countless community made maps)

+ MODDING (OMG this game's modding community is awesome. Check the workshop for anything you can think of, or search Youtube for a list of some of the most awesome mods.)

+ Diversity of gameplay (Kind of mentioned in the map section, but you can either play a huge scale mission with several objectives over the map, or a small mission set within a single village. You can change the weather, put on night vision goggles and go dark, and put on suppressors to keep your position concealed for as long as possible. Or you can skip straight to my favorite part, flying a helicopter or jet and wreaking havok on the enemy)

+ Much much more. This review is already fairly long, so I'll just leave it at this: With the pros and cons I've already mentioned, this game get's a recommendation from me. There is no more downsides, however there is plenty more upsides, so if you're not convinced by my review, lemme tell ya, there's a lot more that this game's got going for it. Thanks for reading.

As a platform for expressing the creativity of it's userbase, not much compares. As a milsim, nothing else compares.

I absolutely love Arma 3 and if you're into realism and military shooters I think you will too.

ARMA III is unique as a game because the more time you invest, the more enjoyable it becomes.  To begin playing is admittedly difficult: The controls, level of depth/realism, and complete freedom of a military sandbox without constant reminders is overwhelming for a lot of new players (I'm new and played for only ~30+ hours in-game.)  This 7 year old game now has more players than at any time previously and consistently ranks in the top 50 games played online every day with one of the largest active modding communities: This should tell you something as a consumer, about how engrossing it can be when the learning curve is climbed.  Although I've never served in the military, believe me when I say this "game" is realistic as possible (esp with certain mods.) It is developed and regularly updated/optimized by the same software developers who build actual military simulators.  (Beginners: Expect to die...A LOT. Sorry, that's REAL guns for you.)  As far as FPS and simulator games are concerned, this game is basically the insanely difficult "Dark Souls" version of Call of Duty and may not be for every casual gamer...  
      To enjoy this game, you must pass a "boot camp" of learning, watching tutorials, looking at Reddit unless you're both a video game god and combat infantry squad leader simultaneously: (I'd like to meet that person.)  I've owned it since ~2016 but am only now seeing how this game is superior in terms of replayability, modding, online community, dedicated dev support, and overall "Bang for Buck" factor in entertainment.  If you get this on sale with most of the DLC, it may cost ~$50, but damn if it's not worth every penny.  A refreshingly rare (and old) game which sets a model for all the other games in my library who I love as my children to aspire...most of them...
     It took multiple rage-quits and hours of learning/keeping the main menu screen on (usually falling asleep dreaming of the day I'm actually able to play/understand ARMA III lol), and overall attempts to "get into it" before I discovered this awesome game I already had in my library. 
    ARMA III is my favorite kid out of all my games and I could write paragraphs about why. I'll spare you the long version. If you're into learning and practicing virtual and realistic tactical combined arms warfare whatsoever, then this could be your next mental addiction.  Get it ON SALE (preferably with DLC), dedicate yourself (for hours) learning how to participate in the operations, prepare to feel like quitting, and push through just a little bit longer to "graduate" the learning curve boot camp necessary to access the immense and untapped value of ARMA III. 

  P.S. The main complaint I have is that the stories are not particularly well-done/interesting but...neither is real modern war imo so...whatever.  I think I just realized how realistic this simulator truly is in the macro...A wise gamer once said "Do not make war, make ARMA."

While I admire the ambitions of the game, they are built on a shaky foundation that only becomes evident way after the refund period. It is also difficult to distinguish between legitimate bugs and just poor UI choices or things you have to learn. Commanding an entire squad and being the commander of a tank or helicopter in the same game are definitely interesting concepts, but it is all completely ruined by all the bugs. Bugs that should maybe have been fixed during the decade this title has been receiving more money through DLCs.

This game is as buggy as it is "realistic". My very first realization that I might have bought something bad was when the ragdoll of a defeated enemy started bouncing like some glitch around the landscape after being shot. Alt tabbing makes it crash and you can randomly lose control of your squad (they're still there, but you can't control them). The AI won't follow you into buildings, sometimes it can't drive by itself, it often collides when driving and keeps trying to go through obstacles. I haven't played a game yet where my game didn't crash at some point or become unplayable. The single player experience is extra confusing and you seem to always lose the latest save or something. Indeed, I don't think I even experienced legitimately quitting the game a single time, it was always some crash or other thing that made the situation unplayable or a complete lack of any "save and quit" button. Even when it works, most of it is just very very confusing and you don't know if it's a bug or just you not knowing some esoteric controls.

Those are just the problems the player can't do anything about. There are several problems you can do something about, such as quickly googling for the answer, hoping that the game won't crash this time while alt tabbing (even in windowed fullscreen). If you accidentally hit alt twice you get stuck in a mode where you turn your head, which is confusing and led to abandoning many missions or restarting. Of course later it becomes handy as you can look around while running forwards, but it's really quite confusing if you have ever played any other FPS ever.

Playing on a public server you have to quickly teleport to some other location so that you don't get downed by new players who just teamkill everything at spawn (because there is no indication of who is friend or foe, which is fair in the sense that friendly fire is a common problem in real warfare, but maybe disable damage at spawn or something?).

Learning to command a squad is an exercise in fingerbending, trying to memorize which number was for which menu. And when you finally learn that to make your AA infantry rearm their missiles from an ammo crate you do F2 (or F3 etc) to select the unit (because you can't just order all of them to rearm at the same time), then hit 6 to select the menu, keep hitting 0 through a bunch of completely irrelevant stuff to find the most useful menu selections at the end of the list and use your mouse wheel to scroll to rearm. The soldier says something like "okay" and then does nothing. You keep trying to do it while enemy airplanes and helicopters are buzzing about. Then you read on some forum from 2014 that it just doesn't work and you have to give them missiles manually. That's about the point where you decide that you no longer want to play as infantry. I'm assuming that mine laying is also as tedious as that and you can't just tell your squad to lay mines around a city or something, and you have to tell medics manually to heal your squad, which is just dumb. Or maybe not, healing mechanics seem really confusing where you can keep healing the same person over and over. I wonder if there's a manual command to tell your squad to reload, that's how dumb the AI can sometimes be.

Vehicle controls are also somewhat confusing. There's a steep learning curve. But it's not atrocious. Actually it's a bit unrealistic. The AI gunner seems superhuman in its senses about what's going on around it, seeing things that are well camouflaged and invisible to regular human eyes.

I have to applaud some people in the public servers for their patience with new players, but scold the developers for not making things intuitive in the first place, although I suppose it's very difficult when the scope is so grand. I wouldn't wonder if most of my issues come down to just being new, but I still wouldn't recommend this in its current state. Get some alternative to this instead if there are any.

I have had a blast with this game. The only negatives Arma 3 has to offer is ok optimization ( encountered a few bugs). That's it. Sure there are other issues like bad ragdoll effects and weird gunplay, but all of those issues are fixed with mods that can easily be installed from the Steam workshop, no setup or time required to figure out how to install all of it. Now to the good part. This game is easily the most FUN military sandbox game ever. The base game itself has a campaign that took me around 20 hours to beat, which is bigger than the average campaign for an fps. To top that off, there is a level editor where you can create your own missions and mess around for, making it replayable for a lot of time. If that isn't enough to make you go buy this, Arma 3 has the largest modding communities ever, with largescale modding projects that add in new maps, terrain, factions, weapons, and more, one of my personal favorites being Operation Trebuchet, which adds the Halo universe to Arma. Overall, if you love modding, military simulators, disappointed by the recent ghost recon games, or just overall looking for something new go for it. Just keep in mind this game requires a lot of patience due to its high learning curve.

So, I play strictly singleplayer. I tried multiplayer and its taken way too seriously for me and far too hardcore. Then one server it felt like I was scrum at bootcamp being literally yelled at. I told them f* off its a game not real life and left. So unless you are into super hardcore multiplayer games with communities that go way too into a game, and don't like singleplayer, probably not for you. I just wanted to have fun, not join military propaganda. Though maybe there are servers like that, but I didn't find those.

With that said Campaign is a lot of fun so far, very much looking forward to reaching Contact campaign which looks and sounds amazing. And I added a few mods (one is antistasi for an epic 100+ hour dynamic campaign, another adds citizens and animals and a bunch of immersive world stuff so its more like a living breathing world and a third is faction stuff that goes well with antistasi). Not very many mods, but they add a TON to the singleplayer experience and makes singleplayer perfectly playable (and more enjoyable than many singleplayer games)

Besides mods, there is a lot of content by default. Though do need a lot of the dlc for that content. I got it on a super good sale for 33 dollars for all DLC except S.O.G, so I bought that extra. I'm very glad I did as well, as while its mostly a multiplayer game...like I said, singleplayer (do need mods for it though really) has been a great experience and (again) better than a lot of singleplayer games I've bought. 

Plus its just nice to see how active the modding community is, a healthy mod community is a good sign of a healthy successful game.

An absolutely outstanding milsim game.
Base game is a lot of fun, but if your going to play this game your gonna need some mods. Mods are key to the Arma experience as it allows you to explore new avenues that were previously unknown to you and completely change the experience. Mods let you go to Vietnam, Star Wars, 40k, hell even ancient Rome. and thats just scratching the surface of content mods. other mods like ACE3 and LAMBS Danger change how the game is played and how the AI behave, in the case of LAMBS the AI is able to call artillery using nearby artillery emplacements along with proper artillery with ranging shots.

If you decide to pick this up I highly suggest picking it up with friends. Play through workshop scenarios and then what I personally would recommend is that you have one or more of your members learn how to make scenarios in the Eden editor (Its a lot simpler than most people think.) and from there you can do basically whatever you want. I don't have any experience in the clan community so I cant speak for that aside from that it looks funs and I would highly reccomend trying to go that route if you play the game more regularly than I do.

Experience true combat gameplay in a massive military sandbox. Deploying a wide variety of single- and multiplayer content, over 20 vehicles and 40 weapons, and limitless opportunities for content creation, this is the PC‚Äôs premier military game. Authentic, diverse, open - Arma 3 sends you to war.

Key Features in Arma 3
Altis & Stratis
Defeat your enemy on a richly detailed, open-world battlefield ‚Äì stretching over 290 km¬≤ of Mediterranean island terrain. From expansive cities to rolling hills, whether steamrolling your tank across the dusty plains, flying a transport helicopter over the dense forests, or waging asymmetric warfare from the rocky hills, the islands of Altis and Stratis are dynamic worlds, which lend themselves to the most varied engagements in gaming.
Weapons & Vehicles
Head into combat on foot, drive armored vehicles, or take to the skies in helicopters and jets. Conduct a combined arms attack over air, land, and sea, with over 20 vehicles to drive and pilot, 40+ weapons to pick from, customizable loadouts with short- and long-distance attachments, and various types of gear to suit your needs on the battlefield. With a massive arsenal at your disposal, Arma 3 moves you into a world of tactical opportunities.
Singleplayer
Follow the story of Ben Kerry, a soldier who gets caught up in a Mediterranean flashpoint, across three gameplay-driven campaign episodes: Survive, Adapt, Win. Immerse yourself in Arma 3‚Äôs diverse gameplay by completing the focused showcase scenarios. Run through the competitive firing drills to hone your shooting and movement skills, and complete your training by signing up to Arma 3 Bootcamp, which features SP and MP tutorials, and a dedicated Virtual Reality practice environment.
Multiplayer
Fight online in the massive military sandbox that is Arma 3. Form a squad and team up against your enemy in the official Defend and Seize multiplayer scenarios. Or jump into one of the many popular unofficial game modes developed by the Arma 3 community. Experience a new form of multiplayer in Arma 3 Zeus, where Game Masters have the ability to influence the battlefield of other players in real-time.
Content Creation
Start creating your own experiences with Arma 3‚Äôs intuitive scenario editor and powerful modding tools. Enjoy a platform filled with player-created content, ranging from custom weapons and vehicles, to intense singleplayer scenarios and entirely new multiplayer game modes. Share and discover content on the Arma 3 Steam Workshop, which lets you install player-created content with a click of a button.
Revamped Engine
Navigate the battlefield with fluid new animations; feel the devastating power of combat with the upgraded sound engine, new ragdoll simulation and PhysX‚Ñ¢-supported vehicles. Pushed forward by game-changing innovations, the highly moddable Real Virtuality‚Ñ¢ 4 engine powers a new generation of Arma with even more stunning graphics, broad simulation gameplay, and massive sandbox terrains.

This game is garbage on its own. The guns are weak, the campaign is awful but somewhat enjoyable. The vehicles are shitty retextures of irl vehicles like the merkava 3 or CH-148. Anything below .30 to .50 cal take about 15 shots to kill. However, this game has the most modding potential out of any game on the market. You can play anything from WW2 to modern conflicts. Hell, theres even very popular mods for the Halo universe and Warhammer 40K. The mods especially make Arma 3's main appeal of combined arms gameplay come to life. Baffling. One in particular i wish to mention is ACE3, or Advanced Combat Environment. In other words, a realism mod. Main features of this mod are a new advanced medical system, advanced ballistics, a new interaction menu to replace the terrible scroll menu, a new arsenal and new items to go along with all the previous features. If modded, this game can be the ultimate milsim experience, however only if an experienced player is Zeusing and making the mission (Zeus is basically the dungeon master, and missions are made through the Eden editor). Get this if you have friends to play with. Playing alone is not fun, but with other people this game can be amazing.

Despite being a pretty fun shooter, it is the most needlessly complicated game I've ever played.
It feels like the developers were given a challenge to use the most amount of keys they possibly could, Because of this, I spent 3 hours alone remapping the controls.

The Singleplayer Campaign's AI are also very difficult to fight, Able to spot you and drop you way before you even get the chance to retaliate, meanwhile, your friendly AI are so incredibly incompetent, rarely ever killing any of the combatants, and dying, leaving you by yourself against 10+ enemies. The combat lifesavers don't even heal injured soldiers.

I've dabbled very little in the multiplayer portion of this game, not from lack of trying, But because it is just as complicated as the rest of the game, introducing new mechanics that have no obvious tutorial.

There is no dedicated filter system for servers in-game, leaving you to sift through dozens of empty/full official servers, and trying to find servers in the "internet" tab is nearly impossible, the vast majority of them requiring Workshop content/mods or optional DLC that aren't listed. Any others are either empty or private.

As far as I'm aware, there are no traditional FPS modes, Such as Battlefield's titular Conquest or the ever-common Team Deathmatch. Again, there are no obvious tutorials for what the different game modes are, leaving you to rely on the internet for information about them, But even then, finding a comprehensive guide is difficult.

There are many other problems I haven't listed here, Such as various crashes, some performance issues, etc. I'm sure others have touched upon these in their own reviews So, I won't go into depth with my experiences.

Due to these issues, I can't, in good faith, recommend this game to fans of the FPS genre. Even fans of military simulation games should probably steer clear, though, due to the lack of competition, This may be the best/only option.
