To be honest, I have a love/hate relationship to Arma 3. 

1. For one, Arma is a really good foundation in regards to being a pretty good military sim in most regards. Although it focuses mainly on infantry gameplay, it does provide pretty solid vehicular und aviation gameplay.
2. There are a multitude of different gamemodes. Be it hardcore sim with heavy rp or the casual life simulating experience.
3. One of most valuable things Arma provides, is the extensive modding and map editing functionalities. Combined with the Zeus Mode, it allows for so much variety.

[b]But...[/b]Arma is so poorly optimized, even the best hardware money can buy, wont change the performance. Turning down settings doesnt work either, since it will put more load on your CPU. Furthermore the more mods you have installed and the more complex these are, performance will drop even further. This is a problem typically encountered on Life Servers. But, I'm sure there are a multitude of problems i havent listed here.

[b]Though beside the hate[/b] Arma is a pretty unique game in terms of what it achieved and provides. Military Sims like Squad, Insurgency, or similar all dont give you the same easy to use, flexible and accessible scenario editor and methods of altering your playtime. Ultimately I will recommend it, but be aware that it might heavily disappoint you, depending on what you like to do.

Okay, so let me state this review is purely based upon my opinion of this game, as someone who has over 1500 hours in.

The reason I do not recommend this game is for a multitude of reasons. So, I'm gonna do a pros and cons system so that people can understand why.

Pros:
1. This game is great if you're playing with friends and want something tactical that you can play with or without mods.
2. This game has a pretty diverse modding community with people making maps, overhauls, graphical improvements, sound improvements etc. There's something here for almost everyone.
3. This game has a pretty damned decent equipment system with everything having different stats in terms of ballistic and explosive protection, and it adds a good diversity in terms of equipment.
4. This game has a pretty good community depending upon where you go, some communities/units are good but just like every game there are bad apples, that's unavoidable.
5. It's a lot of fun if you can figure out a complex game like this and what works and what you're good at.

Now here come the cons. I know some people may be angry/disagree with me but there's things that need to be said and I'm gonna say them.

Cons:
1. A good chunk of the modding community is toxic, there's no way around that. Whether it be elitism, or just straight up bad apples, some of them are just awful toxic people.
2. A good chunk of the unit/community groups are also toxic, meaning you will be constantly wanting to pull your hair out trying to even participate in them and deal with their BS.
3. This game, ruins friendships. I've lost so many friends to this game because of Uniting BS that I've uninstalled this game a numerous times,
4. This game will make you absolutely insane. There have been numerous times where the constant politics of units or communities or mod developers whatever it may be that it's absolutely a drive straight to insanity.
5. This game has bugs in it that date back to it's release, bugs that tend to absolutely break the game sometimes and cause it to almost be unplayable or will anger you to the point you want to smash something.
6. This game has major, and I mean MAJOR performance problems even on a higher end PC. There's a reason why it's considered #2 in terms of most un-optimized games on Steam right behind ARK: Survival Evolved.
7. Mods break everything a lot of the time. It doesn't matter how hard you work, it doesn't matter how hard you try, it doesn't matter how well you code a server. The bugs with this game will cause mods to break absolutely literally everything.

So, now that we've weighed the pros and cons, you understand why I cannot in good conscience endorse or upvote this game for this review. I love ARMA 3 but I also hate ARMA 3 with a burning hate that rivals the sun. This game is a mess. Always has been, and always will be. Sorry guys but this is my opinion. So I'm an ARMA series veteran. My first game on the OG xbox was Operation Flashpoint Gold from 2001. It's really nice to be here after  years and see the AI is still brain dead.

In all seriousness Arma 3 is less game and more platform. It's important to understand that because vanilla arma 3 is rough. The campaign is mediocre at best with bad acting, bad AI, and a bad story. Single player in general is also awful because you have to command said AI through a convoluted interface. I have been playing these games for all my life and I still think leading a AI squad is a pain. Vanilla MP is also pretty hit or miss. There is public servers but most of the time they are pretty empty and people don't do much. Most of the times if you are playing vanilla it is part of a clan and they usually run at least one mod (task force radio)

On the other hand though the modding community is astounding and the tools ARMA gives them are wonderful. Chances are if you are going to have a good time with this game you are going to be running a lot of mods. Where vanilla is pain and suffering the mods build off the platform's core and make amazing things. Wanna good singleplayer experience using vanilla assets? Go to the steam workshop and look up pilgrimage, Hunter 6, dynamic ops, or any number of other excellent single player mods. Wanna have fun in MP? Alright, go to the server browser and look through what servers are running and see what sounds good then download the mods or find a clan. Wanna build your own stuff using interesting assets from games like mass effect, halo, or even other eras of warfare? Cool, go to the workshop. Chances are you can even find a AI mod to fix the AI such as VCOM.

That's the thing with ARMA (here's your TLDR) you should not buy the game for vanilla. If you want to have a good time your pretty much stuck buying it for a platform for it's mods. For that it is worth every penny paid and a thousand times more.

This game saved my life

I am 29.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

I purchased this game sometime in like 2018 probably. (Edit: I was wrong, 2019)
Didn't play it once until like 2020 when I did the bootcamp scenario, followed by an attempt to do the first arc of the base Arma campaign.
Didn't go well (I stepped on a landmine and died immediately). Didn't play it again.
Cue January of 2021 (or February, idk) when LateNightGaming makes three videos detailing his experiences playing the Operation: Trebuchet mod for Arma 3.
Sometime in March, a server owner of a discord server I'm on asks who would be interested in doing some Arma 3 ops.
I think I had like an hour or two in Arma 3 prior to March 2021.
I now have 84 hours in Arma 3. At least 20 of those hours in the first weekend of us doing ops, namely me playing military dress-up and fiddling with vics in the virtual arsenal (I got super excited when I learned either RHS russian or Unsung added in a Tu-95 Bear).
Need I say more? This game is frakking amazing. It's the first game I've enjoyed in ages, has a wonderful set of mods, and passionate developers both in the Czech Republic and in the community.
This might be one of the few games, if not the only game, in my library that I am giving a solid 10/10 review. While the campaign is forgettable (honestly purely vanilla Arma is so far removed from something as simple as CBA and ACE that it's actually hard to play), the physics engine is a bit janky (thankfully I have yet to experience getting arma'd in a vic or as a person), and the optimization leaves something to be desired (Space Engineers runs better than this game, and that's saying something because that game runs pretty poorly), the amazing and often funny moments I have had with my friends in the over 80 hours I have in this game make up for all the issues it has. From not understanding ACE medical and chasing down an innie in a warthog, to hitting V and going over a barrier on the top floor of a three floor building and falling, somehow only breaking my arm, playing military dress up for 2 hours, running from cover-to-cover as a Spartan II super-soldier, holding the line against seemingly endless waves of orks with nothing but my hellgun, getting ambushed by innies in the jungles of Tanoa, accidentally fragging my team on Tanoa and promptly going "I am unbinding G right now," and dropping feet first into hell on a snowy island crawling with Innies, I have enjoyed almost every moment of this game. And I expect to continue enjoying every moment of this game for years to come.
(also if you make arma 4 please frakking optimize it better. while I haven't had issues with frames yet, I expect to as our unit gets bigger. I like my 60+fps)
Edit: I reviewed this game for the first time on April 26th, 2021. I had 48.2 hours in it at the time.
It is now April 30th, 2021. I now have 56.4 hours in Arma 3. 8.2 hours since I reviewed it. Need I say more.
Edit edit: It is now June 9th, 2021. I have some 84+ hours in the game. I love it.

[h1]This isn't a "game that doesn't hold your hand".[/h1]

It's a game- and I'm going to call it a "game" and not a "military simulation" for reasons that get more obvious later in this review- that bites your hand off, and when you cry out in pain and ask, "WHY on EARTH did you do that!?!" it just sits there, [i]sullenly unresponsive[/i].

The problem with these games that want to [i]be everything[/i] is that they usually [u]aren't very good at anything[/u].  This is something I've encountered before, and it's a real issue in game design; there are simply points where adding more features is actually the wrong choice; sometimes less is more.

Look, I get it, Bohemia Interactive; you've been pursuing military-sim paradise since Operation Flashpoint, which I played 20 years ago, and quit playing somewhere around that awful mission with the forest the AI could see through and a BMP with perfect aimbot.  

I think everybody (well, all 10 of us, at least) who played that game back then will know (and shudder at) that reference; it was the place in that game, 20 years ago, where the computers of the day just weren't up to the tasks the developers wanted to achieve and the design just kind of fell apart.

Unfortunately, 20 years later, ARMA 3 just feels like somebody just kept iterating on that game design, adding features until the control systems were a jumbled mess of CTRL-LSHIFT-THIS and SPACE-RALT-THAT, without ever considering where it was all going.  Enemies still have uncanny abilities to see through cover; turrets have laser-like focus that seeks the player out with immediacy that feels completely unreal, and the player's experience will largely be one of frustration and confusion unless they're utterly determined to suffer through it all.

The game's clearly got a fanbase that loves it, despite all the general unpleasantness and obvious levels of jank.  The mods that generally improve it and add things like open-world systems, rather than canned missions, looked enticing, indeed.  But I have to review what the core game is, not what it's like when you finally have the Perfect Mod List... and by that standard, it's just kind of un-fun.

For a few more examples:

Little things like, "commanding your squad is both over-detailed and under-useful" (for example, you cannot just open your map and say, "deploy here, line formation, 50-meter dispersion, engage if fired upon").  Yet you can (and will have to) select one guy, via an F-key, and make 3 middle-mouse clicks (talk about awkward) with perfect timing to get them to ... board a truck.  

Three clicks (and arrow-keys, to boot!) to [u]board a truck[/u], because the AI isn't context-sensitive enough that simply aiming at the truck and selecting a "quick order" key was, apparently, too hard to code. Seriously? 

When things like that are in games, you know that "board a vehicle" was added long after the order system and basic AI was; that's not how it's supposed to be done; that kind of thing is a [i]core feature[/i].  Core features have to be polished and easy for players to use, so that they're immersed, not constantly reminded that, "hey, this is really just a super-complex piece of software with layers of things we added later on top of stuff that was probably too complex when the game first came out... not reality".

Besides breaking the Fourth Wall constantly through sheer awkwardness, the actual missions felt super-rough. 

For example, one point, after a truck heist gone wrong, I'm being told to save my squad and run away from enemies.  I give orders to my squad, "hey, join me", and... er... nothing, they're too busy staring like a deer in the headlights at the attack helicopter that's about make them little red smears on the landscape.  

Things like that happened constantly; AIs were either unresponsive to commands or didn't execute them with reasonable levels of competence, while enemy AI was either blundering around or amazingly focused on killing me. It never felt "real"; in the real world, you can get people to follow you without being dolts and real humans can't suddenly stop and magically kill you when you're hundreds of meters away. 

Worse yet... all of the systems that were clearly meant to make the game feel "real" [i]did the converse[/i].  

For example, the player has some sort of (totally unexplained) encumbrance system which causes them to lose their breath in seconds if running around with "too much stuff".  This is clearly meant to limit player power, and that's fine, except that, besides never being explained... you're automatically larded down with all that stuff, whether you want it or not, on the vast majority of missions.  

Meanwhile, no matter how much stuff your AI teammates carry, they are are totally (and obviously) unaffected by this system and can sprint all day long.  

As another example, the player's asked to deal with absurd amounts of "weapon sway" all the time; the AI is clearly not affected by such problems.  

That list goes on and on, and as it became obvious that that's how things actually work, the "sim" feeling rapidly faded away; it's just a game with incredibly over-complex control systems, badly designed missions and game mechanics feel like they were put in as artificial difficulty ramps.

I have no idea if an ARMA 4 is on the horizon.  But... look, Bohemia Interactive... if one of your staffers reads this, take some notes:

1.  Video games need the simplest control systems possible, even for complex tasks.  If it takes more than 10 QWERTY keys and a mouse to play it competently, it's probably in trouble, design-wise.  This is a lot more work (designing contextual systems is hard) but it's worthwhile.

Somebody will chime in, "but flight sims have more controls than that"... but, if you use a stick with buttons, you're usually good for 95% of the gameplay in a typical flight sim, on all but the most "realistic" modes. I'm using quotes there, because there's nothing "realistic" about memorizing dozens of keyboard shortcuts to do minor things a real-world pilot does nearly automatically; a real aircraft's control interfaces are designed, with great care, to be as simple and intuitive as possible.

2. AI design about humans in a setting like this, if it wants to be taken credibly as a "sim", needs to feel like it's dealing with all the same problems a player is.  AI should not obviously see through things the human can't, react with unnatural speed, or have accuracy that doesn't make sense.  Human players will miss a lot; AIs should miss at least as much, and probably more (after all, you seem to design missions where I routinely had to kill 10 guys all by myself).

3. Games where there's a command element need to consider that part very, very carefully, to ensure it's simple, fast, and easy to use.  The way it's done here felt tacked-on, frankly, which is hard to understand after 20 years of basically making the same game over and over again. Mount and Blade did a pretty good job; for something as complex as this, and I'd suggest something like the Spring RTS's command system, where the player can, for example, draw a formation line on the terrain, and where selecting a single troop and giving them a basic movement order in the map is simple, fast and painless.

4.  Ditch the UI and start over.  Really.  It needs to be elegant and intuitive and most of all, not get in the way of actually playing the game.

Look despite me giving this game a thumbs down I'll be the first to admit that this game has given me hundreds of hours of fun. And some friends that truly shaped who I am today thanks in part to the units I joined and the op's I did with them. I had some of the most memorable times in my gaming career in Arma 3. It will suck you in because there is no game like this that is just a straight up sandbox where you can do whatever you please thanks to the myriad of mods this game has.

But I just cannot recommend this game to anyone anymore. The game runs like shit even on good hardware due to how unoptimized this game is. The AI is either crap or just straight OP there is no in between. The gun play while fun feels so loose compared to squad or really any other game. Despite being a milsim they have a really rudimentary systems to simulate armor for tanks etc. Getting Arma'd (its a term when Arma just fucks you or does something weird. It happens more than you might think). Like I hate that I have to write this but all we really get is just DLC's now. And like thanks that's cool that we get DLC's but the game still has its fundamental problems.

Like look when you get this game and you find people to play with consistently you'll be sucked in and love it. But slowly you'll become more and more annoyed with the game because of all the problems (and more) stated above. You keep coming back because there is no other game like this. A true fuck all sandbox where you can do whatever. But you just realize over time that this game becomes a chore to play because of the problems.

This game has all the tools of an excellent milsim experience. Many people have a great time using multiplayer and so do I from time to time. However, this game is a complete disaster from the single player perspective. The campaign is so buggy that it basically can not be completed without lowering difficulty, researching forums, or reloading hundreds of saves to complete a single mission. For example, in the final mission of the first episode many players are prone to the commanding officer being killed before reaching an important trigger to start the next portion of the mission. You end clearing out an entire town, you were never supposed to clear (solo) and then the mission never ends. If someone didn't tell you why this was happening, this would be the end of the campaign for you. 

One of the final missions, requires you to defend a city from a large infantry and tank attack. You have a squad of stupid AI however which basically do nothing. If the enemies even set foot in the town you automatically lose. The tanks are super powerful, but there is no tutorial or instruction on how to take it out. You end up reloading lots of saves just trying to figure out the tanks predetermined path so you can call strikes in advance of it actually showing up. 

The story is not award winning, but interesting enough to keep you going. Unfortunately the frequent breaks in immersion throw a wrench in the works of what could be an amazing campaign. Some missions are very exciting and compel me to come back to this game from time to time. For a casual gamer, who is more interested in casual campaign rather than a strict milsim multiplayer lobby or chaotic mess of a king of the hill match, this game leaves a lot to be desired. Some of the dlc campaigns do "look" interesting, but I have learned my lesson.

I am 45

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

I have been loving this game as a multiplayer game with friends although there are some glitches/bugs.  You have to keep in mind this isn't Fortnite where you have shields and can take a  bunch of bullets or where you can run all day long and then be able to aim real nice.  Getting tired affects your aim temporarily.  This is a game that focuses on some degree of realism as much as a video game can provide.

Pros
Combat feels very immersive to me.  I feel like I am a soldier in the jungle with danger lurking around every tree or bush.
Great array of weapons to choose from.
The vehicles are fun to drive or fly.
So many mods out there that you can find MANY different types of experiences that are not just "shoot these guys".
You can run your own server and play with friends if you want full control of everything.
Missions can be very long or short depending on your preference.
You can build your own missions.  Sandbox.

Cons
I have seen some of the modded zombies walk through closed doors.
I have hit a person with my armored vehicle and I have gone flying through the air.  Sort of funny to me.
The server can be a little difficult to get optimized so it doesn't feel jumpy but there are resources out there for tuning.
The vanilla AI is a little stupid but there are plenty of enhanced AI mods that will make them MUCH better.

All in all, I think it is a great game even with some of the glitches.  Some of the "Capture The Island" servers/mods are AWESOME.  Look up Overthrow, Liberation, or Antistasi and see what you can do.

Arma 3 has given me more than 3000 hours worth of gameplay. Even though I am extremely deep within the game hour wise, it still teaches me new things I never knew how to do way later into my career. It gives the player endless replayability due to the nature of combined forces. You can always hold an island from attackers, secure and escort a hostage out of a AO (area of operations), assault enemy compounds, and much more. If the AI can do it, so can you. (Other than clipping through walls when there is too many modules or AI placed). With mods it makes the game even better, this can cause your vanilla LDF vs NATO or AAF vs CSAT operations, into a full scale world war involving the Germans, Russians, Americans, British, AAF forces, Chinese, and more. Those were to list the popular armies seen within Arma 3, but that is not all; Arma 3 modding can support the undead. You can recreate scenarios from WWZ if you have a good enough personal computer, or have a simple rescue civilians from a town full of infected, or download ravage and have a good time playing with friends, or solo as the world changes around you. Overall i'd give Arma 3 vanilla a solid 7/10, with the modding community still going hard, i'd give it a 9/10. The community has made Arma 3 amazing as it is now, and everyone can agree when I say that Arma 3 would not have grown this large without them. <3

This is an excellent simulator plagued by a single long standing issue. [b][u]Performance[/u][/b].

It is marketed as a large scale air / sea / land warfare game, yet only a small amount of AI can be present in any one scenario before the engine crumbles under the weight of itself. The mid-range PC I had in 2013 to play the alpha runs it about the same as my 9700K / RTX3080 / 32GB RAM / SSD PC does today, 8 years later.

The scale of the game is largely pointless when it cannot be utilised to create a truly dynamic war-like experience. The best you can hope for are little set pieces or battles that take place in small parts of the map. Scenarios that attempt to create dynamic, large scale battles quite clearly illustrate that the engine isn't capable of handling much else. There are even some official campaign missions that will take you from 100+ FPS to sub 30 FPS when a decent amount of AI is present. That's using VERY modest settings (below what the game itself even recommends) as well as optimising the game according to various guides and forum posts.

If BI would get with the times and take advantage of the hardware on offer, this series would be near perfect. Utilisation is abysmal. ARMA2 had the same issue for years and I certainly expected that we'd be past this by now. It is a PC exclusive, after all. What's the hold up?

This game saved my life.

I am 48.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 fucking minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

There is something unique about Arma. Sure, other games have stuff like infantry combat, building clearing, tanks, APCs, UAVs flying above the battlefield, helicopters and planes striking ground targets and dueling it out in the air above you... but the main difference is: All those other battlefield elements are players too.

There are no killstreaks. You don't get an UAV above the area to scan for enemies because you just killed 3 people. You don't get to be the gunner of a gunship because you killed 15 people. Everyone has their own role, and everyone works for that role. If you need an airstrike, you need to coordinate that with the people in the sky, same goes for artillery. If you want an UAV doing recon, you need someone to fly an UAV to the battlefield and do recon with it. And if you need ammunition, you need to call logistics to bring you the ammunition you need.

With mods, the game can drastically change. There are mods which turn this game into Star Wars, with blaster rifles and lightsabers. Other mods turn it into WW2. Others again turn it into Halo, or Vietnam, or whatever. Other mods again don't introduce new units, but instead make it more realistic, adding radios to the game where you need to set your frequency in order to talk to others on the same frequency. Yet another mod changes medical from "Apply First Aid Kit" to "Okay, he has 2 large avulsions, 1 puncture wound, he lost about two liters of blood, his heart stopped beating, and his airways are occluded. We need a medic over here!" And by combining multiple mods, you are creating your very own gaming experience, where you preferably play together with friends, or at least with those a**holes you can halfway tolerate for the next 2-3 hours to play the mission your Zeus prepared for you.

You can also play with other Milsim groups that could teach you anything about the game. Overall like the game very much and I am addicted to it!

-JG

They're Not Bugs They're Features: An ARMA Review Essay 
-After well over a decade of playing the ARMA franchise I can safely say that ARMA 3 is an amazing successor to ARMA 2. I've been playing ARMA since the early DayZ mod era, and immediately grabbed 3 pretty soon after release. I soon found myself disappointed in the game however as my PC ran the game like garbage (it was a lackluster rig to be fair) and a lack of mods similar to DayZ at this point made me head back to ARMA 2, feeling kinda cheated out of 60 bucks. This experience almost made me leave a negative review, but not quite. Flash forwards to the release of the still popular (yet no longer supported, team moved on) Exile mod. My dad and I, best friend, and cousin all picked up the game again and fell in love with Exile. While its a different experience it still delivers a good survival experience, along with being very modular. The forums were alive and active, with loads of people creating scripts, map additions and just their own servers (myself included). The community could be toxic, as it can still be now but hey its online gaming. 
The Server Hosting Experience- 
-My cousin and I had hosted ARMA servers for KOTH, Domination, and AI missions. So heading over to Exile wasn't horrible, the servers can be touchy as ARMA can be but they didn't cause us too much trouble. The community we built was awesome, my dad had his own servers and most of our players hopped in between the offerings. To get to the point, this game helped build some great communities, brought people together and changed the face of "milsims" (I use that term lightly here, some might get salty). 
The Bu...I mean Features- 
Yeah this game is a buggy mess, modding it heavily like we did doesn't really help much. BUT, it still stands up graphically (if you can run it, this game isn't efficient whatsoever and doesn't utilize resources properly). It also can be a real pain to get working at times.
Conclusion- 
This game is one of the GOATs, and if you can get over some of Bohemia's recent bullshit. Its an amazing experience.

Arma 3 is a very interesting game. Yes, parts have their flaws, like the physics engine freaking out and senting you to space if you hit a tree, or the rather demanding system requirements (that is, as long as you want to run it at 60 fps+) or some of the DLC being rather pricey (though it is not as bad as some other games, like DCS, but that may not be a fair comparison because modules in DCS take an obscene amount of time and effor to make, because they are one-to-one recreations of the actual aircraft) But as a whole, if you have some friends, Arma 3 is well worth it. There are so many aspects that I like about the game that I can't name them here, but I will say, if you have $30 (USD) and a couple friends, buy it. You won't regret it. And the general community is pretty good too, even some of the more hardcore groups are perfectly happy to teach a new player the game.

This game saved my life.

I am 22

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Over all i would say this game is not worth it.
A lot of parts of this game are great such as the graphics and the textures. It does have glitches but its playable 100%.

The reasons this game is not worth it: 
Getting into combat is hard and very time consuming, you spawn 3000m from the battle zone to travel there you need a vehicle which unless you have DLC's you wont have which means depending on someone else to take you there. This will then result in you're vehicle being destroyed 9/10 on the way to the battlezone. 
If you survive long enough to get to the battlezone you will likely be killed very fast by enemy players with OP armour and weapons which will wreck your level 1 armour and youre weapon will do next to nothing to them thats if you actually see them. Chances are you will be shot by a sniper over 1000m away that you never see, who has DLC advantage. 
The DLC provide a huge advantage in the game with everything from weapons, armour and vehicles. 
Not only that if you dont want to spend ¬£50 on DLC's icons will apear on your screen while playing to try and get you to buy them. Including a DLC pop up that will take up your whole screen every 5 minutes even while you are in combat that will likely lead to your death.

Chances are you will play a match for 2 hours and get approximately 30 seconds of actual combat and that's if you are half decent at FPS games. The rest you will spend re spawning and simply travelling to the war zone.

I like how the devs let you mod the game to make it as realistic as you want and how fun it can be to play multiplayer with friends to mess around or do missions.

You and your buds get in the heli. One of your bravest comrades takes up the job of flying the helicopter to the objective.
You hop on the bench. You wait patiently alongside your comrades to reach the objective and complete the task at hand.

A few minutes pass, and the pilot forgets that he needs to land a safe distance from the objective. As it turns out, the enemy had anti-air assets!
Your heli is shot down. The pilot manages to scream out 'MAYDAY MAYDAY!' before you all crash. You've just failed the mission. The other helicopter lands safely, meanwhile your helicopter has failed, because the pilot forgot that he needed to land a few hundred meters away!

Just then, the other part of the team sets up a spawnpoint, and you decide to make it over there. You group up with the other part of your team, and start slowly but surely, taking the enemy base. You kill many enemy infantry, and take out their anti air assets. You've done it. The mission is complete!

Everyone rushes to the heli. It becomes too full, but you managed to rush over there in time. The pilot states he will come back to pick up the rest of your buds. You fly home back to the airbase. You've just completed the mission successfully!
Repeat! But, it doesn't feel redundant, and I was able to play this game for 7 hours in one sitting once, because of how fun it is.
Buy it. If you enjoy it further, buy the DLC.

My wife and I have 4 children 3 beautiful boys and one beautiful girl they're my heart.

This is when the pain pills came in I quickly was ushered into the cruel prison of addiction...the only thing I could do was take more and more pills. 


But one day, one day I said this is enough. I can't live like this. My wife was getting tired of it. My children, they didn't have a father.

Thank you, Bohemia Interactive!

Well, I originally had posted a long and detailed review of this game...but I have decided to shorten it to the simple basics after attempting to play more multiplayer.

The game is old, I know. Me being a former 11B of 9yrs and a combat veteran, I really never got into mil-sim games after I got out.. I recently decided to try some and ended up liking them...now catching up to the games. This one I had seen recently and saw the open world etc and thought it was pretty decent...... until I tried multiplayer...

2 main reasons I don't recommend this game...despite all the good things in it.

1: 75% of the Single Player content requires paid DLC. This will end up costing you 4x the cost of the game. The main campaign that came with the game was only about 2hrs of play time that I saw. I paid for an expansion and got a mission from it. Although there is a bit to do for editors and single scenarios, it would seem you get spawned in with a pre-made loadout that you can't change..

2: Multiplayer....man oh man..what a train wreck it has been. In the 4 days I have owned this game, I have attempted multiplayer on 13 different servers. 2 of which were the official servers... ALL 13 ATTEMPTS WERE HACKED. I have never actually witnessed hacking like this before until I got this game. I am piecing together a video for my channel showing the insane hacks being used on ALL players on the servers. It would seem the big hack is this massive kill-everything-on-the-map-in-one-click thing that destroys the match or game. ALL servers I tried to play on had someone doing this. The longest I got to play before this happened was 15 minutes. Even the official servers.... 

 It has been a massive let down to see over a thousand servers running with players...and literally the first 13 I try to play on are riddled with the above hacking. It's a shame....

At the time of writing this review, ArmA 3 without a doubt is already a classic.
I have enjoyed every single one of my 1500 hrs of playing this game, and from that experience 
I can say ArmA 3 is the most perfect military sandbox to date, even 8 years after its initial release.
The controls take some time getting used to, but every keybind has a purpose and will help you be a better player.
You want to create Artwork? Don't worry, ArmA has you covered with endless possibilities provided by Bohemia's official content as well as the amazing mod community at the workshop.
You like to customize your character to the last detail possible? Worry not, the only only thing limiting you is your hard drive's capacity for mods.
You are more of a singleplayer type of player? Thanks to ArmA's exellent mission editor and a few hours of learning how to script missions, you'll have your own custom playing experience from raiding Insurgent hideouts to a relaxed sunday drive.

So basically ArmA has it all, and even with ArmA 4 being a possibility in the not so distant future, I still recommend you buy this game if its ever on sale, and I assure you, it's money well spent, if you have the time to get into it.

Well, after over 600 hours spent in this game - it deserves a review. I bought this game in 2017 and I am playing ever since, being in two milsim units, then playing with two of my friends in different gamemodes.

But let's start from the beginning. Before you buy ArmA 3, ask yourself this question: "Do I have experience with milsim shooters?" - if you answered yes, Arma 3 will be good for you, but if you answered no - worry not. ArmA 3 works on the basis of "learn on your mistakes", there are many tutorials and showcases which will show you everything from shooting a gun to flying a plane. If you have friends, they can teach you everything - and the game has a strong community which will teach you with tutorial videos.

I run the game sometimes at only 20 FPS at high settings. It surely guzzles PC resources like an iced tea on a hot summer day alongside making my PC fans sound like a 30mm GAU-8, however that is a personal problem. There are a lot of settings, however take my one advice... Disable the picture-in-picture graphical setting (the one that is responsible for all the mirrors in vehicles) if you rarely look at them, it will significally boost your FPS. (Funfact: ArmA 3 doesn't use multi-core, so that may be a problem)

Now, after that mumbo jumbo - the gameplay. It is punishing as in every milsim shooter, with AI laser targeting you through walls, being able to sometimes shoot down a plane flying 500 KM/H with an APC, not being able to enter a vehicle, etc. But, overlooking that, ArmA is great fun, from the different mods and gamemodes to it's glitches, but let's talk about the campaign.

ArmA has a campaign which will introduce you to many of its aspects, driving, shooting a gun, placing explosives, driving vehicles, firing a rocket launcher. It is however buggy and can break often, so I recommend downloading a mod which will be a failsafe to remove an enemy that is stuck...

...Mods. Yes - ArmA 3 has a strong modding community. From the wonders of detailed plane mods, to packs of weapons and vehicles alike by Red Hammer Studios, to the realistic and hard ACE mod, everyone can find something for themselves. Like in bethesda games, it can even fix the bugs created by the developers, which isn't a surprise for a 2013 title that has oftenmost problems. It also has a map editor, the so-called "Zeus", which allows you to even edit in real time when in-game, alongside making scenarios starting from a convoy mission to a mission where you have to destroy a giant rabbit. Is it hard to learn? Yes. Are there youtube tutorials? Of course, there are many great ones, but I never dipped my toes in them nor the editor.

The DLC. I own most of them except for helicopters and Contact, which is one of the more expensive DLCs. Bohemia Interactive has a great DLC policy, you can use equipment from them in the arsenal with only an occasional ad popping on the screen alongside being able to sit as passenger in vehicles. What DLCs are worth it, you may ask me? The Apex DLC. It adds a terrain, alongside many weapons and equipment - it is also a basis for many different mods made by the community. But every DLC is for a different person, such as Laws Of War being a great campaign with few major bugs, Jets being great for people who fight air-to-air and air-to-ground and Karts being for the ones that waant to make a meme operation.

Multiplayer. It is rather visible in ArmA 3 with many gamemodes being created, ranging from King of the Hill (the most popular gamemode), to Exile (which is DayZ on steroids) to the likes of Antistasi and Vindicta, playing as guerillas and starting from the bottom. The community may be sometimes friendly, sometimes toxic, sometimes scream on voice chat (which is of garry's mod quality). MilSim units are an another popular type of a community and technically a gamemode, most often using the ACE mod (which adds things such as morphine, bandages, ballistics, earplugs etc) and being either serious or rather casual, playing their own scenarios. Personally I enjoyed them, laughed at them, made great friends in them, but they require a microphone most often, so prepare for that - alongside knowledge of ACE. Some units have basic training, so they will probably teach you everything you need to know. I recommend joining an unit after you get the basics down and play around fifty hours of both multiplayer and singleplayer combined, but if you feel safe after ten hours, then go for it.


 I think I wrote major points that came to mind. It is one of my longer more professional reviews in a new era. Do I recommend ArmA 3? With all my heart, for new players and veteran players alike. It is simpler than it's sibling of ArmA 2, with it's simplified controls that will fit on keyboards (but numpad is important for third person, so keep in mind you will probably need it if you want it). Thanks for coming so far into my review, please send any criticism my way to improve my writing.

Final rating: 8.5/10 "Something for everyone inside."

Basically, if you get a bug, or something like a simple waypoint doesn't work... that's just the way the game is. Enjoy the disappointment after spending a few hours on a custom mission to find out that IF the AI helicopter takes of when it was supposed to it might refuse to recognize targets or just hover in place instead of droppng off your troops and landing somewhere as requested.

I have been disappointed with Bohemia Interactive in these regards since buying the game after it was already a few years old. It's just sloppy.

I've tried to play this several times over the last few years and stopped playing in frustration each time.  I just can't anymore.  

First, saved games in the single player campaign are routinely deleted.  From what I have read online this is by design; as in: the developers planned it this way.  If you are in the middle of a mission and save your game and then quit out, your saved game will be deleted and you'll need to start the mission over again the next time you play.  From wheat I read, it appears the only way to mitigate this is to manually make backups of your saved games while you are playing.  I suppose this means Alt-Tabbing out of the game and copying your saved games to a new folder each time you save?  This is just broken.

Secondly, sometimes, for some reason, all of your progress in the campaign will be deleted, and you'll need to start the entire campaign over again.  Fun, right?  There is a way to fool the game into thinking you've completed the entire campaign, which will let you restart or replay a mission, but any good gear you had found and kept with you in your now-deleted campaign will be gone.  You'll just have a default loadout.  Like, I lost my scope and extra first aid kits and had to go back to iron sights on a mission which included engagement with snipers.  And for those wondering, this just happened to me between when I played last night and when I played today, and the version of the game was not updated, so there's no way an update to the game did this.  (Yes, in the past game updates removed all previous game progress...)

Third, for some reason, the game obstinately refuses to retain any keybinding changes I make.  This means any time I start the game, I have to go back in and rebind all my keys again.  There have even been times where my keybindings have change [b] in the middle of a mission [/b] while I was playing.  I've also had other configurable options, such as screen resolution and audio settings, mysteriously change between play sessions with no warning.  I've never had these issues with other games in my 30 years of PC gaming.

As I said, I really want to like this game.  It's clear that, as a simulation, it's fantastic.  But my experience so far in the 20+ hours I've played is that I've become an expert in configuring my keybindings and have played the campaign's first eight or so missions at least four times now, due to constant deletion of my saved progress.  This just isn't enjoyable.

With all the incredible mods offered by a very active community, you are able to render nearly any conflict in the 20th century onward (not to mention a number of other fictional universes), and with enough time and patience learning how to use the Editor (where I've spent 99% of my 1600+ hours making the missions I want to play for myself, then sharing them back w/ the community), this is as close as you can get to a DIY tactical first-person shooter. I love reading about historical conflicts, then rendering them in Arma 3, researching the units, and getting creative with the tools to bring ideas to life. Mods like Faces of War, Unsung, and CUP offer expansive options for WW2, Vietnam, and the GWOT, respectively. If you enjoy building mechanics similar to Fallout 4, you will find scene-building in the Editor to be addictive. If you saw a photo of a modern combat zone only to realize it was actually a heavily-modded screenshot from this game, you will find yourself tumbling down the rabbit hole. My only complaint is that the AI can be a bit stiff, even with mods, when it comes to CQB and vehicle control. A small price to pay to be able to easily bring your game ideas to life and actually play/share them.

So, Arma 3 by Bohemia Interactive. . .

They develop software used to train modern military forces around the world. They also make some of the best war games you can find. Sure the controls aren't the best on the market, (some joke that you need a manual just to move your body) but they offer movement features you just can't find elsewhere. Turn your head without moving your rifle or body? Multiple stances of crouch to prone? Incremental leaning? Hip fire dead zone to move the weapon without turning? Check on all of these.

Multiplayer can be a blast, ranging from the ultra-serious military realists, to battleroyale type gameplay (the genre started as a mod of this game series). My personal preference is Wasteland (red team vs blue team vs green independents): Stores to purchase vehicles, aircraft, seacraft, weapons, gear, bodywear. Material gathering, base building, territory grabbing, generated missions. It's almost always a blast. (Some players are possess uncanny skills). Voice chat is well handled. Character mouths sync to VoIP, adding to immersion. Despite the aggressive attitudes (the game can indeed induce stress), most experienced players helpful and always willing to give advice or explain how something is done. 

Do not fear the VoIP. Although, you can be heard by nearby players when communicating. Be wary of chatter in combat situations. 

The graphics are better than what one would expect from most simulators, and hold up well given the course of time.
Given, buildings don't collapse as beautifully as Battlefield, and character and weapon animations aren't as fleshed out as CoD. What you give up from the Arcade, graphics driven game such as these, is a drop in the proverbial bucket compared to the immersive, realistic experience this Military Simulator has to offer. 

Audio isn't the greatest in the world, but it does attempt to echo and bounce off objects. Locating the source of gunfire in urban areas can be stressful and disorienting, while open area gunfire can be easily tracked. Explosions will rock you, and tank engines will drown out chatter. The game has an excellent audioscape overall, but the sfx isn't perfect,  some weapons just don't sound right from a distance. There are mods, however, that aim to fix this. Kudos to them, I'm all about the ultra-realism. 

AI is a mixed bag as well. They can see through bushes and leaves, etc. Sometimes, they have godly shooting skills, other times they get confused trying to cross a wooden fence row. Again, there are mods that significantly improve AI, some even possess unnerving levels of adaptation.

Single-player campaign has it's moments and helps teach you the ropes of the game's internal systems. It's worth playing through, at least until you feel confident with the bullet mechanics, movement and all else. There are tons of scenarios others have made, ranging from surgical covert ops missions, to chopper or jet sorties, to full on dynamic territory warfare modes. (Of the latter, i I have enjoyed many hours of game-play). 

This game is for those who feel constricted by the accepted norms of titles such as Call of Duty or Battlefield. Here, your kit carries weight and all you carry will slow you down and fatigue you. Being tired effects your accuracy and your ability to move properly. Your heavy breathing can also give your position away. Gear and stamina management are often challenging hurdles to new players. Many online servers forgo this system, the ADS while tired can be absurd. That being said, weapon resting/crouching is a thing and works on most objects, including tree branches. 

Day/Night and weather systems can sync to the location of the server, or being adjusted (like everything else) by server admins. Night play can be difficult. It is possible to navigate by the stars, if you know your constellations. Flares and tracers will mess with your night vision (if you have any). Yes, tracers do indeed work both ways. It is possible to load ammunition without tracers as well. Flying at night has it's risks as well. HUDs in aircraft do not track trajectory against forward geography well, so you can crash into mountains, if unfamiliar with the terrain. Lights on vehicles and craft can be toggled on and off, however. Engines can even be killed while in motion, so stealth that last 1km or so. 

Weather systems look great, but don't transition so well. Rain will affect driving conditions and heavy rain will affect vision. Lightning will totally give you away at night and gunshots can easily be masked with thunder.

Realistic projectile physics (I've seen flak cannon operators and spotters coordinate make-shift artillery, by doing the math, and fire into the sky bringing the rounds down, on target). The physics are realistic enough to make that possible. Wind is not a factor in vanilla gameplay, but there are mods that add this feature. 

Advanced Flight Physics (meaning you can stall and actually damage your engines, etc, overdoing things. I've seen pilots lands loaded transports without tail rotors (impressive). 

Location based damage. A powerful enough rifle and well placed sniper round can actually disable rotors and turrets. Knock the tracks off that tank, climb up, open the hatch and toss in a grenade. Watch jet pilots try to bail when spinning out because you blew their wing off. See where they land and hunt them mercilessly. 

Loot choice gear from the poor saps inside the wreck. Take prisoners of war and coerce information from them. Play a medic and drag wounded soldiers from the line of fire, then patch them up. Be an engineer and get that busted tank operational again. Sweep for mines, lay your own. Operate actual mortars and artillery. 

Want to operate a fleet of attack drones from 2km away from the target, while offering IR targets and AA support to friendly strike craft? You can. 

Want spend hours stalking through the forests in a Ghillie, sneaking and waiting for the perfect shot? Boobytrap structures to collapse? Mine roads and set ambushes? 

Crew a flight or tank crew with your friends. Even maintain logistical supply lines, by hauling the ammunition or fuel out into the field.

Coordinate with dozens of team-mates, and groups of friends, and feel a real sense of victory when you drive out the other team and achieve your own objective? Find it all here, folks.

Again, Arma 3 is an incredibly immersive experience. One that I keep coming back to, time and again for various reasons. Sometimes just to hop online and snipe with large guns at incredible ranges. I enjoy playing a sapper in multiplayer scenarios. Spotting traffic routes and distrupting them. Often I play just to enjoy the excellent flight model. No other game can offer the complete package of modern military immersion. Games like Battlefield are very enjoyable to, but they have never aspired to the kind of scale and realism I have found in the Arma series. I've tried to go back to CoD and Battlefield games and their likes. When I can't adjust the ironsight for range increments, I'm done. Seriously, I'm that spoiled on this game's features.

If the company doesn't all go down for war crimes or espionage, Arma 4 will be an instant buy for me. Bugs and all. 

By the way, my hours on record is a lie. I've spent far more time with the game not connected to the net.

Who is 98th Nova Corps:
98th Nova Corps is a unit that has its roots in US armed forces, focusing on a more serious environment, something akin to what you would see from a standard MilSim, while we are more serious, we do still strive to maintain stress levels for individuals. hard work, dedication and fresh idea are paid off in the 98th. We focus more on legitimate structure and military tactics in our trainings to maintain a standard through out the unit, 98th Nova Corps considers itself one of the more serious and "Hardcore" units in the StarSim community.

How we operate:
98th Nova Corps, while keeping in mind how StarSim is at its core different, is based on the US Army 75th Ranger Regiment. We instill a mater of mental discipline in order to maintain seriousness and quality among all of our troopers. Here everyone is expected to learn and comprehend everything needed to be successful trooper. everything from Machine Gunning, to Medicing,  to even land navigation.
While we not only teach all of these things through  classes and certifications, we also have our own version of Ranger School for individuals to test their knowledge and skills to elevate them into a much better trooper.

What does 98th Nova Corps offer?:
CERTS/MOS:
Anti-Tank/Air
Machine Gun
Demo
Grenadier
CQC (Close Quarters Combat)
Marksmen (Future)
Medic/CLS
RTO

SCHOOLS:
We offer a wide range of schools and classes everything from Leadership Courses to our previously mentioned Ranger School.

BRANCHES:
Line Infantry
Aviation

we do not have any detachments currently planned, however we are open to ideas in the future as we grow as a unit.

Where to find us:
If you are looking for that serious edge from a StarSim and any of the above interests you please be sure to join our discord to be recruited by one of our recruiters, and hop on the Teamspeak to be sure your recruitment is processed.

Discord: https://discord.gg/zKxnx6xXcc

Would I recommend ArmA 3? Well that depends. 

First things first the game is a "milsim" a military simulation so it is to be expected that if you've played shooters such as CoD or battlefield before and like the fast pacing you most likely wont enjoy ArmA. Though on the other hand if you are looking for something more realistic with huge maps and combined arms combat and actual military strategy ArmA has you covered.

Let's get the singleplayer out of the way. The singleplayer in ArmA 3 is ok, it will show you the basics and some bitch basic "strategic" know how. However the base game  campaign storyline is mediocre. it's not bad it's just not that good either, but that isn't really the point of ArmA.

Then we get to the multiplayer. The multiplayer is really the games bread and butter. It has basically everything there are less realistic game modes such as King of the hill and such, then there are more realistic ones like invade and annex. However if you want a true Milsim feel you should to join one of the milsim communities and join their OPs. Though the main thing about ArmA 3 MP is that depending on what you want play with the same sort of people. Want a true fullblown milsim join their group, wont be as easy but a LOT of fun once you get there. Want milsim content but at a less realistic level just find a group that does such OPs. If you want to fight as a resistance movement play Antistasi. There really isn't an OP type that isn't routinely ran by some group you just need to find said group. 

Another thing that is keeping ArmA alive after all these years is modding. No milsim community plays the base game. People push for more realism and scenario types so there are mods for that. The base game ArmA 3 is set in 2035 want an OP with modern day gear like M4s, AKs, T-72s and M1s try the RHS or CUP mods, want to go roll over the eastern front in Tigers, T-34s, or just as a normal rifleman try the Iron front mods, or perhaps vietnam, there is the unsung war mod for that. Even Sci-fi mods Excist such as Warhammer 40k, Halo, Star Wars and so forth. 

Also the most important form of mods in my opinion are the "Realism enhancing" ones like ACE or TFAR. ACE adds an enormous amount of thing to list a few an improved medical system with different medicine, bandage types and IV, it also completely reworks ballisticks to the level one would expect from say Sniper Elite with not just distance affecting bullets but also wind, temperature and air humidity. TFAR adds a new radio system that works through TeamSpeaks 3D audio. It makes basically all combat situations feel far more alive when its distance based how well you can hear others, or you have to communicate through radios.

Then the DLC. The DLC in ArmA 3 isn't required. Personally I haven't used most of the DLC assets even though I own them. I mostly utilize mod assets due to the zeus scenarios we run with our friend group. Also the way bohemia deals with DLC vehicles is also great. You can enter DLC vehicles as a passenger no problem so even if DLC vehicles are utilized it won't limit you getting a ride in them. 

TLDR: If you want a realistic milsim shooter and can put the effort of becoming a part of a milsim group and utilize mods you can have endless amounts of fun, however if you just want a shooter you can just open the server browser and join a game I would instead recommend squad.

Now this is the best military simulator I have ever played!

I love the environment and islands on which the scenarios take place. Nature looks amazing and I like to go on a patrol on my own and just walk around and enjoy the atmosphere. The detailed possible movement and stance variations (9!)  are great and that you can put down your weapon, when not in need. Also switching between two sight variations and different firing modes are nice. The inventory system is also great and gives a great variety in customization.

The campaign missions are mostly fun. I enjoy the general slow pace of the game: long walks or flights to the destinations and that the firefights are mostly fast, lowkey and unspectacular in comparison to other FPS titles. Radio chatter is also nice but some of the dialogues or scenes that take place in the campaign are not well written and the characters seem at times overly patriotic American or very childlike with simple mindsets, making condescending remarks about the quality of local military for example. At some points in the campaign it was not very clear how to use a certain device to complete a task (e.g. UAV) and one mission had to be skipped because of a mission breaking bug.

So it's not perfect. But the general engine and gameplay mechanics are amazing and complex and there are so many possibilities in this program.

Yes, I gave this game a thumbs down, but before I explain why, I should preface that the game design itself is not poor in any way, and is an exceptionally executed military combat simulator. 

My issue with this game is the tediousness amount of time it takes to set scenarios up. In the context of Arma's original usage, that is totally ok. But for non-military people, and casual gamers who want to just play an FPS game that doesn't overcomplicate things, this game can never be that for those people. 1) Multiple mods are already a base requirement for this game since the starting factions don't really do much, so rip people with low storage. 2) One player will always be relegated to the role of creating the scenario, which if they don't have the complete skill set to do, will result in long wait times. Another thing that doesn't help is the fact that modded scenarios don't save, so depending on how things work out, you may have to leave the game open and hope your computer doesn't crash (I have to verify this last point, because it may be innaccurate).

Ultimatley, the appeal of this game depends on what you are looking for. If you need to have the most accurate military simulation as your FPS game, then I totally recommend it. However, if after a long day of work, you want to sit down and get a quick gaming fix, this isn't the game for you.

There is something unique about Arma. Sure, other games have stuff like infantry combat, building clearing, tanks, APCs, UAVs flying above the battlefield, helicopters and planes striking ground targets and dueling it out in the air above you... but the main difference is: All those other battlefield elements are players too.
There are no killstreaks. You don't get an UAV above the area to scan for enemies because you just killed 3 people. You don't get to be the gunner of a gunship because you killed 15 people. Everyone has their role, and everyone works for that role. If you need an airstrike, you need to coordinate that with the people in the sky, same goes for artillery. If you want an UAV doing recon, you need someone to fly an UAV to the battlefield and do recon with it. And if you need ammunition, you need to call logistics to bring you the ammunition you need.

With mods, the game can drastically change. There are mods which turn this game into Star Wars, with blaster rifles and lightsabers. Other mods turn it into WW2. Others again turn it into Halo, or Vietnam, or whatever. Other mods again don't introduce new units, but instead make it more realistic, adding radios to the game where you need to set your frequency in order to talk to others on the same frequency. Yet another mod changes medical from "Apply First Aid Kit" to "Okay, he has 2 large avulsions, 1 puncture wound, he lost about two liters of blood, his heart stopped beating, and his airways are occluded. We need a medic over here!" And by combining multiple mods, you are creating your very own gaming experience, where you preferably play together with friends, or at least with those a**holes you can halfway tolerate for the next 2-3 hours to play the mission your Zeus prepared for you.

How can a game that prides itself in being a realistic military-shooter simulator be so immersive and precise while also being the buggiest shit I've ever played? Arma 3 allows users to create and share endless experiences, scenarios and missions that lets other users immerse themselves in combat and strategy. You can hop into the editor, spend an hour or two creating a base of operations and enemy encampments to raid and destroy, while also being able to share that experience with friends or the public. Its arguably the main reason that Arma 3 is so popular after all these years. While many servers are dedicated to military simulation, many others are all about simulating warfighting in some of the most popular video games and movies. Star Wars servers exist that allow you to join up with dozens of other clone troopers to take down the Separatists. Warhammer 40K servers are still up with plenty of space marines to praise the Emperor! There is no limit to the places you can bring war in Arma 3. 

With all that being said, this game can be buggy as hell. Small drones the size of watermelons tipping over artillery tanks. Planes blowing up on a clear runway with no obstacles. Getting stuck inside of rocks or containers. Many things can ruin the immersion of Arma 3 while you are playing.

Yet somehow this adds to the Arma-ness of the experience and has made many playsessions of mine more enjoyable and fun! Defending a small hole while being pounded by artillery and surrounded by enemies is already a fun and challenging experience. Then out of nowhere an AT squadmate pulls out his Vorona missile launcher and hits a T100 battle tank. The tank goes flying hundreds of yards in the air and we are all dying laughing while dying in game!

I would strongly recommend buying this absolute unit of a game. Make sure to get the "Apex edition" if you intend on going into multiplayer servers due to many of them requiring certain DLC's that the Apex version contains.

As a person who has at the moment put in 1k hours into Arma 3 I recommend it highly. Its a game that I've put so much time and effort into and the result is a community of people that can come together and have a good time. If you get this game, you should find a community to play it with. That's where it shines the most, whilst public games are okay; the extent at which you can play with a group of people is amazing. 

This game takes Combined Warfare to the max, in a single operation you can have squads of troops carrying out a mission whilst Aerial and Motorised groups support the ground troops, doing things like gunruns and convoys. Its insane how large the game can feel and how alive a single operation can feel when you have so many different people working together in different ways to accomplish one goal.

The infantry gameplay is extremely enjoyable, even if it takes a long time to learn all the keybinds. It has a steep learning curve, but if you can put in a couple hours to learn how to play you will reap thousands back in immersive gameplay.

Whilst not a game built around helicopters and planes, Bohemia has done an incredible job of making these vehicles extremely fun to fly and use. If you enjoy flying games, whilst not ultra realistic, it still gives an extremely fun time as you fly at insane speeds, pulling off incredible manourves or formation flying with friends.

The vehicle aspect of this game is i think very underlooked, the driving in this game feels really good and I love sitting in vehicles driving and hearing my gunner pop shots off at contacts. 

A lot of things in this game work so perfectly with eachother it creates a truly amazing experience and I have to say if you can get past the bugs and steep learning curve you will end up having a truly amazing time

Thank you too the devs for the continued support on this game and I look foward to Arma 4 ;)

Alright, real man talk - I have never played an ArmA game before.

Arma 3, where to start...

I think the best place to start, is the Basic Training or "Tutorial" that the game suggest upon you starting the game. This training will take you through the basics of Arma, the controls, how to read a map, and the mechanics of this military simulation. This then leads into a small "campaign", this will teach you the basics of combat and fearing for your life (In game), reacting to contact and the difficulties of engaging AI. 

This then leads into the main campaign, where you are a "Future Soldier", you experience the difficulties of combat and other various situations that give you an "Oh shit" kind of feeling. The campaign is long and sometimes tedious, but the missions are worth it, the experience and combat is great, commanding a fire team sized element to a squad sized team, is very useful when the situation can change in an instant. The campaign, is unforgiving into where you are unable to go back on a decision very easily, with every decision you make, resulting in victory or a mass casualty situation. Fantastic for single player people who wish to have that experience.

Public Multiplayer is a whole other situation. Multiplayer is difficult due to the Arma mechanics, its difficult to see people sometimes, and reacting to players who are more focused on a kill shot more then the suppression of an AI you might experience in the campaign. 

Ah, Milsim, where the Arma community shines. Milsim or Military Simulation, is something that is differently not for everyone. Milsim (Depending on the community) is where you will find the best communities as they are full of people who love the game, as well as people who are military enthusiast and or people who are active duty or retired. It takes time to wiggle your way into a unit (again, depending on the unit), but most units are fun, you enjoy playing with the same people, learning how to be leaders and to work together as a team making these communities friendship groups that can last for years to come.

What I love about Arma 3:
Arma 3, to me, isnt like any other game. It has its restrictions, but Arma is completely up to you. With little to no limitations other than the strength of your computer. You can do what you want in the game, You like planes/helos? You like tanks/APCs/IFVs? You like drones? You like tactics and acting like a commander to a larger unit? This game is for you. I can not stress this enough how much you can do in this game. With its vastly expansive Steam Workshop and other modding communities, it offers almost limitless opportunities. 

I hope this has helped you determine if you want to play this game and join the awesome communities it have to offer!

ArmA 3 can have an appeal to all types of military shooter players. If you enjoy more casual and arcade gameplay while also incorporating realism into it. Things like Official serves and groups who specialize in that type of gameplay will apply to you. If you want a hyper realism experience to immerse yourself in your game, there are private servers who do it every day. ArmA also has an extensive workshop to customize every single game to be a unique experience. From WW1 to Afghan+ the ArmA has it all.
