Arma 3 Vanilla and Modded - 7/10

Vanilla: 

The vanilla version of Arma 3 has a lot to offer, if you bought the DLCs; multiple campaign stories (some unique and some are bland). Overall the optimization is up to standard as it runs on 90 FPS with Ultra settings and 30-60 when there are a lot of vehicles or assets  in a particular mission.

The vanilla multiplayer is amazing if you have the right people, as it seems like a CODMW2 lobby with zero coordination if you go onto the Zeus, TDM, etc. with incompetent people. However, it has a lot to offer with the right people.

In conclusion, the vanilla version of Arma 3 has a lot to offer if you paid for DLCs (which is not a lot if on sale), and with the right people. The game is amazing, but has a lot to be desired in some areas, such as vehicles.

Modded: - 9/10

The modded game has a lot to offer with many great mods porting weapons, vehicles and terrain from Arma 2 and unique gameplay such as RHS (Red Hammer Studios). However, the optimization is abismal, as it requires modifications to the game; it pays off with an organized community to take role in missions that are top tier.

In conclusion, Arma 3 is a full package with or without mods and I highly recommend acquiring the game

Ok, so this is my finally update to this game/review.

So everyone claimed, that my pc was overheated. I did have battery problems.

But then, when I got my laptop repaired. I got back on it, re-downloaded steams and the Steamui.dll was damage and was a fatal error.

So then I went to my technician support, they claimed it was malware that cause the damage. I also get yearly check up. Idk when everyone does their check-ups but I do mind less often due to the fact I only visit websites I know.

So overall, Overheating, malware, and damage files all in one day of me playing this game. I find it very interesting that I claimed this game damage my pc. But everyone claimed it was overheating, yet a bunch of my files were damaged in the process, plus I got malware on the same day as my pc overheated. 

Now, I know coincidence is a thing. But when you get literally 2 completely different things effecting your pc. You start going, not coincidence.

So basically a 20 dollar game since it was on discount turned out to be nearly 500 dollars of repairs. Their goes 500 dollars of my bill for this month. Thanks arma 3.

So now, I am completely not trusting this game even if it free-to-play. I would not recommend new players to buy this game.

I also know laptops aren't that good then desktop. But my laptop cost me over 2.5k which is a very expensive gaming laptop. Alienware as well. Had this laptop for about not even 5 years yet.

The only reason my pc overheated was the helicopter part and the funny part is I have a few games with helicopters in it and more high graphic then this game plus I was playing on medium graphic to high before it all went down.

I also feel like I should get a compensation for this as well. But I know i'm not gonna get it cause someone just gonna make up some fake story relating everything being a domino effect. So just gonna avoid this companies games at all cost, even if it hits console.

So lastly my conclusion to this game is, Is that it could be compromised to new player who buy the game. So I warn the new players.

I would say I had bad luck at the very neno-second before everything went down. But I am doubting it a lot.

For the people who try'd to change my mind. Thanks for trying. But this game and the company is now my black-list of companies/games not to trust.

I'll just stick to the youtube videos of this game. But until they fix this or compensate me for this. No chance I am ever coming back to this at all. Not asking for a million dollars. Just asking for the money I spent on repairs alone. I don't care for the taxes. Just on the main payment I paid for the visit of the repair store, the repair cost, and the technician. Until then. Good bye and Avoiding this game at all cost.

As a person who has at the moment put in 1.5k hours into Arma 3 I recommend it highly. Its a game that I've put so much time and effort into and the result is a community of people that can come together and have a good time. If you get this game, you should find a community to play it with. That's where it shines the most, whilst public games are okay; the extent at which you can play with a group of people is amazing. 

This game takes Combined Warfare to the max, in a single operation you can have squads of troops carrying out a mission whilst Aerial and Motorised groups support the ground troops, doing things like gunruns and convoys. Its insane how large the game can feel and how alive a single operation can feel when you have so many different people working together in different ways to accomplish one goal.

The infantry gameplay is extremely enjoyable, even if it takes a long time to learn all the keybinds. It has a steep learning curve, but if you can put in a couple hours to learn how to play you will reap thousands back in immersive gameplay.

Whilst not a game built around helicopters and planes, Bohemia has done an incredible job of making these vehicles extremely fun to fly and use. If you enjoy flying games, whilst not ultra realistic, it still gives an extremely fun time as you fly at insane speeds, pulling off incredible manourves or formation flying with friends.

The vehicle aspect of this game is i think very underlooked, the driving in this game feels really good and I love sitting in vehicles driving and hearing my gunner pop shots off at contacts. 

A lot of things in this game work so perfectly with eachother it creates a truly amazing experience and I have to say if you can get past the bugs and steep learning curve you will end up having a truly amazing time

Thank you too the devs for the continued support on this game and I look foward to Arma 4 ;)

ArmA 3 is a versatile game, a great jankfest. The base-game is entirely fine on it's own two legs. ArmA has a campaign, which while janky at times (it can be broken due to the nature of the game) is stellar. It manages to educate you on the basics of the game. 

But the true gem of ArmA lies in the modding scene, and the operations. They've added revolutionary new features such as:
Jumping, turning on your safety, radio interference, a million different guns, food system, the ability to carry boxes (though in a janky way), women and a stupidly complex medical system. 

While ArmA on it's own simulates wind speed and air density and every little detail which has a factor on ballistics, the community has added so much that ArmA now can be played as anything from a janky zombie survival game, to a full military simulator with different units co-ordinating and doing different roles. 

The best thing, though. That's the ability to spend 4 hours driving a truck carrying imaginary guns to people, only to slightly overcompensate in a turn and hit a tree pulverizing your leg.

The multiplayer game modes are a slog. The engine is lacking many functions one would expect from an RPG, where those modes are concerned. PVP modes are generally grinds just to unlock the access to gear and vehicles. King of the Hill is the most popular mode, but it would take literal days and days of playing just to level up and gain access to higher end gear that most of the dedicated players already have, which is a drag as you will constantly be killed by things you cannot access (weapons, vehicles, even just optics take days of playtime to unlock). The only redeeming mode, in my opinion, is Warlords, where you can order troops and gear and play out a small campaign in real time. However, even that mode was only fun for a couple hours before the novelty wore off. Bottom line, it's just hard to have fun in this game. You can, but it's more work than it's worth to me.

I highly recommend Arma 3 because of its realism and gameplay. The campaign can feel like driving and walking simulator 2010, but co-op missions are really engaging and realistic. Arma 3 is a game that takes up a lot of processing power, so I suggest not using a Dell laptop with 4 gb of ram. I run on lowest settings with a decent graphics card and 16gb of ram. Everything runs smoothly. This is not a game like COD. Eg. If you get shot in the leg, then you will be limping. If you get shot in the arm, then your aim will greatly suffer. You will slowly bleed out without using a medkit, and with the proper mods that are common in ‚Äúunits‚Äù (ACE [Medical]), you have to apply tourniquets to stop bleeding on your limbs. You may also have to use epinephrine and morphine to stabilize someones heart rate. These common mods and realistic gameplay make the game really detailed and as realistic it can be. Even things like proximity chat and different Radio frequencies set Arma 3 apart from every other game. To sum it up, if you don‚Äôt like the campaign, then don‚Äôt refund the game. If you still dont like the multiplayer and co-op missions, then go ahead. Arma 3 can have players with thousands of hours on the game that laugh at you. Just remember that everyone was where you were, and it may take real combat training to get into the fight.

[h1] 9/10, but it depends on your POV [/h1]
There are two ways to review this game:
Those who play it by themselves, and those who play with friends/Milsim Units

[b] BEFORE YOU TRY AND LEARN THE CONTROLS, FOR ANYONE: [/b]
Play the virtual lab trainings for said area. As a high ranking pilot for a unit, I know from experience that it helps a lot (Atleast the flight ones do).

TL;DR at end
[h1] For those who play alone (FYI its super simple to join a unit, and a lot of fun) [/h1]
The isn't much to do. The campaign is poor because the AI is either horrendous or has literal aimbot. Although it is interesting, the AI makes it a bad experience. You can fool around in Eden Editor/Zeus and explore the absurd(-ly good) amount of things in the game, but it is made more for those hosting a game for other people, and for running operations (in units).

[h1] For those who want to play with others [/h1]
Holy goddamn, it is insane what this game can achieve. Although very outdated, modpacks (usually bigger than the game itself, storage and size-wise) come to the rescue. Want to fight in WWII? Done. Want to fight in a StarWars military? Done. Want to fight for ____ Nation? What about ____ age? How about specific mods for those little things you want? The options are nearly endless. If you want to join a unit, it is extremely simple and can be very fun, no matter your role. If you want to play with your friends, someone will have to host the server and be Zeus to control the AI. Just note that Zeus is very complex, so it will take getting used to.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
It is more orientated toward the Milsim Unit community than solo players, it is outdated but mods more than make up for it, and its complexity may be daunting at first but you will understand it once you really get into it. Great Milsim game, can't wait for Arma 4.

Edit: Now that I've played this game for 70+ hours, I can describe it better, the game is very well optimized, you don't need a gigantic PC to run it as I run it on my laptop that I use for work, my is the AMD A4-9125 and I can run it at 40 FPS max in some areas with low graphics, in places like cities I can get 10-28 FPS which I can still play very well in. The game allows you to destroy pretty much every house or building you can find. The vanilla medical system is pretty simple but if you wanna go for a more complex system, download the ACE3 mod from the workshop, it completely changes the medical system and a bunch of other aspects of the game. The launcher has a mods tab where you can make presets so that when you join a server you don't have to go through the pain of disabling mods that a server doesn't allow every time you want to join a server. You can also host your own server like in Garry's Mod, except for Arma you need UPnP if you don't want to set it up manually, most routers have UPnP on them so you won't have to go out and buy a new router, and if your router doesn't have UPnP, you can still do it manually and you can also still join your friends! 


 The combat, oooh the combat, you will have the greatest time of your life in the combat, from fighting the AFRF (Armed Forces of the Russian Federation) to the CSAT (Canton Protocol Strategic Alliance Treaty) to normal civilians that turn hostile against you if you point your gun at them too many times to committing war crimes. There is so much fun to have in the combat, the suppression actually works because you really don't want to die or get wounded and run out of medical supplies, the frag grenades actually have fragmentation instead of most games where they turn into HE (High Explosive) grenades, smoke grenades actually blow with the wind and create a smoke screen, so if you mess up that smoke grenade throw then you'll just have to go with it unless you have more.


Ballistics, the ballistics are great, bullet drop is a thing meaning you have to use the notches below the reticle of your magnification sight, bullets can penetrate meaning you are never safe in that outhouse made out of wood or plastic. Velocity also affects your bullet's penetration ability, meaning if you're at 400m+ then your bullet might not be going through that outhouse containing that one Russian soldier who needs to take big crap. The audio is amazing, the guns, the helicopters, the cars, the tanks, the jets, they all just sound so great, and you can download a mod called JSRS Sound Mod to overhaul the sounds to make them sound even better (not that they aren't already amazing). The flying is perfect, it's not too complex and it's not too simple, if you've played GTA 5 on PC then you'll know the struggle of having to hold LMB to fly, that struggle is gone with Arma, you can even change the game's flight model in the settings, the game is also joystick compatible meaning you can make it even more complex if you want to (check out OperatorDrewski's video on youtube for his setup). The AI is great, the AI actually uses cover and suppresses enemies so that you can get a better position on that civilian that just wanted to have a nerf gun fight. The AI can actually die in the story missions, so you can't just sit back and relax while the AI does all the work, but it is very rare that the AI will die, so you're not constantly struggling to keep the AI alive.


The customization is amazing, there is so much that you can do, from being in your boxers and your bed shirt to being a literal moving ammo box, you can customize so much, and your weight affects your stamina and slows you down if you carry too much, so if you try to carry those 64 TNT blocks, you're not going any where very fast. The size of items affects your backpack space, so if you're trying to be the portable gunsmith then you'll only be able to carry a few rifles and maybe 10 pistols depending on the size and space the backpack has.


The planes are amazing, you have a literal A-10 at your disposal (A-10D Thunderbolt II), an armed drone, a fighter jet that I can't remember the name of and a lot more. The CUP mods add a bunch of things from Arma 2 like helicopters, jets, drones, cars, guns, uniforms, vests, helmets, backpacks, grenade launchers, rocket launchers, grenades, smoke grenades, and a lot more.


There is a lot more to describe but I am running out of time as I have yet to complete my work, so I shall stop here and possibly return to this review another day.

I was from the era of Arma 2, the feeling back then was that everything had a more darker tone, slow paced. Arma 3 took a sharp turn on that, it evolved, created new mechanics, making the game more acessable even for fast paced players. But it was a well made turn, not abandoning the folks from the past, but also accomodating new players.

Arma 3 has a surreal feeling of freedom done well, me being a mission creator, besides the harsh times scripting and etc, all the bad times go away, as soon as i see my creation come to life, seeing unscripted scenes where you see the bomb dropping near you, or a high speed chase with a AI, a duel with a enemy sniper or a tank approaching you from the tress, knowing that only the scripted parts we're the briefings or the AI telling something. The sandbox experience that besides the linear story you build, will always play different, because of the AI and enviroment combined. And that feeling at the end that you accomplished all tasks without dying, and knowing that you dont have any plot armour imunity. Your not someone special, you're no hero, you're just a goom, and that adds more value to your deed than a game that keeps presenting all the choices or giving the player this imense plot armour.

Arma 3 is not your typical shooter, one bullet can and will end your game prematurely if you dont use your head. Planing ahead, using the surroundings, knowing the enemy and the're weapons is just a basic strategy to turn the tide of the battle in your favour. The feeling that everything worked, because you and your team had coordenation is something that you can only experience playing. Unfortunately in every game, players manage to ruin it somehow. If you seek a fast paced game, where you spawn 5 meters from the enemy, kill him, and then die by another dude spawning above you, them this game is not meant for you. But sure enough, people in this category appear here and there to ruin the fun, rushing, screaming, glitching and acting like a five year old.

Talking about glitches, the most common glitch ive seen, we¬¥re the vehicle physics, where if you bump a sedan into a armoured tank, the armoured tank would fly away like paper. But Bohemia Interactive seems to doenst really care about it, its been years since and they not even started to fix it. Instead, they keep launching DLC's, salty priced DLC's that sometimes are just priced mods from other creators.

About mods, some of them make the game perfect, i play around with 16 or more mods, most of them we're ACE sorts. ACE can make the game more realistic, adding hunger, thirsty, fatigue and a cool medical system, that make you always carry around medical items. Whats more cool about it is that you can edit these and other more options however you like, and make the experience better for you or for you're friends if you are playing in a LAN server.

Not the best-optimized shooter you'll find out there, but the amount of freedom is amazing. Lots of very well made community-content adds to an ever changing experience.

After over 1600 hours of playtime, and working on 7 years now of ownership, I feel its safe to say I like this game. 

This game to me, is like a gigantic tub of Lego, with a couple of pre-built sets on the side to serve as example. The pre-built sets are the vanilla features of the game, the campaign, scenarios, maps, and everything else in between, they function well enough, and offer A LOT of fun just by themselves. The gigantic tub of Lego is the modding community, a huge beautiful melting pot of mods that quite literally change every single aspect of the game. With mods ranging from factions, WW2 content, equipment overhauls, and hundreds of quality player made missions, all the way to crazy sh*t like Halo, Warhammer 40k, and Star wars. On top of the crazy mod selection, most of the aforementioned mods have active and welcoming online communities, that are always eagerly looking for newcomers to join their ranks. I really cannot emphasize enough just how many mods there are, and how diverse the mod scene is for this game. 

If you get this game and somehow play through the hundreds upon hundreds of hours worth of content in the workshop, or you begin to grow bored with game, then this game makes for a great game to forget about for a little bit, to then check up on later to be wowed by what other crazy and new mods people made while you were away. On top of all of this, the game frequently goes on sale, so go ahead, don't be shy, your magnificent tub of Lego awaits you.

Just go buy Squad. You'll have more fun, and spend less money. The Youtubers that play this game arent showing you the hundreds of hours of playing and planning that goes on behind the scenes, let alone the hundreds of dollars they put into this broken game. You're not going to be this "Cool Spec Ops Navy Seal" dude, you'll be a stupid looking character that has no customization available for it, very small amount of guns to use, and be waiting an hour just to gain up CP (Currency in one of the shitty game modes) just to buy a helicopter that gets one tapped by a sniper sitting in a bush.

This was my opinion a couple months ago, things have changed. There are certain things after extended time playing I have come to enjoy. Still, the amount of money you have to spend, the amount of mods, and the preparation itself is still a big downside, but if you can find something you like to do, for example you can make entire battles, fly jets, drive tanks, etc in the sandbox world edit in this game, as long as you have some of the DLC you can use most of the things here. You still need to pay for access to a couple of guns and a ghillie suit but I bought everything, which is mostly my reasoning for rewriting this review. If you are willing to spend time here, good for you, this is what you're gonna want to buy. If you want something like a tactical mil-sim that is gonna be easy to get into, this is not it, you're probably looking for Squad.

This game angers more than one can imagine. I have friends who think this is the best shooter game out there but I have always begged to differ. So since one of them bought me it to play with them. I will leave my review after playing a few games of it.

Main reason of my anger.

The base game is a total mess. Everything from controls, movement, gun play, bugs, the amount it throws its expensive DLCs down your throat, just annoys me.

This game has been out for a long time (2013) and comes as part of a series of releases that follow the same formula of Operation Flashpoint (2001). In my mind, the series of games have not progressed technically at all in almost 20 years where other games have. 

Lets focus on controls for a moment. This game has the most over-complicated controls ever put into a game. There would be no way this could be released on to a console because its so pointlessly complicated. Here are some examples 

1) Default controls do not allow you to look down a sight if you have a more complicated sight setup. Instead, you must press two other keys (at the same time) to "toggle" sight you want (without any feedback of your toggle), then click the mouse slightly to achieve what you wanted. This IS stupid. I launched Insurgency Sandstorm straight after playing this and it was easy and very intuitive in comparison. I launched Call of Duty (although I dont much like it, I do play it on occasion with the lads), the same, very simple to play. Just because something is realistic, doesn't mean it should require a qualification in menus and commands to play it.

2) There is absolutely no climb / vault system in the game (without mods). Instead there is this VERY VERY POOR "step over" animation that usually just moves you slightly into the model you are trying to jump over. That is AWFUL for a AAA game that has been out for 7/8 years and follows on from a series to be improved on. There are literally 3 mods which fix this and add more, so why cant the AAA devs do it?!

3) Movement through buildings / stairs is AWFUL, you stick to walls, you cant climb steps (usually because they are taller than a human body!), you get stuck in doorways. Again, AAA game, that hasn't got the fundamentals right.

DLC issue:
- This game now pretty much throws DLC in your face ALL of the time. So much so, you could play a scenario, try to pick up a weapon and it says "this weapon requires a DLC, press P to purchase now!". After you finish the scenario, it tells you AGAIN "you used this content, purchase now!". I got an idea guys, how about your improve the base game? Then I might think about paying for some DLC.

Pros (for balance):
- The modding community make this game a seller, without it, it would tank, get reviews of 2/10 and nobody would play it
- The expanse of the maps is astonishing and suit vehicles very well
- Realism is great and a very rare sight to see in 2020/2021

Arma 3

Graphics (9 of 10):  An amazing simulation, I love flying across coastal areas and low over forests bringing troops in.  The virtual cockpits, terrain, and water detail are wonderful.  Everything from underwater life to hopping bunnies, the detail is stunning.

Ease of Learning (7 of 10):  The basic tutorials are quite good and walk you through essentials of game play.  There's only one area I find very difficult to learn and that's just learning to spot enemy.  All I can say is don't rush and take your time to scan while moving cover to cover.

Audio (8 of 10):  Sounds are realistically simulated.  As much as I hate wearing headphones I always use them for Arma 3 so that I can get the benefits of stereo to localize enemy fire.

Stability (8 of 10):  Arma 3 occasionally glitches, mostly in game glitches and inconsistencies rather than outright crashes.  Interface or visual defects were the most common, but getting stuck under terrain, or other crippling problems do happen from time to time.  Usually simple to fix.

Fun (8 of 10):  Arma 3 for solo play is poor for anything but learning and practicing, but if you have or take the time to find a good community it can be great.  It is however a simulation, do not expect non-stop intense action.  If spending time finding a good group is not your thing do not buy this game, without a group to play with and help you through the glitchier parts this game is not worth it.

Customization (10 of 10):  Whether you want to write your own mods (extensive scripting is supported and well documented) or just use one of tens of thousands of premade mods and missions this community is stunning.

Overall (8.5 of 10):  A great game if you want a simulation and are willing to find a good group.  I found the APEX, Jets, Marksman, Tanks, Helicopters, and Laws of War DLC to be essential.

This game has had so much potensial and has provided so many great moments that I'll never forget.
A few years from now, Arma was a mod installation and crash simulator. 
We would spend a whole evening just problemsolving issues and then at the end, when 80% of the players had given up trying, we FINALLY got to start our session, got spend 1 hour traversing to the area of operation. 
We would sneak up, scouting and marking enemy positions, planning our attack in detail aaand it crashed..

Today Arma has evoled alot. Correction: The mod community has made mods that makes the game so enjoyable that there is simply no experience like it anywhere.
With the right combination of AI mods you can make the AI very convinsing and allmost humanlike at times!
Some mods are improving sound, immersion, functionality... Just everything turns from a dull and boring experience to a shining gem of a game!
However... without a community or someone that knows how to implement the mods, it will take a loong time to figure out how to implement the mods. 
If you are not willing to spend 1k hours just learning how to set up a server with mods, I suggest joning a community for the optimal experience for arma.
And also: make sure you join the right type of community, as each one is having their own empasis on gameplay: Some are realism based, milsim based and some are just about pure fun. 
Personally I think this game is the ultimate milsim, where you get a very complete feeling of realsm and immersion to a level where you s**t your pants when the firefight starts. 

The game also has a VERY steep learning curve. 
In order to play it properly, you'll have to learn a ton of keybindings.
But this is also the cool part. You'll have more control than in other shooters.
In short: you can pretty much do most of the things you could IRL from movement to weapons functionality.
This is more like a simulation than anything else, so If you expect a pure action shooter, go somewhere else. 

At the and I would say this:  "Arma is hard to love, but once you get to know it, it is loved too hard". 

Here is my verdict (with great mods)
Graphics: 8/10 
Sound: 8 (JSRS sound mod)
Gameplay: 9/10
UI: 6 /10
AI: 8/10

this game runs on an engine so clunky and handed-down, it makes gamebryo 2 from 10 years ago look like cutting edge technology. Gameplay has poor pacing for something so focused around military life. A lot of actions and things take forever to do. Movement is ridiculous in how its handled, and the simplest actions can become complex chores during gameplay due to the overload of keys and their functions. Since so much is also handled through a scroll down, real-time, interaction menu, this further complicates things. Furthermore, the actual menus and design of Arma 3 is confusing to people who aren't as knowledgable about Game networking. I remember spending hours on a Malden scenario, only to find out I couldnt seem to host a game for me and my friend to play together, because of how ridiculously confusing the multiplayer gaming seems to be. There are so many minor quirks and problems in just the moment-to-moment flow of Arma 3 that greatly impede its enjoyability. Compared to the flow of movement and combat in other, modern strategic shooters and milsims(Rising Storm 2, Squad, Beyond the Wire, Post Scriptum), Arma 3 is like 50 feet below the bottom of the barrel.  This movement is outdated and feels like something from 2003 rather than 2013.

Game is also a bit of a dlc-hog. There is a lot of cool equipment and stuff in Arma 3, but so much of it is behind paywalls for miniature DLCs to access more cool equipment and maps. 

However, the game is still plenty fun. The reason my review is so negative, however, is because there is so much potential in this formula if the code of the Arma franchise were to be changed fundamentally to perhaps come away from modability, but a lot more towards creating a fluid, challenging, and enjoyable milsim. I understand the clunkiness of the movement is only partially due to the hand-me-down code, and is mostly because Bohemia Interactive wishes to retain Arma's modding reputation, but its more important to have a fun game that people can buy and play than it is to have a dull game people can buy, mod, and then have fun with after 20 quality-of-life mods are installed.

Arma 3 is a very entertaining game. The multiplayer is very lively, and the campaign is fun (albeit having to run a marathon to every objective). The game does have it's flaws though, there are a lot of keybinds and commands to remember, as well as other parts of the controls that are not explicitly identified. The campaign, enjoyable as it is, also sometimes feels a bit confusing: the missions are laid out in multiple different ways and the objectives to complete are sometimes quite a challenge, particularly Signal Lost, where you are quite literally up against an entire army with a pistol. The multiplayer can also be confusing at times for new players, especially with the players and units that take the simulator roleplay to the max and use proper military codes and call-signs. But playing games of Zeus and King of the Hill are very enjoyable, rushing straight into combat and having to use tactics instead of just: 'shoot shoot bad guy'. Overall, the game is extremely fun once you get to grips with it, but may take some getting used to with new players. I'd give it a solid 8/10.

To be clear, I think there is an audience out there for this game and there are reasons that some people would want to pick this up. I'll outline the reasons someone would like to pick up this game later in my review. That said, I think the average person that hears about ARMA and only wants some multiplayer shooter vaguely grounded in realism isn't going to enjoy this game.

The critical part of the review:

This game *is* realistic. It is a civilian spin off of a simulation software that the US Armed Forces uses for training. But because of that, it runs into the same problems as almost anything else sold to the US Armed Forces. 

Performance wise, it feels like $37 dollar screws the game.  Despite being released in 2013, on low settings with a Ryzen 7 CPU and a GTX 1070 my frame rate will hover around 30-40 in cities. The gameplay isn't that fast paced, so you don't *need* to hit the 60fps mark to be competitive, but it's still fairly disappointing that I need to run an 8 year old game on low settings when I can still play most current games at 1080p 60hz no problem. Outisde of cities, the game runs much better, but it is impractical to change your performance settings every time you enter or leave a city, and the game's art direction doesn't lend itself to looking pretty at low settings. Even with higher graphics, several of the animations (even in single player) look buggy and take you out of the experience.

Gameplay wise, it spares no expense for realism. Advertising materials brag about how bullets that hit your gun will deflect off of it and there being a multitude of stances/poses you can do in game to give yourself the best tactical advantage. However, sparking no expense includes no expense for UX. Interacting with things by default is done with the space bar, and interaction opens up a menu that you then need to navigate and select what you want to do, even if there's one option. To get over short obstacles, you press 'v'. You can't really 'jump' (which may or may not be realistic given how heavy the gear soldiers get irl is). Aiming down sights by default is toggle, and I had to look up a guide to figure out how to change it to the industry standard hold. Doing anything more complicated than your basic movement, interaction, shooting, and reloading feels clunky and you probably won't want to attempt any thing unless you know you aren't under fire. As for game flow, on the single player campaigns and on most military simulation servers, there's a lot of realistic down time where you aren't really doing anything, and a lot of realistic times you try your hardest to check your surroundings to make sure everything is clear, move forward, and get shot by someone too far away to see clearly.

Also some gear is hidden behind DLC. This isn't that big of a problem in multiplayer, the only DLC that splits the multiplayer community is whether or not you have the Tanoa map, otherwise you can still join servers, just can't use the DLC items. However, just be aware that you aren't getting access to everything when you purchase the main game

The part where I praise ARMA:

With all of the complaints above, there are some things I found ARMA did well. I would recommend ARMA if these features specifically sound worth dealing with the frustrations I listed above to you.

The biggest draw by far is the community content. 

The game has a very powerful built in scenario editor. I've seen many creative things done with this, including a remake of CoD: Modern Warfare in game. 

The game also has very strong modding support and and active modding community. Mods can add new weapons, reskin existing things, give you new maps, let you download custom scenarios, script entirely new mechanics etc. Looking at the workshop tab right now, there's an entire Clone Wars mod that straight up adds blasters, light sabers, total faction overhauls, etc..

Servers can use a combination of these mods and scenarios to crate new modes of gameplay. ARMA 2 gave birth to DayZ and PUBG with this process, and ARMA 3 has it's own active set of custom servers that include not just zombies and BR's, but city life RP servers, warlord servers, and probably a tonne of other new gamemodes that I don't know about. 

And also there's single player. If you are anti social and don't want to communicate with other people, there is a built in single player campaign and several others you can download off the workshop.

Conclusion:

What I wanted out of this game was a smooth playing multiplayer shooter with large battles that is loosely grounded in realism, BUT will make sacrifices for the sake of gameplay. This game isn't it. If that's what you're here for, which I suspect many people looking at this store page are, I would strongly recommend looking at Squad instead. I don't have the money to buy it because I'm unemployed and pandemic, but everything I've seen of Squad on Youtube is exactly what I was hoping to get out of ARMA. 

If you want 26 page standardized brownie recipe levels of realism, this is the game you want.

If you want to see what new wacky/amazing thing the community made in the sandbox, or want to try the sandbox out for yourself, this is the game you want.

If you just want a polished experience that is more realistic than CoD/Battlefield but will make some sacrifices for the sake of user experience, consider looking into Squad instead.

So I have 5,000 hours in game now and figured it would be about time to write up a review. This is probably my favorite game based on sheer playtime. Even though Arma III has been out some ~8 years now, it offers a lot for anyone. If you like ground combat you can focus solely on that. if you like flying (that is me) you can just spend countless hours online or offline dropping ordnance and dogfighting. I highly recommend HOTAS flight controls though. And TRACK IR to really get the full experience and immerse yourself in world. If you are worried about getting involved with the game because of its many keyboard controls, don't worry. They come to you with play time. Just don;t think you can jump immediately online and play in PVP servers without even having done the tutorial. (Stares in disgust at all that do this!) Seriously do the fucking tutorial and a few missions of the campaigns to get acquainted with the game! The editor is one aspect I think a lot of people forget to really talk about. If you take some time, you can make some pretty cool missions. This game is great for those who play offline SP because of the editor. You can play the game by just making bases if that suits you. Treat the editor as a world builder for model military bases. But if you need me to endorse this game, then yes, get it. Sure, there are weird collision physics with tank going flying because they hit a parked car sometimes.... and dead bodies will magically float and twitch.... but past all that this game keeps on because it is at its core a decent time every time you sit down and fire it up. Arma is anything you make it. Sandbox, flight sim, roleplay, and so much more.

ARMA 3, which should be known as Asthma 3, is what you will quickly come to understand when you first encounter the hellish stamina system designed for infantry combat. Infantry combat being one of the core and largest aspects of the game. If it wasn't already bad enough to deal with heavy breathing and weapon sway, being wounded makes you wish you were KIA instead.

Those who play ARMA 3 and offer it positive reviews will often fail to mention how heavily modified the game has become over the years in order to enjoy it. Even if you do not personally use mods, you will often encounter server-side mods as hosted by the server you're on to make the experience palpable. The most commonly implemented server-side mod is designed to disable the original infantry stamina system entirely.

One of the largest failures from Bohemia Interactive was their shift towards a "futuristic" representation of warfare for ARMA 3. This includes some absurdly bogus and fictional representations of equipment and vehicles which will take time for you to recognize. ARMA 2 was likely the peak representation of what ARMA's "Military Simulation" experience meant, even with the limitations thereof at the time.

Ironically, if you look up mods for ARMA 3, you will ultimately find a plethora of mods that make an attempt to "revert" the game back into a more "modernized" and "current" version of military equipment and vehicles akin to ARMA 2. Perhaps Bohemia Interactive would be wise to acknowledge the intentions of their player-base that regularly struggle with mods, just to put the game back the way "it should have been".

Perhaps they will pay attention to mods such as the ACRE mod, allowing for more realistic military radio communication with simulated static and keyed-mic sounds. While also including an "advanced" medical system akin to the ACE mod.

One can only hope that Bohemia Interactive takes all the handy features and ballistics of ARMA 3, while incorporating the weaponry and vehicles of ARMA 2, in hopes to ultimately develop the foundation of what could make ARMA 4 the best game of the entire series. That is... If they dare to sell basic vehicles as a "DLC" for a second time...

Realism -is- what people expect from a "military simulator". Not futuristic. Pay attention Bohemia Interactive.

A great idea, but poor execution. It theoretically has all the components needed for gestalt but the final product remains elusive. At the end of the day it remains more of a military simulation framework, where signification modifications are needed for the actual simulation. Any end user experience is blemished by the clunky animations and boring atmosphere that appear to warrant only minimal graphical power, yet for some enigmatic reason the game runs as if it were optimized by a sophomore in college-- requiring beefy hardware and delivering single-threaded low FPS. Beyond the terrible experience of the game, and ignoring the cold unfriendly feeling it gives you, Arma fails to deliver even the basics of game-play. After finishing a hastily-completed-then-sold DLC, the player is left wanting. One may venture to the multiplayer tab expecting long-term game-play, only to be left with no fun server experience and a dreadful selection of public servers. They are wrought with low activity, strict rule-sets, and boring bits punctuated (read: adulterated) with the most basic of minimal realism and a few stray bullets-- good luck getting that revive!

Maybe Arma could be good, if they actually made the game.

If you want a game where you go on perfectly scripted missions, run around like a madman, and destroy enemies by the thousands, then this isn't the game for you. BUT if you enjoyed games like Ghost Recon and Rainbow Six and want to play a hardcore military simulation with one of the most brilliant communities in existence, then GET THIS GAME. ArmA 3 is demanding, but beautiful. The maps are insanely large. There are hundreds of weapons and vehicles to experiment with. The campaign is enjoyable, but also very difficult. The online community is full of helpful people who can help teach you the basics of the complicated systems. Then there's the mods. OH LORD the mods! Ever wanted to pit space marines from 40k against a Russian armored battalion? Now you can! The editor alone will provide you with hours of entertainment. Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy of this game.

If you like the realism aspect of war games then arma is for you, although be warned the realism factor makes the game hard too, it is kinda like the dark souls of tactical combat games.
While other war games try to make you feel euphoric, arma also manages to give you that strange feeling of gratitude that you are not actually there because people die in armed conflicts and sometimes you won't even know what hit you.
The engine has its limitations so some newer games sometimes may excel in some areas but to this day i have not seen anything that comes close to the overall feature package of arma, there are people who have spent hundreds of hours ingame and still haven't explored half of the functionality and possibilities. 
The mission editor is a (sometimes frustrating) beauty in itself and allows you to use the game as a virtual military sandbox.

A hazy cloud of fog had slipped over the ground, condensing possible footsteps and tracks of the enemy army. Its the middle of the night, my team of over ten Spec Ops people were with me and were relying on me, not only to win this war, but save their life. We hear loud sounds nearby. [i] CRACK! [/i] A twig snaps. I order to ready fire but not to shoot. [i ]CRUNCH! [/i] It gets closer. A few seconds later its right by us. I order my men to fire. It attacks back, its not an enemy army after all, its a bear. The bear takes out two men and we manage to wound the bear. However our two soldiers' injuries are fatal. They tell us to go on and take out the enemy. We continue to walk for what seemed like an eternity. We eventually reach the enemy compound and notice that there are quite a few snipers on guard, if we don't sneak past them, its mission over. We slowly creep and crawl our way into the compound, silently taking out any people that might see us. We get to main vault room and prepare to extract the enemy plans, our mission all along. We get the safe open and steal the plans. An alarm goes off. We had set off an alarm. Enemy soldiers rush in to see what the commotion is. Its either kill or be killed. I order my men to shoot. However, because of our shock our men were a little bit slow to shoot, resulting in a mostly dead troop. Me and three other soldiers are left standing in a bloodbath of our former friends. The enemy starts to flank us from the other entrance. One of my men knows there is no way out, and he takes his life. Its just down to me and two other guys. The enemies throw in a grenade and it explodes, knocking both of my men unconscious. I immediately run to the nearest spot I can hide. The enemy grabs both of my men and pick them up, presumably to take the prisoner. The remaining enemy troops continue to search for me. I have to escape this compound or I die, but there was way too many enemy troops. I sacrifice my AK-47, throwing it as far as possible to create a distraction.   They quickly move towards the sound and I go as fast as I can to the nearest exit. I get away as far as possible from the compound. I make it to the nearby forest and camp there for the rest of the night. I set up camp and wait out the night, thinking about how I was most likely the only person that survived. The sun soon rises over the horizon and I start to head off back to station. It's moments like this that make ARMA great, no other game is this realistic in warfare, its amazing. The horrors of war are very accurately depicted in this game, and every mission, something is going to go wrong, there is no whizzing through ARMA. It may not be a perfect game, but still, ARMA is something special. You may see ARMA on sale all the time for 10 bucks or so, I recommend to pick it up, its worth that price. I do warn that you need a decent computer to run it though as it is [i] HEAVILY [/i]  CPU bound, however a decent computer with an i5 10400F or better could easily do the job.

This is simply one of my favorite games to play. It is a realistic military simulator that strives to put you in the most immersive situations possible. While that can turn people away from this game, I personally love this, and the fact that a lot of the glitches and bugs in Arma II have been mostly remedied here. There are some lingering one though, which is to be expected from games this large.

I enjoyed the story, and it's there is plenty to do. The main bounty of the game is the fun you can have in multiplayer situations if you have buddies that enjoy the same games as you! The multiplayer base is alive and well here, and not shut down like Arma II. Not to mention, with mods like DayZ, there is literally endless amounts of fun to be had here.

Some problems I have with this, is that the DLC are expensive. The controls to this game are super confusing for new players, and there is hardly much int he way of help in terms of tutorials in the actual game. I had to turn to YouTube when I started playing this series. Another issue people may not like is the optimization. Sometimes, you will have lag, and it won't always be your fault, but a lot of the problems with optimization have been fixed over time as the game has gotten older.

It is not a perfect game, but I hold it dear to me, and would recommend it to anyone.. but the thing to understand is that it is not for everyone. You have to be pretty patient while you learn the controls, as they can be a bit complicated. Once you get past the learning curve, you should be fine. 8/10

Controls: A MESS*

*For those who use a Controller, neither DS4 or XBOX Controllers work as expected for this game. The worst part is that it's tricky to Map, and you can't map every function to the Keys you'd expect. Sure, some Logic's port over, L2 and R2, Aim and Fire. However, some do not, for example the Crouch and Prone are handled by two different buttons instead of just one. For those familiar with the Franchise and used to using the Keyboard and Mouse, it works I think. I'm not a K&M Player, I really don't find that relaxing. I just spent 5 Hours on a Mission that should have only taken two Hours. NPC Aiming can be adjusted thankfully, but even on Novice, they one-shot me in a blink. Mods make this game great, with total conversions allowing you to make the most of the engine to play in settings such as WW2, Vietnam, Cold War Europe, 40k, Halo and so many more. ARMA always was a Series hard to describe and hard too say if its bad or good. For me personally, the postiives outweight the negatvies by far,
It is advertised as an Military-Sandbox-Combat-Simulation. But its far more, actually.

Its the game thats for everyon but not for everyone.
Why? You can have playmodes that are for every taste. BUT You definilty need Several dozen hours to get atleast the basics of the Controls and Tactics.
Also, when you want to play it with Mods and in Multiplayer you need to know:
You WILL have Performance issues - Your FPS are dependant of the FPS of the Host/Server you play on!
You WILL have bugs and crashes. (But atleast on the server of my Group its runs mostly good).

In the Mulitplayer, you can really play every Mode that Modders can imagine. From Milsim too Roleplaying ala GTA Online everything is possibly.
Or just the Vanilla Experience, that is already fun too. I recommend this, before you go into the rabbit hole that are Arma 3 Mods.
There is a reason that most highly Popular Multiplayer Trends like Zombie Survival (Day-Z) and Battle Royale have there Origins in the ARMA Series.
Multiplayer is variable, complex, overly complicated, sometimes unreliable and Fun. When it comes to Combat I had the most intense Battles in every Shooter-Like game ever with my Group in Coop Missions.

The Singleplayer

... on the over hand. Well, the main Campaign is by far the weakest of the series. Its not exactly bad but the Story is just not engaging, the Characteres are bland or just a Satire. The Missiondesign is often okayish, but often just not ... Good. Also the entire Scenario doesn't quite use the potential creativity they had with the near-Future Setting. (If Arma 4 takes much longer, Arma 3 will be actually Alternative Reality.).
Then there are the DLC's. I haven't played them all until today. But aside from Apex (DON'T. PLAY. THIS. CAMPAIGN. ITS BORING AS FUCK, and feels more like a COD without the cinematic atmosphere...)
But The DLC'S I played so far: Contact, Laws of War, and Tanks. All three I highly enjoyed they all had a good written Story and were just fun and engaging.
Especially Contact. If you liked STALKER, you will love this DLC. Its Atmosphere and Story are just really good written. Might be the Best Story in the entire Arma series.


So... but who should try Arma 3?

Well let me say it easier:
Who Shouldn't:
- IF you can't live with FPS below the 60 Mark
- If you despise overly complicated and not good designed Controls
- If you want to play Singleplayer but don't want to buy DLC's like...ever
- If you get Bored after 10-15 Min of nothing happening
- If you get bored when not every minute something explodes. (Well this CAN happen in Arma too... but than something 
  has gone horribly wrong)
- If You want to Run as fast as Sonic, Stomp da Gitz like in Doom, or can't live without regenerating Health - this game isn't 
   for you

Everybody else should inform himself if he can find a Gamemode that he likes and just try it.

Have played all the games in this series and definetely recommend Arma 3. It is the best Combat Sim out there but here is a few pro's and con's:

Pro:
- The editor lets you set up any situation and most things are possible thanks to various units, triggers, modules etc. as well as the possibility of scripting for more advanced users.
- Huge maps makes it possible to play scenarios by land, sea and air.
- There is a ton of community content as well as DLC's to make the game replayable. 
- The story lines are quite good and entertaining.

Con:
- Controlling the AI can be frustrating as they have problems with pathfinding, keeping formations etc. which has been a problem since the very first game.
- Cinematics in the game are horrible and look like something from the 90's as videos for cut scenes etc. are made with the editor. It makes the making of cut scenes available to everyone but also gives a bad impression of the game. 
- It can be hard for players without programming skills and/or a lot of time on their hands to get into mission making etc. because a certain level of scripting is required for making all but the simplest missions. Arma 3 is way more accessible than the previous games in that aspect, however. 

All in all, this is a great game if you're interested in a non-linear combat sim where you can create your own scenarios.

Of course - after some hours the short version:
If you like realisitc warfare simulation - take this, for sure!
If you like FPS, PVP etc. - go away!

The long version:

- The Gameplay
ArmA really is not a Shooter, it is not a Battle Royale, or a "war game" ... it is a warfare simulation. Out of the box you will get big maps, many equipment, and nice campaigns. Together wit addons/workshops, just to name "ACE" you will get the real thing. After decades of gaming it is the first real game where you can feel the impact of balistic, the speed of sound, the nightmare of combats. You will need to adjust your weapon sights based on the distance to your enemy, you need to hold breath or cool down to perfect hit your target. You have to move wisely.
There are so much functions to reload, to unjam weapons, to hide by smoke grenades, to use tanks, helicopters, airplanes, ships... You can play as a Seal with rebreather and dual-purpose rifle which could fire under water. There are radio-addons (to name TFAR - Task Force Arma Radio) with 3D audio and real radio-communication.

- The AI 
It's a dream. They will counter-attack your position from different directions. They will use cover fire ... they also get affected by your cover fire. They won't see you if you lay down without motion. You can be stealthy... they will take some time to spot you if you use silenced weapons. They will hide, they will run... and they will heal themselves - if they have a medipack.

- The Environment
There is a very realistiv physics engine which will enable you to shoot through walls if you have the right caliber, angle of impact and wall material. You will recognize rebounding bullets from walls, stones and hard materials based on angle of attack. The gras will be flatten if you crouch or drive through or if you start with an helicopter.

Too much to mention ... if you have read until here ... buy it ;)

At least, even after so many years, the Developer Bohemia interactive will support this "platform". The community is also so huge and you will get so many mods, workshops, addons, missions, weapons, cars ... and so on.

Consider this: CoD typically has a defacto playing style suited to the mainstream and newbie player. Arma, I feel, does not. A lot more keys, a lot more focus required and a lot more critical thinking with missions. Like, you actually have to think about the best way to approach a situation and you have to think how you engage the enemy. Something not typically found in either of the aforementioned AAA titles. Really good addictive game, but has some glaring issues. 

Multiplayer is fun, I haven't tried competitive yet but I'm really enjoying PVE. Really good range of weapon, equipment, vehicles, jets, helicopters, tanks, UAV's. Large expansive maps. One of the maps is based off a real island. The single player story mission and the lore is interesting. 

The anti-cheat system doesn't work, the amount of hackers I have seen on my favourite server is insane. They pop on blow everyone and everything up and leave when they get bored. 
Luckily I play on a PVE server, I can only imagine what its like on a PVP server. 

The lag and frame drops is an issue in MP. Clearly unoptimised and seems to suffer from memory leak. 

They don't do enough with the single player campaign. The maps are massive, but the game doesn't take advantage of this or seem to have the capability to allow the player to do different objectives all over the map- either that or flow of missions is lacking. 

The DLC's. In multiplayer DLC content (that you haven't purchased) will still be accessible but there will be advertisements for the DLC content that you use on the player screen/UI. You don't need the DLC to play the game though. 
I do wish that they had spent more time optimising the game than releasing DLC though and it feels like some of the DLC should belong in the base game. 

The physics in this game (although funny) are terrible - especially vehicles crashing into each other. 

200 hours in (mostly in MP), I'm really enjoying this game - I still haven't learned how to use tanks and jets, and I still have the single player missions to complete yet.

This is a game I don't play often, but when I do play it I really fucking enjoy it! The best milsim out there without a doubt - so if you love in-depth, hardcore, complicated military sims then this is for you! There's millions of servers to choose from and these could be Altis Life RP to Invade and Annex, which basically means RP's to PvE and the game even has PvP servers if you fancy that. Here's some pros and cons:

[b]Positives[/b]
- This game is very in-depth, from the amount of gear you can carry to the number of rockets to destroy an APC or tank.
- The sheer number of different things to do in this game means it never gets old! There's even campaigns too.
- As raw as a mil sim gets, which depending on if you like them or not, can be a good or bad thing.
- The game is really fun to play with friends and there are so many ARMA 3 teams out there to join!
- The game aint just run, point, shoot! It's very tactical and you need to think tactical to survive.

[b]Negatives[/b]
- I find the game sometimes doesn't look the prettiest, but I'm sure if you have a great PC you can have it look good.
- Same as in the positives, this game is fucking raw! So if you're not into that kinda thing then it's maybe not for you.
- Kinda ties in with above, there's so many controls and it can be overwhelming and complicated at first, but you'll get the hang of it if you stick to it!

All in all, this game is worth it! It's a great game that I have never regretted buying and I'm glad it's part of my Steam library. Whether it be for zombies, RP or just good old ARMA gamemodes, this game has you covered, so I recommend!

1) You can't board most Vehicles! I wonder why.. Maybe because the AI is still driving as bad as in Operation Flashpoint (The first Game in the Series). 2) The AI seems to be exempt from the Rules that apply to the Player. For example: They can run to cover shoot and hit from a standing stance without having to calm down.. And Vegetation does not seem to block their sight. So in the beginning of the game (when you don't command your squad yet) it goes like this: Your guys rush the enemy in the most suicidal way, some action takes place while you are trying to catch up (Even without a Backpack). Once you're there you can't hit anything for a while because you were running, controlled Breathing helps. Maybe you get a lucky shot, but mainly you are a distraction so that the Enemy doesn't pick of your Squad. If on the other hand you don't try to catch up, half of your squad is dead when you finally arrive.. 

3) There's just too much stupid Drama. It's always an Ambush, a 'Lone Survivor' or 'Horrors of War' Plot going on. In every Mission...

Regrettably, the game itself is quite coarse, what with its lacking AI (allies and enemies both) and the abysmal optimisation (game engine was quite dated even at the release and by all means did not age well).
Mods can add depth and a more modern touch to many base mechanics, but the above mentioned limitations cannot be easily circumvented.
That said, where the game shines is not quite in its single player aspects, but in its multiplayer (which of course eliminates the issues afflicting allied AI) and as a modded sandbox framework.

Arma 3 is a realistic military sandbox. It relies heavily on mods, and this is arguably the strongest part of this game. The mod support is really good implemented and this results in endless possibilities if it comes to content.

This game isn't made for singleplayer. You can definitely download SP scenarios from the steam workshop and have fun, but this isn‚Äôt the place where you can get the most fun. The best of Arma is found in the multiplayer or coop segment. Download a PvE mission from the steam workshop, or build it yourself, and play it with 1,2,3,10 or even 20 friends and up, by hosting a dedicated server. Or have a massive PvP battle.
Its also possible to join a big server with 20-100 players on it. The servers are ranging from coop missions against AI, to a big PvP king of the hill battle, or just an RPG of real-life without any combat. There really aren't a lot of limits. Meeting new players and playing a coop mission with them in your squad is so much fun. Communication is one of the things that Arma is all about. 

Well, there is one important limit. While the game is extensive, the massive scale results in performance issues. This is one of the weaker parts of Arma. You need a pretty powerful processor to run the game above 40 fps in big scenarios. A plus is that you dont need a lot of frames in arma, but playing below 40 fps isnt always fun.
Furthermore, the movement system isn‚Äôt polished at all and is maybe a bit too extensive. The game is also hard to get into. Almost every key on your keyboard is bound to something, so there is a bit of a learning curve there. The game is usually overwhelming for new players.

This game isn‚Äôt for all types of people. It is a complicated game, and you can‚Äôt just hop in and have a quick firefight or something, that is not what the game is about. 

Oh and you need patience, walking 15 minutes just to get your whole squad deleted by a single mortar shell, not all players can laugh at that.

I've played this game for a little bit...yeah certainly, but let me give you an unbiased opinion on this game at this time.
Pros:
This game has a gigantic community and most of them are really nice people, every game I've joined has a community and a discord built around it. 
It CAN be pretty at times and the gigantic maps do allow for tons of exploring and sight seeing.
Speaking of gigantic maps...that's another pro, Altis is a place that I know like my own hometown, but yet there are still areas I have yet to explore, the map and the islands are areas where you can truly have fun.
This game is almost as moddable as Minecraft, do you want to be an insurgent? A police officer? A clone trooper from Star Wars? A space marine or imperial guardsmen from Warhammer? A spartan from Halo? My answer is you can and I've played them all and they are genuine fun.
The game is realistic to an extent and you normally build your plans before rushing in like mad.
The level editor is the bread and butter of this game and it is fun and intuitive, however, scripting can feel and be fairly clunky.
I could go on, but it's a sandbox full of potential.

Cons:
Bugs...bugs aren't exactly rare, it's not game breaking, but you can get the feeling that it wasn't fully optimized, dudes flying about just...rag dolling after an explosion, things clipping through the map and objects randomly floating about.
This game is BORING if you have no friends to play it with, the AI is not very smart and to be honest , you can't count on it to hold a trench and stand in it without scripting.

Well, its about time I wrote this. 

I have never come across a game that has immersed me more than ArmA 3. I've played Bohemia games since the Operation Flashpoint days back in 2001 before Bohemia got out from under the Codemasters a-holes. 19 years of splendid game play and memories I have, all thanks to the incredible talent of Bohemia Interactive and the beautiful, warm, destructive world they have crafted for us. 

If you're even THINKING about getting ArmA 3 and are sitting on the fence because people complain about optimization, take the leap. Get the game. Even if it isn't running at 144FPS on a 4K screen, its still one of the most incredible experiences you will ever have in gaming. It will take time to learn, so be patient. The rewards and feeling of accomplishment over even the most menial things (like transporting troops/cargo to a firefight or main engagement) is next level. The player base is one of the best on Steam, but like any game there will inevitably be a d***h**d or two. Don't worry though, votekick/voteban is a thing. 

For the price of a meal for two, the Apex edition (while on sale) will give you an incredible start. The Tanks and Jets DLC are absolute must haves as well to get the maximum enjoyment out of ArmA 3. The price may seem steep at first, but ArmA goes on sale ALL the time. I cannot imagine a better use of 40 dollars on Steam than getting Apex, Jets, and Tanks. Thousands of hours in the best military sandbox experience money can buy awaits you, my friend. 

Good hunting.

ARMA 3's description calls itself a massive military sandbox, which couldn't be more correct in what the strengths are. 
Arguably, it is the easiest game to pick up and play, including tutorials, scenarios to introduce players to the core mechanics and even a campaign that attempts to provide the player an example of different factions (some of which return from 2 and prior titles by Bohemia) playing a part over the state of Altis. While admittedly the setup and missions are more content to fill in if the player cannot access multiplayer, the campaign is made a little better by it's Law of War expansion, where the highlight is the unconventional campaign. The other island, Stratis, is not really the main focus. Altis is the most developed of the islands, both are based on real life places, in fact, no doubt helping authenticity.

Altis is a large map, transport options can be diverse, even water options open up when reaching the core of the island. The highlight of the island is Kavala, which features a large castle out looking the port and surrounding sea. Even so, what many players consider to be the defining city of the map is only a former capital.
It has an airport, where most military equipment across many game types are usually concentrated. Game modes such as domination (a returning, popular player vs AI combined forces capture the town mode) use these areas to store the numerous vehicles. Something that is to mention however, is that ARMA 3's base game notably lacks a lot of the best or more interesting vehicles. Jets, specialised tanks and more futuristic but not out of touch VTOLs are contained in some expansion packs. 

This comes to be the main problem with ARMA 3. As a sandbox in of itself, it does offer a wide amount of tools. The Eden editor and Zeus functions are arguably the absolute best creative tools added in the games that Bohemia have made, importing over script language from ARMA 2, along with finally giving players a real-time look into what they're specifically placing. I cannot tell you how great these two features are, hopefully the wealth of Steam Workshop content should be able to provide some idea, even made by novice designers or people just messing around. 
The main problem, is the DLC and expansions. All of them are additions to the sandbox, but like many games such as Civlization, you'll find that DLC and expansions become a 'must-have' requirement. There are some really cool workshop levels and mods out there, some of which require them. Rappelling off of structures, an even deeper simulation experience and integration with TeamSpeak are some of them, and they're pushing ahead military simulation. The question is, right now, how much are you willing to put down? I recommend it if you're creative enough to spend some time messing with mission creators or checking out workshop modifications or levels. Sometimes, ARMA 3 can combine together to create a scenario that seems so dumb in your head, but with a little bit of mod searching and editing, you can make something replicating it. 

Otherwise, the controls and movement within the game are as you would expect for a military simulator, but they have noticeably added more positions for the player to take, some of which are unique and provide a different perspective in a firefight. Control presets can be found replicating ARMA 2 or other presets if you would like something more familiar. One thing that is absolutely a problem is the engine. ARMA 3 runs on an engine that is notorious for bugs and general issues. In fact, ARMA 3 is just known for bugs, it shouldn't be much of a surprise that the performance of the game is quite terrible too. While DayZ has been used as a funding and development platform for Bohemia's new engine, Enfusion (Hint, a big reason why DayZ has been in development for such a long time, they were using it as a testing ground for their actual simulators and commercial products) it is unlikely to have ARMA 3 updated to move to a new engine. It would simply break too much, and it would be another nightmare like DayZ.

ARMA 3 is a great military multiplayer simulation game that drastically improves on ARMA 2, while also giving a ton of creative tools that the average player can use to make their own scenarios and content. If you like the sound of this, ARMA 3 is the best Steam game I've played that fits the bill perfectly.

Alright. This Game. After almost 3 thousand hours in this game, I think its safe for me to review it. 
This game can be a truly fantastic experience. There are a scant few other games where 20 of my friends and I can fight a group of Russian Insurgents, take a prisoner, escape 2-5 kilometers to a zone that has already been cleared by another team until evacuation arrives. The sense of realism is huge in this game, where the squad in front of mine got hit by a mine, or a mortar something. I was the only medic tasked with getting up their entire squad, while the rest of my squad secured the area. After over 3 years and almost 3 thousand hours and being in every position of leadership from rifleman, to medic, to team lead, to small teams leader in a PMC to rising to a force commander in that PMC I have tons of these stories and more. 
That being said, this game has issues. Its Physics engine isn't the best, and there are many stories and clips of vehicles hitting a bush and joining the ARMA 3 Space program. The Campaigns, while they tell a good story, tend to be frustrating as you'll need to navigate out of a minefield. With no mine detector. Against mines that are damn near invisible. I've needed to restart more times than I care to admit to get through that field. 
The Pros still outweigh the cons in this game. At the end of the day, this game is a massive sandbox simulator with HUGE modding community. You want to be in a hyper realistic airborne unit? They have 'em! Want to just run around with friends, blowing up the enemy? You can! Want to do a post-apocolyptic survival/zombie game? You can! This game is what you make of it. No other game does what ARMA has attempted to do, as well as it handles it.

Arma 3 has huge potential and huge variation of weapons, gear and mod support. Although there is not sufficient online support or variation of online gameplay mods. Most servers are user made and riddled with people who misuse the online settings and generally mismanage the online rooms. The single player and campaign are pretty small so if you are planning to buy this then you will basically be dependent to the online community or to mods from the workshop which only partly fix the problem with the lack of online options and support. Most online servers are riddled with toxic admins who tend to mismanage their servers to the fullest and  abuse their power. For example many of the Official Servers (for example Zeus) of Arma 3 are basically obsolete since literally anyone can become admin and literally do whatever (f.e. kick everyone and cause havoc)  he wants without any single penalty for mismanaging and abusing his power. Even in the servers which are being automanaged by Bohemia there are often people who get kicked because the BattleEye script is bugged beyond belief and suddenly dysfunctions in the middle of the session without any explanation. I am really sad to say this but despite all the realistic components and its theoretically good concept of gameplay Arma 3 is (at least at this point) a honeypot which sucks the new player in (Good Campaign/ Single Player) but throws him down the cliff when it's online components fail to deliver.  If you plan on buying this game i would recommend you to wait until it gets more updates (After Patch 2.0) and gets fixed by Bohemia in the future. In its current online state Arma 3 is majorly in complete anarchy. If you like an experience similar to GTA 5 ONLINE then the online parts of Arma 3 will appeal to you if you dont mind spending multiple hours on something without learning anything about Modern Warfare and ending up completely wasting your time. But if you want a dedicated online experience protected and updated by the Developer Company then Arma 3 is not for you in its current state.

Great game in my opinion. This game is not a fast paced FPS. If you are looking for a game with a lot of action and shooting then this game isn't for you. This game is about taking it slow and communicating with teammates to plan out a strategy whether that's how to take over an outpost or even just rescue some hostages from a building. It will also take time to learn the controls but once you got it down it is hard to forget. The modding community is also another great thing about the game because there are hundreds of scenarios that you can play with friends. One downside to this game is that to be able to play with friends on a private server, you will need to port forward through your internet provider which is fairly easy but can be a hassle for others. My friends internet provider won't let him port forward as easily as it should be so this can be a problem for some people. One way to get around this is to just find an empty server so it's not all bad. The game has lots of weapons and vehicles and even an editor so you can make missions that you and your friend can play, assuming that the port forwarding that I mentioned above works well (it does for most people).

TLDR; Great game, hard to play with friends, I do suggest picking it up one day though.

To say the least, Arma 3 is a fun, Loud, Action Intense, Hurry Up And Wait military sim. Having spent almost 168 hours in game, at the time of the review, most of these hours in the editor because my pc is from the Dinosaur age, and can't run Super Mario, let alone Arma 3. But in all seriousness, Arma 3 is a great game, and most of that is because the modding community is huge. You could be anything from a Caveman, to a Stormtrooper, all thanks to the mods that the workshop has to offer. There's nothing like leading a head on assault against American troops during the battle of the bulge, or listening to the trees speak Vietnamese while Fortunate Son plays in the background. Of course this is all a lot more fun, when you aren't running at 10 FPS. (Please help I need a New PC, Godspeed!) The Vanilla game isn't completely terrible, but It's a lot more fun with mods. As far as game play goes, there is a big learning curve, with all of the separate controls and keybinds, but once you learn them, and tweak them to your liking, the game becomes much easier. Most of the Vanilla Mechanics are okay, but mods make them a lot better. The Vanilla sounds, and noises are okay, but of course there are always mods that improve them. (You see where i'm going with this whole modding thing?) Iv'e heard people say the graphics look kind of old, but the pictures look great! I don't actually know how the graphics really look maxed out, because my graphics look like a child came and threw a bunch of paint colors on a paint pallet, and then went ham on it. There are also lot's of community groups dedicated to Mil-Sim, or dedicated to just having fun. But iv'e never played a multiplayer game, because it takes 30 minutes for my pc to load a single map. All in all though, Arma 3 is a very fun game, with a dedicated player base and modding community, and it's got a lot to offer. but it's poorly optimized as sh*t. So don't try and play on a 10-12 year old PC. Oh and the Vanilla Ragdoll physics, will give you frequent Nightmares. But of course, mods will take care of that!

Finally gave this game a shot while clearing my backlog and this will likely stay in play cycle for years. Unlimited replayability but is better with friends / a squad. 

1. Do the tutorial 
2. Run through a single player mission to get familiar with the controls
3. (Optional) Watch some Arma videos on youtube to get insider info / tips. I recommend OperatorDrewski's Arma KotH playlist. 
4. Hop into a PVP or PVE server. I recommend KotH (King of the Hill). Would further recommend either the Code4Gaming servers (https://codefourgaming.com/our-servers/) or the ArmaKotH Servers (https://codefourgaming.com/our-servers/).

If you decide to play KotH, be careful when visiting the Code4Gaming servers, they have a regular KotH and an RHS KotH. The latter is modded and, although you may have a different experience, I tend to drop frames in the big city on that server.

Not your little brother's COD game.  Amazingly challenging and fun campaigns and DLC.  It has everything you could ever want: helos, tanks, jets, and all your infantry pew pew tactical action.

I don't like shooting at my friends.  So I focus mainly on co-op missions, and there are some fan-made missions that are very well done.  I get in here with about a half dozen of my friends, and we'll spend two hours in the evening a couple of times a week going up against the AI.  There are some hiccups, like when we are attempting to break out of a prison, and the AI guards suddenly walk through the solid wall or door... doesn't happen often, but it is a quirk which pops up once in a while.  There's also the sense that AI can see you through walls, tall grass, and smoke.  But it's still an excellent simulation/game for an FPS.  The detail in the scenery, vehicles, and weapons is fantastic.  Go enjoy.
