Starting off with the good. At first you do not know what to do and where to start. I started off with single player scenarios, and I honestly don‚Äôt know how to describe them besides bizarre and new. Learning how the game works, using the arsenal creating the ultimate kit and using it in a firefight is just amazing. After a while I started using 3den, I spent over 200 hours making missions and scenarios on the workshop, and oddly enough I still failed to learn any coding. Once I discovered public Zeus I spent days playing with random people doing all kinds of operations and having a great time, I met people who taught me stuff about myself and helped me improve myself as a person, and quite literally improved my charisma and social confidence, which is to this day, bizarre to me, how a video game and its community can change how you act in real life. Once I learned about units I joined a unit called Gamma company, I learned about task force radio and ACE, I went through a Chris Kyle phase where I thought I was a good marksman, spoiler alert I sucked at long range combat and reconnaissance, I found my calling with ace medical, and god is ace a blessing to the Arma community. My experiences in Arma and Gamma company are unreplaceable, and I could not ask for a better game to spend over 1000 hours of my life on. Arma is the first game where I felt no rage and I genuinely had fun, no anger, and no frustrating moments. I genuinely love this game.

Also team AI actually aids in the elimination of enemies which is nice since several games I've played seem to have the worst AI teammates with the inability to hit their targets, so having AI that can eliminate enemies is a nice change. Arma 3 is a comprehensive take on military simulation. It may seem dated to some at this point, in 2020. but rest assured this is easily one of the greatest shooter style games ever created. Be warned - if you are expecting a Call of Duty or Battlefield experience then you will be disappointed; however, if you give this a chance you will see the richness it brings to the genre. Whether you like story driven, or simply shooting multiplayer, there is a part of the Arma world which will satisfy your needs. This game has the best campaign created in a military based game. It is expansive, requires varying skills and tasks, as well as allows the player to take part in scouting missions between regular missions in which you are free to roam the countryside looking for loot. The best part is that the campaign tracks your weapons and equipment inventory throughout - so if you don't scavenge some NVGs and come across a night mission... well you don't get the handout of a free set. Likewise, if you find a gun that you really love, be it a .50 cal sniper rifle, squad weapon, or even a static grenade launcher and tripod, you can loot those items and use them in your upcoming missions. The game is difficult in some ways, but is also very easy to learn and a wonderful experience. On top of that the devs have worked hard on additional content. You can battle on a Greek Island, in the jungle of the south pacific, the dense forests of Europe or the classic island of Malden, if you are familiar with the original Operation Flashpoint (re-branded Arma Cold War Assault). This game is still worth every dollar even in 2020, but if you get it on sale, then it's a no-brainer!

Ah ArmA... 3,000 hours now. where do i even start? boy, this game is everything i ever wanted in a game - The ability to make, manage, and play in your own wars. The only limits are those of the engines and i will get to it later. So, what is ArmA 3? it's not just simply a shooter, actually. I used to believe firmly that "ArmA 3 is a shooter, and every mission maker needs to focus on that!", but the shooting is not the focus of it. If you know what you are doing, and are good at mission making - you can make a good mission without your men even shooting once. That's not to say it's recommended, but when making a Vietnam mission for example i prefer to have the silence of the Jungle around you as you try to look for traps and mines give you fear - because while machine gun fire is good at surprising you with a scare, it's not as good as say - the fear of being watched and the possibility of it. A perfect example of this is an operation made by Rimmy DownUnderGaming, a youtuber who makes ArmA videos and other content, he once streamed "The Forest" mission, which was the most fascinating mission i have ever witnessed (by watching it), and changed my mind regarding ArmA 3 being known as a shooter game. 

So what is my experience with ArmA 3? long ago i started playing, usually played some open co-op server missions, and messed around in the editor, this was back when there wasn't even a 3d editor and you would struggle to put something on a table.. i took a break and when i returned once more i joined a community - Digby Tatham-Warter's Discord community who ran Zeus (a "game manager" who can control units and assets as a sort of a god, like a DM) missions. I never got around to lead the missions myself, but i did enjoy some squad leading. From there i went to also try and find other communities, and on the way have made my own - with my group of friends, to try and see if they would enjoy ArmA as i have. And so, currently managing this small group of about 13 people (though, we never manage to get many on one day) and i am still experimenting with what's good and what isn't. ArmA is not the type of game you buy to get your fun here and now and throw it to the corner for eternity like many recent releases, it's a game with the same appreciation we had to old games - you can spend any given amount of time just messing around in the editor, and i would honestly recommend properly learning mission making once you do. 

The engine of the game is the main issue - you will see this a lot, ArmA doesn't like things smashing into one another. Most of the issues people complain about either come from mods, or can be fixed by mods, which is something some people still need getting used to. The game is not easy to run, and definitely not easy to learn or manage, but if you know how to make a mission and know the strengths and limits of the engine you can play it to a way that makes things you wouldn't be able to in most games - let you make your own video game "Campaign" mission, my childhood dream basically. Back when i played CoD 2 Big Red One i always thought "hmm that's interesting, what if i was able to go to this other side of the airfield and find cool stuff in it? what if i could just get on this vehicle? why am i bound to this path?" - and ArmA 3 allows me to make that, as someone who loves to make missions i can enjoy making a mission with those small details - script a squad to spawn if players choose the "wrong" path to the objective, have them get into cars the guys passed over earlier, and hunt my players. Have an entire dynamic status for everything - enemies will reinforce positions if the players clear it and leave it, and so the players can be surprised when the AI literally solid snakes it's way behind them - following them until they are grouped up and start to gun them down, and yes - it is a possibility. 

The AI, i have seen complaints about it - there will always be complaints about it - It's not perfect, but it deserves far more credit than it deserves. Many hate it for being "too good" - perhaps because unlike most games it can actually aim, and you dont have an insane amount of health. Perhaps because it can spot you through bushes sometimes, and no when it fires at you from inside a building it's not because it can see you it's because it heard your gunfire and or steps and knows you're on the other side. Others say the AI is too bad - that it's stupid, doesn't follow orders, and isn't compliant - you're right, they won't just rush the players like idiots, they wont just run in the open field like a Battlefield Singleplayer AI, and there are ways to override most of the limits, you just probably never heard of them. 

To conclude, it's like a game from our childhood on modern standards - back then we didn't complain about every frame drop, we didn't cry when things weren't perfect, we found ways around them - and that's what i love. 10/10 would sacrifice 50 toasters for my based Vietnam mission to work again.

Oh my, this is a great game. My internet is garbage and I can't really play multiplayer. This game is shown by a lot of people playing only multiplayer and that leads people to believe that this is not a single player game. WRONG! If you want an amazing single player war-sim, this game is for you.
 On the workshop you can play thousands of mods which is great and all but who really cares about mods? What really makes the single player aspect of this game so amazing is the scenario tab. The scenarios range from zombie apocalypse, squad leader sim, front lines combat, stealth mission, etc. A lot of the scenarios have a lot of replay ability and some are short story driven campaigns.
 This game is like a chess game, every action has a strong reaction, needs precision, and can be played a million different ways. I recall failing a mission because my medic vehicle I was transporting got destroyed. Later I thought "What if I walked 400m ahead of the vehicle as it follows me and scout with a small recon team" and it worked. This game will make you use your brain so don't be scared to use it!
Anyways, 4.7/5.0 stars from me, -.3 from slight frustration with freezing and small stutters. Stutters and crashes happen rarely but are still an annoyance. Either way, I highly recommend this game.

The Arma series has sat in a special place for me, offering a longer, more satisfying experience that is incredibly dynamic, even moreso with friends. In it's most hardcore, Arma provides some of the highest stakes engagements in gaming, and some of the most varied combat possibilities. It is janky, the AI is good but not great, where this game shines is in multiplayer.

Zeus mode, my personal favourite, offers the ability to skip all that troublesome map making, scripting and testing and lets you build your multiplayer mission as it happens. This alone reinvigorated my love for the series and provided some of the most intense, ridiculous and fun missions to date.

Where the base game fails, mods and workshop content bring it to life, total conversions, maps, factions and weapons. Hell you can download a mod that gives you Goddamn mechs, the modding community is vast and the potential is almost endless.

All in all, it's a must buy for me. Servers are always full, play with friends if you can.

WARNING - it does have some serious issues, but I am still recommending it for those who would like to create their own missions, and maybe for multiplayer.

CONs:
- Multiplayer might NOT work for you, because the game still does not have IPv6 support (in 2020!?)
- Various movement glitches; you frequently get stuck on rocks, in shrubbery or just trying to step over a sandbag
- If you expect it to be as realistic as some people say it is, you may be disappointed; AI units don't follow even the most basic tactics, don't take cover under heavy fire; enemy AI shoots you through dense forest, from 400m, standing, with iron sights; it might work better for multiplayer, can't really say, I have not played much MP yet
- The worst part if you are looking for realism are the arcade game-like singleplayer scenarios and campaigns; those about as realistic as an action movie
- Some pretty basic weapons/scope/equipment mechanics are not modeled accurately

PROs:
- Fun tacticool FPS with lots of customization options for your avatar and your equipment
- In-game map, GPS, compass, wristwatch help with team coordination
- Much greater number of shooting stances than a regular shooter
- You can change equipment while playing, hand it over to other players, load it into vehicles, etc.
- Moderately realistic small arms ballistics and player stamina (your avatar gets tired if you sprint, etc.)
- Very extensive scenario editor with scripting capabilities; this is the best part of the entire game in my opinion, and mostly the reason why I am recommending it. I probably spent more time in the editor than playing the game.

Iv'e had arma for quite a while, it was one of my first and my favorite game. 
Arma has been a great game from the start, years ago when the community was much much larger, it was better.  Roll play is a ton of fun, KOTH is super fun, sandbox, all of is fun, but at the end of the day it's only what you make it.

The Arma community has shrunk A lot in recent years, and it's really sad to see it, but at the end of the day it's the fault of the Developers and whoever priced DLC's.

The DLC's aren't all worth it.  APEX was NOT worth it when it came out.  Even still, Unless you really play Arma A lot, it's not worth the money.  DLC's shouldn't cost 2/3 what the whole game itself costs.

The DLC's that were released didn't cater to what the community really needed, nearly ever.  The most popular PvP servers were ones without tanks and jets, but the devs release tank and jet DLC's?  Even the "Karts" DLC was more enjoyable.  

I usually recommend arma 100%, but seeing that the games only $30 and theres DLC that aren't huge game changers for $25+, it's just not worth it.  The games dying, and it's too late to recover.  I'm sure there's going to be more DLC's released, but there wont be any chance of recovering the population it once had, if the dev's would have been smarter about DLC's, this might not be the case.  

My advice for anyone looking to buy Arma : Wait for a sale, and the expensive DLC's aren't worth it unless you're going to put 800+ hours in atleast.  Marksmen is the ONLY DLC that I recommend.  The game is going to continue to lose players, and will eventually die.  Hopefully there will be a Arma 4 in the next few years, but my hopes aren't high.

Arma 3 is a great game. You can spend hundreds of hours in this gaming building missions and fighting in them. There are also countless dedicated servers up running milsims, king of the hill, and other mission types. Arma shines in it's sandbox. The campaigns are alright and are sometimes fun, however user made content is amazing. You can get any mission from a recreation of a historic battle or a zombie survival. That being said, the mods keep the game fresh with content allowing you to transform Arma into any game you would like. Bohemia still supports this gem, releasing many dlcs. The dlcs are worth it in my opinion, but with all the mods, you don't need them. As with everything in life, there are some draw backs. The one biggest thing is optimization. To be fair to the game, there are many countless calculations being made by the games engine every second. Bullets are effected by wind, gravity, humidity, and penetration factors. In large scale battles you will definitely notice a decrease in frames but smaller missions won't be as noticeable. Now at it's core, and how Arma was designed to be played, it's all about the struggle. All the tools are given to you but Arma doesn't hold your hand. It will punish you. However, careful planning and movement as well as conservative decision making will help you succeed. This is all according to how realistic you want to be and it can be more in depth then this with supporting roles. Arma also benefits the supporting role like CAS, transport pilots, fire support, and many more. To recap on everything, Arma 3 is a huge sandbox that can be whatever you want. Countless user made content can keep the game fresh and it's constant support is a very nice bonus. It's combat favors all personal to the front line fighters to the supporting roles getting them there and protecting them. This is a must have game if you want either a huge sandbox and or realistic combat.

Over the years with this game I've had some OK moments but it's the kind of game that bites you in the ass any chance it gets. Mechanically, it's complex (especially with mods) but also breaks easily. The community ranges from raging 13 to 65, but any age in that range is equally capable of demonstrating mental illness. 

Moreover it's a game where you spend 6 hours trying to accomplish something and then lose it in a split second. Then you have to choose: start that task over or quit.  But the game's magic is when it draws you back, hoping for that wonderfully complex experience that you really only get with ArmA. The sheer amount of controls, dials, knobs and buttons is ludicrous.

I could go into further detail but it really boils down to this: if I didn't already own this game, I wouldn't buy it. The community is starting to feel small, countless forum/reddit posts over the years have been asking if ArmA is dying due to the shrinking playerbase. And unless you want an ultra-serious clan or server that's going to require you to stay awake for 16 hours (Fisher's LIfe server rules), this game isn't for you.

And that's multiplayer modded servers. So what about the singleplayer or vanilla multiplayer experience? It's empty. You can get into the first 5 missions of the singleplayer and feel like you're in a running simulator. What little combat you encounter is between 3-6 enemies at a time because the game is so poorly developed that it can't handle anything more.

I could go further into detail and give horror stories but I'm sure no one wants to read that. Just save yourself the exposure to more psychosis and stay away from this game.

I moved from ArmA 2 because of a friend's recommendation. I came in hoping to see improvements, especially with the vehicle movement, UI, weapon/vehicle variety, AI, and mechanics. However, I am quite disappointed.
I knew that the game took place in the future, but everything looks like it's out of a Halo/Modern Battlefield orgy. If you like American weaponry and vehicles, don't expect to really see anything familiar out of the base game.
With the workshop, you can download plenty of mods but I find the gameplay mechanics just inherent in the game to really be a problem. In addition, it seems that vehicle realism has absolutely dropped from ArmA 2. Humvees taking RPGs, crewmen surviving after a tank goes up like a nuke, armor values for outdated vehicles way too high while modern ammunition power values are way too low. I set up a large-scale vehicle battle on Takistan with the enemy using T-72As and T-55s and my team using M1 variants with M829A2 and M829A3 APFSDS, only to find out that those rounds are incapable of piercing through their armor while their ammunition cut through mine. So, yea, vehicle realism really hit the fan.

And do not even get me started with the AI. Holy crap, whether it's base game or modded game, the AI is horrendous... Or, should I say, the enemy AI would make you think they're some super soldiers constructed from the DNA of the best spec ops operators in the world while your guys are only capable of standing and walking in one direction. The enemies can nail you in excess of 700 meters with iron sites, but your guys will fail to see an enemy on thermal from 10 feet away (Yes, this is a regular occurrence). Even with enhanced AI mods, this problem is still prevalent.
Then there are the actual characters themselves. Talk about super soldiers physically... well, your enemies at least. I was just playing yesterday with my friend and he was shot in the arm while manning a vehicle turret, and died. But then me and him would hit an enemy 5+ times, a few times in the head, and they would continue running and firing on us with precision. Inspecting them with the ACE medical viewer shows that they were, indeed, struck multiple times before dropping and that it wasn't just game lag that made it appear they were hit. This problem is especially problematic in the vanilla game, where your enemies really are super soldiers for whatever reason.

So, overall, this is what I can say when compared to ArmA 2:

Pros:
- Many more mods for you to tune the game to your liking
- Scripting is way better, increasing FPS (I can run this game smoothly on maximum graphics even with all the mods installed, but had a hard time running ArmA II on medium quality)
- Movement for both infantry and vehicles is a lot smoother, especially with movement enhancing mods
- Active online community
- Weapon customization, especially in Arsenal, is definitely a convenient thing
- Zeus and Eden Editor make game editing a lot easier
- UI is much more convenient

Cons:
- Futuristic combat environment that seems completely isolated from previous installments (A personal bias of mine)
- The vanilla game lacks a wide variety of weapons and vehicles
- Enemy AI is ridiculously high while allied AI is absolutely horrid, leading to you being the only effective member of your team in an environment where your enemy has no problem hitting you with iron sites from 700+ meters away
- Vehicle realism is horrendous compared to ArmA 2. This is due to armor values for certain vehicles being way too high, and power values being for certain anti-tank munitions way too low. (This is being said using ACE2 for ArmA 2 and ACE3 for ArmA 3)
- Enemies have way too much health while your allies seem to be made of range target paper. This is bad to the point where head shots to the enemy will often fail to drop them while you could die from a single shot to the leg or arm.

TLDR; Many small things improved upon, many big things got a lot worse. Makes game play a lot less fun and much more frustrating.

Arma 3 is a really good game without mods, with mods it is on a whole other level. There are endless options to choose from, from WWII to undisclosed franchises that irritate Disney. I really enjoy the USMC mods as the uniforms are very accurate, they use appropriate aircraft, and the weapons are very accurate as well. The modding community on this game truly enjoys what they do and I enjoy using their creations.
YES

Overall Arma3 is a continuation of the true milsim genre, which started with the likes of Tom Clancy, Jane's Simulations and Operation Flashpoint games. It doesn't hold your hand and point out where enemies are, give you medkit pickups or allow you to simply walk out in the street and lay waste to entire platoons. 

It's complicated, got a severe learning curve and the AI is not quite as good at path-finding as it was in Arma2 or the previous Bohemia games, but it is still merciless and will teach you right away why cover is imperative in warfare.

More fun with mods, and an absolute joy when you can mod your kit using a virtual ammobox to fit your preferred weaponry - and artillery works like it should; user beware.

So despite the bugs, I'm loyal to Bohemia for always trying hard to make good simulations; and more for actively encouraging mods to make things better when people have the gumption to make something on their own!

10/10 for being able to learn about the conventions of modern warfare, which ban landmines and reckless use of explosives.... Then go on missions which allow you to use both.

Armed Assault (or ArmA for short) III is the latest and weirdest foray into the world of a near-real life like simulator of an actual military. However, this has some serious drawbacks, and I hope to cover them thoroughly in this review. I'm going to put a disclaimer out there and say I'm not saying you shouldn't buy the game, because it has some moments you can't get anywhere else, and it's certainly fun when you have friends, but if you play solo or are looking for a quick game, you won't find it here. If you want quick solo fun, I suggest you go play Squad.

The first thing to talk about is how ArmA III compares to its older brethren. To put it bluntly, I feel Bohemia put out ArmA III as an excuse to have more money retained to them as parents on their next tax return. ArmA III doesn't feel like a labor of love as much as ArmA II did, which is my personal favorite staple in the series. ArmA II had actual real life vehicles in it, like the T-72 and the T-55, the M1A1 and the M1A2 Abrams, the M3 Bradley, just to name a few. In ArmA III you get these weird GTA-inspired knockoff vehicles that are either amalgamations of different IRL vehicles or just real life vehicles under a different name, like the M2A1 Slammer is just a Merkava, or the T-140 Angara is LITERALLY the T-14 Armata. I don't know if it's because Bohemia isn't permitted to do that anymore, or they just didn't have enough money to buy the licenses to put said vehicles in the game officially. Which, doesn't make sense considering their DLC's like S.O.G. Prairie Fire and Global Mobilization have IRL vehicles in them. It's a mixed bag. 

What about optimization? Is it any good? ArmA III is literally the most poorly optimized game I've ever played next to Dead Rising 3. Before you scoff, "ugh, his rig is just bad," I'm just gonna lay it on the line now that I'm rocking an NVIDIA RTX 3060, Intel i7-10700, and 16GB of RAM. ArmA III is also installed on a Western Digital Black SN750 NVMe SSD. I upgraded because I was trying to run this game on a "gaming" laptop with a GTX 1050 Mobile, 8GB of RAM, and a Toshiba HDD. Pro tip: NEVER install and play ArmA III on a hard drive, or even a hybrid hard drive, install dat shid on an SSD/NVMe. With that pro tip out of the way, ArmA III, on a mostly empty server (we'll say like 5-9 people), for me, on ultra settings, runs at 30-50 FPS. Pathetic. A game from 2013 can't be optimized? What a poor excuse. You need a literal supercomputer (RTX 3090, 32GB RAM, Ryzen 9 5900X or Intel i11 series) to probably even manage 60+ FPS in this game. /end of rant. 

Now the second to last thing to cover is the DLC. ArmA III doesn't exactly pile high with DLC, but if you want to have any fun, you better be ready to pay for it. The top two DLC's you need are probably Apex and Contact, plus the vehicle DLC's like Tanks, Jets, etc. If you try to go into a server and use something from a DLC you don't have? Be prepared for the watermarks. If you use, let's say, the SPMG .338 (a really good LMG, mind you) and you DON'T own the Marksman DLC? You'll see a big square in the right hand corner of your screen that says LShift+P with the Marksman DLC logo over it. If you refuse to buy the DLC whenever they prompt you with this message, which stays there forever almost, they flash the DLC's logo OVER YOUR ENTIRE SCREEN. Can you imagine being in an intense firefight and all of a sudden your line of fire is ruined by some tiles going across your screen telling you to spend your money on the DLC that contains the weapon you're using? Oh, and don't even try to buy a DLC vehicle either. You want to use the T-140K Angara but don't own the Tanks DLC? Have fun trying to get into it. The moment you click "get into T-140K as driver/commander/gunner", it hits you with the "buy the DLC first, d*ckhead" message. This is some EA level of tactics and treachery. Shame on you, Bohemia Interactive.

Finally, there's the multiplayer. ArmA III is like War Thunder. Yeah, there's a campaign and single-player missions, but are you really here for that? No. You're here because you wanna make some people have PTSD. What gamemodes do you choose? Granted, ArmA III has a handful of different gamemodes to play, my personal favorite being Wasteland (called Sandbox in the game's settings), which is, as you would expect, a wasteland. You spawn in with whatever the server decides to spawn you in with. The server I play on (509th Altis) gives you 1500 dollars in your pocket and 20K in the bank (chump change, really) and doesn't guide you. You buy yourself some good equipment from a gun store/general store/vehicle store that you find on the map, and pray someone who's spent 2 years of their life on the server doesn't kill you for no other reason than to assert their virgin dominance over you. That's generally how a game of Wasteland goes. Oh, how do you get more money? You do these missions marked on the map (big red crosses with the names of the missions next to them) and complete the objectives to earn money. Just be careful, the AI can see you from like 50 kilometers out and have pinpoint accuracy. Kill the AI, take the money/weapon crates/vehicles, run for safety, deposit your money (or sell the vehicle or the weapon crate at any shop) , rinse and repeat. Just be wary of other players. There's other gamemodes, like King of the Hill, which is tedious, but leads to quicker action and vehicle usage, and there's Exile, which is like Wasteland but usually has AI that can see you even if you were in outer space, and are able to kill you 25km away. There's other gamemodes, but I rarely see anyone play them. Wasteland servers especially aren't popular unless the server gives you $2,000,000 off the bat and has all the vehicles at base game price. The player base and Bohemia are to blame for this really. ArmA III doesn't do a great job of advertising or even explaining their gamemodes, and there aren't any of the fun modded ones (although I COULD be wrong on this) like in ArmA II (like DayZ). And usually, most players flock to either The Trailerpark, a hectic Wasteland server that gives you a lot of money right off the get-go, or any King of the Hill server, because "hehe, realistic Fortnite"

How would I sum up ArmA III? Basically, buy it on sale. Buy the game when it's super low in price and do the same for the DLC. The vehicle DLC's will cost you like 3 bucks each and the big DLC's like Apex and Contact are like 10 bucks each (on a good sale, BTW). If you're not willing to take the time to learn the ins and outs of ArmA III, and take the punishment whenever it dishes it out to you, then don't waste your money. This review may seem negative despite my hours in it, and I'm also a department lead in an ArmA III Discord server, but ArmA III is not the the "bang for your buck" labor of love that ArmA II was. Arma II had DayZ, it had custom gamemodes, REAL LIFE vehicles and weapons, and it had a strong playerbase. ArmA III is trying too hard to be a futuristic military shooter that just has different elements mixed into it. All in all, if you're looking for a game to play with the mates, ArmA III might be up your alley, but if you're looking for fun, you're going to spend a couple real-life hours trying to have some.

Arma 3 is really the only military sandbox of this scale on the market. It offers an infinite amount of gameplay opportunity through its powerful simulation engines, Eden Editor and Zeus interfaces. Paired with a massive and thriving community, Arma 3 has more content than any other 5 games combined.

However, buyer beware. Arma 3 tends to test your patience. Countless bugs, an aging platform and large optimization issues hinders the Arma 3 experience greatly. Though, through many years of patches, updates, etc. Arma 3 has gotten pretty stable as of 2020. Also along those lines, Arma 3 has many out-dated mechanics. Because of these mechanics, I would say Arma 3 has a non-intuitive learning curve for new players. I would not say the game is "hard". You have to learn just as much as any other large-scale AAA game. But, the learning curve is not straight forward. It's greatly bogged down by old, and poorly implemented UI/UX design.

 All that said, I have played over 1K or something hours and until Arma 4 or a competitor comes out, I will continue to bank hours on Arma 3. There really is a wealth of opportunity for simulating any style of military conflict you could imagine. And as of 2020 I would honestly say this is the best time to get into Arma 3 if you haven't!

Wow. What can I say about ArmA 3. (Armed Assault 3, that is) This is an absolute phenominon of a game, and that goes beyond the core gameplay and fun factor delivered in the executable file itself, but in the knowledge gained from partaking on this veritable adventure. First, there is the transferablle tactical expertise, which when gathered from playtime in this game can be moved to other games like CSGO, or PUBG, or even the Witcher 3, to further enhance your experience there. Upon seeing the loading screen of this game, your mind is injected with subtle yet core changes to its strategic stratephos, allowing calculations on a grand scale to be conducted in lightning speed. Next, we see that the game actually makes you an immediate comedian. Simply saying in game catchphrases like, "Contact Contact Contact", "Im taking overwatch", or "Calling in CAS" will have your friends, family, significant others, and neighbors sprawled on the ground laughing. Finally, this game gives you a complete rudimentary understanding of everything military based, think of it as being in the army for a year or two. When you see a veteran in public, you can now approach with a wide variety of conversational topics, such as PTSD, or how black NPCs are worse than white ones. You can tell them you fully understand how heavy a pack of gear weighs, and how long average in operation transport flights take. If you dont understand some of the "terminology" ive been interspersing throughout this review, I think that just goes to show how simple minded your brain can be pre-ArmA 3 experience. (Armed Assault 3, that is) Talk to me when you barrel roll your first helicopter inside of a friendly APC while blasting trap music over the stereo system while 600 invisible objects explode around you, sending you flying under the map, while your CO applauds you on your incredible dedication to immersion and realism. Silly casual. Maybe (Scoffs) COD, or (Chuckles) Battlefield is more your thing.

Arma 3 is a mixed bag of good, bad, and ugly. Overall, my time with ARMA 3 and the different units I've been in has been positive.

Lets start with the good:
If you're looking for a true military sandbox, this is about as good as it gets. There aren't many games that can simulate full war-games with a server full of real people. From running as infantry as a fireteam leader, to a gunner on a battle tank, to dogfighting in any kind of weather. The modding community is very active, everything from Star Wars, Halo, Warhammer, and Proper Modern/NATO can be roleplayed thanks to the modding community. ARMA's development tools are freely available and allow you to make whatever you desire.

One big advantage this game has is the amount of teamwork that can be made to be required. From squad tactics and dogfighting formations, to logistical and medical challenges that make for a one of a kind experience that other FPS games can't even come close to. Because of the vast amounts of units out there, you are sure to find something that fits your taste.

The Bad:
TLDR: Pricing and Performance

From time to time, there will be instances where you will be using vanilla weapons, especially if you're in a modern day unit.
At least a third of the weapons and vehicles are locked behind DLC paywalls and feels pretty empty without them. If you don't do modern stuff this shouldn't affect you as much since you'll be getting your weapons and stuff from mods.

Something that you will notice a lot of if you don't have a beastly computer is the frame rate. Despite the PC standard being 60 fps, pretty much everyone that plays modded and doesn't have a good rig will usually get less than 30 fps depending on what you're modlist is. Considering this game has been out since 2013, it's a little frustrating to have a game run this poorly that was released 7 years ago and is still getting DLC packs released. 

I've talked a lot about the multiplayer aspect of this game because it's really the main drive behind this series. Yes it has singleplayer content, but it is nothing to write home about. If you play this game as your main time sink, 99% of your playtime will be on multiplayer servers. 

The Ugly:
The ARMA community is.... interesting to say the least. Like many servers and units in different games it's a constant rat race. The people you can meet in these units can range from 14 year olds who think they are god, to power hungry members and admins that do not care, and the occasional racist/hateful unit that are very open about what they think. Despite these negative attributes, you can find a group that clicks with you, and even make IRL friends from this silly little video game.  

As stated at the beginning, this game can be fun with a proper group of people, but beware of higher performance requirements and game instability from using mods.

Oh man. Where to even begin with this one. It would be an extreme disservice to simply call Arma 3 a shooter, as it is so, so much more than that. Arma 3 is a military simulator. This is a distinction that it‚Äôs developers hold sacred and are proud of, and one to which I can attest is completely accurate and deserved. But it‚Äôs even more than that. Arma 3 is a gaming platform, upon which so much has already been and will continue to be built for years to come.

At its core though, Arma 3 in a supremely excellent military sim. The graphics are stunning, the gameplay is excellent, the mechanics are solid, and Bohemia Interactive has done an absolutely amazing job packaging this all together. New comers to the Arma series (as I was) may initially be overwhelmed by the game‚Äôs complex mechanics and decidedly different pace from your typical FPS/shooter. Enemy engagements happen at much greater distance than is typical in the genre and are often brief, brutal, and more times than not will conclude with your demise. There is no handholding here. No mini-maps, no enemy UI icons/indicators, no hit markers, no health bars. If you get shot a couple of times, you will find yourself unceremoniously dispatched. While this creates a high barrier for entry and a steep learning curve for new players, it provides a unique and distinctive play style. Situational awareness, cover, teamwork, suppressive fire, and generally moving purposefully and as if your ass depended on knowing what was behind the next ridge or hiding in the bushes are paramount to your success. Add to these infantry mechanics the amazingly rendered vehicles, armor, helicopters, and planes, each with their own realistic mechanics to learn and master, and you end up with a truly amazing military simulation experience.

Out of the box, Arma comes with a great single player campaign comprised of 3 separate acts, each containing ~12-15 missions. The campaign focuses on a well crafted story of a military conflict that has erupted over Arma 3‚Äôs two HUGE islands of Stratis and Altis. You play the part of a NATO soldier who finds himself stuck in the middle of a complex engagement. The campaign is rewarding, and challenging. (I have yet to complete it as I‚Äôm stuck on one mission that I simply can‚Äôt seem to complete.)

However the single-player campaign is FAR from the end of this title. The mission editing tools have allowed this amazing community to develop some absolutely awesome single player missions, all of which can be downloaded free of charge from the Steam workshop and numerous other sites around the interwebs. I would also recommend you check out the supremely excellent full game conversion single player mods Whole Lotta Altis and Dynamic Universal War System which will provide countless additional single player hours and could be completely stand alone titles in themselves.

Oh and the multiplayer, oh god the multiplayer. Wasteland, King of the Hill, Invade and Annex, Battle Royale, Breaking Point, so many Co-Op opportunities, the amazing looking upcoming Epoch (currently in closed Alpha). I‚Äôm sure there are so many others that I haven‚Äôt even discovered yet. Each of these represent COMPLETELY USER GENERATED and totally disparate ways to play Multiplayer within the Arma 3 platform. By purchasing Arma 3, you immediately have access to each of these completely gratis and each could essentially be considered totally separate game.

In wrapping up this lengthy review, Arma 3 is an amazing experience and a true accomplishment in game development. It is the only game in recent memory that I can say with confidence that I never get bored with playing. Bohemia Interactive has made it clear that they plan to support this game for years to come, and they have built something amazing on which the possibilities are truly endless.

The base campaign of Arma 3 was not especially fun in my opinion. The AI is sometimes near omniscient and capable of hitting you with a buckshot shotgun from 500 meters. The vehicles sometimes launch up several hundred meters into the air due to physics collision anomalies. It can get frustrating and would benefit from improvements, for sure.

The modding and the sandbox nature of the game make up for all the quirks and problems in my own opinion enough to justify recommending the game. It works well enough most of the time to be played and enjoyed with friends and provides a platform for a host of different combat scenarios. Far from perfect yet good enough.

Insert mandatory "Played a bit, was nice" here

Jokes aside, both the game and the community is nice. The amounts of mods you get download even enhances the gameplay even more. Most servers you join would be really helpful towards new players, introducing them to some less known features or help out with some mechanics.

Finished all of the campaigns I could (except the Contact DLC one) and I liked all of them, each of them used a game mechanic that helps you get adjusted to them easier while still leaving you with a sense of enjoyment. 

Sure the game has some optimization issues that need to be addressed instead of more content. In multiplayer, when servers are populated, in towns the fps tends to fall a lot so that's one of the issues. There are several ways to glitch through stairs or walls and be able to shoot through them giving a total advantage, but since it's the fault of the engine, I doubt it will get fixed.

In the end I still recommend people to play this game, try it out and share their experiences. Arma 3 keeps community alive because of it's such expansive workshop content. Whether you are a singleplayer fan or a multiplayer one, if base game gets boring, you can always download mods to "expand the horizon".

This game needs up to date and powerful CPU and graphics card with minimum of 16GB RAM and with the game installed on an SSD on a computer that has a very good cooling system. On top of that we need to buy the base game with DLCs to enjoy the game. And beyond that, there is a good learning curve behind this military sandbox. Add another hundred hours of finding and gelling with an Arma 3 unit for multiplayer experience and community building. Is all of this worth it. Absolutely. Yes! Hardly you find a game with developers with the passion and customer support like that of Bohemia Interactive. The community of modders are great and this game is standing on their shoulders. For a lean experience of this game I suggest a CPU that runs at least 3.4GHz base clock speed 4-6 cores with a good 4GB VRAM graphics card.  And nominally have the base game, marksman DLC, helicopters DLC, Jets DLC, Apex DLC others are good and have really good storylines, but if you are like me who primarily tries to push his budget and hardware for great multiplayer performance, these DLCs are all that you would ever need. Stories in all the campaigns are good. Weapons and ballistics perform close to what one would expect on a real life counterpart. Vehicle physics and that includes boats and airplanes are mostly done well. Mods are usually running stable till a drastic update comes from BI. Community in Arma 3 is possibly the best in the PC gaming and this includes modders to 18 year old digital Sgt.s  Graphics in this game are splended, night missions and fog missions feel incredibly immersive. With the right set of mods this feels like a simulator for infantry combat. And possibly the biggest one yet, some mods in this game get Arma 3 a couple of levels lower than DCS. This is a true sandbox experience with something for everyone. Add a great Arma 3 unit in the mix and you have the best Arma experience, I promise you. Now the game does have its flaws. Lack of optimization, clunky mechanics and some (rare) ridicules glitches to name a few. The game is perfect for large scale combined arms gameplay. But in scenarios like CQB the game really misses a lot and I am not saying because it cannot, I am sure the issue is fixable. But the game should improve the CQB experience. Removing AI glitches in buildings is a start and making the movement for both AI and players in the buildings as smooth as possible is the hopeful end. I have played Operation Flashpoint Cold War Crisis and it used an Action menu. Decade and a half later Arma 3 continues to use such an outdated interaction menu with lots of issues. And lack of a functional radio in game is something that should be fixed in the game's official release and not be patched up using ACE or ACRE. Bohemia you must improve the Optimization and Mechanics. Editor, Zeus and Mod ability is second class to none in any gaming genre. Cons, though few but significant are far overshadowed with the many many great things this game has to offer. This is the most unique thing out there and it deserves support. This is a game tries to do a lot of things and I hope they try to innovate in the next iterations of the series. This is a game of special significance in our culture. And this review box isn't big enough to talk about the best in this game. If you are a rich person with a top computer hardware and a  curiosity and willingness to dive into the rough yet rewarding sea that is Arma 3, I suggest you go ahead and buy the game. It is worth it keeping in mind the things I mentioned. And if you are someone looking for a friendly and fun Arma 3 unit, there are many of them there very good ones. One of them is TheSpeshalPlatoon. Free to join. Buy this game. Go now.

I am 1500 hours in to my Arma journey, and there's a lot I gotta say. Bohemia has released a masterpiece of a game. This milsim is not too much in your face to the point where it's confusing, and everything is easy to understand. Modding the game can give it a lot of depth and expand upon already simple concepts if you find it too easy. Maybe you don't like shooting a rifle and hate combat? Well there's Zeus and Editor which allow you to sandbox the game and have fun making scenarios in which the AI will fight each other. Maybe you don't like firing a rifle, but you find Zeus and Editor boring, no problem! You can be a vehicle driver and operator, a extract and insertion pilot, you can use your wits to assemble Mortars and operate artillery for support to your unit. The community itself is also okay, I won't say it is good or awful however. I do find that most of the community is pretty funny and although hard on one another, do it out of fun and sarcasm. But there is the armpit of the community which exists that do like to be problems and enjoy making people mad, but what community DOESN'T have them? Overall, this is a neat and amazing title to play, I guarantee with mods and the frequent community attention the devs give this game, you will never be bored and always find something you want to try or do.

Ah yes, a review for Arma 3.

Arma 3's a decent game, though it could do with some fixes here and there, especially with the physics engine.
I've been killed a few times thanks to it acting up when im operating a vehicle.

Overall, the main campaign does require save-scumming at times, but generally, if you know what to do, how to do it, and do it well, you'll mostly end up only having to retry once or twice. I (accidently) went for the "Bad ending" (im not going to spoil what that means.) 

The Tanks DLC is a good DLC to buy, if you want to play with 2 of the 3 (I count the Angara's as one.) vehicles it adds in a "Campaign" setting.

The VANILLA Multiplayer scene is kinda isolated to Livonia, making getting the Contact DLC a pretty decent priority if you wanna play VANILLA Multiplayer.
Overall, when it comes to Multiplayer, try and find a unit with a friend or two in it, that's the best way to enjoy Arma 3 in Multiplayer.

My advice, get Marksmen, Tanks, and Apex, then join up with a unit you like.
It is a labour of love that if you can stick with will give you countless hours of fun especially if you find zeus groups

I wish I could recommend this game but unfortunately there's too much wrong with not only the game but also the community and developers. I will admit here and now that I have had many hours of good entertainment with the private groups that I was a part of. This game can be very enjoyable with the right people and if you're willing to overlook its many flaws. 

Compared to the previous title where $20 could buy you a whole new campaign, terrain, weapons & vehicles this game is overpriced with much content missing from the base game added through overpriced DLCs. It is rife with in-game and full screen advertisements if you try to use any of the DLC content. They will even take unpolished mods and slap price tags on them. The only good thing about that is that at least the original developer gets a cut of the profits. You will encounter poor multiplayer optomisation which will be blamed on the specifications of your computer and many bugs the developer has known about for years. This is allowed simply because they have no competition on this scale. They essentially have a monopoly on large-scale military simulator sandboxes.

The only way I could recommend this game to someone is if they already have friends who play on their own private server or if someone is willing to sink hours into simply trying to find a group that best suits them. You'll most likely have to try out many different groups before you find one that's good for you because just like the rest of the community you'll find lots of power hungry men trying to control other people, blatant racism, misogyny, homophobia and general anti-queer sentiment. Essentially if you aren't white, male, or straight you will have a hard time enjoying yourself. I would never recommend someone play on a public server. However, if you're willing to overlook the toxic community that the developer seems to willfully ignore then you might just have a good time. 

In the end this game is a huge disappointment. I can't say I'm looking forward to future titles from this developer.

Very fun milsim, spent most of my time on KOTH servers or playing the campaign. I will warn, it is very difficult if you attempt to play this like other shooters on the market; it's called a military simulator for a reason.

I was amazed with the variety of weapons and vehicles in the game(with many locked behind paywalls, which seemed reasonable to me) and the vast methods to customize your weapons. I sat down one night customizing just a few loadouts for what seemed like eternity, comparing all the similar scopes, judging for clarity, zoom, features, etc. They really put effort into every aspect of this military experience. I would recommend this game to anyone who is interested in an immersive military experience.

So I'll just give you the recipe for making Pumpkin and walnut squares

Ingredients:
125g plain flour
40g porridge oats
110g dark brown soft sugar
110g unsalted butter
2 egg whites
500g pumpkin puree
350ml evaporated milk
150g caster sugar
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
1/2 teaspoon ground cloves
65g chopped walnuts
110g dark brown soft sugar
30g unsalted butter
250ml whipped cream (optional)

Method: 
Preheat oven to 180 C / Gas 4. Spray or grease one 23x33cm or similar sized tin.
Mix together the flour, oats, dark brown soft sugar and butter. Press into tin; bake for 20 minutes or until golden brown.
In a large deep metal bowl, beat egg whites until soft peaks form.
Blend together the pumpkin puree, evaporated milk, egg whites, sugar, salt, cinnamon, ginger and cloves. Pour into baked pastry case; bake for 30 minutes or until firm.
Mix together the chopped nuts, dark brown soft sugar and butter. Sprinkle topping on custard and bake additional 15 minutes. Remove from oven and allow to cool. Cut into squares and top with whipped cream, if desired.

This game... where to start? I know I don't have near the high hours that some players have, but you can still get so much experience with so "little" time. I've played in PvP KOTH, Invade and Annex, Altis Life, Wasteland, tried and am learning in-game photography, and many operations filled with a loving community. And you know what the funny thing is? I don't think I'm going to stop playing this game any time soon. There is so many possibilities on what you can do! Most of my now 250 hours have been in the air or on the ground with an MG. I love playing the supportive role and just making everyone in the unit, team, or four person squad feel relaxed knowing that when the firefight starts, I'll be spitting 10x the metal that the enemy is. Flying in this game is extremely rewarding. Every time I jump into an MiG-29 I know what it's capable of. I've been in that seat so many times and know the quirks of the aircraft. The best thing is is that your experience in each plane transfers to the next! As you continue with your hours, you tend to find habits, techniques, and strategies that help you. Same with helicopters! I use to rush myself in KOTH to get the players to where they needed to go and usually got myself, or the entire group killed. After a while, I started playing on this massive Invade and Annex server. I met a few pilots that told me to slowly try out the big helis before going to the lighter and faster birds. This tip alone helped me so much. Making tiny movements instead of huge over-correction led me to find the sweet spots and how the aircraft could be handled. On the ground, it's an entirely different ball game. You don't have the advantage of countermeasures and being able to see your target miles away. You have to work on such a high level of teamwork that it astonishes me how unit's can have over 100+ players for an operation. Like I said, I'm usually posted up with a PKM or an M249 with hundreds of rounds, ready to open up at a moments notice. I have played rifleman and recon (M110) and enjoyed it, but nothing beats seeing the enemy flee to cover as I rip them to shreds with my 7.62, 650 rpm. 

Yes, there are a few bugs, issues, the whole sha-bang. But you'll find thousands of tutorials to help you out. Maybe your game files are broken, or it's simply you forgot to put in a keybind. There's always someone out there to help. Even for the simple things!

This game is absolutely wonderful. From the scenarios players make, to the silly dogfights with A-10's, or the serious operations where you're actually breaking a sweat, this game has something for everyone. Bohemia, you did one hell of a job and I hope the next Arma is just as legendary as this is. Oorah!

Thank you to these units and servers that have made a mark on my playing experience and the wonderful people I've met,

Task Force Disaster, Cyclone Company, United Gaming Network, 55th Delta Squad, Code4Gaming, and special thanks to the 107th Air Wing for teaching me all that I know now. I love you guys.

I held off on a review because Arma is one of those special games you only have good memories of, but when you really look into it you realize that the game itself is only a very small part of why you had fun. In a lot of cases you had fun *because* the game didn't work as intended. Honestly, I could write pages about what is good and wrong about the game, but I can explain everything simpler.

When Arma 3 came out, I didn't even know despite waiting for the release. At the time it looked so good it came off the screen, but nobody had a rig to play it. 7 years later, still nobody can run it, and while the game still looks good it has clearly aged in more than just the graphical aspect, but Bohemia don't seem to care about it.

Indeed, their DLCs don't exactly add too much to the game when everybody uses the workshop content to make an actually fun and playable game. They did have a few good and important updates, but it just shows what a joke it is when part of the fricking 2.0 changelog is 

"as well as a new color edition of an existing firearm, a camo variant for selected gear"

Greeeeeeeat, Arma 2.0 everyone, we have new skins... kind of sad really. So many more people could play and enjoy this game if they just focused on optimizing the game for multi-core performance and updated the shaders a bit. Yes, that is no small feat for a game this big, but if I saw that in the new changelog I would be playing Arma already.

At the end of the day, don't buy Arma 3 if you can do what you want in Arma 2. Yes, you get better graphics, but probably can't run it properly, and yes you get better physics and support, but honestly not to the extent that you want. And since you basically NEED Apex to play half the things, I would highly advise buying Arma 3, unless it's on a massive sale and you really want it. You are probably better off spending your time with other games, unless you have a big group to play with who specifically need Arma 3's uniqe capabilities and large variety of mods to play. But if you want to play alone, give up before you waste your money.

Pros:
-Wide array of different communities allowing you to slot into what you find enjoyable really easily.
-Huge gallery of mods and addons to optimise the game to how you like it.
-Interesting story that sets the bare basics of what the game is.
-The multiplayer is just fantastic, many different gamemodes from RP to Realistic Training to HUGE battles or even small scale team deathmatches and everything in between.
-Helpful community.
-Realistic physics and gameplay.
-A game that helps you to find your role and giving you plenty of options within those roles to experiment and master certain types of gameplay (everything from Land to Sea to Air or even the Zeus Creator mode).

Cons:
-Not incredibly optimised, graphical and framerate issues are part of the deal when getting this game unfortunately.
-Certain servers/gamemodes may deter some players because of their realism or long waiting times to get into the action.

My Opinion:
-I love this game, the previous games and cannot wait for the next. This game helped me to find a community that shared my interests and led to great friendships. Although I have ran into the Cons listed above, as you can see these are the only ones I can think of objectively, the Pros for me outweighed these Cons and are the reasons why I keep coming back to pick up the game again, hop on my favourite servers and just have a good time. Where Insurgency nails the realistic close quarters battles, SQUAD nails that teamwork and ACE Combat nails that sweet air combat, this game seems to take the best parts of all of these games and more to deliver a whole experience filled with everything military or whatever you want it to be through addons. I could easily load up my Star Wars mods and there I have an Incredibly large scale game of battlefront with realistic physics and great sound design, or maybe I feel like running around as a grunt from Halo or re-live the events of blackhawk down or maybe some tower defence, ever heard of DayZ? Maybe zombies are what I feel like that day, it doesn't matter at all because this game lets me do what I want to do and have fun with it. I hope you do too.

MIXED REVIEW. SPECIAL NOTE: If you enjoy LARPing as a genuine special forces operator, there is a Military Simulation community here that will be right up your alley. Personally, I find it cringe as hell. 

GAME MECHANICS: This is probably the most advanced military simulation on the market. That's saying a lot since it came out in what, 2013? The graphics are nice. There are ways to bump up the realism (such as advanced ballistics, radio simulation, contemporary military armaments, etc.). 

SINGLE PLAYER MODE. I personally feel that this game runs dry on single player mode. The missions are really not my cup of tea. Server-wise, people are generally accepting if you're polite. They answer questions. 

MULTIPLAYER MODE. This is probably where the game shines the brightest. There are a lot of servers offering a lot of different experiences. Some are very serious about squad based combat operations. Others, it's just a free for all. There's even RPG servers. Those make my skin crawl but they are very populated - which shows a very high degree of enthusiasm.

There are a lot of positive aspects to this game. Overall, I think I've got my money's worth. It's not my cup of tea.

Whilst a bit of a learning curve for anyone coming from more mainstream fps shooters which are little more advanced than a arena run and gun, Arma 3 shines in being a platform for thousands of different experiences.
Stances, mounting weapons and the weapon handling and ballistics feel superior to anything else I have seen or played.
The huge open maps give you opportunity to free roam and discover details and approach problems however you like.
With the combination of vehicles, infantry, explosives and a lack of intelligence being readily provided to you of the enemies position unless you or friends go and do the groundwork it gives an idea of what real warfare may be like.
Death is omnipresent threat with higher consequences which makes the firefight when you are caught moving between cover all the more visceral.
It has its issues;
Physics collisions between players, vehicles, rag-doll corpses and equipment being the one which first comes to mind followed by inventory bugs in some scenarios where you are handling more items than normal.

The Scenario Editor is complex and difficult to understand with what could be imagined as simple concepts such as respawning being un-intuitive in how to set up.

There is nothing I can say about Arma 3 that you aren't going to read somewhere else but I'll break down a few things for you. This gets a little rambling but bear with me.

The game was released in 2013 and is part of an ongoing series. I've been playing since Operation: Flashpoint originally came out. Even with that amount of time in various Arma games and the amount of time I've put into this one, I'm no expert. Most people joke that you're not even officially out of the tutorial until you've logged at least 700 hours.

Firstly, is it worth the money? That really depends on you and what you make of your time in the game. For most people, it's nearly an addiction. This game has so much to offer and so much that you can do but it's not really laid out for you on a silver platter. You've got to look for it and talk to veteran players. Many can point you in the right direction. It's pointless to list all of the things you can do in this game with the proper mods because for all practical purposes, there's not much of a limit.

You're going to get the most enjoyment out of this game by playing alongside other people. There are single player campaigns and missions (within the game and in the Workshop) that will help you kill some time or even learn the ropes but playing alongside other people enhances just about everything about this game. So, if you're going to play, get some friends together or make some in the community (or both). You'll be happy you did.

Are there bugs? Yes. Most definitely. If you haven't been killed by some bug or glitch in the game, you're not doing it right. But for the people that continue to play this game, those bugs don't matter. Everything else about this game makes up for it. There is going to be that occasion when you curse this game because of a bug that lays you out flat when you thought you had everything under control but when you weigh the rare bug against everything else that could possibly be going on in the game, you'll realize why some people call them features and just laugh them off.

Is it difficult? Refer to my tutorial comment above. Whenever I step away from this game for any amount of time I find that I've got to get back into the groove of playing. I'll forget some of the things that I learned to not do from previous deaths and end up making those mistakes again until my mind and body starts to remember. And it'll probably be that way with you if you stick with this game. There most definitely is a learning curve and if you don't have the patience for that, you're not going to have the patience for this game. Unlike some other games that you've probably seen mentioned multiple times in various reviews for Arma, charging a defended position is not likely to get you the win. It's just going to get you killed. This game is about patience and a healthy concern about getting shot up and bleeding out in some patch of mud on the outskirts of some town that you don't even know the name of. It's also about knowing when to quit being so patient and just charge in.

Speaking of that, the maps on this game are huge. And that still doesn't express just how big they are. The largest official map in Arma 3 is Altis. That map spans 270 km2. There's nothing I can think of to compare it to off-hand that can adequately express just how much play area is available. You won't be disappointed. Additionally, almost every structure in the game is destructible. Put enough artillery into a building and it's coming down. And there is definitely bullet penetration. Hiding out in that tin shack won't do you a bit of good if someone with a powerful rifle is seriously looking to put you down.

One of the great things about this game by far is the modding community. There is a lot of love put into this game by those modders and mods like Liberation and Antistazi have given my friends and I hours upon hours upon days of enjoyment (and possibly a few war crimes may have been committed but I wouldn't know anything about that and that's my story). Additionally, Arma 3 gives you the tools to create your own scenarios if you so choose; within the game itself via Zeus and outside of an actual session with the Editor. Mods are the way to truly optimize the level of fun you can have in this game.

If you love CoD and BF, chances are, this is not the game for you. The same tactics that make you good at those games will most likely get you killed consistently in this one. However, if you're the type of person that is adaptable and wants a serious challenge in a (and I dread calling it this) "shooter", then this is worth a try and worth sticking with.

I own every DLC this game put out and, for me, it was well worth it. If you think you're going to enjoy the game, wait for the sale and pick up, at the very least, the core game and the Apex DLC. That should pretty much tide you over until you can pick up the rest of the game. If you're just not sure, pick up the core game. But don't expect to be able to play for Steam's ridiculously short refundable play time and expect to get a real feel for the game. Honestly, if you limit your play time to that short of a period, chances are you're probably going to walk away from this game thinking it's not worth it and miss out on something truly great.

EDIT: One thing I forgot to note is that this game is primarily CPU intensive. I've heard that at lower settings, it shunts off more of the work to your GPU but I've not verified that myself. The best thing you can do if you get this game is, unless you own a beast of a machine, do some research and read up on settings changes you can make that will work better for your PC. Make those changes. But don't expect to ever get 120fps. For most, that will never happen. But, for those having problems with their frames, the right tweaks can make all the difference in the world.

I've owned Arma 3 for roughly 6 months now and have sunk nearly 600 hours into this game. You do the math.

Though I will preface that the majority of my time played (Likely around 400 hours) was solo play or with one other friend, it is some of the most intense and fufilling gameplay I've come across in any mil-sim. The online community is by far from dead, however there are only a handful of fullish servers that play only a handful of modes. To me, the most fun and dynamic part of the game come from hopping into a workshop created scenario with one or two friends and taking on whatever time period you see fit.

The biggest strength of Arma that shows to me is the incredible modders, map makers, and story tellers that fill the Workshop with singleplayer and multiplayer scenarios reaching across the globe all the way back to WW2 and some even farther back. You can go from playing alone with an AI squad in the lush jungles of vietnam, defending your beach landing from encroaching vietkong. To five minutes later in Pakistan with your 3 friends running Intel missions on terrorizer compounds in the middle of the night with fully M O D U L A R modern gear. To 20 minutes later in a 16 person co-op game where you are culling the chechen uprising in Chernarus.

While the game was likely once touted for it's large, robust, and inclusive online, The game has been out and in the hands of talented modders for years now. The workshop with it's scenarios, weapon and apparel mods, game modes, maps, etc is probably one of the most impressive on steam and makes it an easy buy for anyone wanting to get into some tense action where every shot counts.

So one thing I will definitely say about Arma 3 after the countless hours I put into it, is that the game is only as fun as you let it be. You can play it super casual, competitive, PvE, PvP, what have you. All I can say is, do what you enjoy and find some friends for the ride. A game like this is infinitely better with a squad of friends to work together. 

One final note, is that modding is ABSOLUTELY Mandatory for the maximum amount of fun. Wanna play WW2? Iron Front. Expand the modern setting? RHS and CUP. Wanna get more realistic and indepth in controls? ACE and ACE Medical. Wanna go to the battlefields of the 41st Millenium? Grimdark Armory and There is Only War.

This game's variety is practically infinite thanks to the amazing modding community, and means that Arma 3 no matter what can keep going strong and give people who love the military shooters something to do.

when I was looking for a game to play I heard about Arma 3 and Squad. I got squad first because back then, it was cheaper. I enjoyed Squad so during a sale I bought the apex pack for Arma 3( Arma is unplayable without at least the apex pack) at first I went into the game and did the tutorial. I was pleasantly surprised, Arma unlike most shooters had realistic gunplay and movement which is rare in most games these days. BUT when I went into an actual game I realized what I hate about Arma. in Arma 3 there are many different game modes BUT the only one anybody plays is Zeus, in Zeus one player controls an enemy team and the other players have to work together on one team. in the tutorial you can choose your loadout and armor its great fun, BUT in the actual game, the game master (Zeus) gets to decide your teams 3-5 loadout options. the gamemaster usually spends the whole game doing NOTHING!. even if your gamemaster is controlling his units, you have to walk for HOURS is a quite frankly bland and boring environment to fight a bunch of at best rookie-level NPCs with a loadout that makes no sense.

There is a campaign. but at best it's mediocre at best with funky directions, easy combat and when you run out of bullets you have to restart the whole campaign. You could have fun with Arma 3 but quite frankly it's more trouble than its worth.

overall Arma 3 is a steaming turd. 

If you want something that's like Arma 3 but fun I can recommend:

Squad
Battlefield 1
Battlefield 4
Battlefield 5

An impressive classic in the genre of military simulators. Despite the relatively fast development of 'squad', Arma 3 is still at its level and it is worth buying on some promotion to get to know this phenomenal game. It still has problems with optimization from the beginning, but for people with a slightly better computer it is not so arduous problem, such as learning the mechanics of this difficult game

If you ever have a craving for a fun fest in editing missions and playing scenarios on a military simulator type game then this is for you. I found myself coming back for more and more as I jumped from one mod to another with friends as I would create stories that they could play in. I joined a few regiments and found more fun as we would sing in the back of trucks on our way to overthrow the government as rebels. Here are a few more things of note:

- Be prepared to have your PC run overdrive as you go into larger missions that you or your friends make.
- Get ready to have PTSD as your regiment leader plays god and controls an enemy sniper to blow out your friend's leg or be surrounded by enemies and have no ammo or medical supplies insight.
- Playing with friends or a good group is the primary way to have fun in this game. Although there are other servers with different modes that can be fun too like King of the Hill. (I find KOTH to be quite repetitive tbh but that is just me)
- You might need a second drive to hold a large number of mods you are going to download as the developers do not add much to the game and the modding community makes everything. (I mean everything)
- Role-playing servers can be fun although getting into a good one can take a bit of time.

The game has a lot to offer and with a bit of dedication, you will find fun. You make what you want to experience so have fun and godspeed to you.

Riddled with heaps of game-breaking bugs, game feels fairly thin without the expensive Apex/Contact DLC, extremely obnoxious with watermarks when using any items from DLC you don't own (go suck a lemon Marksman DLC), has a mediocre campaign that I haven't even bother finishing due to some of the unbelievably grueling missions, commanding AI is like herding lobotomized cats, CSAT units look dumber than crap and are exceedingly frustrating to fight due to that idiotic underbarrel .50 (smooth brain firearm design on insane levels, like what the frick even is the point of that), and last and worst of all: the server system (e.g. I'm trying to host a server for a friend to join) is THE WORST THING I HAVE ENCOUNTERED IN MY MISERABLE EXISTENCE. I can't even begin to describe how much of a pain in the scrotum it is to use. I still can't manage to host a server, despite watching like 15 different stupid YouTube videos.

10/10 game, worth twice the money I paid for it.

Despite the myriad of issues I listed, I love this game. I've never had more fun with friends in a game, the "mil-sim"-ish appeal this game has scratches an itch that no other game has managed to do. The modding support is fantastic. Need earplugs so helicopters don't give you tinnitus? There's a mod for that. Want to repack your magazines? There's a mod for that. Want to customize your character face to look like an abomination of a crying-laughing emoji? There's a way to do it.

There are also plenty of public servers for game modes like Escape, Liberation, and the like. Really good multiplayer experience for PVE, though not PVP largely because I hate 3rd person for multiplayer. Again, had a lot of fun with my friends on this game, and we've all racked up tons of hours teamkilling each other at the FOB, executing prisoners, and mortaring villages. 

As a whole I'd say Arma provides a great base for talented modders to really shine and put out some really creative and interesting stuff, like Anistasi and Dynamic Recon Ops. If you have some buddies who are pestering you to pick it up, wait for a Steam sale and grab it with the Apex DLC and you'll get a few hundred hours out of it if you're into this kind of game. As long as you can handle being shot by enemies you can't see, much less even make out the direction of, as well as having your MRAP explode for running over the wrong bush, it should provide you with a fair amount of fun.

I rarely endorse games. This one far surpassed the realism to an agonizing degree. The long chopper rides, the faint pops of gunfire in the distance. The whirling of the blades as you gaze at the ground below you flying by. Nothingness, endless terrain ranging from forests, mountains, and valleys. While on the way to the LZ that someone marked on the map with little to no knowledge of what AA batteries are in the way you bravely forge into sprinting distance of your objective. Perhaps you get shot down, maybe you hear the blaring alert that your chopper has been locked on and your pilot bless his heart has to deal with the choice of landing, pulling off some wild moves and landing or death. Regardless, you land and nothing awaits you but the sound of gunfire and the brief flash of the enemies tracer rounds flying right by your face. You look towards your teammates but they are also just as lost as you are. You're in hostile territory but you forge on looking wildly around you while diving for what ever scant cover you can find. You spot them far enough for them to hit you a couple of times, just far enough that your best aim is jostled by the recoil while you lay prone in tall enough grass to obscure your view that you have to kneel and expose yourself to gun fire. Then you hear it, the faint motor of a tank heading towards you and just like that it takes aim and fires and no sooner than that you're dead. Only to attempt the same fate again. This is but one of the many situations you can find your self in Arma 3. Between being able to fight back using missile launchers and calling for air support you can find yourself in the midst of providing cover fire whilst your FOB is being attacked on all sides to being on the top of a hill raining down missiles on a convoy. Either way both the sheer confusion of combat coupled with the sheer variation in the ways to play there is something for everyone here.
