Usually people on steam reviews complain about bugs or glitches but I never see or rarely exprience what the bugs they are complaining about

Not this game, it is RIDDLED with glitches and bugs. Holy shit I dont even know where to start because every aspect and gameplay element has bugs, from rocks to bushes to vehicles to guns to doors to windows to grenades.

Not to mention the insanely clunky animations and movement system. It supposed to be 'realistic' yet with clunky movements you could zig-zag like a lighting bolt and do 180 degree turns and weave left and right like you weight like a feather and throw off the aim of even the best marksman in the game.

All of these bugs, glitches and exploits have been in the game since release and they have invested 0 amount of effort into fixing any of them.

The community knows about all of this but shrugs it off.

Save your money and effort, if you want hardcore/realistic first person shooter, go buy Squad or Insurgency, they are a thousand times more polished. If you want a 'battle' simulator with tanks, jets, helis and etc, then get Battlefield. Arma is a clunky, buggy and runs like shit even on top end PCs because you are always bottle necked by the single core performance of your CPU. 

Community is hyper-toxic and full of basement-dwellers/neckbeards like RoidRage and moderators of C4G (Not an insult, they confirmed they are overweight/anti social in several chats). Squad has the same type of people but there countless alternatives and servers to chose from till you find people that you fit in with. This is not the case with Arma 3 since C4G run the 2 most populated HC/FPV only servers.

The other half of community is mil-sim 'gamers' who spam reddit with 'screenshots' (check arma subreddit) and play 'operations' against 'AI Bots'. If you are not into that crap, you're already alienated from half of community alone.

tl;dr clunky buggy do-it-all "game" with a garbage community on top. Get Insurgency or Squad instead for a polished PVP experience. Gameplay wise, Arma 3 doesn't offer anything extra.

ARMA 3 is a very interesting game. Broadly, it is a very detailed simulation of war, but ARMA 3 also has the potential to be a modder's resource for so many other scenarios. I must admit that the sheer amount of keybindings for this game is quite intimidating at first, but with just a little effort, you can easily learn the necessary controls to make for an enjoyable experience. It should be stated that the target of this game is realism and sometimes realistic controls and game mechanics can be frustrating. Mechanics as small as a shaking first and third person camera while moving and changing directions or a helicopter exploding because it was landed too quickly. It is also not uncommon to have to travel a distance of 20 kilometers in online matches to reach your objective. 

All things considered, ARMA 3 is an excellent war simulation that provides all the tools you will need to create your own war and more.

After over a 1000 Hrs on ARMA 3 I have to say you can soak a lot of time into this game. 

CAMPAIGN - I've played about 10 Hrs of the single player part of this game and I'll be honest the bit I played where very interesting and at times immersive. and i think for a game that was released in 2013 it's well up there with the games of the time. although by today's standards as I've only played it the past year it's very dated and I feel that if an ARMA 4 is ever released we'll see a better more vast campaign should they make one again.

ONLINE CO-OP / MULTIPLAYER - Now this is where this game is different with a multitude of servers game types and play opportunities this is where ill say this game shines, with assets from the workshop you can go from playing a modern day military shooter to a survival type scenario, or role playing servers to WW2 style servers. I'd day there is probably something for everyone. However this is all dependent on the server you join and the Admins / Rules to each server and I'd be lying if i said all servers are perfect as this just inst the case. but once you find i good server or one that is best suited to you, you'll be lost for hours in this game. 

OVERALL - A good game that I have and would recommend this game to friends. it can be buggy and clunky at times however this doesn't take away much from the overall experience. 

So if i was to give this game a rating I'd say 10/10 and I hope that Bohemia release a newer smoother game within the next two years. Hope this helps someone.. Jeff

If your looking for a war time experience, where your able to log off and sleep in your own bed every night. I suggest this game. Multiple Game Modes and DLC's. The mod community is extensive, and you can even find iconic missions, ranging from Real World Wartime Missions / Assets (Task Force Canada, which adds CDN and US forces and assets.) , Scenarios from popular movie franchises. (X-files, Starship Troopers, Aliens, Predator, Terminator, The Thing.. ECT.) Perhaps you would like to produce missions of your own, if so, the game also offers a feature for you to take command as Zeus, (GOD) Class, which allows you to create missions and add assets as you see fit, the only real limitations are time and imagination. For an in game Dev kit, it works well and is quite entertaining to use once learned.  The game features a wide range of mechanics and assets, some of which will only be usable upon purchase of the subsequent DLC.  Each DLC offers something new to the game, and although it is a bigger purchase i recommend, (if the wallet allows) purchasing the the Ultimate edition of the game. This will save you a couple of bucks in the long run. If the $100+ price point is too demanding on the pockets, Look towards the Apex Edition, as it comes with most of the DLC content.
trust me when i say this, You wont be sorry. Additionally Bohemia offers a DLC called CONTACT, where you play as a squad member in a first contact scenario. what do i mean by first contact? "Intelligent Life, and not the kind you find every time you cross the boarder." The DLC is interesting, and it features you guessed it, its own specific assets and missions. (CONTACT IS NOT REQUIRED TO PLAY ONLINE MULTIPLAYER AS IT IS A SINGLE PLAYER SCENARIO, HOW EVER SOME ASSETS CAN BE USED IN THE MULTIPLAYER GAME MODE.)

Further more, The player base in this franchise is TOP TIER, Players in this game actually play their roles! Team work is a must if you plan to survive the engagement with the enemy. Make use of your skills and your team mates skills to survive. Leave no man behind, as you run wounded soldiers to the nearest Medi Vac. Snipe from great distances and give our forward forces the edge of your position in over watch. Got the enemy location mark it on the map and call in an air strike. Finally got that friendly  tank to the AO? UNLEASH HELL! What ever role you play in Arma 3, I see you out there, Holding it down! and if your still reading this... THE HELL ARE YOU WAITING FOR SOLDIER!!! WE NEED REINFORCEMENTS AT THE A.O. A.S.A.P!!!

Had this game in my library for a while after picking it up on a sale. Gave it a try last week.

Downloaded the Antistasi (realtime guerilla war mod) mods. 

Profited.

Just to give an idea: my time with Antistasi; Liberation of Malden so far:

On sunday, I put on my civvy clothes to scout out the factory near my rebel HQ. Checked it out with the binoculars, counted a few soldiers. Got caught by police somehow, and shot. 

Shit was on. Immediately went back with a team of 3 guerillas. Put on my guerilla gear. Moved up on the factory from the west, where a patch of forest provides enough cover to move up close to the factory perimeter. As we get closer, the shooting starts. I keep my head down while trying to somehow position my men. Before long, they are all shot and I make a frantic run for it.

I decide to wait for night, and try again - this time with more guerillas. 8 of us get in a truck and take some backroads close to the factory. I bring a medic this time.

We move down the road with the lights out (no idea if this matters btw), and I park the truck next to the road. I organize my troop in 4 teams and order them to hold their fire until my command. 2 teams take the western approach again. My team and the remaining go around the north, where we can see up the hill to the northeast and down the hill to the southeast. All clear. The enemy is inside the factory perimeter to our south. I sneak all my men as close in as I can, the western forest and an office building across the street from the factory providing cover. With everyone in position, I order my guerillas to open fire.  It quickly becomes clear that we control this fight as enemies move toward cover and away from the fight. With them surrounded, we quickly finish them off as I order my men to advance. We have now taken the factory. I order my men to rearm with the shiny weapons of the NATO troops we just took out. I finally gain hold of a radio and use it to recruit an infantry team and an MG squad.  It turns out to be a good call, as the enemy soon starts a counterattack from the hills to the northeast, which we manage to repel. Not much later, some loud bangs rock the little island - CSAT is attacking the island. 



It's now tuesday night in game, and I have lost the factory. NATO knows the location of my HQ and is clearly stepping up it's game. I still intend to take the factory and the town and seaport surrounding it. 


This game, and especially this mod - they provide a very good all-round wargaming experience. Real time sandbox, quite atmospheric. Does a good job at immersing you in the action. Firefights are spectacular, in spite of a lack of effects to hammer home the effects of being under fire or anything fancy like that. 

Very enjoyable. I think every wargamer should pick it up. All in all, Arma 3 provides more than the sum of it parts to me.

I used to play this a lot more, but don't find myself able to do it anymore. Most of my time in this game has been spent in the editor making missions. The reason why i stopped playing is:
1 The framerate is really just terrible  
2. the AI are so god awful they cannot follow even the simplest commands without something stupid happening such as:

Getting stuck on a rock
Wasting all their ammo at an enemy who is completely in cover
Walking through doors and walls (Why couldn't they do that for the rock?)
Repeatedly shooting the edge of the bunker they are in because it is in between them and their target
Driving straight forward from point A to B on one road but somehow flipped their car/tank, got stuck on something, ran over friendlies, rammed another friendly vehicle destroying them both and killing everyone nearby, or even just deciding to drive the opposite direction you told them to, and ended up miles away from the combat area.

One more thing showing this games age is the way you would select a gun from the arsenal, i have about 50 variants of an M-4, but really most of them are the same just with different attachments, or different camos. This system is archaic and tedious at best. Now imagine this for every gun in the game. It's absolutely terrible, and one of the top things they need to fix in Arma 4.

Unfortunately i can no longer even recommend this on a technical standard either- if you want a good combat flight sim go play DCS, if you want good tank/ infantry gameplay go play squad. They offer more in terms of simulation and in terms of fun.

One thing this game does well is its amount of content- but not from the developers, i mean the steam workshop has thousands of mods, some of which completely change the game to something like star wars, fallout, starship troopers, ww1, ww2, vietnam, pirates, halo... you name it. When you get enough weapon mods it feels like the scene in the matrix when Neo says he'll need guns, and racks on racks fly past him. When you get enough maps this game has by far the most square miles of any game ever, spare NMS.

Unfortunately everything is showing its age. Even something like squad offers more immersion even in something as simple as shooting the .50 cal machine gun. The sound, the handling, the debris from the barrel, the tracers, bullet impacts... everything is so much better. (Not to mention the framerate!)

I'm gonna have to say no i don't recommend, because i never find myself playing this game anymore, mostly because of these listed reasons. Just wait for Arma 4 or pick up squad.

If you're reading reviews and wondering if Arma 3 can be fun solo, I'm here to say that yes, it definitely can be. Download some maps from the Steam Workshop, or the armaholic website. Next, download some mission generators like Dynamic Recon Ops, Dynamic Combat Ops, Dynamic Universal War System, Fight Back, Antistasi, or Ravage for said maps and you basically get infinite replayability.

If you need anymore convincing, just look at my playtime and remember that every minute of that has been exclusively single player.

The main issue overall however is performance. The frame rate can vary from 15-200 depending on a variety of reasons caused by the mission at hand. There are almost no graphical tweaks or other improvements that will provide a better experience in most multiplayer matches.

If there's a military sim fan in you with an urge for something, Arma 3 can more than likely provide a fix for the said urge. Stealth, special ops, sniping, close quarters, vehicular combat etc.
Day and night, storms and bright skies, air and sea, low and high tech, small huts to cities, realism to zombies to Warhammer 40K. You just have to find what you're looking for.

The game is good but leaves a bit to be desired, the controls are fairly smooth but I like the feel of a controller. The game has plenty of features which makes the controller useless, however if you download another program you can edit the controls to various degrees of preference. With that out of the way.... The game itself without all the expansion dlc updates is far too BORING for the amount of hype it's had for me.

As much as I love this game, Bohemia's neglect, lack of communication for years, reselling of Arma assets again in DayZ, poor treatment of contract-modders, string of poor quality DLCs, and gaps of updates which add unnecessary sidecontent that introduces new bugs and fixing few/no old ones, brings me to this point.

Bohemia of today is vastly different from the Bohemia of 2011 when this game first entered Early Access.

I would say it's an awesome game but with its difficulties to play with. Next, I will be putting down what I like and dislike about it:
Firstly, Graphics:
The graphics need A LOT of work on. I know it's an old game, but come on guys.. gotta do better than that. Don't get me wrong, the graphic are OK, but there is staff like planes when crashing are just bouncing in place, death animations need a little work on. For someone that is looking to buy this, you could add a few 'mods' to fix that.
Next, the community:
It could get a little toxic, but in time, when you get to understand the game properly, you will not have a problem. 
There is 2 kinds of people in this game:
1.) The EXTREME strategist that bosses everyone around and if you crash your chopper/plane while getting to the mission, you get your head bitten off.
2.) The guy that only wants to enjoy this game after a hard day at school/college/work and has got to deal with 10 people yelling at him to get his ass to that position on the hill. 
SPECIAL 3rd PERSON: That kinda guy that just does not give a flying f... about anything and crashes every single time for the fun of it, if that's you, I love you man, you ARE MAKING MY DAY, keep doin whatcha doin.
Next, the complexity of this game:
It can be VERY hard to get used to the controls in this game, there are a couple of mods that will help you get more comfortable with 'em, but I would say it would be better to just learn everything through vanilla.
In this game, YOU, as an individual will have a lot to learn and to be fair, it is FUN! You have a HUGE range of vehicles and weapons you will have to make your way through, that's makes this game AMAZING. Another point that I want to make is that ARMA itself will never get boring and it will never let you down. Not mattering what you are doing, you will have fun while doing it in this game.
Next, servers:
You could play campaigns in single player or co-op, but I would prefer joining the servers themselves, getting to know the communities. There are LOTS of gamemodes you could pick from in the servers.
Long story short, every game has its downsides and its upsides. In principle, I highly recommend buying this game and if you want to experience it fully, I recommend buying APEX as well.

As the game's description implies, Arma 3 truly is a "massive military sandbox". Most of the DLCs are solid and include additional campaigns and units. In addition, there is a fairly active modding community that offers a lot of great additional content adding maps, factions, multiplayer modes, and plenty more. Would you like to recreate WWII battles? See the Cold War go hot? There are mods and DLC for that. Want to have the US Army fight Isis on the Moon? You can make that happen.

Multiplayer is what draws most people to Arma 3, but sandbox fans like me can spend hours in the included editor, dropping squads, vehicles, and emplacements in real time to set up both realistic and wildly unrealistic situations. Using Zeus you can quickly set up small squad vs squad engagements, or massive combined arms operations. Opposition proving too tough? Just spawn clouds of A-10s so thick that the sky blackens and fills your headphones with BRRRRRT, while the ground ahead (and your frame rate) are ground into dust. The only limits in this game are one's imagination and PC specs. 

For the cons, Arma 3 is not the most well optimized game and does better when run on machines with higher single core clock speeds.  However - I run the game on a Ryzen 2600/2060 RTX and 16GB of decently fast DDR4 and unless I am dealing with hundreds of units and vehicles all firing at the same time I find my FPS is in an acceptable range. Multiplayer games are a non-issue  here since almost all of the heavy lifting is done on the server. A lot of the optimization does also come down to how responsibly you choose to perform garbage collection (removing dead/unused assets from the scenario), whether it's done by hand in Zeus or via scripting. 

The AI, while fairly advanced for all that is being asked of it, can be quite dumb sometimes and for more complex maneuvers often need to be literally told  how to do certain things (see: way-points and/or scripts) - like driving in an orderly fashion to form convoys, or garrisoning inside buildings. There is also nothing major in the way of an AI "commander" although the great ALiVE mod and others offer that functionality and tons more if you so desire.

The cons are far, far outweighed by the positives. If realistic FPS and war simulation games appeal to you, Arma 3 should already be in your library. If you like sandboxes, base building, survival games, coop, PVP - get this game and prepare to sink many hours into it.

7 years from original release, I can finally recommend a playthrough of the ARMA 3 campaign. However, you need to install a lot of mods not only to try and bring the gameplay up to modern standards, but also the visuals. Framerate is still a major problem in 2020. Out of the box, this game is a no-go unless you have a supercomputer. I was able to tweak object view distance with mods to hit 50-60 fps as normal for walking around on foot. Flying, the framerate can drop to 30, and that's acceptable. Definitely a CPU bound game. I noticed an improvement in smoothness of the game when overclocking from 4.0 Ghz to 4.8 Ghz (i7-4790k). Hope this info is helpful.

When I first installed this game, it was a few weeks after it was released in 2013, and let me tell you, the game back then needed a LOT of work to live up to it's name... the game genuinely felt incomplete.
So, after a few weeks of messing around with mods from armaholic and experimenting offline, I dropped A3 and went back to ArmA 2.

Well, it's been 7 years and a lot has changed since those days, too many updates to count, steam workshop support, the eden editor, and a bunch of DLC, just to name a few.
This game as it was released wasn't worth the 60$ they were asking at the time, but today, it's not only worth the 30$ they ask now, but it's still worth that 60$ in my opinion.

Had this game been released in the state it is now, back then, I'm confident it would've competed against GTA V for the best game of 2013, and ArmA 2's servers would have dried up a lot quicker than they actually did.

However it should be noted, while they no longer have just 2-3 helicopters, no planes, and only a handful of infantry weapons, you're still probably going to need a few basic mods to enjoy the full ArmA experience. Keep in mind I have over 300 mods, but these are the most essential in my opinion;
CUP - brings back remastered versions of the ArmA 2 units and maps which is necessary because... well the vanilla ones kinda suck.
RHS - these are sort of the default "modern military" unit/equipment packs, if you've seen any YouTuber play this game, they were probably using content by RedHammer Studios, you'll need Armed Forces of the Russian Federation(AFRF) and US Armed Forces(USAF) for the basics, and then there's two more packs that add additional weapons and units for diversity.
FIR - has made some of the best aircraft I've seen for a game, RHS has a few and they're okay, but FIR specializes in aircraft, so his stuff is all top quality.
If you're into WW2, don't forget to check out IFA3 and Faces of War.
And zombie fans will be happy to hear DayZ's influence on this game continues to live on, as there have got to be literally thousands of custom missions for the Ravage zombie survival mod.

The only issues I have are, the game is still extremely taxing on my PC with more complex missions, and the multiplayer can be a bitch to figure out if you don't have exactly the right combination of mods and DLC to join a match.
Overall: 9/10
(My 2013 rating if you want to know probably would've been a 6/10)

This game is immensely popular, but you have to understand it's the community-created content that people actually enjoy.  Quite a few games create a basic framework of game mechanics and then depend on modders to fill out the rest of the content.  Arma is relatively inexpensive, so the total lack of actual content you get with the base game can be forgiven.

. . . except for the fact the framework the developers made is almost unplayable.  I am not a skilled FPS player by any means, so if I die because I made a stupid tactical decision, that's just part of the game.  If I die (over and over and over again) because the controls are physically impossible to do on a keyboard or I try to "climb over" a fence and instead phase into it portal-style and can't move (providing the enemy a stationary target) then that is something else entirely.  This is one of those games where 5% of your deaths will be due to enemy fire, and 95% will be due to bugs.  Not much fun.

If they update this game with actual working mechanics in the future, I may change my review.  But at the moment this is one more game where the devs receive all the money and rely on the mod community to fix the game, for free.

As a silver lining, I do like how they incorporate realistic military tactics and procedures - even pathfinding using the map is a fun puzzle in itself.  But again, if you have to avoid taking cover because you might end up super-glued to that cover and need to restart the mission. . . the path finding doesn't really matter does it?

Best played with a regular group who can design missions or play Zeus (game-master), but due to the sandbox nature and extensive modding options, the game supports a wide variety of activities. Some single-player is available, but the real core of Arma is a co-operative team (whether that's against other players or the AI).

The game is a bit long in the tooth, but despite being old it can have poor performance on even first-rate hardware, depending on the complexity of the scenario. That being said, twitch shooting is not really what the game is about, and unless things are really going sideways you'll usually have sufficient frames to have a good time.

Arma isn't really an action shooter, it's more about teamwork, coordination, and good planning. If you're after a jump-in-and-play high-speed game with excellent gunplay, try Insurgency or Battlefield instead. Arma does offer realistic ballistic simulation, but the movement and physics are still quite clunky. That's fine for what Arma is, but if you're looking for something smoother and faster, this ain't it.

For convenience, I'll be splitting this review into several points: the main base game, the modding community/multiplayer, and the DLCs. I believe each of the points will make it easier to understand why I love this game so much. I don't believe this game serves any single purpose but multiple.

The main game on its own is... limited at best. You get a pretty full campaign, but it is plagued by terrible AI either quick-shooting you or mentally unable to fully utilize basic motor functions. It's frustrating, to say the least, but I like the story for what it's worth. For a military simulator, Arma 3 does not fall too short in that aspect for sure simulating explosive fragmentation and bullet ballistics. Sure the base medical system is one of its weak points, but there aren't many games that fully simulate so many aspects of combat. The true "base" fun I've had relies on the game's editor. Ever since the Eden update, mission making has only become stronger and easier to do. I've had more fun coming up with scenarios to play with my friends than playing the actual game. It's a military sandbox the fun comes with what you can make. However, if you are still looking for something beyond mission making or military for that matter, the multiplayer will surely supplement it.

The only other game I know which exceeds the number of communities of Arma is Gmod. You have servers for full-on milsims, RP servers, or just pure PVP KOTH. If you can't find value in the single-player, the online community is a good place to find it. Besides the community servers, the workshop is huge. It fully encapsulates the meaning of a sandbox. Whatever you want to make, there's probably a mod out there that can help. Not to mention mods like Ace which expand the game's complexity 10-fold. If you love games like Garry's Mod, Ravenfield, or anything like those. I highly recommend you try out Arma.

For the DLCs, I'll be quick on each of them as I expect to write a review for each separately later on. The amount of content for each one varies but if you're looking to pick and choose, I can group them into several groups. If you're looking for a single-player experience, the IDAP DLC, Tac-Ops DLC, Tanks DLC, and Contact DLC all expand on the single-player story in one way or another. The Apex DLC can count as well since you can play those scenarios solo. Each DLC (-Tanks DLC) explores a different way to play Arma single player. The IDAP DLC focuses on story/world-building; to me, it has the best story in Arma 3. The Tac-Ops DLC explores multi-role operations and is based on immersion. They are built to make you feel like a cog in the war machine influencing other squads in various operations. The Contact DLC brings true open-world scenarios and is akin to something like the Farcry series (but miniature in scale). The Apex DLC is a Co-Op campaign, nothing too special besides being very cinematic for a multiplayer scenario. The other DLCs not mentioned (Marksman, Jets, Helicopters, etc.) are more useful in vanilla multiplayer but I do not recommend getting them besides supporting BI. The only one I would recommend is Marksman bringing unique weapons such as High-Caliber machine guns and subsonic guns. Overall, the DLCs are not needed to fully enjoy the game. Most mods are not DLC dependent and if you plan to play on community servers, they are most likely modded.

END
IF there's anything I missed, I'll make the changes later. If you're one of my friends, I'm sorry for the review spam.

I am going to start off this review by clarifying something. This game is not for everyone.

I initially got this game at request of a previous gaming buddy. He had really enjoyed it after he got it. I started it, and immediately hated it. It's not what you expect at first glance. This game, in my opinion, has very long learning curve. You have to power through the initial disappointment to get enjoyment from my experience. From there, we move onto the actual Pros and Cons that may at first be viewed differently due to a potentially stressful first twenty-ish hours.

Pros: Awesome community. You can find quite literally any mod you may want. Online games can be very, very involved. Many servers and many fun gamemodes to go along right out of the gate. 

Cons: I do not know of a game that runs worse than this does. It must be designed to punish you performance wise, as it will refuse to use extra resources available when it needs them to run better. UI Can be confusing. Time requirement. Occasional cheaters ruining muliple hour, or day long games.

Overall, it's a pretty good game. I personally would not buy it full price. I got it on sale and would recommend everyone else do the same. DLC is alright, although a little pricey for what it is in my eyes. I would mainly recommend this to someone who has the time to sit down and play for a few hours straight, as some of the games can get very involved as previously stated. Don't buy it if you are used to a Call of Duty Headglitch and Jump around multiplayer experience.

This game, is definitely versatile. There are so many possibilities and things you can do. And I've had my fair share of time put into the game. But most of the time, was spent in the EDEN editor. Personally, I'm not much for one to play online with randoms. Just isn't my thing. So I did what I could in finding missions in the workshop, and many addons to explore in the editor. Ravage is a great one for a beginner, not much scripting needed as well as some other stuff. It's all very in depth. 

So why did I not recommend this you ask? Well personally. I'm at a loss. I'm a really creative person. But I feel as though a lot of my creative ideas have become halted by the fact that so much in this editor and such require scripting. And not only that, but I think this is more of a game that thrives off its multiplayer experience. And that really is not something I'm on board with. I was excited to explore and create, learn new things. But the amount of time I feel as though I have to take to learn the editor. As well getting certain other addons, or missions to work for that matter. Is daunting. It's starting to feel like a chore. I am still going to take my hand at figuring things out, but I've become burnt out right now for trying. If I can figure more things out, and get my many, many questions answered. Then I will update my review. For now, I'm not happy with it. 

However, for those of you, who enjoy multiplayer experiences and playing with friends. Exploring the vast variety of missions and workshop items to create an even more vast experience, then by all means go for it! This game is for you! I just wanted to share my opinion on why I can't recommend this. It's for the ones like me, who enjoy their single player experiences and getting to explore and create. If you're one of those, keep in mind. You will be fairly limited on your ideas, unless you know your way around the editor and scripting. If not, be prepared to watch and read a boat load of tutorials, as well as google searching almost anything.

ArmA 3 is my all time favourite game, there are few games that I have racked up over 1000 hours (as of writing this I have around 1470 hours), with so many game changing mods and communities to play with its difficult to get bored! I went through my fair share of milsim groups and clans but since 2016 have been playing with 4 others doing our own mini missions. Best played with mods and friends.

Many reviews and gamers alike will have a love/hate relationship with this game, not me, I love it.  My first introduction to this genre of gaming was way back in 2001 with Operation Flashpoint, Cold War Crisis.  After playing the demo (when game companies did that sort of thing) I was hooked.  What game at the time allowed you to fight as an Infantryman, a pilot, tank commander, special ops etc.  An editor to make your own mission or mess around, a campaign using different military resources, it had it all.  Okay, there were some bugs but hey you can overlook those just for the amount you got in one package.

We move forward in time to ARMA one and two,  same deal as above, more action, better visuals and variety and yes it had the bugs.  I've played them all even the VBS series and without a doubt, nothing comes close to putting you there in the hot seat unless it's the real deal.   Now I'm showing my age by waffling on about the "good olde days" let's talk about ARMA 3.  I know this review is 7 years too late but remember above I'm old and can't keep up with you younger fellas. 

Now ARMA 3, what to say about it that you probably don't know already, don't worry I won't bore you.   You can skip to the credits if you so choose but for you new bloods this a great no, may I be bold and say the greatest game in its genre.  I know it's not a COD, MOH, Battlefield experience but as close as you can get to a military simulator.  Its clunky, slow, boring at times, keys that will make your eyes bleed, buggy but it's the best on offer, just ask the millions of owners.   What's on offer, well everything a military simulator can offer plus much, much, much more.  A campaign, co-op, multiplayer, sophisticated editor, mods, training, Air/sea/land environments, DLC's adding more stuff to the game.  I spent a lot of my time in the editor sampling all the toys and mechanics.  It's your choice to do what you want in the game, lots of entertainment for a small investment. At least give it a try, you've nothing to lose (play for 2-hours or under and get a refund from steam).
Anyway, I'm done, be good, have fun and stay safe out there.

Amazing tactical gameplay!
If you're looking for something like CoD, don't look here. That said, if you're looking for somewhere to build missions and create your own campaigns to play through alone or with friends, with complex systems, supporting arms, amazing atmospherics and real tactical and punishing gameplay, look no further.

Arma 2 and 3 are in my eyes the spiritual successor to old school tactical shooters like Ghost Recon. Though the 'campaigns' are very limited and basically just teach you how to play the game, they all tie into the larger scenario. A realistically complicated relationship with host nation and NATO forces, after some sort of rebellion on a Greek based country is basically the plot, then CSAT ties in in 2035. Like I said though the campaign leaves something to be desired, but the editor is the real gem here.

The Eden editor is where you go to build you own missions and even campaigns. Learn how to use the systems and you can have near endless fun with different scenarios, and that's all before the steam workshop. Custom content creators have build hundreds of mods, ports, and reskins as well as original content for this game. You can easily find lists of the best mods on youtube or other places and be on your way to fighting in whatever area, with whatever troops and equipment you could want, from WWII to HALO and Star Wars, there's something for pretty much everyone.

Main takeaways: strong learning curve to master, limited campaign, vast amounts of custom content in the workshop including mods factions and missions, multiplayer, singleplayer, or co-op.

When it comes to popular consumer-grade ballistics simulation, this game is what Kerbal Space Program is for popular consumer-grade interplanetary flight mechanics simulation. Which makes it the best ballistics simulator I've ever encountered (not to be confused with "Receiver" - the best gun handling simulator I've ever encountered). This aspect alone fascinates me enough to start appreciating and even admire a mil-sim game (I am a simpleton and generally stick to fast-paced action FPSs), which offers a lot of hiking, a lot of planning, a lot of team communication for the sake of coordination, at the expense of, well, shooting. You can make your own scenarios, if you have the time for it (they probably won't resemble Quake's action, though). The best thing about Arma 3 is, in actuality, not the gameplay, but the sandbox opportunity it gives you. One could even try/test all the weapons in the "VR" environment (available right from the start - pretty cool).

One of the common complaints is that it takes a lot of time to start feeling comfortable in this game, because of the many things one could actually do (with, surprise, the keyboard and mouse), besides movement and aiming. It's valid and is a definite deal-breaker for less committed people.

Unfortunately, gun handling (i.e. bolt/slide management, magazine management, round in the chamber management, malfunctions management, etc.) is still extremely simplified (okay, you still need to manage the zeroing of your scope, but that's related more to the ballistics of the projectile itself; it's also pretty basic (you see the distance, and you adjust for +/-100 m difference with two buttons)) and, thus, unrealistic. If you are like me, and still want a somewhat realistic  gun handling experience, then I recommend Receiver 1/2:
https://store.steampowered.com/app/234190/Receiver/

TL;DR: It's okay in single player, and unbelievably fun in multiplayer. Unstable at times, but surprisingly worth the money. Buy it if you want a game for a difficult singleplayer; or if you want a really good multiplayer; or if you like running missions with 30 people.

Let's start with the gameplay: the vanilla game is good, but lacking in some departments. The two maps (Altis and Stratis) are great, based off of islands near Greece. The actual gameplay is somewhat difficult, but rewarding. There are limited guns and uniforms in the vanilla game, but the DLCs fill these holes VERY well. And, you can try out DLCs without owning them! For a Zeus (will get to later), you can use DLC units and scenery in your missions.

The next two things are why I have over 1,700 hours (and counting) in the game:
Zeus: With the MCC, ACE, and Ares/Achilles mods, this is hands down the best part of the game. By yourself, you can pit two factions against each other, command their units, and even get on the ground as a unit and test out everything. Inn multiplayer, you can run entire campaigns with your friends, make small, 4-man team missions, or just mess around and have your playerbase escape "Arma-geddon" in go karts as you send C-130s, fighters, and the entire US miliraty after them. Oh, and you can drop nukes and cause earthquakes.

Eden Editor: The other best part of the game. It requires a small bit of research and trial-and-error to get things set up, but this is where you can set up missions, place buildings and assets, and even set up respawn areas and capture points for missions. I actually would set up missions while waiting between classes during college.

Mods: There are so many mods for this game. From missions to take out terrorist leaders, to destroying Reapers with Mass Effect: Opposition, to even fighting the CIS or Empire in a Star Wars operation, you can do so much with mods. My own recommendations for starting off are all of the CUP and RHS mods, along with SSPCM (for when you only want to have fun and not worry about ammo or dying), MCC, Ares/Achilles, Arma 3 Aegis mods, and ACE3


All in all, this is a very good game. It's a learning curve, but a fun one. If you're like me and are really bad a shooters, try your hand at Zeus-ing or map making. If you are a vet at shooters, you'll love the new challenges provided by thousands of mods (not all at once though!).

Arma 3 is like that long-term girlfriend/boyfriend you date where, at the honeymoon phase, you are smitten and are like "wow, this is a 10/10 unique experience." However, as the months turn to years and time rolls on, you start to realize there are shinier, prettier experiences out there- better looks, sexier moves, more stable, but you stick with it. You realize you're really with a solid 7/10, but **** is it fun. There are things he/she can do that no one else can, and well, despite deviations time to time to fantasize about other experiences, and several on-again/off-again times spent dabbling in those fantasies, you find yourself coming back to him/her. You find yourself truly happy...even after the worst (and unstable) times. Come to think of it, maybe this isn't a healthy relationship, but at the end of the day, it's a **** fun one.

Arma is an unstable, buggy ride and a bit overwhelming on first impressions, but it's an experience that you don't get in any other sandbox game or military shooter. The community is really what drives this game. It's a quasi-sim/quasi-arcade experience that can be tailored to the community/user's need given a little time spent learning how it all works. The developers do a decent job of providing documentation to understand how content creation and mission editing functions, and the community fills (and exceeds) the areas unfulfilled and self-imagined. There are few communities as diverse and robust as Arma's. In one night's events, you can go from playing a modern-day military sim night with your homies, to WWII, Vietnam, then Star Wars, Halo, Starship Troopers, Aliens, to the bloody revolutionary war and more. In short, Arma should be judged more as a sandbox & framework for community addons than a game on its own, and one that over the last 6 years developed into being highly accessible to the average user without even needing to touch a text editor or understand how it works to get custom games going through its implementation of a "Dungeon Master" style mission builder called "Zeus." Arma's experience varies greatly depending on your level of tolerance for troubleshooting and patience with searching/installing addons.

This is best experienced by being dragged in by a community of friends... really it's kind of Stockholm Syndrome that kept me in it to start, and the incredible, fun, sometimes frustrating, and hilarious experiences made along the way is something no other game has offered and keeps me coming back. Give it a go, or watch some communities stream their experiences and see for yourself.

Okay, so this is an iffy review, this review will be a pro and con list and note: i only have 5 hours in this game, but its enough to leave a review, now, lets get to the pros and cons (TL;DR AT BOTTOM)

PROS:
-This game is the most realistic military sim that you can get, the gameplay is very tactical and team based, its not like every other shooter and run and gun getting airstrikes left and right, this game requires a lot of team work, and the game is less of getting kills and more of getting an objective done.

-The Community is very kind to new players, i love the fact that no one is rude to other people, i have been on the popular servers and its non toxic, i am not saying its like that on every server, but in the majority of them, very nice community.

-The addition of mods in this game is awesome, not only is there more to do than shooting bad guys, but you can create and mod things, thats really really cool.


CONS:
-This game has terrible optimization, like the worst i have ever seen, just for reference, i have a GTX 1650 super Overclocked with a ryzen 3 3200, 2x8 16gb 3200mhz ddr4 Ram, and with low settings, i am getting 20 fps average in firefights, that is unplayable, i know i don't have 64gb of ram, and an rtx 2080ti with a 64 core processor, but i should not be getting 20 fps average on the lowest settings.

-The ads in the game is so annoying, i have the marksman DLC for the game, and every time i hop in an official server you have that stupid "buy this DLC" logo on your screen, and every 5 minutes, you have just a bunch appear on your screen randomly, like this blocks the screen when you're playing the game, that can hurt your game play a lot, imagine you're about to shoot a guy, and then you see a bunch of "buy this dlc" logo appears on your screen, and you miss your shot because of that, that is not right at all, that is just pure greed from Bohemia, they would rather have a player buy the DLC, then have someone enjoy the game.

-This one is kind of picky, but im wishing for better mic quality in the game, ik the game is 7 years old, but still.

NOTE:
And with that, I give this game a thumbs down, by no means will i stop playing a game just because i gave it a thumbs down, all i have to say is, i would not recommend getting this game if you have a bad PC, dont let the recommended and minimal system requirements fool you.

TL;DR: The game has a good community and good game play, but the game has poor optimization, and annoying ads in game

Message to Bohemia developers: I enjoy your game, and i know you guys work hard on this game, but we need better optimization, and its really annoying when i die because of the ad popping up, i just hope you guys can do better on this game, Thanks!

Having logged 8600+ hours over the years on ArmA3, may I say it's been a wild ride.
Grossly outdated graphics engine, poorly optimised, it remains the closest game you can ever play to the real thing. During its heyday, milsim communities and modders made this more of an experience than some simple combat simulator - I was able to don exactly the same equipment, uniform and loadouts that I served with while in the army.
NOT worth it if you're playing vanilla arma - terrifying and immersive if you use mods.
You can eat, climb walls, abseil, drink, splint fractures, dress burns, dig foxholes, engage in melee, interrogate, be suppressed and find yourself in a house being breached and cleared by the enemy.
Unless it's vanilla...
Mods are everything.

Fun, intense, realistic, and challenging, Arma 3 focuses on large scale warfare within obscure wars.  The game takes inspiration from many lesser known conflicts like Papua New  Guinea - Bougainville Island war and The second Congo War. The multiplayer is hectic, terrifying, realistic, and requires teamwork to survive any of the large scale, vehicles riddled, battles. You and your team must use everything at your disposal and having at least one person who can use helicopters and jets is almost required but with such high playercounts, there will never be a situation where you don't have a competent pilot. The singleplayer is abysmal though except when played in coop, because when you play coop it becomes excellent, issue is the only campaign that can be played coop is the apex dlc campaign but it doesn't really matter because you can just play the zeus mode which lets you play unique and diverse coop custom missions. in conclusion, buy it, get your friends to buy it, have infinite fun.

Genuinely a fun game. Playing with a good group of friends who mix seriousness with fun, I've had some of the most amazing  moments I've had on any game. The game plays how you want it to, it's a sandbox after all. It can be slow at times, but can really get you bohemian hollering when you really get into it. Best moments include carrying a wounded teammate out of a village seconds before it's leveled by rocket artillery, landing that perfect GBU that takes out 10+ people, genuinely feeling fear when pinned down by an army of Russians who want nothing more than to sink their lead into me and many more awesome moments. Vanilla is awesome and has a great setting, but mods and custom scenarios can take the game so much farther and I would recommend playing what you want with friends as they can make the game so much more enjoyable. Zeus has probably been the most enjoyable experience for me personally, being able to create a mission on the fly that brings my friends through urban firefights, zombie apocalypses, soaring through the skies and securing objectives all at the tips of my hands is an amazing feeling. I love to give my friends a fun experience that they can take away from and make memories playing, and I can make mine watching them really get into my scenario. Such an amazing game that I'm so glad I've been able to experience by myself and alongside my friends. Not a game for everyone, specifically the impatient and immediate pleasure seeking individuals who prefer running through their objectives and expecting results, but you can find that it has something for everyone who wants to give it a try. Good luck on the battlefield!

The vanilla gameplay is honestly kind of trash. Bots are unbalenced, there are many pay to win situations regarding the dlc, and gameplay is just not that good. In the end Arma 3 is a system for making experiences, and i believe this is what it is trying to be sold as, they just aren't doing a good job of it. The editor is incredible.

I've seen my closest friends blown to red paste by a T-90. I've watched as a machine gunner gunned down so many leaving them crippled and bleeding out on the floor only for me to make my way over to them to help and them bleeding out in my hands. I've seen so many nuclear explosions that I have probably developed radiation poisoning via my screen, I have seen my commanding officer shot through the chest by a .50 cal when he was giving me orders. -2/12/2021 update- After about 800 hours of Arma 3, it dawned on me that the reason I thought I would love it so much was because of the YouTubers I watched. Womble, Rubix, and so on, made it look like a fun blast. But after a while of playing, I realized that there is a reason for the edits that cut between operations. If you are joining because you watched Womble, remind your self that this game, on its bad days can be the most boring thing for someone who has no idea about the military, or a want to join an armed service. Don't get me wrong, I had plenty of fun, but just as the YouTubers cut out funny moments between a set amount of ops (which mind you unless your server does it every day, it doesn't often happen and is usually either a weekly or bi-weekly thing) don't expect to have each operation be a blast. And don't expect to get to do what you want to do.

This game has been there through so much in my life. It has been amazing to quick set up an intense battle or scenario using the map editor. Out of the 1000+ hours I have 99% of those have been spend in the editor. However. The developers need to add more intuitive map editor tools. Easier ways to set up invasion style scenarios and way better building occupation. Mortar and artillery explosions/damage are just clumsy and over powered to the point of leaving them out. For the amount of detail they go into infantry simulation the tanks still use a health bar system. I would expect/hope that the next armour game learns from games such as war thunder with the penetration and side effects of hits. Don't get me wrong. This is a fantastic game. Just... for a game that is aiming to be at the top of the sandbox and simulation it runs the risk of falling short of other games which are starting to take over.

I write this review with the hopes the arma devs get to see this (however I doubt they will). Please. Focus on the sandbox/narrative side of arma. Please factor in the desire of your players to recreate scenes from movies, real life battle events etc. Make it better and easier to set up CQB and intense urban warfare and please please please fix artillery so it is not so OP. As a player I want to start arma and design my own battle scenario to drop into and have a half an hour to hour long battle. I know you guys can do this. Please do this. I beg you!!

A strong learning curve for new players who are just getting into FPS games. This game is definitely not an arcade type of game, but rather more for strategic and military simulation tactics to use and play with online and privately in a single player survival to get off of one of the islands. Personally, it has taken me over 120 hours to learn my own way to play, and adapt to new scenarios. Customization of your classes has a wide selection, however most of the different weapons such as Sniper class weapons and vehicle use are only obtainable if you purchase it. I personally believe this is slightly pay to win, especially if you are facing a team with more users that are able to use vehicles, while your team cant. There are lots of workshop content but I find that most of it is outdated and hasnt been updated for a few years at this point. If you enjoy a challenge, and have the money to put forth for the DLCs to use the vehicles, I suppose I would recommend this game - I just wish it was a little more popular. In short i love this game. 

Pros:
The campaign is decent not anything crazy good but its there and some fun when your alone. 
The scenario editor is great and while complecated at first once you watch a few videos you can make some decent scenarios for you and your friends to play and i still now am discovering new things in teh editor that lets me make my scenarios better than before. This also allows you to make some basic sandbox testing ranges so you can just run around and blow stuff up.
The best part about this game is the modding scene. I have 56GB of mods installed not because of a lack of content in the main game but because there is so much that you can add to make this game even cooler. The RHS mod pack adds the entire vehicle and weapon lineup of countries like the USA and Russia. You can do so much with mods that can completely change your game for the better adding in new assets, scenarios, and tools.

Cons:
The game is poorly optimized so if you dont have a decent pc you may run into some major frame drops.
I kind of wish there was a bit more realism such at having to check you magazine to see how much ammo you have left among other features but that can be added in with mods very easily.
It can be hard to get into at first. Unless your already really into milsim games your going to want a friend thats already into the game to help guide you so you can get hooked quicker. If you dont have friends watching some youtube videos from people like operator drewski definitly will send you on a quest to have the most fun you can possibly have in this game.
The graphics are a bit outdated since it came out in 2013 but this doesnt take away from the actual gameplay.

Conclusion:
If you are already into milsim games get this game, plain and simple. If you want to get into milsims i would wait for a sale since they happen often and often see the game going for under $15.

After watching reading some reviews and watching some streamers gameplay on Arma 3, i never realised how much i would really enjoy this Army based Simulator. 
This realistic based Simulator meets all my expectations from single player scenarios all the way through to online co-op and PVP servers, along with the many choices of the players choice of weapon kit outs and vehicle choices.  serious, casual and everything in between, as we take on the AI trying to storm the HQ we are defending from all directions. As players start to drop you hear people calling "MEDDDDIIIIIC" with a fake cough and splutter over the mic as they are waiting to be resurrected, along with players praying to the in game gods to give them that slight chance of revival.
Casualties will occur as the insurgents take no hostages and will drop you like a sack of potatoes if you are not careful. This Simulator that has been finely polished to meet player expectations through updates and released DLC, which is proven due to the game being released 2013 and still having a massive player base. I would easily rate this Simulator a solid 9-9.5/10

Arma 3 is like that long-term girlfriend/boyfriend you date where, at the honeymoon phase, you are smitten and are like "wow, this is a 10/10 unique experience." However, as the months turn to years and time rolls on, you start to realize there are shinier, prettier experiences out there- better looks, sexier moves, more stable, but you stick with it. You realize you're really with a solid 7/10, but **** is it fun. There are things he/she can do that no one else can, and well, despite deviations time to time to fantasize about other experiences, and several on-again/off-again times spent dabbling in those fantasies, you find yourself coming back to him/her. You find yourself truly happy...even after the worst (and unstable) times. Come to think of it, maybe this isn't a healthy relationship, but at the end of the day, it's a **** fun one.

Arma is an unstable, buggy ride and a bit overwhelming on first impressions, but it's an experience that you don't get in any other sandbox game or military shooter. The community is really what drives this game. It's a quasi-sim/quasi-arcade experience that can be tailored to the community/user's need given a little time spent learning how it all works. The developers do a decent job of providing documentation to understand how content creation and mission editing functions, and the community fills (and exceeds) the areas unfulfilled and self-imagined. There are few communities as diverse and robust as Arma's. In one night's events, you can go from playing a modern-day military sim night with your homies, to WWII, Vietnam, then Star Wars, Halo, Starship Troopers, Aliens, to the bloody revolutionary war and more. In short, Arma should be judged more as a sandbox & framework for community addons than a game on its own, and one that over the last 6 years developed into being highly accessible to the average user without even needing to touch a text editor or understand how it works to get custom games going through its implementation of a "Dungeon Master" style mission builder called "Zeus." Arma's experience varies greatly depending on your level of tolerance for troubleshooting and patience with searching/installing addons. 

This is best experienced by being dragged in by a community of friends... really it's kind of Stockholm Syndrome that kept me in it to start, and the incredible, fun, sometimes frustrating, and hilarious experiences made along the way is something no other game has offered and keeps me coming back. Give it a go, or watch some communities stream their experiences and see for yourself.

There's also not that much to the game without mods. 

So why am I recommending this?

What can I say that hasn't already been said? This is probably the jankiest piece of software I have ever touched. Through careful study and occult divinings to the machine gods I have compiled a mostly complete list of things that can break Arma in some critical way.

1) Mod interaction
2) Unsupported drivers
3) Supported drivers
4) Settings
5) Nvidia Surround Display
6) Windows updates
7) Graphics driver updates
8) New hardware
9) Old hardware
10) ACE Hardware
11) Bad internet settings
12) Missing a sacrifice to the god of ArmAScript
13) Not standing and saying the pledge of allegiance

This list is by no means complete but can be used as a general guide of 'things to be careful around for a pleasant Arma experience.' All that being said this is a great game for a 60 year old retiree. I highly recommend this game if that's you, otherwise this game is going to be a war crime on your senses.

I mainly play Arma online multiplayer modes and Warlords especially. It offers a fantastic free world war experience where you can collaborate with other players and command your AI squad. You can CPs to buy off-roaders, tanks helicopter, boats or fixed-wing aircraft. It's like old battlefield games but more realistic and tactical.

The relatively old age of this game shows in some graphics and physics modelling. For example you might very well be able to destroy or catapult a tank by colliding a jeep on it even if it's not much more than a scratch or fender bender. Such  instances are not particularly common because you usually wont get a chance to get close to an enemy tank or vice versa but it occasionally leads to unintended team killing. Despite a few frustrating or amusing bugs the game is pretty solid.

If you want a good war game with tanks and all this is good candidate. It also has noticeably modest system requirements so you can run on older hardware or laptops. Check the recommendations before buying it to make sure.

Arma III is a military simulator with a lot of depth. The gameplay itself can have a very long learning curve for some, as the amount of actions you will need/be able to perform are numerous. It's often mentioned that almost every key on your keyboard will be used in some way. The game also has full controller support, but you'll need to map it yourself, and your average joypad won't have enough buttons. That said, you can map button combinations, so some creative thinking can still make it work.

The most interesting part of this package, however, is the Eden Editor. You can use it to create custom scenarios. Out of the box, it has all of the game's assets to choose from to create a near endless array of missions,  and game modes. More advanced users can make use of scripting, animation, and mods to open those possibilities even further. Everything from zombies, to aliens, or one of my personal favorites, battle mechs. 

Now for the bad. Or in this case "Inconvenient."

The online community can vary greatly. Overall toxicity isn't very prominent, and I've never encountered any trolls, but more serious players are incredibly whiny and annoying when it comes to the roleplaying aspects. (observing military chain of command, following the geneva conventions, calling out targets, confirming kills, and following orders.) It even gets to the point where half these people are basically online Drill Instructors. For some, this is the ultimate level of immersion, but for others (like me) it can be annoying. That said, vets are willing to teach, if you're willing to learn.

Arma 3 is the best, most immersive, most fun to play, worth the price military simulator that the common man can buy. You can have fun with friends, have fun with yourself and the ai, and even play a ton of different singleplayer campaigns. 

Price: The price of 30 euros/dollars is very reasonable, and logically the game would cost even more. The price is more than reasonable, and completely worth it.

Performance: The game does fairly well on modern, well-equipped PC's, but on older computers will start to lag very quickly, due to all the work that the game has to do in processing all the different characters moving around the map, as well as the graphics. It will also start to lag when more people than regular are present on the map. This is what the game is mainly lacking in.

Gameplay: Very enjoyable, and as realistic as it seems, is actually very simplified so that the normal gamer can get into it, with complete mod support making you able to get that ultra-realistic experience easily. The gunplay is pretty alright, however the sounds and physics are pretty lacking, but easily fixable with mods. A very good military game.

Story: Despite most players choosing to play multiplayer and with user-made scenario, the game's story campaigns are actually very well thought through, and hang together with each other. The game has extensive lore and background information, such as surrounding the organization of CSAT and their activities on the island of Altis. Despite the game not mainly focusing on the singleplayer campaigns, they are very good and enjoyable.

DLC: Despite the abundance of DLC, they are not required to enjoy the game, and while good if you have them, are not a necessity for a good experience. I do recommend getting a few of them though.

[b]Arma 3[/b] was released 7 years ago on 2013 and it is still such a popular game. This title tries to be a Military Simulation game and realistic, but with many flaws.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
- Huge maps [i](Entire Islands)[/i]
- Decent campaign story with multiple endings
- Good looking graphics
- Steam workshop support
- Community servers
- Solid playerbase [i](10-20 thousand players daily)[/i]
- Lots of Weapons
- Many vehicles, tanks
- Really good soundtrack
- Scenarios
- Scenario editor [i](Custom made missions)[/i]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- [b]Awful performance[/b] even with a decent rig
- Many weapons, items, vehicles are locked behind paid DLCs
- Clunky controls
- Very dumb A.I
- Clunky interaction UI
- Weird physics
- Leading your own AI squad is very exhausting and bad
- Many missions can be bugged or just simply really bad [i](For example, Preventive Diplomacy)[/i]
- The huge maps are mostly empty
- Some parts of the game looks outdated

[b]7/10[/b] It's a pretty okay game, people love this game and I guess because of its realistic approach and co-op modes or any other community made stuff. The campaign is only decent, the community stuff is really good, but the very poor optimization can be in the way for many people, including me and I have a pretty decent rig.

I originally purchased Arma 3 to make my own missions and play them offline. The downside of this is the AI team mates are as dumb as posts. The upside is that most of the AI don't follow what they were told to do through the various tools provided, which actually will result in random moments that are unscripted. When this happens and it works, it can be quite fun. Otherwise, if I'm expecting my team mates to do as they're told I'm usually banging my head on the desk because they seldom do as they're told. 
I found the campaign to be unmemorable and am not sure if I ever bothered completing it.
I finally figured out how to get on to a "quick match" in multiplayer and have been playing combat patrol missions. This has been genuinely fun as the total strangers you are randomly placed with are for the most part great to work alongside. If a person takes on the role of Team Leader seriously then good things happen. If there is good communication going on in the team, good things happen. Because you are randomly thrown together in the quick matches it's a bit of a gamble as to what you'll get to work with, but that's the nature of the beast. I'm sure those who work in squads with their friends don't have to gamble like the rest of us poor souls who haven't had the privilege.
I've been gaming since 1991 mostly through console gaming and have finally been able to play PC games. I've waited over 20 years to finally have this kind of experience in gaming.

My vote is based on the single player campaign, which is what I have been playing.

My problem with this game is, I think what I was wanting was a military simulator, whereas Arma 3 feels more like a military simulator simulator, if you get my meaning...

First off, I guarantee that nobody in any serious military would constantly call out to their team e.g., "MOVE 200 METERS RIGHT", it's just not practical. Whoever might be partaking in such "tactics" would be dead in a real combat situation. Communicating grid coordinates? Sure. Signaling directions with your hands or moving with your squad leader? Of course. But giving these overly explicit direction + short distance commands every 10s? Come on, the game's trying too hard to be "realistic" that it ends up being unrealistic and robotic. It's also quite obnoxious, especially when you're "commanding" an AI team and it constantly has your guy yelling these commands out to them (that is, even commands you didn't issue)...

That leads me to my next problem: commanding an AI team... They're TERRIBLE at following orders! You have to wait like 5 minutes for them to move to an area that takes you only 1 minute to arrive at, even when they're not being shot at. Combine this with the campaign constantly rushing you to get things done under a time limit, and it makes you want to throw the game in the trash.

Then there's the issue of fighting AI infantry and tanks (this is probably my most hated aspect of the game by far!). I have a REALLLL problem with this in Arma 3, and no, it's not because the game's "realistic". It's a fact of life that, no matter how good your skill or vision or hearing, if you don't have some kind of heat signature detection or night vision going on - i.e. you're out in broad daylight in a regular combat situation - and you can't see the enemy - and he steps out from behind a wall but there's literally 100% bush/foliage covering up your line of sight to him... you can't just shoot and kill him. You HAVE to see your enemy or have some kind of reasonable way of knowing that your enemy is there (e.g. he runs out in the open then ducks behind a bush). These rules DO NOT APPLY AT ALL to the AI, and it's even worse when you're in a city surrounded by enemy patrol groups and enemy APC's, all of whom can instantly shoot you down if you dare to move at all and play peek-a-boo with them, when they can see you but you can't see them...

This really ticked me off. I'd be e.g. in a building, ready to move to the next cover, I'd just BARELY peek out the door, literally see nothing but green + walls, and immediately get shot up and killed by an enemy infantry or APC. I'd load my save, do the same thing over and over with different variances 20 times in a row, and the same thing would happen again and again. And there's NOTHING you can do about it. It's like they knew the INSTANT you stepped out the door (no actual door being opened, mind you, just a doorless opening there). I found that I would have better luck shooting all of my enemies through a window first and then going out the door once they're all dead.

That leads me to the next problem: a lot of these windows have panes or whatever blocking 80-100% of their view. Not only that, but, as you might expect, you can very easily and quickly get shot and killed through these same windows, without even having a chance to breathe or see who's shooting you first - not even if you approach it stealthily. And you can't clear these windows out! There's not even a melee option. So like, say you were walking around stealthily, and you ran up behind an enemy. You can't knife him down, you HAVE to shoot him and make a loud noise, revealing your position to everyone in the city. Knowing this game, it's probably not even possible to sneak undetected in the first place...

Then there are the campaigns. I feel like I've played enough of them to get the gist of how they work. Look, I've learned the hotkeys, I've watched the videos, etc. I've given this game a solid try, and I'm no noob to FPS games. A lot of these missions are poorly designed. For instance, you'll be assigned to take over a city and clear it out, something like that; then, all of a sudden, halfway across the map, another squad on your team will be getting shot at. What does the game then have you do? The obvious, smart play: it tells you to basically abandon your mission to clear out the city, and in the middle of your firefight, it wants you to run THROUGH TO THE OTHER SIDE of the UNCLEARED city, keep going, and randomly run into a forest, to "safety". What?! It just doesn't make any strategic sense. There's a lot of this kind of crap in the built-in campaign missions...

Also, driving vehicles is kind of obnoxious, very difficult to maintain control over them with the keyboard at reasonable speeds.

Anyways, to sum it all up: I wanted a military simulator, which could help me refine my understanding of realistic tactical warfare: how not to get shot, the best way to approach various scenarios, etc., but I continually find Arma 3's strange mechanics, unrealistic AI's, bizarre campaigns, and so on getting in the way of that. It's making me seriously consider whether I even want to continue playing, whether I'll get any enjoyment out of it or learn anything useful.

Magna Carta Libertatum (Medieval Latin for "Great Charter of Freedoms"), commonly called Magna Carta (also Magna Charta; "Great Charter"),[a] is a royal charter[4][5] of rights agreed to by King John of England at Runnymede, near Windsor, on 15 June 1215.[b] First drafted by Archbishop of Canterbury Stephen Langton to make peace between the unpopular king and a group of rebel barons, it promised the protection of church rights, protection for the barons from illegal imprisonment, access to swift justice, and limitations on feudal payments to the Crown, to be implemented through a council of 25 barons. Neither side stood behind their commitments, and the charter was annulled by Pope Innocent III, leading to the First Barons' War.

After John's death, the regency government of his young son, Henry III, reissued the document in 1216, stripped of some of its more radical content, in an unsuccessful bid to build political support for their cause. At the end of the war in 1217, it formed part of the peace treaty agreed at Lambeth, where the document acquired the name Magna Carta, to distinguish it from the smaller Charter of the Forest which was issued at the same time. Short of funds, Henry reissued the charter again in 1225 in exchange for a grant of new taxes. His son, Edward I, repeated the exercise in 1297, this time confirming it as part of England's statute law. The charter became part of English political life and was typically renewed by each monarch in turn, although as time went by and the fledgling Parliament of England passed new laws, it lost some of its practical significance.

At the end of the 16th century there was an upsurge in interest in Magna Carta. Lawyers and historians at the time believed that there was an ancient English constitution, going back to the days of the Anglo-Saxons, that protected individual English freedoms. They argued that the Norman invasion of 1066 had overthrown these rights, and that Magna Carta had been a popular attempt to restore them, making the charter an essential foundation for the contemporary powers of Parliament and legal principles such as habeas corpus. Although this historical account was badly flawed, jurists such as Sir Edward Coke used Magna Carta extensively in the early 17th century, arguing against the divine right of kings propounded by the Stuart monarchs. Both James I and his son Charles I attempted to suppress the discussion of Magna Carta, until the issue was curtailed by the English Civil War of the 1640s and the execution of Charles. The political myth of Magna Carta and its protection of ancient personal liberties persisted after the Glorious Revolution of 1688 until well into the 19th century. It influenced the early American colonists in the Thirteen Colonies and the formation of the United States Constitution, which became the supreme law of the land in the new republic of the United States.[c] Research by Victorian historians showed that the original 1215 charter had concerned the medieval relationship between the monarch and the barons, rather than the rights of ordinary people, but the charter remained a powerful, iconic document, even after almost all of its content was repealed from the statute books in the 19th and 20th centuries.

Magna Carta still forms an important symbol of liberty today, often cited by politicians and campaigners, and is held in great respect by the British and American legal communities, Lord Denning describing it as "the greatest constitutional document of all times ‚Äì the foundation of the freedom of the individual against the arbitrary authority of the despot".[6] In the 21st century, four exemplifications of the original 1215 charter remain in existence, two at the British Library, one at Lincoln Castle and one at Salisbury Cathedral. There are also a handful of the subsequent charters in public and private ownership, including copies of the 1297 charter in both the United States and Australia. The original charters were written on parchment sheets using quill pens, in heavily abbreviated medieval Latin, which was the convention for legal documents at that time. Each was sealed with the royal great seal (made of beeswax and resin sealing wax): very few of the seals have survived. Although scholars refer to the 63 numbered "clauses" of Magna Carta, this is a modern system of numbering, introduced by Sir William Blackstone in 1759; the original charter formed a single, long unbroken text. The four original 1215 charters were displayed together at the British Library for one day, 3 February 2015, to mark the 800th anniversary of Magna Carta.

At the time of writing this, I have over 2,000+ hours. Arma 3 is a military "simulation" game that allows players to play almost EVERY role on the battlefield as long as the mission allows it, want to be a special ops laser designating targets for destruction, you can do that. Want to lead a squadron of A10's into combat, raining 30mm cannon fire onto enemy troops, you can do that. Everything from a simple rifleman to the tank commander to a pilot, and from my experience is there is no other game that provides such a variety of different gameplay styles, and while the engine is now around 10+ years old which does have its limitations, frame rates on lower end PC will be fairly poor, so if your pc isnt powerful dont buy it. Another issue with the game is the amount of glitches that happen in a game, from one moment your driving a tank to the next becoming the next space shuttle going into orbit because your cannon glitched into a building. But even with all that being said, there is NO OTHER GAME that provides a similar gameplay AND workshop integration, and with the game only being 39.99 US, its still worth the price
