Easily my favorite game on steam, hands down! I love it, and here's why:

Arma 3 is a military sandbox shooter, allowing you to interact with almost all aspects of military warfare, from ships to planes to trucks to tanks to infantry. There hasn't been a single game which has released since Arma 3 that lets you interact with all of these aspects on anywhere near as large a scale (25x25km map, 1 to 1 scale with an IRL island), if at all to begin with.

By modern standards, the gameplay is relatively clunky, the graphics are out of date, and performance is relatively poor on lower-end machines. The game is also CPU intensive, which is better or worse for some rigs. In spite of this, the game has a very healthy playerbase with thousands of concurrent players, although spread out among a wide variety of different gamemodes and units which can give the impression the game is less populated than it actually is at any given time.

Although the game has a number of DLC, what many people tend to not know is much of the DLC releases came with free patches and updates for the game which everyone can enjoy - Helicopters DLC came with a helicopter overhaul for all helicopters, not just DLC ones. Marksman DLC allowed firing from vehicles for everyone, and so on. 

The game has also gotten significant improvement in the AI department over time as well, although by modern standards the AI is still relatively lackluster. Compared to previous Arma games however, the AI in this game is actually extremely smart and complex, but also require experience with their behavior and knowledge of the honestly terrible system of actually controlling them. Still, I'd take Arma 3 AI any day over Arma 2 AI or god forbid Armed Assault AI.

The game also comes with honestly one of the best editors I have ever used in gaming, hands-down. It's essentially a built-in SDK for making missions that you can access straight from the main menu, and allows nearly anyone to sit down and make whatever the hell they want. Some of the more complicated things do require scripting (usually extremely simple scripting) but the Modules system alleviates the need for many scripts. You can spawn in and play with every single vehicle in the game, regardless if you own it or not if you can bear the annoying watermark that flashes on your screen.

One potential downside is that much of the multiplayer is PvE focused, and that's where you'll find the most amount of actually populated servers, doubly so if you get involved in the unit and modding scene behind the game. Still, you can easily find a couple hundred players playing PvP if you check during prime hours (during the day, weekends, etc.). Personally, I have spent the overwhelming majority of time playing PvE as the gamemodes and missions are significantly better balanced and fun regardless if you've spent 10 hours or 1000 hours in the game. Many PvP gamemodes like KOTH or Warlords require you to grind exp or money (or both) in order to get better gear and equipment.

All in all I would definitely recommend the game, especially during a sale where you can get the major content adding DLCs (especially Apex) for cheap and if your computer can play it. It's a unique experience you can't get anywhere else, with the ability to turn it into whatever kind of experience you want it to be.

I just recently hit hour 1,000. This is the only game I've spent that much time in, except for Minecraft, and I started playing Minecraft when I was eight.

What is it about ARMA that made it fun enough to play until hour 1,000? Why do I think I'm probably going to hit hour 2,000 and keep going?

It's the modding community. The ARMA community has several amazing parts to it, but the modders make it all happen. There are mods for this game that add EVERYTHING. Want to be a US Army rifleman invading Iraq in 2003? Mod for that. Want to be a British infantryman fighting the Nazis in France? Mod for that. Want to be a Space Marine from Warhammer 40k? Mod for that. Want to be a Clone Trooper from Star Wars? Mod for that. Want to be a Mobile Infantry from Starship Troopers? Mod for that. Want to be a Roman Legionnaire? There's a mod for THAT, if you can believe it. Almost any possible conflict, from history or fiction, that involved soldiers, there's a mod for it. Sure, they're sometimes janky, and modded ARMA 3 will teach you that 30 FPS is a luxury, not slow. But the game allows you to immerse yourself in a conflict in a way no other game does, and sometimes does it far better than the source material for that universe.

There's no better example of this than Operation: TREBUCHET (OPTRE), a total conversion mod for ARMA 3 that takes you to the Halo universe. The Halo universe is one of my favorite scifi universes out there, and it has so many interesting concepts, characters, and locations to explore. The Human-Covenant War is an amazing setting - an apocalyptic battle where half of humanity loses their lives in a desperate fight against a genocidal alien menace. However, the Halo games always lacked something, and I never quite understood what they were missing until I played ARMA with OPTRE installed.

OPTRE adds a million different little things that allow you to live the Halo universe. All of the human weapons that fans are familiar with, and many more from the novels or even Halo-flavored weapons that are just from the minds of the devs, are available to you. True to the setting of the 2500s, you're given a dizzying array of technology. Jetpacks, motion trackers, thermal imaging neural implants, quick-healing biofoam, ODST pods, and body armor that makes you pretty damn durable. With this wide array equipment, you're either pitted against the Insurrectionists, a faction in a human civil war that was ongoing before contact with the Covenant, or against the Covenant themselves (even if the Covenant do lack content compared to the Insurrectionists). However, OPTRE doesn't lose that signature ARMA feel, and that's where the beauty of the mod lies. Even when you wrap yourself up in the heaviest armor a Marine or ODST could wear, a few well-placed shots can still lay you low.

That's the fundamental beauty of ARMA, its mods, and OPTRE in particular. In the mainline Halo games, you play as Master Chief, a living god who can shrug off barrages of machine gun fire and cave in the skull of his enemies with one punch. In ARMA, you play as a scared Marine who has to take cover when the guns start going off and call in air support to clear out strongpoints, instead of charging them solo.

Specifically, fighting the Covenant has an entirely changed face in ARMA compared to a Halo game. Take an Elite - Eight feet tall, energy shielded, and wielding plasma weapons firing deadly energy bolts with a high rate of fire. As Master Chief, it's a worthy adversary, but nothing more than that. As a Marine with nothing but a rifle and his wits, even a single Elite is a monster that you have to coordinate fire with your squad to take down. The existence of ARMA's extensive mission making tools means that you can play through a thousand different battlefields with the only limit being the imagination of the mission maker. I'll never forget when I lived through my first glassing as a Marine, watching a city full of civilians I was trying to save get burned to ash while I was forced to run and hide.

ARMA in general - and Opreation: TREBUCHET specifically - is the most enjoyable experience I've ever had with a video game. I've made friends that will last a long time, gone through missions that I'll never forget, and I'm still playing - and hope I can keep playing for a long time still. ARMA is glorious. Also, love you, CITF Sierra. You know who you are.

I bought Arma3 way back during Beta/Early Access and I finally got around to playing and trying it out. I saw the DLCs it got and figured if I enjoyed my time with it, I would buy them eventually.

So here I was playing coop maps with nearly 100 players, having fun, til I picked up a DLC item. I don't mind the nagging on the side and when you go to leave the match to buy the DLC.

But then...

If you wear the item for long, the nagging becomes shop icons all over your screen and a MOTHER FUCKING BUY THIS NOW ON THE MIDDLE OF THE SCREEN, blocking your view from whatever it is you're doing. I would have felt way less aggravated if the game simply didn't let me wear the item at all to begin with.

Now, this kind of behavior is so infuriating that I WILL NEVER BUY A SINGLE DLC. In fact, if I could have asked for a refund I would have on spot.

Since I can't refund and try to not to endorse this kind of garbage anti-consumer behavior, I will just enjoy my time without touching any DLC item ever again and never giving money to anything touched by Bohemia ever again.

Good job.

--------------------

This is not a free game, I bought the base game years ago and by making the mistake of wearing a DLC item once, I can see exactly what they think of me. Just a wallet to give them more money. I'm really against how they did DLC in ARMA 3 compared to 2. (In ARMA 2, DLC objects you didn't own would be very low res, but in ARMA 3 if you use a DLC item it places huge ads on the screen and can pause gameplay with yet more ads leading to possible deaths due to this).

Arma 3 is a fantastic game and is the foundation to a Mil-Sim masterpiece. The vanilla version is a fantastic base to which the content creator community only build further upon. The Modding community have taken what the developers finished with and ran a marathon, taking the game to a completely new level. 

I would strongly suggest involving yourself with Mil-Sim groups if you have the time and energy. Before I became an adult I has plenty of time to invest into this game and joining an Australian Mil-Sim group took my Arma 3 experience further. 

The vanilla version has a limited amount of maps, weapons, vehicles and functions however, adding Mods really changes this. Some Mod packs include most weapons and vehicles ever used in modern combat. You can also download mods which make you a little developer and give you the chance to create scenarios with lots of components involved. 

I strongly suggest this game to anyone who has enjoyed games such as Battlefield & Squad.

Arma 3 is a unique game, a realistic military shooter which provides the ultimate sandbox, more than any game can ever offer. You can approach an objective any way your heart desires (stealth is not an option, because AI go full on terminator if they spot you, and their spotting mechanics are sort of unrealistic and weird). But if you want to go loud and proud, that is where the game shines. Take gunfights, or snipe them from far away, or call in mortar strike, or artillery strike or get a plane to provide close air support, come in from any direction, do it however you want and get the job done.

Multiplayer is fun as well. But you most definitely need a mic and most definitely have to communicate. Plan your attack, arrange an organised assault, take over a town, rescue hostages, kill HVTs, destroy convoys, equipment, structures, your mission can be anything, anywhere, you have to be up for the task. Co-op is where I enjoyed the game most. PvP is interesting but can be frustrating since you can get destroyed within seconds.

Arma 3 would never have survived unless it was fuelled by the dedicated and skilled modding community. There are lot of mods, which can exponentially make the game more fun. From adding guns, equipment, vehicles, maps, missions, mechanics you can get everything from playing chess to nuking a town. Total overhaul mods allows you to convert arma 3 into any game you desire, of course with arma mechanics. Want to play halo? Yes there is a mod for that. Want to play half life? Yes you can get that as well. Want to play zombies? Got that covered as well. Hell there are some mods that allow you to go dinosaur hunting. The modding community adds something priceless to the game which we are all thankful for. 

For solo players who don't want to touch MP or Co-op, of course the game is fun but you will be missing out on a lot. More the merrier.

I was skeptical about getting the game at first, now I regret not getting this sooner.

1) Get a friend or maybe an acquaintance who will listen to your every command and is willing to lay down his life for you.
2) GET THE GAME
3) Enjoy the vanilla game 
4) Visit steam workshop
5) PROFIT

My first Arma game of the franchise and i got to say from the salt flats of Altis to the mountain forests of Stratis this is hands down one of the funniest and pain in the neck games to play. This game can be modified to be a hyper realistic Military sim or a more complex single player military fps. Arma 3 has challenges for new players and allows players to learn the game at their own pace. However, make no mistake, multiplayer game modes such as wasteland which is a team vs team of many players of different skill levels will challenge everyone's abilities and skills. Some players are there for the up close combat. Others are there for the power of a unmanned vehicle to strike fear into enemies hearts with one missile. The Gracefulness of transport pilots or the long breaks between fast paced battles in the sky's with planes and attack helicopters. Arma 3 has a place for everyone. For the role-play community, to the fps player, to the master pilot, the skilled sniper, the powerful drone operator, to the armored vehicle operator. Arma 3 and its many game modes that range from a group effort to take over territory in Invade & Annex to the destruction and skill in Wasteland and the many other game modes. I hope like me you and your friends take the dive to learn and play this game. There is something for almost everyone.

Do you like Call of Duty?
Do you like Realism?
Do you like the idea of driving your 8 Billion dollar tank into a static light pole and blowing up?

Then this game is for you. ARMA 3 is a fever dream made by a bunch of of Czechs and their drug binge while thinking of a way to coddle Rainbow Six and Call of Duty together while making it a thousand times more realistic. Though they failed at that the result was the amazing rookie failure that is ARMA 3. This game is hard, you will go down in 1-3 shots if you are not careful. Though it may not seem like it, strategy makes up almost eighty percent of the game, not in general terms, but in quick-thinking terms. You will go from standing out in the open, getting shot and downed on the first shot; To being in cover and getting shot and downed on the first few shots. You will develop quick thinking and improvisation skills quickly and absentmindedly. 

Does the dictionaries worth of keyboard function scare you? Don't let it, cause once you get the hang of it it soon becomes second nature really quickly.

Does the vanilla sandbox feeling of the game turn you off? Does the price and warranty of the DLC make your wallet quiver at the thought? No worries, ARMA 3 modding exist, you will find amazing mods that look like they belong in part of the game, you will also find mods to completely ruin your experience so tread carefully.

This game WILL put your computer to the test, Pro-Gaming Desktops will struggle if you are not careful with your settings and mod choice list.

This game is far from perfect, there are fair shares of hackers and exploiters in the games, thankfully most servers and online facilities are run independently, so those kinds of people are a rarity. 

This game never lacks for players, you will always find full servers of warlord, KOTH, and many, many, MANY more. If you were drawn to this game from other sources such as filmmakers, streamers, or references by colleague. Don't be put off by the 'serious' appeal to the game, rest assure you will not find anything majorly hardcore unless you look for it.

This game however, is anything but perfect. Bohemian Servers are constantly having issues. The game will crash in vanilla for seeming reasons. I wasn't lying about blowing up from a light post either.

However, don't let that dissuade you, the glitches and constantly unbeknownst chaos are what gives this game the gold value many of us veteran players adore.

Play it. Struggle. Die. Give up. Return two weeks later cause there are no other games out there at the moment you'd enjoy. Get the hang of it. Enjoy it. Realize you are having fun. Keep having fun.

Arma 3 is a ever growing Military Simulator Sandbox with endless possibilities. Featuring a good Single Player mode, but the star here is the community and the multiplayer aspects both cooperative and competitive.

This is a sandbox game! Do not enter with a group of friends, a buddy, yourself, or even on a huge server expecting a very straightforward experience right off the bat. You create and experience your own memorable moments.

It is incredible how this game keeps pulling me in. The community keeps sculpting and shaping the game in the greatest ways including but not limited to ACE3, ACRE, RHS Sound, etc... Arma serves as one of the best war story generations and simulators even after soon to be a decade later from release.

New PC gamers will struggle to find footing in this game but for those who are willing to learn. It's the biggest and most sophisticated military sandbox on the market.

As quoted from another steam user by the name of [TFH] Webster as of this post. He said on June 23rd. "A lot of people in the Arma community don't play this because it's easy - they do it because it's hard. But when you're through the first frustrating weeks, you will learn to love it. And you might have some of the most fascinating moments in your gaming career..."

With that, it's no wonder why I keep coming back to this game. The community, friends, and endless content.

How to describe ARMA in a little rectangle...? Well, it definitely covers all basis of a good open world tactical shooter for one but the real gem of ARMA is in it's continued development both by Bohemia Interactive and the ever active ARMA community at large. Third party content allows the player to do just about anything, from plug and play fast pace online gaming to an immersive experience of you'r choosing and to your own degree. 

Straight shooting.

To run this game with all manner of colourful MODs you will need loads of free SSD space.

Being and intensive combat immersion there are loads of controls that overlap with various engagement/ transport styles. Getting to know the game will take some getting use. 

Expect bugs. ARMA has had bugs since day one. In comparison to the days of playing ARMA 2 and navigating the endlessly clashing clusters of mods and addons, I must say that BI have certainly made the best of this epic project over the years.

Was it worth picking up then? Is it still worth picking up now? 

Well, even just simply looking at numbers, I'd say so! I've spent about twice the amount of money on a game that I've only played for maybe 100 hours, tops. With Arma, I've squeezed a good 3.2k hours out of it and counting! The game was fun enough alone or with just a couple buds for about a thousand hours, and joining a unit full of genuinely AWESOME people  reinvented the game for me. After so long, I can't even confidently say I've seen all there is to see because the community as a whole constantly adds to the game and mission devs out there seem to have endless creativity. 

As far as the game itself goes, it's just simply amazing. I saw the cool near-future style with really advanced gear and the emphasis/focus BI put on the infantry combat this time around, and I was drawn in immediately. The campaign alone wasn't a masterpiece, but it definitely had its moments. The map design of Altis felt warm with the sun beating down on everything from dawn til dusk. Being so immersed, I immediately felt the urge to find some sort of shade, even! The addition of diving and seeing everything in the ocean made their frogman showcase feel almost like a vacation. Ambient sounds in the quiet moments and sweet cacophonies of gunshots and explosions that erupt make this game an absolute FEAST for the ears. The rain and thunder will pick up, which will nearly blind and deafen you, and it'll remind you constantly that you're on a big, tropical island. Being on foot isn't so bad in A3 when compared to A2.
The vehicles are still fun in their own way. I never really had an interest in them personally, but the way BI handled them this time around makes them powerful, but not overpowered. It's always going to be scary seeing that APC or tank rolling down the road at you, but with the different factions playing in entirely different ways, it's not always so obvious on how you should handle them as a threat. That goes for both Co-op and PvP modes.
Playing as a crew in a vehicle, however? That's a blast. They've all got their functions, and no vehicle is the same as the other. You'll learn what a particular vehicle is capable of, and you do have to use your head to get the most out of a particular tank or APC. The Tanks DLC added a few interesting alternatives to the regular tanks, like tankettes, or MGS tank destroyers. 

Now, I'm not saying it's a perfect game by any means. Sometimes it's the odd bug here or there, or sometimes it's the game being characteristically janky, but at some point or another, this game will begin to hurt you. After so long, you'll learn to like it, though. Once you get over that hump, it's smooth-ish sailing! The AI can be a little hard to deal with, but feeling overwhelmed at the start is definitely appropriate. There's a lot to learn before you stop surviving and start thriving.

The public online stuff is often a memefest or sometimes you'll get griefed by someone way too bored. Sometimes it's the opposite, with people getting genuinely immersed and running the missions tightly and actually working as a team. It's finding that perfect unit that fits your attitude and your playstyle that'll really bring out the best this game has to offer.

TLDR Still worth by a long shot! Anyone just picking the game up now wouldn't be missing the boat by any means.

Bugs, bugs, and poor design. This is the most clunky, bugged, and cumbersome game I have ever played. It's like I'm playing military QWOP. Even after 36 hours in, I feel like I can't properly control my movement, or see, or shoot, or command, or manage my inventory. I've watched some great Arma 3 multiplayer videos online, but my experience has been very different. My computer meets the recommend system requirements, yet the game barely runs, even on the lowest settings. And I think this might be my main issue. For instance, the aliasing on my cross-hairs, rendered at a low resolution, makes them barely visible. On a very high-end system, with a large screen, and a high-speed internet connection, the multiplayer could be enjoyable, overall. But I have been playing the single player campaign, and it has not been enjoyable. Again, that list of bugs is endless. At times, the enemies seem unaffected by my bullets, even at close range shooting and square on. The enemies, however, can be uncanny at spotting at killing me instantly. The movement mechanics are frustrating. The inventory system, especially kitting up, is terribly cumbersome. Squad commands are impossibly slow. The squad AI is as dumb as any AI gets. I can't get any better at the game because it's not my skill holding me back; it's the clunky-built engine filled with bugs, barely running on my mid/low-level PC.

Arma is one of those games every gamer should try at least once in their life, just be prepared to put some time into understanding the mechanics of the game. There are so many different things you game do with this game from Swat hostage rescues, massive scaled military battles to Dayz style game modes. There is a little bit for everyone's taste.

This game is one of the best games I know, I love games that are realistic and this is one that shines in that category. There are ballistics which mean no bullets are hit scan (instant hit) and also drop because of gravity pulling it down, so you either have to adjust your aim or use something called "zeroing" where someone adjusts the sights of the gun to where it shoots higher than where it is actually aiming to compensate for the bullet drop to make it easier for someone to aim. Your character has stamina which affects how much scope sway you have and how long you can sprint for, weight also affects your max stamina. if you sprint a lot and have no stamina your aim will be all over the place. If you don't sprint and run that much and have full stamina, you will have little scope sway and you can also hold shift to steady your breathing for even better aim.

Different stances also affect your scope sway, standing has the most, crouching has medium amounts and lying on the ground or prone has the least since your guy rests his weapon on the ground to help him aim and you can press C to lock your weapon on the ground for the best amount of aim and if you have a bipod on your weapon it increases the accuracy even more. There are many stances to do in all different positions. When you are standing you can lean left or right by pressing and holding q and e as well as holding left Ctrl and then pressing "w" "a" "s" or "d" which are default controls to step left, step right, look higher and get a bit lower. While crouching you can also step left or right, and get lower and higher. When you are prone things are a bit different, instead of stepping left or right you lie on your sides and leaning turns into rolling instead. going lower makes you lie on your side but facing forwards and going up make you do a sitting position.

Different calibers do different damage and bullet trajectory differs. Shooting different limbs cause related effects, being injured in the arm increases your scope sway, being injured in the legs makes it so you can only walk, I do not know what torso shots cause though. There is an armor system where depending on where you are hit deals different amounts of damage depending on where the armor is as well.

As someone who has put over 5k hours into this game. I would recommend it, there's ALOT of content here. From the singleplayer campaigns, scenarios, Trails and challenges. To the online multiplayer modes such as King of the hill, Exile, Role play modes and many many more. Additionally there's a mission editor which will allow you to make your own scenarios for yourself or for a group. The modding community is just as huge as the ones for Bethesda titles, such as Fallout and Skyrim. These mods will add even more content for you to dig into.

However the clumsiness of the engine and the poor AI code will make you want to pull your hair out. As someone who has created a lot of missions for the game for many different groups, the games poor optimisation and derpy AI has pushed me to uninstall this game many times in frustration. The game runs best when you play with, or against other players. 

If you are new to PC gaming, you're going to have a tough time with this game at first. The learning curve for the controls alone is really steep, if you have the patience's of stone, then you shouldn't have a problem.

Warning: This game is hugely complex, and incredibly unfriendly to new players. 

That being said, it's the Dark Souls of shooters. Tough to learn, even tougher to master. You want to look at your map, and it's night time? You better have a torch, or stand underneath a streetlamp. You want to find your way to a checkpoint? I hope you like orientating yourself via a real-life static map - as in, piece of paper. 

Once you get past that and accept those quirks - and many more - though, it's strangely addictive.

Pros
-Once you get the hang of it, it becomes rewarding and deep.
- Graphics are really pretty
- Tons of content

Cons
- There are inbuilt buttons to speed up the game, for when you're walking miles in realtime... let that sink in
- Hotkeys for [b] everything [/b] - players on smaller keyboards might have massive rebinding to do
- If you want to get good you're going to have to sink in some serious time, but that could be a pro if you're into that. 

Worth it?

I do recommend Arma. 

Arma really did something quite rare. The Mod support, Mod Creators, & Devs did a fantastic job at giving this game longevity. This game is still hugely popular, and really that's because there is nothing Newer, that is quite like it. Arma offers customization as well. Which is something Developers really seem to undervalue now days. 

Take Squad for example; There is absolutely Zero customization in Squad, and that is Imo- The main thing keeping Squad from blowing up like Arma did. Which is unfortunate, because we are terribly due for a new Large-scale tactical game, with  updated graphics, updated performance, that also offers customization. 

No-Customization, is a bit of a deal breaker.

Developers need to Wake up, and realize, that in 2020- you have to offer customization.

Insurgency Sandstorm for example, or Ground Branch have great customization. Ground Branch specifically has phenomenal customization. You can even customize how many pockets and ammo mags and grenades slots on your vests & gear you have, as well as customizing even where specifically you put mods on guns on the actual gun rails. Incredibly in depth. Its just still in very early Alpha, and they're not really Large-Scale games.

Squad, totally dropped the ball in this regard. And no one can say, that "Customization ruins Immersion", because in Insurgency and Ground Branch Both; The Immersion is even better because of these things.

So, Developers, please realize this. Arma is so long standing because of this. There are many options, and There are many mods. The leaning system in Arma is even still; the Most in-depth leaning system in any game, to-date. And thats pretty remarkable. Arma has like a 10 point leaning system. More games need to offer this as well.

All in all, I give Arma an 8-10. Deducted 2 points. One for a bit outdated Graphics, & One for performance; Because as we all know; the performance in Arma, even on very high-end systems is shoddy, and this is just due to the Engine/Coding.

Everything else is superb.

Hopefully, in the very near-future, we get a New Large-Scale Tactical game, thats Updated, offers loads of Customization, Mod support, lots of Vehicle Options, lots of PvP Scenarios, Updated Performance, and Updated Graphics.

Whoever offers this^ will have one hell of a money train on their hands.

Thanks for reading, and enjoy Arma.

This game is unlike any First Person Shooter you've ever played. Sporting multiple features spanning from next-to-real ballistics, ranging, traversal, and vehicle operation models. Everything has it's purpose in the game, nothing is the same in terms of applications.

Infantry ranges through all types of preset classes, from Ammunition Bearer to Sniper. These presets provide the best possible equipment to aid you in whatever operation you're going into. Of course, with the help from the Virtual Arsenal, you can mix and match your kit to be your own customized badass.

Vehicles in this game bring a more sense of heaviness and control, it just feels right driving around in an HEMTT and get that real sense that it actually is a heavy transport vehicle. The Tanks have a sense of overwhelming power, the helicopters and jets feel right to use for their intended purpose - especially with a flight stick, and nothing is bulletproof. You can damage any vehicle with small arms fire and the hit boxes are true to the vehicles.

LMG's, Assault Rifles, Snipers, Submachine Guns, and Pistols aren't OP. You can't run around with a single buffed rifle and dominate like you can in Call of Duty or Battlefield. Every weapon is balanced, the heavier punch it packs comes with drawbacks to stamina and backpack space so nothing is unbalanced when it comes to on the ground infantry tactics.

There are a multitude of things you can do in the vanilla game of ArmA 3, but I found that the best experiences come from the mods and ability to seek community Units and participate in custom Zeus Operations with them. The ArmA 3 community is so extensive there's endless possibilities for what you can do with mods, anywhere from World War 2 to Warhammer 40,000. The player lead units bring a sense of Comraderie and structure to operations created by skilled Zeus players.

TL:DR - If you're looking for a tried and true Military Sandbox, this is the game for you, plus the DLC goes on sale pretty often so it wouldn't be bad to think about picking them up and expanding your arsenal.

ArmA III is hands-down the greatest title I have ever invested time into. If you launch the game and play 10, 100, or even 1000 hours, you will not understand the full grasp of what this hobby has to offer. 

-This game is your playground. With the modding community, you can create any scenario you want. From a camping trip with your friends, to being invaded by giant rubber duckies, even to portraying historical battles such as the Battle of Hurtgen Forest, YOUR IMAGINATION is the limit.

-You can find anything you want here. Casual, realism, hardcore, survival, etc. This platform allows me to run a realism/milsim unit where I can create entire story-based campaigns that are more in-depth than AAA titled games like Call of Duty - AS SOMEONE WITHOUT A DEGREE IN GAME DESIGN. You do not need a degree to make a good game or story. ArmA III allows you to do both, this is a 3D canvas. Where you can create a mission or scenario in any clime, era, universe, or place. Don't like a map's layout? Use the "Hide" tool and delete what you want; then make it however you want it to be. ArmA III is the best Halo, Warhammer 40k, WWIII, WWII, WWI, Vietnam War, Korean War, etc game I have ever played. This will capture an immersive feel you have never felt elsewhere, and give you so much freedom that so many titles refuse.

-This game has been out for 8 years and has more functionality with infantry movement than every other game you can think of combined. And that's the basics, not even going to scrape what else it has to offer. 

LASTLY, do not blame your bad experiences with groups, mods, your personal missions, etc on the game. I have spent the last year as a mission maker/unit leader designing gameplay for people to enjoy, so I have credibility when it comes to this. Like I said before, your imagination is the limit. My group, Task Force Trauma, is where I commit every second to attain the highest level of detail, optimization, compatibility, and immersion to achieve unforgettable ArmA (and gaming) experiences; most groups do not take it this far. We are special, and ArmA allows people like me to be. This is something I have always wanted to do in a video-game environment, and ArmA provides it. 11/10, this is the last shooter I will ever need until ArmA 4 releases.

As good as you can get right now in regards to a realistic shooter or what ever mischievous actions you want to experiment with! 

A vast expanse of DLC and Mod support that covers everything from world war era maps, weapons and vehicles to advanced flight models. 

I mainly play King of the Hill where 3 teams (blufor, opfor and independent) fight for control over a rotating selection of towns earning xp and money for kills and control over the zone, levelling up and unlocking new weapons and vehicles to play with whilst emphasising the critical team play aspect where players will dedicate themselves to specific skills sets such as transport pilots (RESPECT!). 

But you must also take a look at mods such as; exile (for the survival/base building/looting aspect), "altis" life (and other various "" life servers for the role play and depth of content) and finally the old classic wasteland which along with the original dayz mod were the main components that distracted me from my college assignments all them years ago.

10/10 - Control bindings may be difficult to understand to start with but persistence will build muscle memory and before you know it you'll be there.

In terms of immersion, new military simulation games like SQUAD and POST SCRIPTUM are reigning over.  If only Arma 3 could have focused more on visual effects and sound immersion, I might still be playing it today. 

Note: Even older games like Red Orchestra 2 focused on immersion which is almost non existent on Arma. When bullets start flying and bombs start dropping, games that focus on suppression and immersion just gives you the best battlefield experience. 

I may re-install Arma 3 one day, but I'm definitely looking forward for an Arma 4 (if they ever produce it)

Imagine Squad as a sandbox game, 10x scale and content (not including mods), and about 5x jankiness and you get Arma.

This game sets the bar for milsim and semi-realistic games for me. Squad, Insurgency, Rising Storm, etc. are all great games but none of them compare to Arma's scale, possibilities, attention to random details, and jank. 

At 7 years old, it still looks good for what it is. CPU is most important with this game.

Client-side FPS is dependent on server-side FPS, so some servers you just won't get the framerate you want (and you shouldn't play on those servers anyways [spoiler]Arma Life[/spoiler] [spoiler]Wasteland[/spoiler]

Look for servers like OFPS Warfare that have epic game modes, custom content (which is nicely handled by Arma's mod launcher), and attention to optimization/server framerate. 

Some servers really don't care and throw as many scripts as they can together, giving everyone 30fps.

10/10 would get blown up by some guy in a tank from 2000 meters away without knowing he was there because my load distance was set to 1500 meters.

My girlfriend gifted me Arma 3 in 2015. Although my computer at the time had issues handling it, and I was forced to take a break from PC gaming for a couple years in college, it has proven to be the single greatest gift I have ever received.

The sheer customization, replay value, mod support, and multiplayer functionality of Arma 3 will forever cement it in my mind as the single most valuable game for fans of the genre. Want to keep is small? You can do that. Want to go crazy with tanks, jets, helis, and 10 infantry units? Go for it. The only limits are what your computer can handle, which leads me to my only real criticism of the title:

Bohemia, please prioritize optimization in the future (whether that be for Arma 4 or continued support for Arma 3). My new computer handles Arma 3 okay, but I know so many others who cannot run it well enough to get the most from the game. In some ways, Arma 3 feels like a benchmark test for military themed renders.
If you want to play this game and shoot a LMG get some earplugs in real-life in advance. Thank me later.

Absolutely amazing war-sim game with often stunning visuals and details put into certain areas such as vehicle interiors and weapon details. Certainly did enjoy every single second I've invested into playing this game, and the majority of it was spent on vanilla servers. I did role-playing, semi-fast paced action, walking simulators, and DayZ like surviving on mods. There's tons of fun to be had (There's tons of other things to try of course but that's just my personal experience listed.) but it's a game for mostly patient people as you can't necessarily expect fast-paced action to be a key entertainer here. There is of course King of the hill servers but c'mon, that's only a minor fraction of what the game truly has to offer and who plays arma to run and gun all the time :)  

People mainly praise Arma for it's endless amount of mods that can be tried out in order to spice up the gameplay and all, but the only mods i ever played on were Epoch and Exile so I can't speak too much about that. 

Also, the game will probably run like hell (20-40 fps) on highly populated servers, although i do have an average mid-priced pc. Despite the low frames however, it's still a lot of fun and the amount of things which you can do is basically endless. Would and still do certainly recommend for anyone wondering if it's a game worth buying and investing time into. 

For new players who may not have anyone to play with, I'd highly recommend visiting the 'Invade and Annex' servers. There usually always full of cool people to play with and they're quite welcoming to new players as well. Will teach you how to play as well as give you a fair experience on what the game's about and what to kinda expect in a way. At least that's where i ended up when i bought Arma 3 for the first time.

9/10 awesome memories and might come back someday for more :)

Damn what do I say about this...? I have been playing for 1000 hours when I writing this. This game has a LOT of glitches, all of them being somewhat funny in some kind of way. Rubber banding in a convoy mission because of lag and sending the vehicle behind you flying to the moon, hitting a tank with a quad bike flipping the tank and sending you across the map, trying to flip your tank back over with your APC and having your APC do a barrel roll onto it's back, losing both your tank and APC because of it. Having the AI walk through walls just to hunt you down, and the fact that the AI sees you through grass and hedges is also a problem, but the laughs make up for it. Now I haven't gotten to the mods yet! The mods make the game 10 times better, although you need a group to enjoy it in it's full form (TSB, TCS, and TMTM are only some of the groups that do modded missions that aren't fully sci-fi (The 501st is a star wars group that is VERY organized and do very laggy missions, yet they are also satisfying.)) You can enjoy this game in single player, but the multiplayer is were it shines (although being laggy). There are many game modes from your standard KOTH (King Of The Hill) to your escape from altis. The community also has made other game modes like Altis life. ArmA 3 also has this game mode that I believe is only in ArmA, "Zeus". Basicly a multiplayer sandbox where the "Zeus" (the mission maker) makes anything he wants to with the resources he has. ArmA 3 also has Eden Editor which is a mission maker that you can test things in, and make your own missions from scratch. I have spent a lot of time just testing things and playing around in my own missions (that likely will never get to the public). I believe that ArmA 3 is great and I have had lots of laughs with this game. I hope this helps with your choice in buying this game. Have a good day!

After spending nearly 1500 hours on this game, I can tell you that the it is worth it's replay value. The game has it all, from a variant of guns, missions, vehicles, and tactics to be used on the battlefield. The one problem where it falls short is the A.i. Unfortunately, Bohemia has never had smart NPCs- as they all stagger haphazardly throughout the land getting stuck on buildings, crashing into walls with vehicles, and somehow seemingly head shotting you from 1,000 meters out without even blinking. As said above, even though the a.i's intelligence is stupid to say the least, this does not make them pushovers. If you do not take proper cover you will be in immediate danger so learn to use the environment to your advantage, alongside the positioning of your character to give you the greatest advantage. Another great reason this game is still playable to this day are the plethora of mods, ranging from dayz survival esque, to king of the hill, and battle royale. This game has it all for pretty much any game type. My only advice to newcomers is that this is a first and foremost a military simulator. Play smart, be a team player, and communicate. Call or duty fan boys beware. You Rambo, most likely you will be the first to die amongst your unit. Then it becomes a marathon simulation for 20 minutes unless you are fortunate enough to have a pilot to ferry you from one destination to the other, and in most cases this is not going to happen. For this reason alone it is frustrating, but also gives a sense of realism and forces you to play cautiously. Ultimately, if you enjoy shooting guns, realistic simulation of the military forces, and don't mind modding every once in awhile this game is for you.

ArmA III is a military-simulation video game developed and published by Bohemia Interactive Studio (BIS) exclusively for the PC. It is the third installment of the ArmA series, officially announced on May 19, 2011, and is built around the new Real Virtuality 4 engine owned by BIS. The playable alpha version of the game was made purchasable on the Steam store and BIS' page on March 5, 2013. The beta was released on June 25, and the full release was on September 13, 2013. New weapons and vehicles are added with each new part of the free-to-download campaign, split up into multiple chapters.

The storyline is set in 2035, when NATO influence is on the decline, while a new Eastern military alliance led by China and Iran called the Canton Protocol Strategic Alliance Treaty (CSAT) is on the rise. The setting are two islands located in the Aegean Sea, the 270km¬≤ Altis (based upon the 477km¬≤ Greek island, Lemnos) and the 20km¬≤ Stratis (based on the 43km¬≤ island of Agios Efstratios). The Republic of Altis and Stratis is in a state of civil strife following a military coup by the Altis Armed Forces (AAF), where a loyalist insurgency group known as the Freedom and Independence Army (FIA) wages a guerrilla war against the AAF. Following the signature of a ceasefire between the AAF and the FIA, the US Armed Forces is involved as NATO peacekeepers to oversee the ceasefire. However, the ceasefire breaks down, and the AAF allies with CSAT to suppress the FIA by full force, while restricting NATO to Stratis. Things go from bad to worse when the AAF declares war on NATO due to a muddied firing incident on Stratis, triggering an all-out war. The main protagonist of the campaign is Corporal Ben Kerry, an American NATO soldier stationed on Stratis, who needs to work with the enigmatic Captain Scott Miller and the FIA remnants to survive and turn the tide of the war.

The MX family of rifles is the standard-issue weapon for NATO forces. The MX series, designed by real-life CMMG, Inc., has design elements borrowed from the Remington ACR and Robinson Armament XCR. It fires caseless 6.5x39mm ammunition, though it is implied that it could could fire traditional cased ammunition due to the presence of an ejection port on the right-hand side of the weapon.

The MX comes in five variants:

The standard MX rifle, equipped with a Magpul UBR stock.
The MXC carbine with a shortened barrel and handguard, equipped with a Magpul CTR stock. Both the MX and the MXC are also equipped with the Magpul AFG2 Angled Foregrip with a flat "A1-style" surface.
The MX 3GL grenadier variant with an underbarrel Metal Storm 3GL instead of a foregrip.
The MX SW squad support weapon with extended lower handguard and barrel, Z-M LR 300 stock, vertical foregrip, an integrated bipod, and using thicker 100-round magazines.
The MXM marksman rifle with the Magpul PRS stock, extended barrel, and vertical foregrip. Both the MX SW and MXM also feature simplified Picatinny rails on their handguards.

In 2001, the Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC - Crane Division) initiated Block II of the SOPMOD program, which called for both new accessories (optics, flashlights, etc.), as well as a new M4/M4A1 Rail Interface System (RIS) to replace the Knight's Armament Company (KAC) forearm from Block I. Among others, SOPMOD Block II introduced accessories such as:

Elcan SpecterDR 1-4x Scope (designated SU-230/PVS)
EOTech 553 HOLOgraphic Weapon Sight (designated SU-231/PVS)
Insight Technology M3X Tactical Illuminator (designated SU-233/PVS)
Advanced Target Pointer Illuminator Aiming Light (ATPIAL) (designated AN/PEQ-15)
During the rail selection phase, NSWC-Crane surprised most observers when they chose a new lightweight free-floating rail forearm manufactured by a then-unknown vendor, Daniel Defense, based in Black Creek, Georgia, over competing rail designs from KAC and ARMS. In contrast to the earlier KAC rails, Daniel Defense's design, designated RIS II, extended nearly the full length of an M4's barrel, past the gas block, thereby increasing M1913 Picatinny rail space relative to the KAC rail. The RIS II was also free-floating (it had no contact with either the barrel or front sight post), and was capable of mounting the M203 grenade launcher without a barrel attachment. Two versions of the RIS II exist: A version which contains a slot to fit over an M4's A-frame front sight post (known as the "RIS II FSP"), and a continuous version (simply "RIS II") which contains no FSP slot and therefore must be used with a low-profile gas block. The RIS II was first adopted by SOCOM in 2006. However, in contrast to most of the other SOPMOD Block II accessories, which began reaching operators in the field in 2007, SOCOM did not complete testing on the RIS II and issue its first major procurement contract until 2009, and Daniel Defense's own production lines initially strained to meet delivery orders on their SOCOM contract (which also limited the RIS II's availability on the commercial market). Consequently, the RIS II did not enter usage with SOCOM component personnel until after 2010, and it did not fully replace the KAC rail in SOCOM until 2016, by which point newer, modular rails had begun to usurp Picatinny quad rails on the commercial AR-15 market. Despite being a dated design relative to current AR-15 rails (e.g. those using Keymod and M-LOK attachment systems), the RIS II is currently the standard-issue M4A1 carbine rail for U.S. SOCOM.

Not your typical run-and-gun shooter games. Recommended for those who like realism.

Overall when it comes to the bare bones content and Singleplayer aspects of the base game there's a decent amount of polish and content to keep you involved for a handful of hours if needed, that being said though i personally felt the campaign for the base game to be a bit of a slow burn when on Altis. In regards to the DLC campaign (Scenarios) i personally haven't tried them yet but have heard decent/good reviews from friends.

Though i believe where ArmA 3 itself truly shines is the multiplayer and further super in depth Modding Support and capabilities that provides content creators and the countess communities, if you are looking for a military sandbox game Arma 3 is THE king of military sandbox shooters at least at the time of this review. The scope at which the modding community has stretched can provide you with any experience, You want a WW2 mission? There's a mod for that, Wanna fight the Empire from Star Wars? There's a mod for that as well. The sheer size of the modding community is easily the number one reason this game hasn't faded from memory.

PROS:
- Thousands of Mods.
- Outstanding Communities (There are ArmA Units for Every Niche)
- Deep arsenal for the base game. (All DLC's Taken into Consideration)
- Anything is truly possible with ArmA so long as you can code etc.
- Hundreds of Youtube Tutorials (Wealth of Information at your Fingertips)

CONS:
- Sound design for the game is a bit hit/miss.
- The game is CPU intensive and therefore can seriously dampen the experience for lower end rigs.
- Graphics are feeling more outdated as this is by default a fairly old game. (7 Years)
- Engine itself feels clunky at times and some seriously game breaking bugs occur (Tank ramming a bush can go Space Shuttle status.)
- A rough learning curve for beginners. (Dozens of controls/keybinds and not easy to get the hang of if on and off play.)

I bought ArmA 3 roughly when it was initially released for Steam and haven't regretted the buy one bit, if Military Sandbox games are something that tickles your fancy than by all means pick it up and check it out!

Though it can be played in SP, Arma 3 is definitely NOT a SP game. It's hard to learn and even harder to survive. With almost a hundred keybinds und dozens of features to provide a realistic combat enviroment, it will take some time to get a good routine. That's why Arma unfolds its full quality by joining a community or at least playing on dedicated MILSIM-Servers (not the official ones). It's meant to be played as a military simulation, and if you don't like that, you'll probalby won't like this game neither. MILSIM-Communities can train you how to play Arma in a team, cause it's a team game. Communities can give you technical support, cause there are always a lot of technical issues to solve. And finally, you need someone to guide you through the almost unlimited forrest of community-based modifications, and a lot of this stuff is just AWESOME! It's the biggest and most sophisticated military sandbox on the market.   
A lot of people in the Arma-community don't play this because it's easy - the do it because it's hard. But when you're through the first frustrating weeks, you will learn to love it. And you might have some of the most fascinating moments in your gaming career...

Arma 3 never ceases to amaze, it looks great, has compelling gameplay and suprises you with it's customization. But after playing nearly two months in the game, I can tell you that it no longer holds up to modern standards. 
Whether it's the piss-poor performance, incredibly dated controls, and the lack luster "V2.0" release that came out recently it is clear that this game has  aged very poorly. With games like squad getting constant content releases and support from the devs it goes to show that Arma 3 is on it's last legs. At it's core it is a functioning game but after 7 years of postponed development its obvious that there is no hope for Arma 4. I would recommend that you look elsewhere for a military shooter.

This is a game that can unite casual gamers and hardcore milsim fans. The game takes some getting used to; to learn the factions, the vehicles and the weapons but gives you limitless possibilities therein.

Perhaps the best part of this game is the Zeus addon. No two games on Zeus are the same, unlike repetitive normal server games can be. So long as permitted by the Zeus, you have the opportunity to use whatever customised loadout you want.

The game's biggest downfall in my opinion is the vehicle physics. One vehicle touching another on a server can turn a vehicle convoy into either an explosion caused crater or a NASA mission to the ISS. 

Overall this is an incredible game giving the chance to go on fast paced missions or those of a more strategic theme, or even if you wish to create missions of your own.

ArmA 3, a great source of controversy, and game from over half a decade ago. To list ArmA's all shortcomings would require an essay. So why do we all play it? It's because we all love it. ArmA, while a buggy mess at times is a wonderful host. And ArmA's replayability has kept us around for all these years. 

Comparing ArmA 3 to other military games is honestly like comparing an apple to an applepie. For example Squad and ArmA 3. Squad has undoubtedly better graphics, and smoother gameplay, but that's it. In Squad, the playerbase is limited to a singular gamemode. In ArmA, the game has numerous gamemodes in vanilla in-and-of-itself. And what makes ArmA ArmA is the ability for the regular user to make their own world. Want a guerilla based gamemode, if you can make it, you can play it. In Escape From Tarkov, the players are limited to whatever the devs create. ArmA has no such issues, as the players are free to create pretty much whatever.

Keep in mind that I'm not trying to say 'ArmA is perfect no matter what', that's not what I'm saying. I am aware of ArmA's shortcomings as much as the next mate, but beggars can't be choosers. ArmA has proven to be a generous host, and since there are no alternatives to it, us the playerbase pays no mind to the issues Arma has. 

ArmA 3. It may be expensive, run poorly, and have graphics dating back half a decade but there's nothing like it. Until ArmA 4 whenever Bohemia get's their stuff together, we are here to stay.

It's the dead of night on the CSAT-occupied island of Stratis, and the peaceful darkness is about to explode into chaos. I'm leading one of two spec-ops teams on a mission to liberate the leader of a local guerrilla faction and return him to the much larger island of Altis. A British squad is in charge of the actual rescue. Our job is to cause as much trouble across the island as possible to distract the CSAT forces and give the British the opening they need.

Over the next hour, that's precisely what I do. Inserting by boat from the northwest coast, I head south and raid an ammo dump before cutting across to the eastern shore to destroy a heliport. Then my squad suppresses an enemy encampment from a hillside near the centre of the island as I swoop in from the west to flank them. Yet before we can regroup, my entire team is killed by reinforcements descending from the north, and the British still need more time to complete their mission. Alone, I rush to the southernmost tip of the island, where I blow up a fortified anti-air position before escaping by riding a quad bike back through the swarming enemy forces to the extraction point, where the boat takes me home.

Arguably the biggest complaint about Bohemia Interactive's post-Flashpoint games is that their campaigns haven't used the magnificent landscapes they create to their full potential. The first Arma's campaign was a hastily cobbled-together disappointment, while it took a certain zombie-survival mod to harness the austere and foreboding power of Arma 2's Chernarus. That Arma 3 uses half an island for just one of its twenty-odd missions is indicative of Bohemia's effort to resolve this ongoing issue. Indeed, taken as a whole, Arma 3 strives to make this deep and impenetrable military simulator series a more comprehensive, more engaging and more user-friendly experience. It isn't completely successful, but I had an awful lot of fun watching it try.

While Arma 3 was officially released back in September, the campaign has been portioned out in three substantial chunks over the last six months. Each chapter is a self-contained entity with its own story arc and theme; combined, they tell the tale of the excitingly named Corporal Ben Kerry and his role in the war over the fictional Mediterranean island archipelago of Altis and Stratis, waged between four different factions.

The first part, Survive, is geared towards introducing players to Arma. It takes place entirely on the smaller of Arma 3's two islands, Stratis, and sees Kerry banding up with a group of NATO survivors after the local Altian Armed Forces, backed by NATO's eastern equivalent CSAT, rise up against the local US garrison. For the most part, missions are small-scale skirmishes that keep you firmly in the "follower" category while teaching you the basics of minimising your daily lead intake. Rescuing a downed helicopter crew instructs you on establishing a defensive position, while a midnight liaison with local militia explains how to flank and clear buildings.

It's hardly the campaign's most spectacular stage. Story-wise, it's let down by voice acting that ranges from passable to cringeworthy and a script that understands military radio chatter but not how human beings interact with one another. Even here, though, Bohemia's approach to maximising the assets it has built is apparent. Missions are nearly always multi-staged, with objectives being added and changed as events rarely go according to plan.

While it smoulders rather than sparks, Survive concludes strongly and the momentum is carried over into Adapt, definitely the best of the three chapters. This introduces Altis, a masterwork of environmental design. I could write another 1000 words on its remarkable sights and sounds: its misty dawns, crimson dusks and streetlight-speckled nights. But what's most important is how the detail that's gone into mapping the landscape's undulations - the lumps and bumps, hills and valleys - plays into the game's combat. A little rise in the ground might be the difference between life and death as you throw yourself down in evasion of the fiendishly accurate enemy AI. When they stop to reload, you'll rush to locate a better vantage point, order your men to "find cover" (an extremely handy new command) and plant half a dozen bullets in your opponent's surprisingly tough body.

Tactics are vital in Arma 3, but it's terrain that really makes the difference between success and failure. It's crucial to learn this before Adapt begins, because the difficulty suddenly ramps up. The first mission sees you alone, unarmed and with a city full of enemy soldiers between you and any kind of safety. At this point, setting saves to unlimited using Arma's highly customisable difficulty levels becomes a necessity. Fittingly, after Survive, you will die many, many times. That said, it's important to note that combat is more satisfying than before thanks to improved animations, smoother weapon handling and better optics - meaning the challenge stems from your opponents rather than clumsy controls and slow-to-aim weapons.

Adapt also changes the way you play. It gives you a squad to control, which is a mixed blessing. AI units tend to be much more perceptive of enemy locations than you are and are especially useful when facing down tanks and APCs, but they also require a fair amount of babysitting to keep them alive, and the lack of changes to Arma's squad commands means this can be a chore. Especially problematic is AI ammo management; your teammates go through bullets like a swarm of locusts through a corn crop, and resupplying them in the field is a nightmare in Arma 3's clumsy interface.

Alongside its story missions, which include the brilliant raid on Stratis described above, Adapt also introduces an open-world component. From your base you can go out on "Patrol" and complete multiple optional objectives, from clearing enemy checkpoints to smoking out a sniper hidden inside a labyrinthine industrial complex, all while collecting weapons, ammo and equipment to use during the main missions - though the clunkiness of Arma's inventory management means this is less enjoyable than it should be. If you want to bring stuff back to base, you need to find a vehicle and load it item-by-item from your own inventory, while before each mission the game defaults to a standard equipment loadout and items you previously had can be lost in this process.

After the meatiness of Adapt, the final chapter Win feels fleeting by comparison, with only six missions to its name. But they're also the most spectacular, displaying vast, combined-arms battles that cover sweeping areas of Altis. It's strongly reminiscent of the opening of Operation Flashpoint, but with you in control rather than being led by an AI squad leader. In these closing stages you can call in devastating artillery strikes and helicopter assaults, simultaneously demonstrating the sheer destructive power of modern warfare and your own insignificance in the scale of things. Story-wise, it's also the most interesting segment, making unsettling use of its near-future setting and offering a branching conclusion that is fascinating, whichever direction you take.

Arma 3's campaign is a big, powerful, deeply engrossing thing, but there is one disappointment: its lack of vehicular missions. Since the story focuses on one not particularly interesting character who is ultimately a grunt, there are no tank missions, no helicopter missions and no jet missions. I can understand why, to a point: Arma's vehicles, especially its airborne offering, take time and effort to learn to control. Moreover, in these kinds of games infantry combat tends to be more enjoyable anyway. On the other hand, Flashpoint offered plenty of vehicle engagements during its campaign without any issue, and it's frustrating that, 13 years on, Arma's campaigns still lag behind it in terms of breadth of experience.

8 /10
